description: This series covers implementing and managing Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) v7.  RHEL v7 is the leading commercial Linux server software used by corporations around the world.  Topics covered by this series include installation, configuration, troubleshooting, and backup and recovery.  The goal of this series is to prepare any systems administrator to be able to support RHEL v7 in a production environment.
name: Red Hat Enterprise Linux
subtitle: World's leading enterprise Linux platform

episodes.description: This series covers implementing and managing Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) v7. RHEL v7 is the leading commercial Linux server software used by corporations around the world. episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:01.937
[SOUND] In this series,

2
00:00:01.937 --> 00:00:07.786
we're gonna be taking a look at
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7.

3
00:00:07.786 --> 00:00:09.660
Now most of you have
already heard of the OS.

4
00:00:09.660 --> 00:00:12.255
It's why you're here, but
for those who haven't,

5
00:00:12.255 --> 00:00:15.320
RHEL is the largest commercially
supported version of Linux.

6
00:00:15.320 --> 00:00:18.250
And what that means is,
you can go and you can pay for it,

7
00:00:18.250 --> 00:00:19.910
which I know sounds contradictory for
Linux,

8
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:22.160
that normally we get it for
free from the various providers.

9
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:26.110
But we can pay for it, and in exchange for
that payment, we get support.

10
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:29.830
We get an actual corporate entity
sitting behind the distribution that's

11
00:00:29.830 --> 00:00:32.270
available to assist us
when we have problems.

12
00:00:32.270 --> 00:00:35.734
And that's really something that's
extremely important if you're using

13
00:00:35.734 --> 00:00:37.420
Linux in a production environment.

14
00:00:37.420 --> 00:00:39.560
And let me tell you, a lot of people are.

15
00:00:39.560 --> 00:00:40.793
When you go out on the Internet,

16
00:00:40.793 --> 00:00:43.776
the majority of web servers you hit
these days are Linux-based web servers.

17
00:00:43.776 --> 00:00:46.890
Fortune 500 companies rely
on it every single day.

18
00:00:46.890 --> 00:00:51.137
All of the big Tech startups that are out
there using on a regular basis, and

19
00:00:51.137 --> 00:00:53.169
Red Hat is at the forefront of that.

20
00:00:53.169 --> 00:00:55.228
Now, because there's a pay element to it,

21
00:00:55.228 --> 00:00:57.588
a lot of people don't have
a lot of exposure to it.

22
00:00:57.588 --> 00:00:59.357
But you'd actually be surprised.

23
00:00:59.357 --> 00:01:02.481
Many of the free Linux
distributions that are out there,

24
00:01:02.481 --> 00:01:04.890
are based on the work that Red Hat does.

25
00:01:04.890 --> 00:01:07.010
So if you've run CENTOS,

26
00:01:07.010 --> 00:01:10.780
which is the Community Enterprise
Operating System, it is actually build

27
00:01:10.780 --> 00:01:15.460
right off of the public open Source
code from Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

28
00:01:15.460 --> 00:01:16.990
Oracle Linux, same thing.

29
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:21.900
Built right off of Red Hat's code base,
and even Amazon's Linux AMI that they

30
00:01:21.900 --> 00:01:25.170
use on Amazon web services that is used
by millions of virtual machines around

31
00:01:25.170 --> 00:01:29.200
the world also built off of
Red Hat's open source code base.

32
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:31.370
So the work that Red Hat
does to improve and

33
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:35.140
secure their product, gets out there and
improves other platforms too.

34
00:01:35.140 --> 00:01:38.980
So if you've worked with CENTOS,
or the Linux AMI from Amazon, or

35
00:01:38.980 --> 00:01:42.430
Oracle Linux you've actually already
worked with Red Hat, and your skillset

36
00:01:42.430 --> 00:01:46.210
moves right into it, and everything's nice
and the same, and that works out great.

37
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:50.240
But in addition if something goes
wrong You can pick up the phone,

38
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:51.860
open up a support ticket with Red Hat, and

39
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:53.710
their engineers will help
you through the problems.

40
00:01:53.710 --> 00:01:56.530
That's what makes it
such a robust platform.

41
00:01:56.530 --> 00:01:59.080
Now, in this video series, what we're
gonna do is we're gonna take a look

42
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:02.790
not just at what Red Hat Enterprise Linux
is, but how we can use it.

43
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:05.450
And we're gonna run through some of
the different configuration schemes and

44
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:08.800
settings, the way that we configure
the system and get it online, and

45
00:02:08.800 --> 00:02:11.920
make it where you can get out there
in a production environment and

46
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:13.240
use it to its fullest.

47
00:02:13.240 --> 00:02:16.315
We start by taking a look at how to
install Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

48
00:02:16.315 --> 00:02:18.770
Either doing it manually or
doing it automated.

49
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:21.340
If you need to roll out to a thousand
machines, you don't want to go and

50
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:22.310
do this by hand.

51
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:24.190
We'll show you how to create
a custom installer and

52
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:25.960
actually get that installation going.

53
00:02:25.960 --> 00:02:28.600
We'll show how to use
the security features inside of

54
00:02:28.600 --> 00:02:29.750
Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

55
00:02:29.750 --> 00:02:31.940
There's SE Linux and Firewalld.

56
00:02:31.940 --> 00:02:35.350
There's all sorts of additional
security sublayers that are in there.

57
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:37.460
And we show how they work,
how you configure them,

58
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:41.560
and how you can maintain them to maintain
the most secure operating system possible.

59
00:02:41.560 --> 00:02:45.480
We also spend a good bit of time looking
at file systems, choosing the right file

60
00:02:45.480 --> 00:02:48.950
system really does have a big impact
on how your server performs, and so

61
00:02:48.950 --> 00:02:52.550
we get a chance to see that and how it
works inside of the Red Hat environment.

62
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:54.287
And then lastly,
we throw in some odds and ends.

63
00:02:54.287 --> 00:02:57.899
Some other services and things that you
might need out there in the real world,

64
00:02:57.899 --> 00:03:01.507
like how to back up the system, how to
do snapshots, how to install software,

65
00:03:01.507 --> 00:03:03.641
third-party software, and maintain that,

66
00:03:03.641 --> 00:03:06.787
how to use the graphical user
interface as well as the command line.

67
00:03:06.787 --> 00:03:10.197
And all the other skills that are needed
for a systems administrator that's gonna

68
00:03:10.197 --> 00:03:12.800
be supporting
a Red Hat Enterprise Linux environment.

69
00:03:12.800 --> 00:03:14.320
So if you're that kind of person,

70
00:03:14.320 --> 00:03:17.670
if you're tasked to the job of supporting
Red Hat, this is the place for you.

71
00:03:17.670 --> 00:03:20.480
If you just wanna learn more about it,
if you're a hobbyist and you wanna explore

72
00:03:20.480 --> 00:03:24.250
the world of Red Hat Enterprise Linux,
again, another great place to jump in.

73
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:26.890
If you're just getting started with Linux,
though, if you've never really touched

74
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:30.150
the OS before, this might not be
the best place for you to start.

75
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:33.237
You might wanna check out some of
the other shows we have on ITPRO.TV,

76
00:03:33.237 --> 00:03:36.585
like the Linux+ content, where we take
you from no Linux skill all the way up

77
00:03:36.585 --> 00:03:39.015
to being proficient as
a basic system administrator.

78
00:03:39.015 --> 00:03:41.240
That's a great starting point for you.

79
00:03:41.240 --> 00:03:42.883
But if you've already worked with Linux,
and

80
00:03:42.883 --> 00:03:45.455
you're more concerned with just
learning the differences in Red Hat and

81
00:03:45.455 --> 00:03:48.002
how we can support it in our environment,
then this is the show for you.

82
00:03:48.002 --> 00:03:50.786
And if this sounds interesting,
well stay tuned,

83
00:03:50.786 --> 00:03:55.069
cuz we've got episodes of Red Hat
Enterprise Linux version 7 coming up next.

84
00:03:55.069 --> 00:03:58.539
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate installing Red Hat Enterprise Linux; installing both RHEL7 with Graphical User Interface and RHEL7 CLI-Only. Actually, let me go and

00:02:28.618 --> 00:02:29.919

00:02:29.919 --> 00:02:33.273

when we install Red Hat Linux,

00:02:52.397 --> 00:02:57.084
We go through, we get it all installed,

60
00:03:05.403 --> 00:03:09.760
So if you just install

that's a real problem especially,

64
00:03:16.859 --> 00:03:18.320
we certainly know what that.

65
00:03:18.320 --> 00:03:20.405
But even just as far as
customizing features,

66
00:03:20.405 --> 00:03:22.488
if you wanna add resources
after the install,

00:03:22.488 --> 00:03:25.759
you really have to struggle to do that,
cuz it's all kind of turned off.

68
00:03:25.759 --> 00:03:29.730
As soon as you activate a subscription,
that's when it all becomes active.

69
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:32.640
So we're gonna run through
the installation here in this episode, and

70
00:03:32.640 --> 00:03:34.492
I'm gonna show you each
point along the way.

00:03:34.492 --> 00:03:37.343
And we'll kind of get to that point where
you have to do the subscription and

00:03:37.343 --> 00:03:39.258
punch that data in,
we'll get a chance to see it.

73
00:03:39.258 --> 00:03:42.113
Now if you're gonna install Red Hat Linux,
step one, is get it, right?

74
00:03:42.113 --> 00:03:45.305
So that's what I just talked about,
we got to get that ISO image and

75
00:03:45.305 --> 00:03:47.550
then we get prepared to do the install.

76
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:51.400

a physical disk, if you're in 1995.

77
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:54.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if you're in today as there,

00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:58.729
we normally kind of burn it on to USB
key to get that bootable USB media.

79
00:03:58.729 --> 00:04:02.806
Once that's done, it really installs
just like any other operating system.

80
00:04:02.806 --> 00:04:05.476
We fire it up and
we start to run through our processes.

81
00:04:05.476 --> 00:04:07.723
Now most of us don't even
burn to a USB key anymore,

82
00:04:07.723 --> 00:04:11.490
because the majority of servers deployed
today are virtual machines, right?

83
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:16.140
So whatever virtualization software you're
using, you simply mount the ISO image and

84
00:04:16.140 --> 00:04:18.240
fire it up from there to
get the OS installed.

85
00:04:18.240 --> 00:04:20.746
>> Now Don, we were joking before
the show started about yeah,

86
00:04:20.746 --> 00:04:22.414
it's real easy to get Red Hat installed.

00:04:22.414 --> 00:04:24.509
You run the AWS, and
you fire up an instance-

00:04:24.509 --> 00:04:25.123
>> [LAUGH]

00:04:25.123 --> 00:04:26.456
>> And you say, I want Red Hat Linux, and

00:04:26.456 --> 00:04:27.847
there you go, you're up and running.

91
00:04:27.847 --> 00:04:31.544
And while that is legitimate, you could do
that, and you would have Red Hat Linux.

92
00:04:31.544 --> 00:04:33.531
You'd be able to use it as you like, but

00:04:33.531 --> 00:04:37.766
you don't get that installation experience
because they kind of did that for you.

00:04:37.766 --> 00:04:40.243
And this is where it is good to
be able to walk through this,

95
00:04:40.243 --> 00:04:42.688
because you might not be doing
that in your environment.

96
00:04:42.688 --> 00:04:43.588
>> Absolutely, and

I do wanna show a couple of
different ways to do the install.

98
00:04:46.588 --> 00:04:48.278
In this episode,
we're gonna do the manual one, right?

99
00:04:48.278 --> 00:04:50.802
So we're gonna manually go through and
do the installation.

100
00:04:50.802 --> 00:04:54.645
In another episode, we'll do what's
called the Kickstart process, and

Kickstart is where you can

102
00:04:57.521 --> 00:05:01.552
That's really handy,
because maybe you're a developer, and

you work with like a LAMP stack, right?

Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP.

And so you constantly have
to deploy machines, and

Well I guess Linux would

00:05:12.921 --> 00:05:16.448
But the other components you have to

package that just automatically deployed,

00:05:30.388 --> 00:05:32.833

00:05:32.833 --> 00:05:35.367

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the process of updating software on a freshly installed Red Hat server. They start with system registration with Red Hat using the GUI and Subscription Manager then jumping right into software updates using the graphical tools. Next they introduce you to the YUM package management system for installing software through the command line.

00:20:22.050 --> 00:20:27.520
There's also an entitlement folder and
you'll see the pem keys right there.

430
00:20:27.520 --> 00:20:31.060
The first two, these are identifying you.

431
00:20:31.060 --> 00:20:34.901
The second two, these are identifying
your subscription for this machine.

432
00:20:34.901 --> 00:20:37.997
And if you don't have those you can't
talk to Red Hat's update servers, and

433
00:20:37.997 --> 00:20:41.120
that's what the subscription
manager is actually doing.

434
00:20:41.120 --> 00:20:44.660
But once you've got those keys,
now you can do the update.

435
00:20:44.660 --> 00:20:50.180
And when I did that yum list a moment ago
notice error no matching packages, right.

436
00:20:50.180 --> 00:20:51.670
I looked for Apache and couldn't find it.

437
00:20:51.670 --> 00:20:55.500
Now I can't believe that
Red Hat doesn't have Apache.

438
00:20:55.500 --> 00:20:59.892
Well, they do,
it's just not in the name, right.

439
00:20:59.892 --> 00:21:03.025
The Apache package is
actually listed as httpd.

440
00:21:03.025 --> 00:21:07.178
If I were to do a yum list httpd,
right, I can pull it up and

441
00:21:07.178 --> 00:21:11.609
I get all my key stuff up here,
so we just kind of ignore that.

442
00:21:11.609 --> 00:21:15.767
And then right after that
available packages, there's httpd,

443
00:21:15.767 --> 00:21:18.340
that's Apache, right.

444
00:21:18.340 --> 00:21:21.880
But if I didn't know that that was the
name, well it is actually tucked in there.

445
00:21:21.880 --> 00:21:27.890
If we do a yum info httpd, like that,
it's gonna show me information about that

446
00:21:27.890 --> 00:21:32.360
package, and I can see in the description
right here it's the Apache http server.

447
00:21:32.360 --> 00:21:34.480
>> A quick question about Yum, Don.

448
00:21:34.480 --> 00:21:38.990
When you're searching, does it look inside
of the package, in those attributes maybe,

449
00:21:38.990 --> 00:21:42.800
to look for Apache, if you use Apache,
or do you have to force that?

450
00:21:42.800 --> 00:21:44.243
>> The yum list command,
like I used it there,

451
00:21:44.243 --> 00:21:46.082
it's really just looking
at the package name, right.

452
00:21:46.082 --> 00:21:48.211
And the package name wasn't Apache,
so it didn't find it,

453
00:21:48.211 --> 00:21:50.340
even though it's right
there in the description.

454
00:21:50.340 --> 00:21:53.560
But instead of yum list,
we could use yum search, and

455
00:21:53.560 --> 00:21:56.270
the yum search command will
actually look in the descriptions.

456
00:21:56.270 --> 00:21:57.650
It'll get you a lot more results normally.

457
00:21:57.650 --> 00:21:58.890
So that's why I don't normally use it.

458
00:21:58.890 --> 00:22:00.150
I use yum list,

459
00:22:00.150 --> 00:22:03.020
but I've also kind of memorized
the package names so that helps too.

460
00:22:03.020 --> 00:22:04.186
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if you haven't memorized

461
00:22:04.186 --> 00:22:06.381
the package name,
then yum search is a little bit better.

462
00:22:06.381 --> 00:22:07.970
And let me just show you.

463
00:22:07.970 --> 00:22:09.850
If I jump back in here, right, so

464
00:22:09.850 --> 00:22:14.900
when I did yum list apache,
it didn't find anything, right?

465
00:22:14.900 --> 00:22:16.810
No matching packages to list.

466
00:22:16.810 --> 00:22:20.390
But if I do a yum search apache,
and we go and

467
00:22:20.390 --> 00:22:22.980
we do a search,
it finds all sorts of stuff, right.

468
00:22:22.980 --> 00:22:25.430
Because now it's not just
looking at the package name, but

469
00:22:25.430 --> 00:22:27.350
it's also looking at the description.

470
00:22:27.350 --> 00:22:30.970
And it's finding, like here's
Apache Tomcat, which is not what I want.

471
00:22:30.970 --> 00:22:35.480
We've got mod look ups, all the modules
that we can add on to Apache.

472
00:22:35.480 --> 00:22:38.450
Whoa, if we go a little scroll
crazy we can bump up and

473
00:22:38.450 --> 00:22:40.530
see some more, there's OpenSSH.

474
00:22:40.530 --> 00:22:47.300
We've got PCI Utils, open-vm-tools,
we got all sorts of junk in here.

475
00:22:47.300 --> 00:22:51.070
But not what I'm looking for so let me-
>> People like that web service.

476
00:22:51.070 --> 00:22:55.626
>> There we go, all right so here's some
packages that actually have Apache in them

477
00:22:55.626 --> 00:23:00.390
except they're no architecture, so
they're usually documentation and things.

478
00:23:00.390 --> 00:23:02.574
Actually what it looks like
a lot of these are, but

479
00:23:02.574 --> 00:23:04.840
right after that I should
be able to find the httpd.

480
00:23:04.840 --> 00:23:05.920
>> Http server.

481
00:23:05.920 --> 00:23:10.800
>> There it is, now notice how that was
just one entry in a cloud of other stuff.

482
00:23:10.800 --> 00:23:14.344
So it's a little difficult to
use yum search sometimes, but

483
00:23:14.344 --> 00:23:18.317
that is the way you'd find it and
look through those descriptions.

484
00:23:18.317 --> 00:23:21.980
All right, so we've seen yum list.

485
00:23:21.980 --> 00:23:23.760
We've see yum search.

486
00:23:23.760 --> 00:23:28.400
And all this time it's been talking
to Red Hat and getting that data.

487
00:23:28.400 --> 00:23:33.170
If I wanna install something like
Apache I can say yum install and

488
00:23:33.170 --> 00:23:37.597
the name of the package, right,
which I now know is httpd.

489
00:23:37.597 --> 00:23:41.440
I do need to sudo that, so
that I have permission to do it.

490
00:23:41.440 --> 00:23:46.220
And once that's done it's gonna
reach out to Red Hat's server and

491
00:23:46.220 --> 00:23:48.700
it's gonna find that yeah,
I wanna install Apache.

492
00:23:48.700 --> 00:23:51.560
But Apache depends on some other packages.

493
00:23:51.560 --> 00:23:53.075
And so it's gonna find those for

494
00:23:53.075 --> 00:23:55.553
me, there's four packages
that Apache requires.

495
00:23:55.553 --> 00:24:00.092
So I'm installing httpd, but these are
dependencies that need to come along with

496
00:24:00.092 --> 00:24:02.480
it, and it's gonna install those for me.

497
00:24:02.480 --> 00:24:04.515
All right, now it's gonna install it.

498
00:24:04.515 --> 00:24:08.290
It's verifying that key and
saying, do you trust the source?

499
00:24:08.290 --> 00:24:12.060
Because, if a hacker compromises your
data repository, you can be installing

500
00:24:12.060 --> 00:24:15.340
a compromised version of Apache,
so it's validating that for me.

501
00:24:15.340 --> 00:24:20.340
So, I'm okay with that, and I have to
validate each of the entries there.

502
00:24:20.340 --> 00:24:24.640
Once it's done, there it goes installing
it, downloads first, and then it installs,

503
00:24:24.640 --> 00:24:26.330
that's why you see everything twice.

504
00:24:26.330 --> 00:24:28.060
Once it's done, now we're up and

505
00:24:28.060 --> 00:24:33.130
good, now when I did yum update earlier,
I had 589 updates.

506
00:24:34.660 --> 00:24:36.950
When I installed those dependencies and
packages,

507
00:24:36.950 --> 00:24:40.230
it could potentially have updated some
of those, I doubt it, but let's see.

508
00:24:40.230 --> 00:24:44.200
Whoops, let me pseudo that and
see if that's changed.

509
00:24:44.200 --> 00:24:45.810
It's probably still the same.

510
00:24:45.810 --> 00:24:49.400
If I were to run a yum update right now,
it would probably take a good 15 or 20

511
00:24:49.400 --> 00:24:53.080
minutes because you've got to download all
these packages, and we're still at 589.

512
00:24:53.080 --> 00:24:58.620
But, if I want to update an individual
application, I can say yum update.

513
00:24:59.670 --> 00:25:02.790
I'm forgetting pseudo httpd, and

514
00:25:02.790 --> 00:25:07.690
now it's just gonna update that one
package and its associated dependencies.

515
00:25:07.690 --> 00:25:11.570
It's gonna look, and there's no updates
available for httpd, but if I look up

516
00:25:11.570 --> 00:25:14.770
here, I've got things like the Python
firewall that is apparently installed.

517
00:25:14.770 --> 00:25:18.665
And so if I were to do a sudo yum update

518
00:25:18.665 --> 00:25:24.270
Python-firewall right if
we look at that one package

519
00:25:24.270 --> 00:25:28.840
C was needed and updated and It's actually
tells me that it is not even installed.

520
00:25:28.840 --> 00:25:32.950
So that must be an independent sort
of adding something else that's

521
00:25:32.950 --> 00:25:34.510
not actually installed that so.

522
00:25:34.510 --> 00:25:38.110
If I pick something that was maybe already
installed that will actually make a big

523
00:25:38.110 --> 00:25:39.100
difference with that.

524
00:25:39.100 --> 00:25:45.580
So if we wanted to update right GNUPG2 So
we'll do that one.

525
00:25:45.580 --> 00:25:48.940
And gnupg2 which is
the GNU Privacy Guard or GPG.

526
00:25:48.940 --> 00:25:51.460
If I wanna update just that one,

527
00:25:51.460 --> 00:25:53.860
it's gonna look at it as well
as any other dependencies.

528
00:25:53.860 --> 00:25:57.350
This one has no dependencies, so
I can update just that one package and

529
00:25:57.350 --> 00:25:58.610
now we're in business.

530
00:25:58.610 --> 00:26:05.640
Okay, and if I was in a big hurry, I could
actually do a sudo yum update -y gnupg2.

531
00:26:06.830 --> 00:26:08.520
And now it's gonna do the update.

532
00:26:08.520 --> 00:26:12.060
It's going to apply it, and
I don't have to confirm it,

533
00:26:12.060 --> 00:26:16.980
which is really handy when you're doing
589 and you wanna schedule it, right?

534
00:26:16.980 --> 00:26:21.760
If I have a cron job set to run at 1 am in
the morning, I just want it to run sudo

535
00:26:21.760 --> 00:26:27.340
yum update -y, go find the updates and
apply all of them.

536
00:26:27.340 --> 00:26:29.080
And then when I come in in
the morning it's all updated and

537
00:26:29.080 --> 00:26:32.790
done, with the risk of having
potentially broken systems or

538
00:26:32.790 --> 00:26:36.920
whatever because we haven't necessarily
tested all these like we should have.

539
00:26:36.920 --> 00:26:41.260
All right, Daniel, I've got a good
bit more I need to talk about on

540
00:26:41.260 --> 00:26:42.470
where all this stuff is coming from.

541
00:26:42.470 --> 00:26:45.470
I want to talk about the repositories and
how we can even add third party

542
00:26:45.470 --> 00:26:47.570
repositories to manage software
that's not even from Red Hat.

543
00:26:47.570 --> 00:26:50.340
I want to tackle all that stuff,
it's really important stuff to know.

544
00:26:50.340 --> 00:26:51.330
But I know we're out of time.

545
00:26:51.330 --> 00:26:52.950
So let's do a part two on this one.

546
00:26:52.950 --> 00:26:55.300
And we'll get a chance to dive in, and
see how to bring in all that other stuff.

547
00:26:55.300 --> 00:26:56.280
>> That sounds good, Don.

548
00:26:56.280 --> 00:26:58.870
We're famous for our part twos around
here, and we know you guys love them.

549
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:00.560
So what the heck, we'll do a part two.

550
00:27:00.560 --> 00:27:04.000
Don, thanks so much for
showing these items for us today.

551
00:27:04.000 --> 00:27:08.020
Now we can update our systems a little
better, and get them more secure, right?

552
00:27:08.020 --> 00:27:09.330
A little more stable.

553
00:27:09.330 --> 00:27:11.402
But that part two, we're really
going to see some interesting stuff.

554
00:27:11.402 --> 00:27:12.731
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we look forward to seeing you

555
00:27:12.731 --> 00:27:13.770
guys there, as well.

556
00:27:13.770 --> 00:27:16.746
As for this episode though,
we have run out of time, as Don said.

557
00:27:16.746 --> 00:27:18.198
>> [LAUGH].
>> So, we gonna go and sign off.

558
00:27:18.198 --> 00:27:20.465
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

559
00:27:20.465 --> 00:27:21.388
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

560
00:27:21.388 --> 00:27:23.775
>> We'll see you next time.

561
00:27:23.775 --> 00:27:29.706
[MUSIC].

562
00:27:29.706 --> 00:27:32.884
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue explaining and demonstrating the process of updating and installing software using the command line utility, YUM. They pick back up with YUM groups for "software type" bundle installs. Also, they show you how to roll back and/or remove an update, then move on exploring how to modify YUM repositories; even enabling 3rd-Party repositories.
episodes.title: Software Updates Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.174
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.174 --> 00:00:08.166
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.166 --> 00:00:12.160
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.160 --> 00:00:17.450
>> Greetings everyone, welcome back to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.450 --> 00:00:18.750
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

6
00:00:18.750 --> 00:00:22.990
today's episode we're continuing
on with more Red Hat Linux series.

7
00:00:22.990 --> 00:00:27.560
Joining us back for a part two on updating
softwares, our good friend Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:28.840
Don, welcome back sir, how's it going?

9
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:29.900
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

10
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:31.800
You know in our last episode,
we covered YUM.

11
00:00:31.800 --> 00:00:35.970
The Yellowdog Update Manager,
just the update subsystem in Red Hat.

12
00:00:35.970 --> 00:00:37.220
And we covered a lot of good stuff,

13
00:00:37.220 --> 00:00:39.220
we really covered the things
that you're gonna use everyday.

14
00:00:39.220 --> 00:00:41.050
That was all in part one.

15
00:00:41.050 --> 00:00:43.760
Here in part two though,
I want to address a few other things that

16
00:00:43.760 --> 00:00:47.330
are pretty darn useful that you may
come across out there in real life land.

17
00:00:47.330 --> 00:00:51.350
Now, I showed you guys in the last
episode how we can do a yum install, and

18
00:00:51.350 --> 00:00:52.850
then whatever package
you wanted to install.

19
00:00:52.850 --> 00:00:58.110
And I added Apache on mine which is
pretty easy to do, yum install httpd.

20
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:02.280
But we can also install
collections of software.

21
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:04.710
Remember back when you were installing
Red Hat, you pop in the disk,

22
00:01:04.710 --> 00:01:06.610
you boot off of it,
you start going through the GUI, and

23
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:08.500
at one point,
it asked us what we wanted to install.

24
00:01:08.500 --> 00:01:12.370
And you could choose minimal server,
or infrastructure server, or

25
00:01:12.370 --> 00:01:16.320
web server, the server with GUI,
you kind of pick.

26
00:01:16.320 --> 00:01:20.420
Well, what you're actually
seeing there are yum groups.

27
00:01:20.420 --> 00:01:22.860
They're groups of software, collections.

28
00:01:22.860 --> 00:01:26.020
And with the yum command line utility,
we can actually do that.

29
00:01:26.020 --> 00:01:27.650
We can work with those groups.

30
00:01:27.650 --> 00:01:30.890
So maybe you installed a command
line only version of Red Hat,

31
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:34.430
and then you decide down the road,
I really meant to add the GUI.

32
00:01:34.430 --> 00:01:36.930
And so you can use the group
install command to do that.

33
00:01:36.930 --> 00:01:39.060
Let me show you how it works.

34
00:01:39.060 --> 00:01:46.470
From the command line, if we do
a sudo yum and instead of doing list,

35
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:51.940
like we were doing before where it lists
all the packages, we can say group list.

36
00:01:51.940 --> 00:01:54.340
Now, I do wanna point out one thing,
I'm running Red Hat 7.2 and

37
00:01:54.340 --> 00:01:58.270
in Red Hat 7 these commands
changed a little bit.

38
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:01.010
So if you used previous versions
you're probably used to

39
00:02:01.010 --> 00:02:04.650
group list being all one command,
and now they split it out into two.

40
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:08.240
So that doesn't work in Red Hat 6 and
earlier, you gotta take away that space,

41
00:02:08.240 --> 00:02:10.360
but with all the group commands
I'm about to show you,

42
00:02:10.360 --> 00:02:12.740
that space is a new thing in Red Hat 7.

43
00:02:12.740 --> 00:02:16.870
So if I do group list, it's gonna reach
out to the Red Hat repositories and

44
00:02:16.870 --> 00:02:18.330
it's gonna show me the groups.

45
00:02:18.330 --> 00:02:22.060
And right here are the things
that we saw during the install,

46
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:24.580
it asked us which of these we wanted.

47
00:02:24.580 --> 00:02:26.720
And I picked server with GUI for this one.

48
00:02:26.720 --> 00:02:29.330
But, maybe I want it to
be a virtualization host.

49
00:02:29.330 --> 00:02:33.840
Well the virtualization host group
contains multiple software packages.

50
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:37.410
And there's more groups down here,
compatibility libraries,

51
00:02:37.410 --> 00:02:40.930
we've got Legacy UNIX compatabilities,
smart card support.

52
00:02:40.930 --> 00:02:45.130
And then it'll install all the software
necessary to provide that functionality.

53
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:47.170
So it's groups of software,

54
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:52.590
and if you wanna install one it's just
yum group install, followed by the name.

55
00:02:52.590 --> 00:02:55.600
All the groups have spaces in their names,
so you're gonna have to put it in quote.

56
00:02:55.600 --> 00:02:59.438
Well, I guess maybe not RT but the rest
of them, so if I wanna come in and

57
00:02:59.438 --> 00:03:04.030
add Development Tools I would
need to add it like that right,

58
00:03:04.030 --> 00:03:06.400
well with a little help from sudo.

59
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:09.220
And so now it's gonna reach out,
it's gonna find the group called

60
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:14.710
Development Tools and is grabbing 25
packages, it's grabbing perl and so on.

61
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:18.740
I know what some of you thinking is well,
Don, when you get just yum install,

62
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:20.700
it also installed the dependencies too.

63
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:22.720
Well, these aren't
necessarily dependencies.

64
00:03:22.720 --> 00:03:25.670
There might be two software packages in
here that are completely independent from

65
00:03:25.670 --> 00:03:28.600
each other, but they're both wrapped
up under development tools and

66
00:03:28.600 --> 00:03:29.910
you see that a lot of times.

67
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:34.412
There might be SDKs for some languages and
IDEs to actually work with and

68
00:03:34.412 --> 00:03:38.630
all that other stuff that gets
kinda packaged in with developers.

69
00:03:38.630 --> 00:03:41.484
So you'll see a ton of things here that
are not necessarily dependant on each

70
00:03:41.484 --> 00:03:43.990
other, that's the big advantage
of groups is that we can do that.

71
00:03:45.060 --> 00:03:49.955
So as far as installing packages,
we had yum list and yum install,

72
00:03:49.955 --> 00:03:54.830
with groups it's yum group list and
yum group install.

73
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:57.360
So we're just adding the word
group to the previous command and

74
00:03:57.360 --> 00:03:58.790
that's why they put that space in there,

75
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:02.090
so it's just a simple way to
differentiate between the two commands.

76
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:06.780
Now getting these things
installed is one thing.

77
00:04:06.780 --> 00:04:10.470
We can also remove them,
we can get them back out again.

78
00:04:10.470 --> 00:04:14.590
When you use the remove command,
it uninstalls a package.

79
00:04:14.590 --> 00:04:17.430
Now there are some little quirks
with that in that you might have

80
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:18.980
dependencies in place.

81
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:21.850
And when you uninstall a package,
it may not uninstall the dependencies.

82
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:26.210
So know that it's not necessarily
a perfect system, but getting a package or

83
00:04:26.210 --> 00:04:29.420
a group out, is simply a matter of running
the same command's we've been running,

84
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:33.030
except using the word remove instead
of install, and off it goes.

531
00:27:37.310 --> 00:27:40.320
That being said and done is there
anything we need to add to this

532
00:27:40.320 --> 00:27:42.130
cool little episodes that we've done so
far.

533
00:27:42.130 --> 00:27:43.596
>> Not really, it did actually finish-
>> [CROSSTALK]

534
00:27:43.596 --> 00:27:44.130
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]

535
00:27:44.130 --> 00:27:46.470
>> It just took a little while, but

536
00:27:46.470 --> 00:27:49.070
just be aware,
there's tons of software out there.

537
00:27:49.070 --> 00:27:50.430
Obviously you want to test, right,

538
00:27:50.430 --> 00:27:53.370
I guess that's the lesson I really need to
stress here is always test software, and

539
00:27:53.370 --> 00:27:55.910
always test updates before you
roll them out in their production.

540
00:27:55.910 --> 00:27:59.120
But otherwise, as far as the basic
updates, pretty straightforward system.

541
00:27:59.120 --> 00:28:00.660
The GUI's nice if you have it.

542
00:28:00.660 --> 00:28:02.870
The command line's not
very hard if you don't.

543
00:28:02.870 --> 00:28:04.790
Yum is a very powerful utility.

544
00:28:04.790 --> 00:28:08.530
There are some new package
managers that are on the horizon.

545
00:28:08.530 --> 00:28:11.500
Red Hat is currently
testing one called DNF, and

546
00:28:11.500 --> 00:28:14.070
DNF is supposed to be the replacement
to Yum down the road.

547
00:28:14.070 --> 00:28:16.430
It'll provide the same functionality and
some additional things.

548
00:28:16.430 --> 00:28:19.600
But it's still very beta.

549
00:28:19.600 --> 00:28:24.600
It's actually in Fedora, but
it's not the main package manager yet.

550
00:28:24.600 --> 00:28:26.760
So we'll see that change in a few years.

551
00:28:26.760 --> 00:28:30.830
But for now, Yum is like the bees
knees for updates on Redhat.

552
00:28:30.830 --> 00:28:31.440
>> Awesome stuff.

553
00:28:31.440 --> 00:28:33.070
Well now you guys know how to use Yum.

554
00:28:33.070 --> 00:28:36.430
Go out there, play with your
installations, play with Yum, see what you

555
00:28:36.430 --> 00:28:40.680
can do with it, work with some packages,
maybe install a new repository or two.

556
00:28:40.680 --> 00:28:42.870
That being said, I'm looking at
the clock for this episode and

557
00:28:42.870 --> 00:28:44.640
it looks like we've run out of time.

558
00:28:44.640 --> 00:28:47.590
So now we'll leave you to
go do that very thing.

559
00:28:47.590 --> 00:28:50.192
Don, thanks for joining us today,
we thank you guys for watching.

560
00:28:50.192 --> 00:28:52.970
We're gonna go ahead and sign off,
for ITPRO.TV I've been your host,

561
00:28:52.970 --> 00:28:54.590
Daniel Lawry,
>> And I'm Don Pizzazz.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss and demonstrate how to perform an unattended installation of RHEL7 using Kickstart. They begin by explaining the basics of Kickstart and how to create a ks.cfg file which provides the answers an admin would normally have to enter manually during installation. Then they show you a quick and easy way of using Kickstart with the default RHEL7 installation media.
episodes.title: Deploying with Kickstart
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:02.601
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.601 --> 00:00:06.624
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.624 --> 00:00:08.278
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.278 --> 00:00:12.250
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.250 --> 00:00:14.010
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.010 --> 00:00:16.422
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

7
00:00:16.422 --> 00:00:19.625
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode well you know,

8
00:00:19.625 --> 00:00:23.470
it's more back for our Red Hat
enterprise Linux version seven series.

9
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:25.920
Joining us again is our good friend Mr.
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:26.997
Don welcome back sir, how's it going?

11
00:00:26.997 --> 00:00:28.887
>> It is going great Daniel thanks for
having me back.

12
00:00:28.887 --> 00:00:32.309
And in this episode we're gonna be
tackling a pretty neat topic which

13
00:00:32.309 --> 00:00:34.970
is the Red Hat kickstart for
the Anaconda installer.

14
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:39.510
Now if you think back to episode number
one, the very first episode of the series.

15
00:00:39.510 --> 00:00:42.210
I showed you guys how to install
Red Hat enterprise Linux and

16
00:00:42.210 --> 00:00:44.040
we went through
the graphical installer and

17
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:46.730
we put in a bunch of options,
clicked next a bunch of times.

18
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:49.570
A very exciting,
thrilling adventure filled episode.

19
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:53.370
And at the end of the day we had
Red Hat Enterprise Linux installed.

20
00:00:53.370 --> 00:00:57.348
And that system works out great if
you're installing one machine or

21
00:00:57.348 --> 00:00:58.828
maybe in five machines.

22
00:00:58.828 --> 00:01:02.052
But what if you need to
install a thousand machines?

23
00:01:02.052 --> 00:01:03.995
That system gets pretty old pretty fast.

24
00:01:03.995 --> 00:01:05.316
>> Now your just making up numbers, Don.

25
00:01:05.316 --> 00:01:09.067
>> At that point,that's when you start
getting the disgruntled employee and

26
00:01:09.067 --> 00:01:11.773
now you've got to do background
checks on everybody.

27
00:01:11.773 --> 00:01:14.060
I hate to say that stuff.

28
00:01:14.060 --> 00:01:17.470
What redhat has is a system
called the kickstart.

29
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:21.280
What kickstart does is that it lets
us create a configuration file

30
00:01:21.280 --> 00:01:24.480
that tells the system what
to do during the install.

31
00:01:24.480 --> 00:01:26.270
So that when we actually
go to perform that install,

32
00:01:26.270 --> 00:01:28.180
It doesn't ask us anything
it just gets to work.

33
00:01:28.180 --> 00:01:31.300
It just starts doing it, turning through
and putting all the settings in place and

34
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:34.090
getting the system configured
the way that we want it.

35
00:01:34.090 --> 00:01:38.760
And that's really handy if you've
got a lot of machine to deploy.

36
00:01:38.760 --> 00:01:42.600
In fact you can take kickstart all
the way to the next level, right?

37
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:44.720
It goes to 11 we can turn it to 11.

38
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:47.890
If we couple it with
something like pixie booting,

39
00:01:47.890 --> 00:01:53.060
you can have a completely blank system,
you power it on.

40
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:55.390
The network adapter fires up,
looks at the network,

41
00:01:55.390 --> 00:02:00.500
finds a pixie server,
grabs the redhat kickstart.

42
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:04.350
Starts to boot up, grabs all the files and
installs it and completely populates and

43
00:02:04.350 --> 00:02:06.020
builds a server and brings it online.

44
00:02:06.020 --> 00:02:09.480
And all you had to do,
was push the power button, right?

45
00:02:09.480 --> 00:02:12.120
They call that a zero touch install.

46
00:02:12.120 --> 00:02:14.550
Technically you got one touch you
got to push the power button.

47
00:02:14.550 --> 00:02:17.080
But once the power button is pushed
that's it, you don't do anything else.

48
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:17.909
It does the full install.

49
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:20.740
Normally we don't do it that way.

50
00:02:20.740 --> 00:02:23.528
Normally we do what's called an LTI,
or a light touch install,

51
00:02:23.528 --> 00:02:25.091
where you do have to do a few things.

52
00:02:25.091 --> 00:02:26.330
Just a few little things.

53
00:02:26.330 --> 00:02:30.270
And the reason is, we probably have
more than one configuration file, right.

54
00:02:30.270 --> 00:02:33.060
The more configuration files you have,
you gotta pick which one you want.

55
00:02:33.060 --> 00:02:36.260
So there's at least a menu that you pick
and go through, and you do your install.

56
00:02:36.260 --> 00:02:39.920
So that's what we can do with kickstart
and if you're coming from the Windows

57
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:43.770
world this is very similar to doing
things like an unattended install or

58
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:47.820
auto install,
whatever Microsoft calls it but

59
00:02:47.820 --> 00:02:52.350
in the Red Hat world it's kickstart and
actually works in a very similar method.

60
00:02:52.350 --> 00:02:55.400
Now I mentioned Pixie Boot, that's
probably the hardest way to deploy it.

61
00:02:55.400 --> 00:02:56.820
Kind of fun but it's hard.

62
00:02:56.820 --> 00:03:01.020
An easier way is,
we can create bootable USB media.

63
00:03:01.020 --> 00:03:05.430
Or a bootable CD that already has the kick
start right on the disk, all right?

64
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:08.350
And when you do that,
now you can boot off of that disk.

65
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:10.090
And it just automatically installs.

66
00:03:10.090 --> 00:03:13.982
The negative of that method is, what if
you want to change the kick start file?

67
00:03:13.982 --> 00:03:15.600
You want to modify
the configuration a little bit.

68
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:17.720
Now you've got to go and
reburn your installation media.

69
00:03:17.720 --> 00:03:19.000
It's kind of a hassle.

70
00:03:19.000 --> 00:03:22.720
So what I usually do Is
find a healthy medium.

71
00:03:22.720 --> 00:03:27.710
What I like to do is place the kick
start file in a network location.

72
00:03:27.710 --> 00:03:31.020
And then just use the regular,
old, red hat bootable media.

73
00:03:31.020 --> 00:03:35.766
I might have RHEL 7.1 and
then RHEL 7.2 comes out.

74
00:03:35.766 --> 00:03:39.430
Well that's okay, I get my 7.2 media or
7.3, or whatever.

75
00:03:39.430 --> 00:03:43.270
And I can just boot off
the regular old disk and

76
00:03:43.270 --> 00:03:47.870
during the boot process I can point
it to a network kick start file.

77
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:51.330
And then after that it does everything
else unattended, so it's light touch.

78
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:55.290
I just have to get involved enough to tell
it where to get the kick start file from,

79
00:03:55.290 --> 00:03:56.870
and after that it runs nice and smooth.

80
00:03:56.870 --> 00:04:00.434
And by storing the kick start file on
the network, anytime I need to change it,

81
00:04:00.434 --> 00:04:01.406
I just go and edit it.

82
00:04:01.406 --> 00:04:03.752
I don't have to change any
of my installation media and

83
00:04:03.752 --> 00:04:04.930
it makes life a lot easier.

84
00:04:04.930 --> 00:04:06.640
That's one of the best methods for

85
00:04:06.640 --> 00:04:09.630
actually deploying a Kickstart cuz
it gives you the most flexibility.

86
00:04:09.630 --> 00:04:12.310
>> Anyway,
we have to do that a thousand times

87
00:04:12.310 --> 00:04:14.610
instead of [LAUGH] the entirety
of the installation.

88
00:04:14.610 --> 00:04:18.100
>> And servers are usually unique
enough that you can't reuse Kickstart

89
00:04:18.100 --> 00:04:19.160
files too much.

90
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:20.359
But workstations, you might be deploying.

91
00:04:20.359 --> 00:04:21.865
>> That's fantastic.

92
00:04:21.865 --> 00:04:23.510
>> Yeah,
thousands of them that are identical.

93
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:25.610
And in that scenario it's not even
a bad idea to just go ahead and

94
00:04:25.610 --> 00:04:27.810
burn the kickstarter file right
onto the installed media.

95
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:29.300
Now you don't even need a network.

96
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:32.864
You just, hey this computer's acting up,
let me put this CD in and boot from

97
00:04:32.864 --> 00:04:36.724
the CD, and look, it automatically
formats, it automatically partitions.

98
00:04:36.724 --> 00:04:40.172
It copies the operating system,
it installs the applications,

99
00:04:40.172 --> 00:04:44.250
it sets the IP address, and everything,
and all I had to do was boot it up.

100
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:45.155
>> Yeah.
>> And it's done.

101
00:04:45.155 --> 00:04:46.690
Yeah, that's instant tech support.

102
00:04:46.690 --> 00:04:48.690
System's reformatted and
you're in business.

103
00:04:48.690 --> 00:04:50.490
That's kinda nice to have.

104
00:04:50.490 --> 00:04:52.010
All right, so enough talking about it.

105
00:04:52.010 --> 00:04:53.570
Let's see how this works.

106
00:04:53.570 --> 00:04:56.000
First thing we need to do is we
need to create a kick start file,

107
00:04:56.000 --> 00:04:58.250
and a kick start file is just a text file.

108
00:04:58.250 --> 00:05:00.870
It's a text file that has instructions for
the system,

109
00:05:00.870 --> 00:05:03.540
and the instructions are broken
up into sections, all right.

110
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:06.557
And most of it centers around
your system configuration.

111
00:05:06.557 --> 00:05:08.860
What network adapters do you have?

112
00:05:08.860 --> 00:05:10.400
What IP address do you want?

113
00:05:10.400 --> 00:05:12.460
What's the root password?

114
00:05:12.460 --> 00:05:15.550
Think of any question that
happens during the installer and

115
00:05:15.550 --> 00:05:17.590
that's something that
can go in the kickstart.

116
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:20.860
But then there's things beyond it,
like there's a pre and a post section.

117
00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:25.731
There's a pre install and a post install
section where you can put scripts I might

118
00:05:25.731 --> 00:05:28.680
say, all right I need a preinstall script.

119
00:05:28.680 --> 00:05:31.680
Because there's different hard
drive configurations out there, and

120
00:05:31.680 --> 00:05:35.290
I need to be able to configure raid first.

121
00:05:35.290 --> 00:05:38.030
And so I might have some commands
that run before the installer starts.

122
00:05:38.030 --> 00:05:42.740
Or post-configuration, hey this machine
is now in place, but I didn't put

123
00:05:42.740 --> 00:05:46.610
a host name in the config file because I'm
gonna use this on many different machines.

124
00:05:46.610 --> 00:05:50.050
So in my script, it's going to look for
some kind of information to generate and

125
00:05:50.050 --> 00:05:51.090
assign a host name.

126
00:05:51.090 --> 00:05:52.600
I do that after the fact right.

127
00:05:52.600 --> 00:05:56.190
So the pre and post scripts,
they allow you to do whatever you want.

128
00:05:56.190 --> 00:05:59.780
And now you've got the ultimate
flexibility with your deployment.

129
00:05:59.780 --> 00:06:02.610
Now creating a kickstart
file,it's not exactly easy if

130
00:06:02.610 --> 00:06:03.870
you've never done it before.

131
00:06:03.870 --> 00:06:05.067
Because you've got to know the syntax.

132
00:06:05.067 --> 00:06:06.976
And the syntax is a little bit tricky and
if you make a mistake,

133
00:06:06.976 --> 00:06:08.390
the whole thing doesn't work.

134
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:09.820
And you get all sorts of weird errors and

135
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:13.680
stuff so we need to create
a consistent kickstart file.

136
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:17.280
And to help us with that,
redhat has a nice little utility for

137
00:06:17.280 --> 00:06:19.810
it called the kickstart configurator.

138
00:06:19.810 --> 00:06:23.030
Or they call it system config kickstart.

139
00:06:23.030 --> 00:06:26.066
Now you may already have it
on your system you may not.

140
00:06:26.066 --> 00:06:28.960
A lot of systems don't include
it in the default install.

141
00:06:28.960 --> 00:06:34.940
So if you don't have it,
you can add it in real quick just

142
00:06:34.940 --> 00:06:40.686
by doing a yum install
system-config-kickstart.

143
00:06:40.686 --> 00:06:44.490
I've already got it on my system so
it's not gonna complain for me here.

144
00:06:44.490 --> 00:06:49.390
But if you don't have it, that'll install
it, right, system-config-kickstart.

145
00:06:49.390 --> 00:06:52.060
If you just have
the command line interface,

146
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:55.250
then you now have a tool you
can run that's going to let you

147
00:06:55.250 --> 00:06:58.080
do your Kickstart file that's
all command line based.

148
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:01.840
But if you have a GUI really you should
be creating these on your work station,

149
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:03.160
not on a server anyway.

150
00:07:03.160 --> 00:07:04.989
So you probably do have a GUI.

151
00:07:04.989 --> 00:07:09.176
If you have a GUI, you can go up under
applications and go down to system tools,

152
00:07:09.176 --> 00:07:11.720
and you'll now have a new entry for
Kickstart.

153
00:07:12.870 --> 00:07:17.720
The kickstart gui and the kickstart
command line have the same functionality.

154
00:07:17.720 --> 00:07:21.830
So if I have the choice I
generally use the gui, right?

155
00:07:21.830 --> 00:07:23.990
That's going to be the easiest one to use.

156
00:07:23.990 --> 00:07:26.460
Doing it from the command line
is really about the same thing.

157
00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:30.020
You see on the left side all
of these different categories.

158
00:07:30.020 --> 00:07:32.170
And on the right side,
the setting that are inside of it.

159
00:07:32.170 --> 00:07:35.030
And we're basically providing
the answers to all the installation

160
00:07:35.030 --> 00:07:36.450
questions, all right?

161
00:07:36.450 --> 00:07:40.990
If we answer every single question,
we now have an unattended install,

162
00:07:40.990 --> 00:07:43.350
it will do the install
without interaction.

163
00:07:43.350 --> 00:07:47.490
If you leave one or two questions off,
It will prompt for those.

164
00:07:47.490 --> 00:07:48.887
And now it is interactive, but

165
00:07:48.887 --> 00:07:52.561
you could at least shrink the amount of
questions that people get asked, right?

166
00:07:52.561 --> 00:07:55.676
An end user might know enough to
pick what language they speak.

167
00:07:55.676 --> 00:07:57.118
Some end users are that smart.

168
00:07:57.118 --> 00:07:58.048
[LAUGH] And so, But

169
00:07:58.048 --> 00:08:02.389
an end user probably doesn't know how you
wanna partition the hard drive, right?

170
00:08:02.389 --> 00:08:03.610
They don't normally know that.

171
00:08:03.610 --> 00:08:05.490
So maybe I just go in here and

172
00:08:05.490 --> 00:08:09.400
set the partition information and
I let them pick their language.

173
00:08:09.400 --> 00:08:10.910
Right, I don't wanna force that on them.

174
00:08:10.910 --> 00:08:11.570
They can pick.

175
00:08:11.570 --> 00:08:15.300
So it's up to you what you wanna provide
and what you don't wanna provide.

176
00:08:15.300 --> 00:08:19.910
You might choose not to provide a root
password, because you wanna have a unique

177
00:08:19.910 --> 00:08:22.310
root password on every
single machine you deploy.

178
00:08:22.310 --> 00:08:26.270
So if I leave that blank,
it is gonna prompt me for that, all right?

179
00:08:26.270 --> 00:08:28.810
But if I have a consistent root
password I'm gonna use everywhere,

180
00:08:28.810 --> 00:08:30.330
I can come in and I can put that.

181
00:08:30.330 --> 00:08:33.236
So let me just kind of run through this
file here, and we'll see to those options.

182
00:08:33.236 --> 00:08:37.060
My default language, English USA is fine,
USA English for my keyboard.

183
00:08:37.060 --> 00:08:40.850
My time zone, I am not in Africa,
at least not right now.

184
00:08:40.850 --> 00:08:45.880
So let me go down to America/New York
cuz it's the time zone that

185
00:08:45.880 --> 00:08:49.046
we use which is almost there, there we go.

186
00:08:49.046 --> 00:08:53.470
I can chose to use UTC if I want to, I'm
not going to, I can set my password, so

187
00:08:53.470 --> 00:08:59.920
I'll specify a password and by default,
this password is getting encrypted.

188
00:08:59.920 --> 00:09:05.401
I think it uses SHA-256 if I remember
right to, it might be SHA-512.

189
00:09:05.401 --> 00:09:07.951
I'm pretty sure it's SHA-256,
and it encrypts it and

190

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their exploration of Kickstart, this time creating a standard Kickstart install ISO. Then they create a custom Kickstart ISO and show you how to edit the boot screen to give you the option of choosing any number of custom Kickstart installations. They also show you how to employ Kickstart with network based connections.

We thank you guys for joining us.

627
00:32:54.250 --> 00:32:56.358
But we are gonna sign off for ITProTV.

628
00:32:56.358 --> 00:32:57.880
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

629
00:32:57.880 --> 00:32:58.780
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

630
00:32:58.780 --> 00:33:00.941
>> We'll see you next time.

631
00:33:00.941 --> 00:33:06.919
[MUSIC]

632
00:33:06.919 --> 00:33:13.829
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don attempt to dispel some of the mystery and even controversy that is Systemd. They explain what systemd is and what it does. They then introduce you to some key terms like Unit and Target. Finally they show you how to manage services, run-levels, and system power with the `systemctl` command.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2

3

[CROSSTALK]
>> Live from San Francisco, California.

4
00:00:05.636 --> 00:00:12.277
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.277 --> 00:00:13.090
>> All right.

6
00:00:13.090 --> 00:00:15.930
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:17.710
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:17.710 --> 00:00:20.800
In today's episode we
are moving on with more on our

9
00:00:20.800 --> 00:00:23.100
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7 series.

10
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:25.270
That's right I can say it correctly.

11
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:26.880
And joining us back in the studio for

12
00:00:26.880 --> 00:00:30.740
something about system D is our
good friend, Mr Don Pizzet.

13
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:33.420
Don, welcome back Sir,
what is the system D and how are you?

14
00:00:33.420 --> 00:00:34.720
>> Boy let me tell you,
I'm doing great Daniel.

15
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:37.620
And I'm entering into this episode
with a little bit of trepidation,

16
00:00:37.620 --> 00:00:41.920
because, System D is a bit
of a controversial subject.

17
00:00:41.920 --> 00:00:43.070
>> It is.

18
00:00:43.070 --> 00:00:44.725
>> If your ever bored-
>> Google that.

19
00:00:44.725 --> 00:00:48.530
>> -go onto any Linux forum on
the internet and just push the questions.

20
00:00:48.530 --> 00:00:53.094
Punch in there, what do you guys
think is wrong with SystemD.

21
00:00:53.094 --> 00:00:54.143
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

22
00:00:54.143 --> 00:00:55.670
>> And just proceed to-

23
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:56.870
>> Get the popcorn out.

24
00:00:56.870 --> 00:00:58.152
>> Yeah, yeah, it's amazing.

25
00:00:58.152 --> 00:01:04.350
So systemD is the new boot system that
is a part of Red Hat enterprise Linux.

26
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:07.720
It was rolled in with Red Hat 7 and

27
00:01:07.720 --> 00:01:12.070
it was fully tested over in Fedora and all
that stuff before it made it into Red Hat.

28
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:13.600
But it's a big change.

29
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:16.750
It's a change to the way the system boots
up, and the way that we interact with

30
00:01:16.750 --> 00:01:21.110
the system, and so on, that's just
different from what we had before.

31
00:01:21.110 --> 00:01:24.310
And in a way,
gives us a lot more power and flexibility.

32
00:01:24.310 --> 00:01:29.500
But there's a lot of people that
are true to the Unix ideal that was

33
00:01:29.500 --> 00:01:32.530
established back in the 1970s
that just don't want to let go.

34
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:33.970
And so it is a big change.

35
00:01:33.970 --> 00:01:35.760
And a lot of people
are not happy about it.

36
00:01:35.760 --> 00:01:36.790
Now, I say a lot of people.

37
00:01:36.790 --> 00:01:39.470
It's actually like
a really vocal minority.

38
00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:42.350
Obviously, Red Hat wouldn't
roll out a technology if most

39
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:43.234
everybody hated it right?

40
00:01:43.234 --> 00:01:43.920
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

41
00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:45.630
>> So
it is something that people have adopted.

42
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:46.980
And I personally like it.

43
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:49.160
It's a little easier to work with,
in my opinion.

44
00:01:49.160 --> 00:01:50.310
But who am I, right?

45
00:01:50.310 --> 00:01:53.470
I'm not some operating system engineer or
anything.

46
00:01:53.470 --> 00:01:56.690
But, there are people that have
some very divided opinions on it.

47
00:01:56.690 --> 00:02:00.340
But it doesn't matter because if you're
using Red Hat, when you go to Red Hat 7,

48
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:03.250
you will be using systemD,
there's no choice to turn it off.

49
00:02:03.250 --> 00:02:06.430
So we need to understand what it is,
what it does, and

50
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:09.170
how we work with it in order to
be happy and maintain Red Hats.

51
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:11.820
That's what we're gonna take a look
at right here in this episode.

52
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:14.360
>> So Don
>> What is systemd?

53
00:02:14.360 --> 00:02:16.910
>> All right.
So when you boot Linux up,

54
00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:19.380
you push the power
button on your computer.

55
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:23.100
And your BIOS or UEFI kicks in.

56
00:02:23.100 --> 00:02:25.610
It finds the operating
system on the hard drive.

57
00:02:25.610 --> 00:02:27.290
It reaches out to the hard drive.

58
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:29.200
It looks in there and
finds the boot loader.

59
00:02:29.200 --> 00:02:31.400
The boot loader tells
it where the kernel is.

60
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:34.520
And the kernel starts Linux, right?

61
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:36.130
Well, the kernel's actually really small.

62
00:02:36.130 --> 00:02:37.880
There's not all that much in the kernel.

63
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:41.450
It's usually one and a half megs in size.

64
00:02:41.450 --> 00:02:46.150
A lot of people say, man,
how did Linus Torvalds write all of Linux?

65
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:50.520
And you just gotta remember that
Linux is actually just the kernel,

66
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:52.860
everything else is software
that's been developed by

67
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:56.330
tens of thousands of people and
it's an impressive project as a whole.

68
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:00.060
It's way beyond what one person
could achieve but that kernel

69
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:04.920
is really just responsible for
allowing software to talk to hardware.

70
00:03:04.920 --> 00:03:08.260
I mean that's really what it does
is allowing access to the CPU and

71
00:03:08.260 --> 00:03:09.620
communicating.

72
00:03:09.620 --> 00:03:12.160
So after that we have
all of the software and

73
00:03:12.160 --> 00:03:16.860
something has to turn the software on,
and that's the initialization sequence.

74
00:03:16.860 --> 00:03:21.790
And in previous versions of Red Hat,
we had what was called the SysVinit,

75
00:03:21.790 --> 00:03:23.580
or system five init.

76
00:03:23.580 --> 00:03:25.243
When Linux was originally created,

77
00:03:25.243 --> 00:03:29.850
Linux Torvalds, he set out to create
a Unix like operating system.

78
00:03:29.850 --> 00:03:33.310
And originally he set out for
binary compatibility, and

79
00:03:33.310 --> 00:03:34.710
I think they abandoned that a while ago.

80
00:03:34.710 --> 00:03:39.130
But But basically it wanted
to function just like UNIX.

81
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:44.400
And UNIX was System 5 back then, like
Sys5, R5 or something like that back then.

82
00:03:44.400 --> 00:03:48.380
And so we had System 5 in it
in most Linux distribution.

83
00:03:48.380 --> 00:03:51.630
So if you ran Slackware or RedHat or

84
00:03:51.630 --> 00:03:56.410
Ubuntu, Debian, any of those guys,
everybody has Sys5 or SysV in it.

85
00:03:56.410 --> 00:03:58.630
Well, over time there were some changes.

86
00:03:58.630 --> 00:04:01.160
We had a new variation that
came out called Upstart and

87
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:03.800
Upstart was really compatible with sys5.

88
00:04:03.800 --> 00:04:06.290
It just kind of added
some extra functionality.

89
00:04:06.290 --> 00:04:08.030
People were okay with that.

90
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:10.560
Well, systemD came along.

91
00:04:10.560 --> 00:04:15.350
With systemD they said here's
a new initialization system and

92
00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:17.440
it works completely different.

93
00:04:17.440 --> 00:04:19.340
The old system, SysVinit.

94
00:04:19.340 --> 00:04:21.590
When your system booted
the kernel loaded up.

95
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:25.370
And then it would call a series of
scripts, you had a bunch of script files,

96
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:28.570
that would all get called as part
of your systems boot process.

97
00:04:28.570 --> 00:04:32.090
And that would start your services and
mount your hard drives and

98
00:04:32.090 --> 00:04:35.030
all the other things that needed to
happen as part of the boot process

99
00:04:35.030 --> 00:04:36.670
It was all handled by script files.

100
00:04:36.670 --> 00:04:39.990
Script files that you could go in and
edit, and change that behavior, and

101
00:04:39.990 --> 00:04:40.880
off you went, right.

102
00:04:42.380 --> 00:04:44.690
Here, let me just show you.

103
00:04:44.690 --> 00:04:47.120
The directories and
stuff are still present in Red Hat for

104
00:04:47.120 --> 00:04:50.910
backwards compatibility, but they're not
used the same way as they used to be.

105
00:04:50.910 --> 00:04:57.099
But if you ever get bored and
browse into /etc /Init.d right.

106
00:04:57.099 --> 00:05:02.900
Init.d that's where the SysVinit
bootscripts are located.

107
00:05:02.900 --> 00:05:07.030
And this folder used to be
packed full of stuff and

108
00:05:07.030 --> 00:05:10.630
when i come in here now,
there's seven or eight files.

109
00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:11.730
Not much in here at all.

110
00:05:11.730 --> 00:05:14.570
Right, in fact some of this
are VMware tools just because I'm in

111
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:15.300
a virtual machine.

112
00:05:15.300 --> 00:05:18.140
These wouldn't even be here by default so
it'd be even less and

113
00:05:18.140 --> 00:05:21.030
that's because these really
aren't used anymore.

114
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:22.340
But they used to be.

115
00:05:22.340 --> 00:05:25.200
It used to be you had a ton of stuff in
here, and they were all called in order.

116
00:05:25.200 --> 00:05:27.550
They'd have little numbers
to change their order.

117
00:05:27.550 --> 00:05:31.440
Or sometimes there were links in here
that would point to directories in other

118
00:05:31.440 --> 00:05:33.210
places, so that you had even more scripts.

119
00:05:33.210 --> 00:05:34.740
You had tons and tons of scripts.

120
00:05:34.740 --> 00:05:36.900
Just fire up Red Hat 6.5 or earlier and

121
00:05:36.900 --> 00:05:40.420
you'll see them,
all these different scripts and locations.

122
00:05:40.420 --> 00:05:42.460
Well, a lot of admins like that.

123
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:46.550
Back in the day the principle of Unix
was that everything could be represented

124
00:05:46.550 --> 00:05:47.170
as a file.

125
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:50.260
If it was memory, it was network
connectivity, if it was whatever.

126
00:05:50.260 --> 00:05:52.410
Everything was represented as a file.

127
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:54.720
And here we had these init scripts,
it was all in line with that.

128
00:05:55.940 --> 00:06:01.730
Systemd comes along, and systemd
says instead of a series of scripts,

129
00:06:01.730 --> 00:06:06.990
we're gonna create one monolithic program,
one big program, and

130
00:06:06.990 --> 00:06:11.750
that program is gonna take control of
the whole initialization sequence and

131
00:06:11.750 --> 00:06:16.210
it is going to take care of attaching
hardware and mapping network drives.

132
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:21.860
It's gonna take care of firing up
services and in controlling that access.

133
00:06:21.860 --> 00:06:26.420
It's going to do a lot of what
used to happen in scripts.

134
00:06:26.420 --> 00:06:28.610
And it's even gonna take
over things like logging,

135
00:06:28.610 --> 00:06:30.880
where we've had Syslog forever, right?

136
00:06:30.880 --> 00:06:32.300
Everybody's used to Syslog.

137
00:06:32.300 --> 00:06:37.000
Well, we still have Syslog under Red Hat
7, and we'll have it for a while longer.

138
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:39.790
But we now have full logging in systemd,
and

139
00:06:39.790 --> 00:06:41.910
that's where you're supposed to
look when you're troubleshooting.

140
00:06:41.910 --> 00:06:42.882
That's the new logs.

141
00:06:42.882 --> 00:06:46.900
So systemd changed a lot of things, and
that's really where the controversy is.

142
00:06:46.900 --> 00:06:47.840
People don't like change.

143
00:06:47.840 --> 00:06:49.435
That's, especially Unix admins.

144
00:06:49.435 --> 00:06:52.061
>> [LAUGH]
>> They just don't like change [LAUGH].

145
00:06:52.061 --> 00:06:56.080
So, and I don't blame them, but
at the same time you need to embrace

146
00:06:56.080 --> 00:06:59.640
new things so
that you can function in our world.

147
00:06:59.640 --> 00:07:01.470
>> Yeah stay with the modern
your exactly right.

148
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:04.920
You can probably get that yourself but
realize that.

149
00:07:04.920 --> 00:07:09.150
And if someone comes in and completely
paradime shifts how you do everything

150
00:07:09.150 --> 00:07:11.540
well you're probably going to
bristle your hairs a little bit and

151
00:07:11.540 --> 00:07:14.700
say well I don't want to I like
the way I know how to do this.

152
00:07:14.700 --> 00:07:17.580
I don't want to learn something new
just so I can do the same things.

153
00:07:17.580 --> 00:07:20.670
But like Don said, technology changes,
you have to stay on top of it.

154
00:07:20.670 --> 00:07:24.010
As we always say in this business you
never step in the same river twice.

155
00:07:24.010 --> 00:07:27.520
That water is constantly moving so
it looks like we're in it for

156
00:07:27.520 --> 00:07:29.690
the long haul when it comes to Systemd.

157
00:07:29.690 --> 00:07:31.240
>> All right so let's take a look at it.

158
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:34.164
The first thing I want to point out
is that normally when we talk about

159
00:07:34.164 --> 00:07:37.923
the initialization sequence, we're really
just thinking about services, right?

160
00:07:37.923 --> 00:07:41.804
And that's been kind of that way for
a long time so In earlier versions of

161
00:07:41.804 --> 00:07:45.551
Red Hat, if I installed mySQL, and
I wanted mySQL to start on boot and

162
00:07:45.551 --> 00:07:49.259
all that, I would have to enable
the service, and set it to boot up.

163
00:07:49.259 --> 00:07:54.221
And you had utilities like the check
config command that would tell it hey,

164
00:07:54.221 --> 00:07:59.100
turn this on when I boot up, or
service start mySQL d, and then ch config,

165
00:07:59.100 --> 00:08:04.453
mySQL d, on to make sure that it came on
every time we booted Well, those services

166
00:08:04.453 --> 00:08:09.940
now get handled by System D, but
System D handles a lot of other stuff too.

167
00:08:09.940 --> 00:08:12.630
System D technically handles
what are called units, and

168
00:08:12.630 --> 00:08:16.130
a unit can be a service, but
a unit can be other things too.

169
00:08:16.130 --> 00:08:18.350
Let me show you the System D units.

170
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:24.540
So with the old System V init,
/etc, /init.d.

171
00:08:24.540 --> 00:08:27.780
That was the folder,
that was the place you wanted to go.

172
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:36.210
In system d, you wanna take a look
at /lib/systemd/system, all right?

173
00:08:36.210 --> 00:08:39.420
That's where all the units for
system D are stored.

174
00:08:39.420 --> 00:08:43.790
And when you look in there,
there's quite a bit, right?

175
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:48.250
And these are all units that are being
looked at when our system boots up, and

176
00:08:48.250 --> 00:08:49.800
many of them are services.

177
00:08:49.800 --> 00:08:51.890
You can spot a service,
because it ends in .service.

178
00:08:51.890 --> 00:08:54.910
That's the nice thing about a unit, is
that at the end, it tells you what it is.

179
00:08:54.910 --> 00:09:00.470
This is a service, but there are other
things in here like, Here's a socket.

180
00:09:00.470 --> 00:09:03.310
So now we're talking about
a network connection of some kind,

181
00:09:03.310 --> 00:09:07.720
or a network connection between two
systems, right here on the same box.

182
00:09:07.720 --> 00:09:10.560
Which, in this case, shut down d is
actually a connection on the same box.

183
00:09:10.560 --> 00:09:12.580
So that one's a socket.

184
00:09:12.580 --> 00:09:14.330
I think I saw a timer in here somewhere.

185
00:09:14.330 --> 00:09:14.850
Yeah, here.

186
00:09:14.850 --> 00:09:16.780
Here's a temp files clean, timer.

187
00:09:17.900 --> 00:09:18.820
Well, what's a timer?

188
00:09:18.820 --> 00:09:20.165
Well remember Cron?

189
00:09:20.165 --> 00:09:21.510
>> Mm-hm.
>> And you can set up Cron jobs,

190
00:09:21.510 --> 00:09:24.130
well, in system d we can
set up timers instead.

191
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:25.310
So we can phase out cron.

192
00:09:25.310 --> 00:09:28.105
Now that's-
>> You're really talking heresy now

193
00:09:28.105 --> 00:09:29.425
[LAUGH]
>> Don't sweat it,

194
00:09:29.425 --> 00:09:31.100
Cron's gonna be around a while longer.

195
00:09:31.100 --> 00:09:35.470
But, this is the point of system d, is
that system d can manage all this stuff.

196
00:09:35.470 --> 00:09:37.020
And that's where a lot of
the paranoia comes from,

197
00:09:37.020 --> 00:09:40.130
people are saying hey,
you're taking away our control of this,

198
00:09:40.130 --> 00:09:43.940
we're losing Cron,
we're losing all these different things.

199
00:09:43.940 --> 00:09:48.240
And it's all going into this one software,
that, if I want to push a change and

200
00:09:48.240 --> 00:09:50.280
it doesn't get approved,
I'm just out of luck.

201
00:09:50.280 --> 00:09:54.230
And you can't take system d out, cuz it's
running the heart of the system, and

202
00:09:54.230 --> 00:09:56.370
that's where people
are starting to get worried.

203
00:09:56.370 --> 00:09:59.550
But, you don't certainly
have to use these.

204
00:09:59.550 --> 00:10:02.290
As we scroll back though,
you'll see there's more things in here.

205
00:10:02.290 --> 00:10:06.130
What I'm looking for in particular,
here we go, mounts, right?

206
00:10:06.130 --> 00:10:07.890
So here's some fuse mounts.

207
00:10:07.890 --> 00:10:12.550
Fuse is a subsystem in Red Hat that
lets you mount things like NTFS and

208
00:10:12.550 --> 00:10:15.700
in other file systems that aren't
normally Linux file systems.

209
00:10:15.700 --> 00:10:20.340
You'll see other mounts that are just for
mounting regular disks, or CDs,

210
00:10:20.340 --> 00:10:21.918
and so on, so there's some mounts.

211
00:10:21.918 --> 00:10:24.830
We've got targets.

212
00:10:24.830 --> 00:10:29.850
Targets are neat, because a target
is actually a collection of units.

213
00:10:29.850 --> 00:10:32.270
Sometimes one unit depends on other units,
right?

214
00:10:32.270 --> 00:10:34.080
And they need to be started together.

215
00:10:34.080 --> 00:10:35.840
If you just start one,
it's going to break something, right?

216
00:10:35.840 --> 00:10:37.330
So you need them to start together.

217
00:10:37.330 --> 00:10:41.480
So it will create a target,
which is a collection of units, and

218
00:10:41.480 --> 00:10:45.740
that collection might be made up of
services, sockets, mounts, and so on.

219
00:10:45.740 --> 00:10:47.280
So they get started together.

220
00:10:47.280 --> 00:10:51.640
So targets are like groups, and
then the units are the individual items.

221
