00:20:28.610 --> 00:20:30.280
you might as well pretend
that's not there.

408
00:20:30.280 --> 00:20:33.580
If you drop that list down,
you'll see Fedora and CentOS.

409
00:20:33.580 --> 00:20:36.290
Because those are free,
anybody can download them but

410
00:20:36.290 --> 00:20:37.960
Red Hat Enterprise Linux
requires a license.

411
00:20:37.960 --> 00:20:40.900
You have to have a license, you have to
have a valid customer portal account to

412
00:20:40.900 --> 00:20:43.320
download it, so
it's not in the drop down box.

413
00:20:43.320 --> 00:20:46.600
So you browse and pick the ISO that you
downloaded from the customer portal.

414
00:20:46.600 --> 00:20:49.900
And then you pick your target device,
your USB key.

415
00:20:49.900 --> 00:20:51.450
It will usually have a name,
you drop it down and

416
00:20:51.450 --> 00:20:53.490
you pick it, right and then that's it.

417
00:20:53.490 --> 00:20:55.500
You hit Create Live USB and
then you're done.

418
00:20:55.500 --> 00:20:58.190
The only real choice we
have here aside from that,

419
00:20:58.190 --> 00:21:01.450
is whether we want persistent
storage by default it will be zero.

420
00:21:01.450 --> 00:21:04.620
I know the picture shows 100 megs but
by default it is zero.

421
00:21:04.620 --> 00:21:06.890
A Live USB is no different than a CD or
DVD,

422
00:21:06.890 --> 00:21:08.880
you're not intended to write data to it.

423
00:21:08.880 --> 00:21:12.450
So you boot off, you do your install,
you take it out and that's it.

424
00:21:12.450 --> 00:21:15.040
Nothing is written to the CD or DVD.

425
00:21:15.040 --> 00:21:17.970
But a USB can be written to or
a USB key can.

426
00:21:17.970 --> 00:21:22.300
So you can create persistent storage,
you'll create an extra partition on there.

427
00:21:22.300 --> 00:21:26.470
And then you can boot off of that disk and
run Red Hat right off of the USB key and

428
00:21:26.470 --> 00:21:28.110
actually save files to it.

429
00:21:28.110 --> 00:21:31.430
So, if you ever wanted to go and
use a computer you didn't trust,

430
00:21:31.430 --> 00:21:35.890
you could create a Live USB key here
with persistent storage on it and

431
00:21:35.890 --> 00:21:38.490
you could load your software and
your files.

432
00:21:38.490 --> 00:21:41.410
And now when you're traveling, you go and
maybe I'm borrowing Wes's laptop and

433
00:21:41.410 --> 00:21:42.710
I don't wanna mess up his stuff.

434
00:21:42.710 --> 00:21:45.890
So, I plug in a USB key and I boot up
off it and there's my documents and

435
00:21:45.890 --> 00:21:47.380
I work with it, so you can do that.

436
00:21:47.380 --> 00:21:50.300
But if you're just creating installation
media, you'll zero that out.

437
00:21:50.300 --> 00:21:54.490
You just drop it down and that's that,
and then create the key, right.

438
00:21:54.490 --> 00:21:57.080
Now, it's just gonna run
through the same process.

439
00:21:57.080 --> 00:21:59.140
Windows doesn't have a DD utility,

440
00:21:59.140 --> 00:22:01.690
they don't have anything
even comparable to that.

441
00:22:01.690 --> 00:22:05.600
So it's gonna go in and just write
this ISO to the physical disk and

442
00:22:05.600 --> 00:22:08.050
once it's done you now have
an installation media.

443
00:22:08.050 --> 00:22:12.240
>> Well Don it's nice that the developers
there at Fedora gave us people who

444
00:22:12.240 --> 00:22:15.770
are in Windows and
need training wheels of a GUI option now.

445
00:22:15.770 --> 00:22:19.990
Question about that, you specified
both in Linux and Mac the block size.

446
00:22:19.990 --> 00:22:23.980
Is that really something that we have
to worry about corruption of the media

447
00:22:23.980 --> 00:22:26.940
if we are in the Windows environment or
because of the integrity check you

448
00:22:26.940 --> 00:22:30.550
get when do you a pre-installation,
pretty much the same thing here.

449
00:22:30.550 --> 00:22:32.290
>> It is actually setting a block size.

450
00:22:32.290 --> 00:22:35.960
I don't know what it is, but it just
doesn't give us the option to change it,

451
00:22:35.960 --> 00:22:39.310
Microsoft supports that but
they don't they just don't expose that.

452
00:22:39.310 --> 00:22:41.280
It's minimizing the GUI elements.

453
00:22:41.280 --> 00:22:43.750
So if you want to go crazy with stuff
like that you've got to move over to

454
00:22:43.750 --> 00:22:45.060
a Linux system.

455
00:22:45.060 --> 00:22:47.634
And if you're a Linux administrator then
odds are you've got a Linux system laying

456
00:22:47.634 --> 00:22:48.900
around somewhere you can use.

457
00:22:48.900 --> 00:22:51.570
Any one will do and it can generate this.

458
00:22:51.570 --> 00:22:54.721
The DD utility is in every
install even the minimal install.

459
00:22:54.721 --> 00:22:57.889
So it's not like you have to install the
software to do it to create the medium.

460
00:22:59.120 --> 00:23:00.110
All right, and look at that.

461
00:23:00.110 --> 00:23:03.410
We are actually finally finished
after a little bit of waiting there.

462
00:23:03.410 --> 00:23:05.480
So I know I'm finished for
a couple of reasons.

463
00:23:05.480 --> 00:23:08.850
One, I get dropped back to my prompt,
this is on the Mac again.

464
00:23:08.850 --> 00:23:10.780
But I also know because
I get this message here,

465
00:23:10.780 --> 00:23:13.740
the disk you inserted was not
readable by this computer.

466
00:23:13.740 --> 00:23:19.860
Macs can't read XFS and ext anything, two,
three, four, they just don't have that.

467
00:23:19.860 --> 00:23:23.500
Which is funny because they run BSD,
they could read the file system but

468
00:23:23.500 --> 00:23:24.600
Apple chooses not to.

469
00:23:24.600 --> 00:23:27.846
So if I initialize, I'm gonna undo all
the work I just did, I'm gonna ignore it.

470
00:23:27.846 --> 00:23:32.348
Now, it's done and on a Linux box,

471
00:23:32.348 --> 00:23:36.770
I would do an fdisk of this device.

472
00:23:36.770 --> 00:23:39.060
And do a p, for
print to be able to see what's on there.

473
00:23:39.060 --> 00:23:43.300
And fdisk dash l, for the device to
see the partitions that were created.

474
00:23:43.300 --> 00:23:46.910
On Windows, you could use the disk
manager or computer management, whatever.

475
00:23:46.910 --> 00:23:51.015
On a Mac,
I can always just say diskutil list.

476
00:23:51.015 --> 00:23:53.081
And it's gonna show the disks
that are out there.

477
00:23:53.081 --> 00:23:56.333
And here's my USB key, woops, down here.

478
00:23:56.333 --> 00:24:00.302
And I can see there's 15.8
GB partition here that is

479
00:24:00.302 --> 00:24:04.870
FDisk_partition_scheme and
is talking about my EXT system.

480
00:24:04.870 --> 00:24:10.570
And then I see this disk1s2 that's
only 6 MB in size, pretty small.

481
00:24:10.570 --> 00:24:12.010
That's gonna be that boot volume.

482
00:24:12.010 --> 00:24:15.082
So it's actually not showing
any other partitions, but

483
00:24:15.082 --> 00:24:18.479
you know there's other ones
there because this is disk1s2.

484
00:24:18.479 --> 00:24:20.221
Where is disk1s1?

485
00:24:20.221 --> 00:24:23.704
It's missing and
actually Apple refuses to look at it.

486
00:24:23.704 --> 00:24:25.666
They go,
we'll just deny the existence of it.

487
00:24:25.666 --> 00:24:28.440
But it is created and
it is available there and

488
00:24:28.440 --> 00:24:31.580
now we have a USB installation
midi that's ready.

489
00:24:31.580 --> 00:24:34.020
We can take that, pop it into a computer,

490
00:24:34.020 --> 00:24:38.270
turn it on and when it boots up we're
gonna see that installation media.

491
00:24:38.270 --> 00:24:40.030
Now just a quick word on that.

492
00:24:40.030 --> 00:24:43.470
A lot of modern computers will
boot from USB automatically.

493
00:24:43.470 --> 00:24:45.480
You just pop it in,
power it on, and that's it.

494
00:24:45.480 --> 00:24:49.960
But there's plenty of them that
either don't support booting to USB,

495
00:24:49.960 --> 00:24:50.920
in which case, you're out of luck.

496
00:24:50.920 --> 00:24:52.390
You've gotta use a DVD.

497
00:24:52.390 --> 00:24:57.160
Or they do support it, but
they've prioritized the hard drives first.

498
00:24:57.160 --> 00:25:00.350
And so you plug it in, you go to boot,
and it just boots off the hard drive.

499
00:25:00.350 --> 00:25:03.790
On a lot of Dell systems, you need to
hit F12 on your keyboard to pull up

500
00:25:03.790 --> 00:25:06.660
a boot menu, and
then you can manually choose USB.

501
00:25:06.660 --> 00:25:11.980
On Lenovos, like the IBM ThinkPads or
Lenovo ThinkPads, whatever they are.

502
00:25:11.980 --> 00:25:14.971
For those, a lot of times you have to go
into the BIOS and you have to prioritize

503
00:25:14.971 --> 00:25:17.472
the USB boot higher than the hard
drives to be able to get into it.

504
00:25:17.472 --> 00:25:21.220
ASUS laptops are the same way,
a lot of times you got to prioritize.

505
00:25:21.220 --> 00:25:25.410
On your servers, most of them are set
to boot from USB by default and

506
00:25:25.410 --> 00:25:26.660
then move onto their hard drives.

507
00:25:26.660 --> 00:25:28.600
So just check your hardware
to make sure you've got that.

508
00:25:28.600 --> 00:25:33.790
But otherwise, once it's created you've
got that media, it's on your system,

509
00:25:33.790 --> 00:25:34.880
it's ready to go.

510
00:25:34.880 --> 00:25:40.050
And you can now go and do your install or
fire things up and be in business.

511
00:25:40.050 --> 00:25:41.370
All right,
sorry if I sounded distracted there.

512
00:25:41.370 --> 00:25:43.885
I was moving the USB key over to get
it plugged into my Linux machine

513
00:25:43.885 --> 00:25:45.916
instead of into my Mac so
that we can actually see it.

514
00:25:45.916 --> 00:25:51.024
And when I plugged it in, see that USB
key shows up as RAGL 7.2 server, right.

515
00:25:51.024 --> 00:25:53.370
It's not showing up as patriot memory or
whatever.

516
00:25:53.370 --> 00:25:55.540
It's actually showing up
as that installation disk.

517
00:25:55.540 --> 00:25:58.570
The Mac wouldn't see it but
my Red Hat box will see it just fine.

518
00:25:58.570 --> 00:26:03.390
And if I go into my disks utility,
let me just jump over to that, and

519
00:26:03.390 --> 00:26:08.140
I take a look at that 16 GB
thumb drive patriot memory.

520
00:26:08.140 --> 00:26:12.410
There's the 6.4 meg, and
see how it's a FAT partition?

521
00:26:12.410 --> 00:26:15.559
And if I look down here,
it's saying FAT 12, 16, or 32.

522
00:26:15.559 --> 00:26:19.490
Contents FAT 12-bit version,
I think I said FAT 16 earlier.

523
00:26:19.490 --> 00:26:21.920
It's the oldest form of FAT.

524
00:26:21.920 --> 00:26:22.590
But that's okay,

525
00:26:22.590 --> 00:26:26.360
cuz it's only 6 megs in size and even
the oldest version of FAT can handle that.

526
00:26:26.360 --> 00:26:29.480
And that there is the Anaconda partition.

527
00:26:29.480 --> 00:26:33.710
Remember, Anaconda is the code name for
the installation system inside of Red Hat.

528
00:26:33.710 --> 00:26:37.100
That's what UEFI is gonna look for
and boot on the system.

529
00:26:37.100 --> 00:26:40.700
The other partition that's magically
showing up here that my Mac

530
00:26:40.700 --> 00:26:45.610
didn't know existed, this sd,
the partition 1 that was invisible,

531
00:26:45.610 --> 00:26:50.680
is Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.2
partition 1 is a 4 GB partition.

532
00:26:50.680 --> 00:26:52.850
And look at that format, ISO9660.

533
00:26:52.850 --> 00:26:55.580
That's a CD or DVD format.

534
00:26:55.580 --> 00:26:58.310
But it's dropped it right
here onto the USB key.

535
00:26:58.310 --> 00:27:02.130
So when I boot UEFI or
my bootloader, I'll hit this.

536
00:27:02.130 --> 00:27:04.050
And it'll start to load the kernel.

537
00:27:04.050 --> 00:27:05.949
And then it'll be able to jump over and
mount this and

538
00:27:05.949 --> 00:27:07.986
perform the rest of
the installation right from there.

539
00:27:07.986 --> 00:27:10.880
So that's exactly what was done
when we created this installation.

540
00:27:10.880 --> 00:27:14.560
And if I look right down here,
I can see that it is flagged as bootable.

541
00:27:14.560 --> 00:27:15.460
And it's ready to rock.

542
00:27:15.460 --> 00:27:17.970
I've got my USB key, and it's in business.

543
00:27:17.970 --> 00:27:19.430
>> Don, we appreciate you taking the time.

544
00:27:19.430 --> 00:27:22.680
And you've taken us through all the three,
well, three major operating systems here.

545
00:27:22.680 --> 00:27:24.990
Now it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode, Don.

546
00:27:24.990 --> 00:27:28.555
But even though you have showed us all
three of the different major platforms,

547
00:27:28.555 --> 00:27:32.495
do you have any additional parting
words about creating your USB media?

548
00:27:32.495 --> 00:27:35.345
>> Just remember that USB media gets
out of date really fast, right?

549
00:27:35.345 --> 00:27:38.625
So I've got 7.2,
you saw on the website 7.3 is already out.

550
00:27:38.625 --> 00:27:41.525
So if I install something with this,
I need to do my updates right away.

551
00:27:41.525 --> 00:27:43.465
And those machines will update to 7.3.

552
00:27:43.465 --> 00:27:48.080
Well, I can remake my installer and
now I would have a 7.3 installer.

553
00:27:48.080 --> 00:27:51.080
Another option, though,
if you watched our Kickstart episode,

554
00:27:51.080 --> 00:27:51.930
you've already seen this.

555
00:27:51.930 --> 00:27:55.270
But with Kickstart,
we can actually set it up so

556
00:27:55.270 --> 00:27:58.850
that when you boot off that USB media,
the installation files aren't on there.

557
00:27:58.850 --> 00:28:00.690
Instead they're on a network location.

558
00:28:00.690 --> 00:28:04.720
And so when a new version of Red Hat comes
out, you just update the network location.

559
00:28:04.720 --> 00:28:08.100
And then people can boot off the USB
key and always get the latest version.

560
00:28:08.100 --> 00:28:11.130
You don't have to go and remake these
USB keys over and over and over again.

561
00:28:11.130 --> 00:28:14.410
The only negative with that solution
is your install is now taking

562
00:28:14.410 --> 00:28:15.350
place over the network.

563
00:28:15.350 --> 00:28:16.950
So I'm copying three and

564
00:28:16.950 --> 00:28:19.960
a half gigs over the network versus
copying it straight from USB.

565
00:28:19.960 --> 00:28:24.210
But as we saw when I made this, the whole
USB side isn't necessarily all that fast.

566
00:28:24.210 --> 00:28:27.632
So going over the network might actually
be faster [LAUGH] in some scenarios.

567
00:28:27.632 --> 00:28:28.984
So definitely keep that in mind.

568
00:28:28.984 --> 00:28:31.260
There's a few different options
that are out there for you.

569
00:28:31.260 --> 00:28:34.650
>> Well, Don, as always, we appreciate
you being here in the studios with us and

570
00:28:34.650 --> 00:28:36.210
we appreciate you, the viewer watching.

571
00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:39.060
Signing out for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

572
00:28:39.060 --> 00:28:39.840
And I'm Don Pezet.

573
00:28:39.840 --> 00:28:40.617
>> And we'll see you next time.

574
00:28:40.617 --> 00:28:47.324
[MUSIC]

575
00:28:47.324 --> 00:28:51.829
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you the essentials for configuring networking in a Red Hat Enterprise Linux environment. They show you common tasks like viewing the current network configuration and configuring a network card. Next, they explore the Network Manager which is used mostly with CLI-Only installs.
episodes.title: Network Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.904
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.904 --> 00:00:07.077
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.077 --> 00:00:08.403
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.403 --> 00:00:12.080
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.080 --> 00:00:13.810
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:13.810 --> 00:00:16.089
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.089 --> 00:00:19.897
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and today's
episode we are continuing on with our

8
00:00:19.897 --> 00:00:22.740
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7 series.

9
00:00:22.740 --> 00:00:24.740
And coming back for
a little more of that action,

10
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:28.020
help lend us down that path is
our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:29.210
Don, welcome back, sir.

12
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:29.849
How's it going today?

13
00:00:29.849 --> 00:00:30.780
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

14
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:33.480
Ready to jump right back in to
the world of Red Hat Enterprise Linux,

15
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:36.730
and in this episode we're gonna take
a look at network configuration.

16
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:39.183
Now, we talked,
just a little bit about network so far,

17
00:00:39.183 --> 00:00:42.679
cuz during the installer we get that
chance to provide a network configuration.

18
00:00:42.679 --> 00:00:44.494
But, we need to revisit that and

19
00:00:44.494 --> 00:00:48.206
the reason is networking can be
really challenging under Linux.

20
00:00:48.206 --> 00:00:51.478
Especially for people coming from other
operating systems because pretty much

21
00:00:51.478 --> 00:00:54.648
every other operating systems you got
a GUI, and when it comes to configuring

22
00:00:54.648 --> 00:00:58.110
the network your normally just clicking
on some buttons and that's it.

23
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:01.978
But if your doing a headless server
that is entirely command line,

24
00:01:01.978 --> 00:01:05.166
network configurations
become really challenging.

25
00:01:05.166 --> 00:01:08.673
Daniel, have you ever configured a Windows
network adapter from the command line?

26
00:01:08.673 --> 00:01:11.323
>> I think I have once.

27
00:01:11.323 --> 00:01:14.240
It's not very often that
you do something like that.

28
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:18.500
>> You've got ten PowerShell commands or
a bunch of other stuff.

29
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:19.880
It's not an easy thing to do.

30
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:22.320
Well, in the Linux world,
it's actually not as bad,

31
00:01:22.320 --> 00:01:24.750
because it's really just a couple of
config files that we need to modify.

32
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:27.310
But we need to know what to look for
and where to look for it.

33
00:01:27.310 --> 00:01:29.800
So in this episode,
that's what we're gonna take a look at.

34
00:01:29.800 --> 00:01:31.870
And the main reason I want
to highlight it here,

35
00:01:31.870 --> 00:01:36.210
is if you do a minimal server install, a
lot of times when you do a minimal server

36
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:38.840
install, it's not going to configure
your network adapter for you.

37
00:01:38.840 --> 00:01:41.116
And some of the utilities you're used
to might not even be there, right?

38
00:01:41.116 --> 00:01:43.250
So that can be a real challenge, too.

39
00:01:43.250 --> 00:01:46.470
The other thing is,
even if you do a full install,

40
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:50.500
the installer only lets you
configure one network adapter.

41
00:01:50.500 --> 00:01:54.300
If you want to do more, well,
if you're doing the GUI installer,

42
00:01:54.300 --> 00:01:55.390
you have the option to add in more.

43
00:01:55.390 --> 00:01:57.410
But, if you're doing
the text based installer,

44
00:01:57.410 --> 00:01:59.020
you don't even see that ability.

45
00:01:59.020 --> 00:02:01.870
So, you're going to have to configure
networking after the fact, right?

46
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:03.440
Well, let's start with the easy stuff.

47
00:02:03.440 --> 00:02:04.990
We'll get that out of the way.

48
00:02:04.990 --> 00:02:06.827
If I had a graphical user interface,

49
00:02:06.827 --> 00:02:09.553
configuring networking under
Red Hat is really easy,

50
00:02:09.553 --> 00:02:13.831
because Red Hat has a service that runs in
the background called the network manager.

51
00:02:13.831 --> 00:02:15.810
The network manager's just a service.

>> [LAUGH]

>> Yeah, absolutely, and
it takes a little while to learn.

00:25:57.455 --> 00:25:57.980
>> Mm-hm.

00:25:57.980 --> 00:26:01.422
>> And the network manager is kind of

00:26:01.422 --> 00:26:04.040

00:26:22.892 --> 00:26:23.730

00:26:23.730 --> 00:26:27.940

So if I were to flip that off and

If you look back here,
you'll we've got the set command,

00:27:15.817 --> 00:27:20.360
whoops, if I get back into the NMCLI here.

00:27:20.360 --> 00:27:21.540

00:27:21.540 --> 00:27:25.240

I'd have to remove the other DNS servers,

541
00:27:46.155 --> 00:27:49.887
>> So the MML of the NMCLI is one

00:27:49.887 --> 00:27:51.298

00:27:51.298 --> 00:27:56.117
>> Yeah, the idea is that if you do

00:28:22.377 --> 00:28:24.215
personally, if I do a head list server,

I usually don't even install
the network manager at all.

554
00:28:27.340 --> 00:28:30.755
It's one extra service that's running

00:28:30.755 --> 00:28:33.807

556
00:28:33.807 --> 00:28:37.140
So you have a wireless adapter

558

But on a physical server, are we

00:28:44.100 --> 00:28:46.610
On a VM, we're not even changing

00:28:46.610 --> 00:28:49.840
In fact, you normally have one or

00:28:49.840 --> 00:28:52.730

00:28:52.730 --> 00:28:55.980

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue exploring network configuration in Red Had Linux, picking up by demonstrating a manual setup through the system configuration files. Here you'll see how to edit and configure the `network`, `hosts`, and `hostname` files, as well as `resolv.conf`. Lastly they show you how to start/stop/restart the network services.

line and I mentioned how there's that

[LAUGH] but if we do that

Nmcli connection reload.

00:02:23.970 --> 00:02:30.750

the connection is the software.

00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:43.050

00:03:10.140 --> 00:03:12.640

systemctl restart network.

00:03:30.100 --> 00:03:32.640

that would restart.

00:03:32.640 --> 00:03:36.580
That's actually the same thing
as what we did way up here,

00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:38.730
when I did nmcli connection reload.

77
00:03:38.730 --> 00:03:42.260
We're kinda reloading all
the connections right there.

00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:47.220

00:03:47.220 --> 00:03:50.020

80
00:03:50.020 --> 00:03:52.930
Well in Red Hat 7,
it's running systemd, but

00:03:52.930 --> 00:03:55.160
it's smart enough to
handle the old commands.

82
00:03:55.160 --> 00:03:58.840
So if I run the old command,

83
00:03:58.840 --> 00:04:02.480
It's gonna take it and
see how it sent it over to systemctl.

84
00:04:02.480 --> 00:04:04.680
It said this admin doesn't
know what he's doing.

85
00:04:04.680 --> 00:04:06.173
Let me change that to the right command.

86
00:04:06.173 --> 00:04:08.240
And then it sent it and it restarted it.

87
00:04:08.240 --> 00:04:10.130
So the old command still
works if you want.

88
00:04:10.130 --> 00:04:13.100
So, I think I just showed you five
different ways to restart the network

89
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:14.840
adapter which is probably
a little overkill.

90
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:17.730
But just know that you kind
of have options there.

91
00:04:17.730 --> 00:04:20.102
>> Well, if you can't start it by now, you

92
00:04:20.102 --> 00:04:21.209
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's not going to happen.

93
00:04:21.209 --> 00:04:21.881
>> It's not happening.

94
00:04:21.881 --> 00:04:23.794
>> All right, so let's dive in here and

95
00:04:23.794 --> 00:04:27.150
take a look at these config
files that I was talking about.

96
00:04:27.150 --> 00:04:30.010
The whole time we were using the network
manager, the network manager's just

97
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:34.010
designed to be a easy,
human interface for this stuff, right?

98
00:04:34.010 --> 00:04:36.910
So the graphical user interface obviously,
that's easy.

99
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:40.110
But then there's the command line in
NMCLI where it's just supposed to be

100
00:04:40.110 --> 00:04:42.440
one place we go for
all of our network adapters.

101
00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:46.760
The reason we need that is that if we
bypass all that and we go the config

102
00:04:46.760 --> 00:04:50.190
files, there's actually more than one
config file involved in the process.

103
00:04:50.190 --> 00:04:51.820
And so it becomes a little
more challenging to deal with.

104
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:53.160
Everything's spread out.

105
00:04:53.160 --> 00:04:54.640
But if you know where all the stuff is,

106
00:04:54.640 --> 00:04:57.700
it can actually be a little faster
sometimes to jump into those config files.

107
00:04:57.700 --> 00:05:01.420
So if you're like me, and you've been
working in Unix type environments for

108
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:04.660
a long time,
the config files are perfectly fine.

109
00:05:04.660 --> 00:05:06.690
But if you're just getting
started with Red Hat,

110
00:05:06.690 --> 00:05:10.360
I encourage you to learn the NMCLI,
because it works really well.

111
00:05:10.360 --> 00:05:12.990
You can do everything in one place,
and it's nice to have it.

112
00:05:12.990 --> 00:05:15.140
But, if you're hardcore,
you don't want the NMCLI,

113
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:18.200
you want a minimal server footprint so
you're not even installing a network

114
00:05:18.200 --> 00:05:21.370
manager, then the config what we go to,
all right?

115
00:05:21.370 --> 00:05:23.250
So let's take a look at these things.

116
00:05:23.250 --> 00:05:25.510
The first thing we need
to understand is that,

117
00:05:25.510 --> 00:05:30.440
there are configuration settings that
apply to individual network adapters and

118
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:33.660
there's configuration settings that
apply to the system as a whole.

119
00:05:33.660 --> 00:05:34.750
To the entire networking server.

120
00:05:34.750 --> 00:05:38.580
So, there are global settings and
interface settings and

121
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:40.970
that's part of the reason
why stuff is spread out.

122
00:05:40.970 --> 00:05:42.680
The other thing is we
have different services.

123
00:05:42.680 --> 00:05:49.049
So you have the TCP/IP networking stack,

00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:54.480
and you've got the routing process, and
each of them have their own config files.

125
00:05:54.480 --> 00:05:57.480
So again, that's another reason why we
have multiple files that are involved.

126
00:05:57.480 --> 00:06:00.830
So we're gonna end up looking at four or
five different files to achieve

00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:04.140

a lot of the other distributions that
are out there it works just fine.

583
00:28:19.770 --> 00:28:20.670
Versus the network manager

584
00:28:20.670 --> 00:28:22.720
stuff that really just works
in the Red Hat ecosystem.

585
00:28:22.720 --> 00:28:25.210
So Red Hat, Fedora, CentOS, those guys.

586
00:28:26.890 --> 00:28:29.000
All right.
I think that about wraps it up.

587
00:28:29.000 --> 00:28:32.550
I threw a few extra commands
in our notes for this episode,

588
00:28:32.550 --> 00:28:34.770
if you support older systems like Nis+ and
things.

589
00:28:34.770 --> 00:28:37.960
It's pretty uncommon, so if you need
those I'll just put those in the notes

590
00:28:37.960 --> 00:28:39.580
instead of boring us with them right now.

591
00:28:39.580 --> 00:28:41.700
But that's pretty much it for
the network configuration files.

592
00:28:41.700 --> 00:28:42.340
>> Awesome stuff.

593
00:28:42.340 --> 00:28:44.593
This is one of the most important
topics your gonna have to know.

594
00:28:44.593 --> 00:28:46.591
Because as one of our lovely viewers said,

595
00:28:46.591 --> 00:28:50.100
if you don't have network connectivity
you ain't gonna do crap, right?

596
00:28:50.100 --> 00:28:54.390
So that's gonna be really helpful for
you to be able to get your systems online.

597
00:28:54.390 --> 00:28:58.480
Find out IP addresses set DNS, work
with the configuration files if need be.

598
00:28:58.480 --> 00:29:01.060
Very, very handy things for
you to understand.

599
00:29:01.060 --> 00:29:03.542
Don, as always,
phenomenal demonstrations and

600
00:29:03.542 --> 00:29:07.273
explanations of those systems themselves
so that we can actually do that.

601
00:29:07.273 --> 00:29:11.880
That being said, looking at the clock we
have run out of time for this episode.

602
00:29:11.880 --> 00:29:15.440
We do thank you guys for watching, but it
looks like it's time for us to sign off.

603
00:29:15.440 --> 00:29:17.660
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

604
00:29:17.660 --> 00:29:18.400
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

605

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the importance of correctly configuring the Network Time Protocol(NTP) on your RHEL7 server. They address some of the usual ways in which time/date/timezone settings are configured and then focus on using the `timedatectl` utility to that end as well as for synchronizing with an online or local NTP server utilizing `chronyd`.
episodes.title: Network Time Protocol (NTP)

WEBVTT

In today's episode, right, that's more

Joining us back in the studio,
well, you know him, you love him,

he's the man that knows

Mister Don Pezet, you can kinda

13
00:00:30.880 --> 00:00:32.640

now I'm supposed to know-

00:00:32.640 --> 00:00:33.410
>> Better make me good.

15

>> All right, well I know some things and

16
00:00:34.832 --> 00:00:37.409
one of the things I know about is
synchronizing the clock on a Linux box

17
00:00:37.409 --> 00:00:39.471
which is what we're gonna
talk about in this episode.

18
00:00:39.471 --> 00:00:43.353
Because Red Hat 7 changed a few things,
so If you've been using Red Hat 6 and

19
00:00:43.353 --> 00:00:45.863
earlier, even other distros
that are out there,

20
00:00:45.863 --> 00:00:48.830
Red Hat does things a little
bit differently in Red Hat 7.

21
00:00:48.830 --> 00:00:49.710
>> What are they, Windows?

22
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:52.177
[LAUGH]
>> Let's just change things arbitrarily.

23
00:00:52.177 --> 00:00:54.464
In this case though,
it is a change for the better.

24
00:00:54.464 --> 00:00:55.697
I like what they've done.

25
00:00:55.697 --> 00:00:57.810
It's actually kind of
a neat little system.

26
00:00:57.810 --> 00:01:01.475
Let's start off with why we're even
bothering doing this episode, right?

27
00:01:01.475 --> 00:01:02.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> Why do we even care about

28
00:01:02.380 --> 00:01:03.420
a clock, right?

29
00:01:03.420 --> 00:01:06.580
It's so easy to set the clock on
a system that it's not a big deal.

30
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:11.030
Well The challenge is so
many things today depend

31
00:01:11.030 --> 00:01:15.810
on the clock on your computer being
accurate that it's really become critical.

32
00:01:15.810 --> 00:01:18.510
And I can give you three quick examples.

33
00:01:18.510 --> 00:01:21.790
One, and probably the most important,
is encryption.

34
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:26.040
A lot of systems like IPsec or
Quivaros authentication,

35
00:01:26.040 --> 00:01:29.350
they use time stamps in their
packets when they transmit them.

36
00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:33.470
And if your clock is wrong,
I think with Quivaros\g it's five minutes.

37
00:01:33.470 --> 00:01:38.890
If it is off by more than five minutes
then, when you reach out to authenticate,

38
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:41.350
the other side is going to assume you
are doing a packet replay attack and

39
00:01:41.350 --> 00:01:43.485
they are going to throw your
communications away and

40
00:01:43.485 --> 00:01:44.658
you're not going to be able to connect.

41
00:01:44.658 --> 00:01:45.539
With IPsec\g,

42
00:01:45.539 --> 00:01:48.900
it's even shorter, I think it's
something like 60 seconds or 30 seconds.

43
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:51.600
I don't remember the exact number but
it's really small.

44
00:01:51.600 --> 00:01:52.410
Those are critical.

45
00:01:52.410 --> 00:01:56.340
To get those technologies working
we need to have accurate time.

46
00:01:56.340 --> 00:02:00.400
And I'm not talking about just close
enough, I'm talking about super accurate.

47
00:02:00.400 --> 00:02:02.315
When you set the time on your computer,

48
00:02:02.315 --> 00:02:05.796
a lot of people make the mistake of
having their time zone set wrong and so

49
00:02:05.796 --> 00:02:08.987
your clock might be right, but
if you're in the wrong time zone,

50
00:02:08.987 --> 00:02:12.613
you're actually several hours off,
and that breaks all sorts of stuff.

51
00:02:12.613 --> 00:02:15.540
So, that's one example of why
we need synchronized time.

52
00:02:15.540 --> 00:02:20.530
Another example is gonna be,
just our logs.

53
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:24.920
The Unix boxes, or Red Hat especially,
logs everything that goes on in the system

54
00:02:24.920 --> 00:02:28.500
as far as errors and start times and
end times and all that other good stuff.

55
00:02:28.500 --> 00:02:30.040
>> It's got a time stamp on it.

56
00:02:30.040 --> 00:02:33.490
If you ever have a security instant where
your network gets compromised, you need to

57
00:02:33.490 --> 00:02:37.730
be able to compare logs across all your
systems to figure out what was accessed.

58
00:02:37.730 --> 00:02:41.600
If the clocks are wrong then
it's hard to say, all right,

59
00:02:41.600 --> 00:02:44.300
show me everything that
happened at 1 PM yesterday.

60
00:02:44.300 --> 00:02:46.470
Well, all right,
1 PM on this server is actually 3:35 PM,

61
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:50.670
and now you've got to go around and kind
of figure all that out, it's not possible.

62
00:02:50.670 --> 00:02:54.430
So having synchronized logs across your
systems helps with troubleshooting

63
00:02:54.430 --> 00:02:55.830
immensely.

64
00:02:55.830 --> 00:02:58.080
And then lastly, your end users.

65
00:02:58.080 --> 00:03:02.232
Your end users will bug
the living daylights out of you.

66
00:03:02.232 --> 00:03:03.020
>> They'll bug you. [LAUGH] >> Yeah,

67
00:03:03.020 --> 00:03:06.670
if that clock is off,
my goodness, it's outrageous.

68
00:03:06.670 --> 00:03:09.580
Now I remember,
there was one company that I worked for

69
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:13.640
where the time on the computer was just
a hair off from the time on the phones,

70
00:03:13.640 --> 00:03:15.625
because you had two different teams.

71
00:03:15.625 --> 00:03:18.680
They weren't IP phones then, there were
just the older digital style telephones.

72
00:03:18.680 --> 00:03:20.715
So you had the phone team
that managed those, and

73
00:03:20.715 --> 00:03:23.780
then you had all of us that did
the servers and the rest of the systems.

74
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:25.420
And the clock was off
by like three minutes,

75
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:30.680
and you would have thought that
it was a travesty of justice.

76
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:35.010
People are like, I don't know, should I go
home now or do I need to wait till 5:03?

77
00:03:35.010 --> 00:03:38.360
And, it was insane, just unbelievable.

78
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:41.395
>> How about, it's close enough,
just go home?

79
00:03:41.395 --> 00:03:43.455
[LAUGH]
>> I think we're done with you.

80
00:03:43.455 --> 00:03:46.000
[LAUGH]
>> That three minutes ain't gonna make or

81
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:47.460
break your day, my good man.

82
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:48.510
[LAUGH]
>> But yeah, you'll never

83
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:49.030
hear the end of it.

84
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:53.080
So just for your own personal well being,
you want the time to be synchronized.

85
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:57.620
And f you have a GUI install,
it's super easy to do that.

86
00:03:57.620 --> 00:03:59.950
If you have a CLI install,
though, like on your servers,

87
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:03.150
it could be a little bit tricky and
that's where Red Hat changed some things.

88
00:04:03.150 --> 00:04:06.090
On the GUI side, yeah, Red Hat
changed stuff, but it's all hidden, so

89
00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:06.960
we don't see it.

90
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:09.280
Let's start with the easy,
we'll start with the GUI side.

91
00:04:09.280 --> 00:04:13.090
If you're in the graphical user interface
for Red Hat, all the way up at the top

92
00:04:13.090 --> 00:04:15.380
right where you see your clock,
you can just click on that.

93
00:04:15.380 --> 00:04:17.950
And a nice big box pops down, and

94
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:21.970
in that box you'll see the current date,
the current time.

95
00:04:21.970 --> 00:04:24.990
So mine says that it's Tuesday,
November 15, 2016.

96
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:28.681
It's 11:33 AM up here.

97
00:04:28.681 --> 00:04:33.420
I can't remember if I'm in a 24 hour
clock or a 12 hour clock, so either way,

98
00:04:33.420 --> 00:04:34.981
11:34 AM, I guess.

99
00:04:34.981 --> 00:04:36.762
on either, I don't know, whatever.

100
00:04:36.762 --> 00:04:37.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> So and

101
00:04:37.750 --> 00:04:39.980
again maybe that/s something
I need to square away too.

102
00:04:39.980 --> 00:04:41.920
So I can see that information here, and

103
00:04:41.920 --> 00:04:46.660
then right down here I can choose to open
clocks or go to date and time settings.

104
00:04:46.660 --> 00:04:49.640
If I open clocks well that's
a little clock applications.

105
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:53.300
That's not any fun, stopwatch, alarm,
world clock, whatever, but if I go to

106
00:04:53.300 --> 00:04:58.320
the other one, the date and time settings,
that's the one I really want to look at.

107
00:04:58.320 --> 00:05:02.667
And right here is where we can see,
my time format is 24 hours, so

108
00:05:02.667 --> 00:05:06.095
I'm 11:33 AM which is fine or 11:34 now.

109
00:05:06.095 --> 00:05:10.045
I could switch that that to AM / PM if
I wanna go that route, and now I know.

110
00:05:10.045 --> 00:05:13.395
I think, is the U.S.
the only country that does that anymore?

111
00:05:13.395 --> 00:05:14.417
>> That stays AM/PM?

112
00:05:14.417 --> 00:05:15.675
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH] I don't know.

113
00:05:15.675 --> 00:05:17.535
>> Pretty much everybody's
gone 24 hour clocks.

114
00:05:17.535 --> 00:05:19.080
>> But we love it.

115
00:05:19.080 --> 00:05:21.912
[LAUGH]
>> You just keep your kilometers.

116
00:05:21.912 --> 00:05:25.707
[LAUGH] So anyhow we can customize that.

117
00:05:25.707 --> 00:05:30.157
You can set your time zone which is
important as well as adjusting the date

118
00:05:30.157 --> 00:05:30.967
and time and so on.

119
00:05:30.967 --> 00:05:34.327
Now I'm not a root user,
I'm logged in with my regular user and

120
00:05:34.327 --> 00:05:36.817
that's why a lot of this
stuff I can't change.

121
00:05:36.817 --> 00:05:40.337
If I wasn't a root user,
if I was just a regular user and

122
00:05:40.337 --> 00:05:44.080
I tried to change the time, I could
be breaking the system for everybody.

123
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:47.490
If I was a root user, I could change
the time, cuz that's a system-wide thing-

124
00:05:47.490 --> 00:05:48.858
>> And then break the system for everyone.

125
00:05:48.858 --> 00:05:50.370
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, absolutely.

126
00:05:50.370 --> 00:05:51.360
And I can set my time zone.

127
00:05:51.360 --> 00:05:53.670
Now, an end user can change the time zone,

128
00:05:53.670 --> 00:05:55.855
because the time zone
doesn't really matter.

129
00:05:55.855 --> 00:05:58.325
The time zone just affects
the visual clock on your screen.

130
00:05:58.325 --> 00:06:02.503
The clock in the background of
the computer is actually in UTC,

131
00:06:02.503 --> 00:06:06.105
UTC [CROSSTALK].

132
00:06:06.105 --> 00:06:08.765
Which is Greenwich Mean Time or whatever.

133
00:06:08.765 --> 00:06:12.275
And an user can change this
cuz it doesn't actually affect

134
00:06:12.275 --> 00:06:13.015
the function of the system.

135
00:06:13.015 --> 00:06:14.445
Everything is done in GMT.

136
00:06:15.680 --> 00:06:18.900
So I can tweak that,
we can do automatic time zone.

137
00:06:18.900 --> 00:06:21.880
If we have a GPS in our system it can
try and figure out where we're at, or

138
00:06:21.880 --> 00:06:24.380
if we had internet access it can try and
locate our IP address and

139
00:06:24.380 --> 00:06:25.430
figure out where it goes.

140
00:06:25.430 --> 00:06:28.280
That doesn't always work out,
VPN's can really screw that up, but

141
00:06:28.280 --> 00:06:29.430
you can try that option if you want.

142
00:06:30.550 --> 00:06:33.270
Now, the automatic date and time.

143
00:06:33.270 --> 00:06:34.580
What does that mean?

144
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:37.800
It means we're using
Network Time Protocol.

145
00:06:37.800 --> 00:06:42.890
That our machine is actually phoning home
to time servers somewhere in the world.

146
00:06:42.890 --> 00:06:44.650
And asking those servers hey,
what time is it?

147
00:06:44.650 --> 00:06:46.959
And they tell us, Network Time Protocol.

148
00:06:46.959 --> 00:06:51.056
Well NTP is great because I can point all
of my workstations, all of my servers,

149
00:06:51.056 --> 00:06:54.725
all my voiceover IP phones,
my switches, my routers, my firewalls,

150
00:06:54.725 --> 00:06:57.200
I can point everything
at the same NTP servers.

151
00:06:57.200 --> 00:07:00.920
I could even build up my own NTP server if
I want, and point them to my own server.

152
00:07:00.920 --> 00:07:04.360
And now they're all gonna have
synchronized time, which is great.

153
00:07:04.360 --> 00:07:07.590
But you'll notice here in the GUI
that that automatic date and

154
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:09.510
time, I can turn it on and off.

155
00:07:09.510 --> 00:07:13.560
But I can't change who
it's phoning home to,

156
00:07:13.560 --> 00:07:17.040
that's kind of the limitation of the GUI,
we can only get so far on this.

157
00:07:17.040 --> 00:07:20.650
If we turn that off, now I can go and
I can override that date and

158
00:07:20.650 --> 00:07:22.630
time if I'm a super user.

159
00:07:22.630 --> 00:07:23.690
I can adjust it.

160
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:27.884
Otherwise it's automatic, that's where
it's pulling from and that's all I can do.

161
00:07:27.884 --> 00:07:31.030
Everything else we have to
do from the command line.

162
00:07:31.030 --> 00:07:34.050
So when it comes to setting the time
on a system, setting up NTP and

163
00:07:34.050 --> 00:07:37.140
things I don't normally do it from
the GUI, even when I have the GUI there.

164
00:07:37.140 --> 00:07:40.070
I still drop to the command line, because
that gives me the full functionality

165
00:07:40.070 --> 00:07:42.551
of even being able to
provide alternate servers.

166
00:07:42.551 --> 00:07:47.358
So let's ditch the GUI, and
go at it the old fashioned way.

167
00:07:47.358 --> 00:07:51.481
It's not really the old fashioned way,
it's the way that works on every server,

168
00:07:51.481 --> 00:07:53.897
versus the GUI that only
works on a few servers.

169
00:07:53.897 --> 00:07:57.649
All right, the first thing that
we need to be aware of is,

170
00:07:57.649 --> 00:08:02.985
there's a lot of old utilities that people
use like HW Clock and tools like that.

171
00:08:02.985 --> 00:08:05.696
That we can use to set the clock.

172
00:08:05.696 --> 00:08:11.380
And, [LAUGH] I guess if I spell it right,
there we go.

173
00:08:11.380 --> 00:08:16.300
I'll see hwclock, and I'm not pseudoing
it right now, so it's not working.

174
00:08:16.300 --> 00:08:19.040
But that's the older utility
that we used to use to force

175
00:08:19.040 --> 00:08:23.300
a clock setting on the hardware,
the BIOS clock or CMOS clock, or

176
00:08:23.300 --> 00:08:26.260
whatever it's called, that's running
on the motherboard of a server.

177
00:08:26.260 --> 00:08:31.060
That certainly works, but what they found
over the years is that the clocks on

178
00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:33.890
mother boards is actually
pretty inaccurate.

179
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:38.039
They lose time pretty readily,
over a second a day most of them, right?

180
00:08:38.039 --> 00:08:41.204
And I know that doesn't sound like
a big deal, a second a day, but

181
00:08:41.204 --> 00:08:43.288
after 60 days that's a minute, right?

182
00:08:43.288 --> 00:08:47.778
Over a course of a year, you're talking
about six minutes that we lose.

183
00:08:47.778 --> 00:08:50.610
Well, remember Kerberos, where I said
you could only be five minutes off?

184
00:08:50.610 --> 00:08:55.050
If you lose six minutes a year, that's
a big deal, right, you can break Kerberos.

185
00:08:55.050 --> 00:08:58.490
So tying into that hardware
clock is not a great idea.

186
00:08:58.490 --> 00:09:01.262
And we can use NTP servers
where we can reach out and

187
00:09:01.262 --> 00:09:05.627
in previous versions of Red Hat and
in most other distros use the NTPD, right?

188
00:09:05.627 --> 00:09:09.219
The NTP daemon and it reaches out and
let's you sync your clock and

189
00:09:09.219 --> 00:09:10.076
bring that in.

190
00:09:10.076 --> 00:09:12.910
And you don't worry about
syncing your hardware clock.

191
00:09:12.910 --> 00:09:15.530
You just say, whatever, the hardware
clock's wrong, what do I care about it?

192
00:09:15.530 --> 00:09:17.440
This is my software clock
that I'm gonna maintain and

193
00:09:17.440 --> 00:09:20.180
I'm gonna synchronize it
with this time server.

194
00:09:20.180 --> 00:09:24.670
Well, in Red Hat 7 they decided
to switch to a different system.

195

00:25:59.550 --> 00:26:00.960
those will be there, I don't lose them.

520
00:26:00.960 --> 00:26:06.060
So that's making them persistent
as opposed to being temporary.

521
00:26:06.060 --> 00:26:09.300
Or ephemeral I think is
the terminology they use [SOUND]

522
00:26:09.300 --> 00:26:10.472
>> [LAUGH]

523
00:26:10.472 --> 00:26:11.598
>> Crazy terms for things.

524
00:26:11.598 --> 00:26:15.519
But that's basically it, so
NFS not that hard to set up and

525
00:26:15.519 --> 00:26:19.050
it is a standard,
it's supported by a ton of stuff.

526
00:26:19.050 --> 00:26:22.900
It's a great system, it's been in
the Unix world for 30 years now.

527
00:26:22.900 --> 00:26:27.250
Really robust and I just gave you guys
a quick primer on getting up and going,

528
00:26:27.250 --> 00:26:28.360
it's very powerful.

529
00:26:28.360 --> 00:26:30.750
If you dig in the documentation,
you can find all kinds of crazy bells and

530
00:26:30.750 --> 00:26:31.390
whistles in NFS.

531
00:26:31.390 --> 00:26:35.840
It's built right in the Red Hat Enterprise
Linux and definitely, in my opinion,

532
00:26:35.840 --> 00:26:37.880
a better option than
Samba if you can do it.

533
00:26:37.880 --> 00:26:40.770
But you'll see most people do
use Samba because they want that

534
00:26:40.770 --> 00:26:41.860
Windows compatibility.

535
00:26:41.860 --> 00:26:45.260
>> Yeah, and that is typically like
when people are making that jump or

536
00:26:45.260 --> 00:26:48.200
trying to bring Linux
into their environment.

537
00:26:48.200 --> 00:26:50.970
A lot, most people run a lot
of Windows machines, right.

538
00:26:50.970 --> 00:26:52.340
They hold a very large market share.

539
00:26:52.340 --> 00:26:54.270
One of their first questions is,

540
00:26:54.270 --> 00:26:57.180
how do I get these things to
share files between each other?

541
00:26:57.180 --> 00:26:59.850
And this is a very simple
way to get that done.

542
00:26:59.850 --> 00:27:01.260
You can set these up.

543
00:27:01.260 --> 00:27:05.030
Get NFS working,
sharing out files to all your clients And

544
00:27:05.030 --> 00:27:08.660
you didn't have to go through a ton of,
it was pretty painless to walk through.

545
00:27:08.660 --> 00:27:10.240
You just need to know a few options.

546
00:27:10.240 --> 00:27:13.155
And Don obviously knew every one
of those that were necessary.

547
00:27:13.155 --> 00:27:14.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> To get in a very simple,

548
00:27:14.600 --> 00:27:17.560
very easy file share
going on your systems.

549
00:27:17.560 --> 00:27:19.110
And that being said, Don,

550
00:27:19.110 --> 00:27:22.140
is there anything else we need
to cover when it comes to NFS?

551
00:27:22.140 --> 00:27:23.080
>> I think that's about it.

552
00:27:23.080 --> 00:27:25.880
Just remember, it is installed
by default on most systems.

553
00:27:25.880 --> 00:27:28.140
So the yum steps I did
are probably optional for you.

554
00:27:28.140 --> 00:27:29.940
But it doesn't hurt to do them again
just to make sure they're there.

555
00:27:29.940 --> 00:27:32.530
And then after that you just turn it
on and go, it's pretty straightforward.

556
00:27:32.530 --> 00:27:35.330
>> All right, well thank you so
much for explaining this to us.

557
00:27:35.330 --> 00:27:39.240
We thank you guys for watching but it is
that time yet again for us to sign off for

558
00:27:39.240 --> 00:27:41.900
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

559
00:27:41.900 --> 00:27:42.600
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

560
00:27:42.600 --> 00:27:43.801
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:27:43.801 --> 00:27:50.697
[MUSIC]

562
00:27:50.697 --> 00:27:56.780
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate setting up Samba for sharing files with Microsoft Windows clients. They start by talking about some of the history of SMB and Samba, then start the Samba Server installation and setup. They also walk you through working with the `smb.conf` and `smb.conf.example` files.
episodes.title: Samba and SMB

1

00:00:08.235 --> 00:00:12.113
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

8
00:00:24.177 --> 00:00:25.237
>> [LAUGH]
>> Server seven.

9
00:00:25.237 --> 00:00:26.670
Version 7 series.

10
00:00:26.670 --> 00:00:30.480

12

>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

13
00:00:32.820 --> 00:00:36.930
Ready back to dive right back in and if
you're watching the shows then already you

14
00:00:36.930 --> 00:00:40.746
know that we just covered NFS a few
minutes ago in digital TV time, I guess.

15
00:00:40.746 --> 00:00:43.941
And in this episode we're gonna be
switching gears and talk about SMB,

16
00:00:43.941 --> 00:00:47.681
Server Message Block and Samba, which is
an alternative to NFS if we need to share.

17
00:00:47.681 --> 00:00:50.123
>> I thought it was a Brazilian dance.

18
00:00:50.123 --> 00:00:51.590

19
00:00:51.590 --> 00:00:53.453

00:00:53.453 --> 00:00:54.307
I don't know.

21
00:00:54.307 --> 00:00:55.363
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyhow, so

22
00:00:55.363 --> 00:00:57.020
that's what we're gonna cover today.

23
00:00:57.020 --> 00:01:01.270
And it is an alternative to NFS and
you might be thinking,

24
00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:05.200
cuz I know I think this, if we have
NFS and it's an open standard, and

25
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:06.740
it's stable, and it works really well.

26
00:01:06.740 --> 00:01:09.190
Why have an alternative?

27
00:01:09.190 --> 00:01:10.300
I guess alternatives are good.

28
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:15.610
But, the main reason that we have Samba
is for compatibility with Windows systems

29
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:21.330
that in the business world,
Linux servers are really really common.

30
00:01:21.330 --> 00:01:24.220
But Linux workstations, not so much.

31
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:27.470
And so what we typically see in the
business word are Microsoft Windows work

32
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:29.220
stations, very, very common.

33
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:32.214
And now we're starting to see Mac OS
systems starting to increase.

34
00:01:32.214 --> 00:01:36.521
And so the numbers I saw last time were
something like 80% Windows, and 5 or

35
00:01:36.521 --> 00:01:39.915
6% Mac, and then after that
things were assorted across all

36
00:01:39.915 --> 00:01:42.510
sort of other weird operating systems.

37
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:46.210
So we had this huge representation of
Windows platforms that are out there.

38
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:50.640
If you have a Linux server, and you want
to be able to share files with those

39
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:54.350
Windows workstations, well,
Windows doesn't have NFS by default.

40
00:01:54.350 --> 00:01:55.860
You can bolt it on if you want.

41
00:01:55.860 --> 00:01:59.010
You can go out and get things like save
win, and it'll have NFS packaged in it,

42
00:01:59.010 --> 00:02:00.420
you can reach out and do it.

43
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:03.390
Microsoft even has a sub-system for
Unix that you can throw on there.

44
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:05.810
Windows 10 has that new
Ubuntu stuff built into it.

45
00:02:05.810 --> 00:02:07.470
So I mean, there's things you can do.

46
00:02:07.470 --> 00:02:10.670
But, if we can just natively support

47
00:02:10.670 --> 00:02:13.970
the same network file system that
Windows does, then we get compatibility,

48
00:02:13.970 --> 00:02:16.160
we don't have to do anything
crazy on the work stations.

49
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:19.770
So, that's what Samba works to do.

50
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:23.550
In the Microsoft Windows world, when they
share folders and they communicate off

51
00:02:23.550 --> 00:02:26.520
the, across the network, there's several
different protocols that are involved.

52
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:28.340
There's a protocol called net bios.

53
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:32.250
And net bios was actually developed by
Intel and it was part of the land manager

54
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:36.770
suite and Microsoft acquired Intel so
it became a Microsoft technology.

55
00:02:36.770 --> 00:02:40.890
And net bios lets two Windows machines
find each other on the network.

56
00:02:40.890 --> 00:02:44.240
And then once they find each other
they can start to exchange files and

57
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:48.270
when they exchange files they use another
protocol again it came from Intel

58
00:02:48.270 --> 00:02:51.170
called server message blocker, SMB.

59
00:02:51.170 --> 00:02:55.410
And SMB is the protocol that Microsoft
Systems using when they share folders.

60
00:02:55.410 --> 00:02:57.990
Now, that's what it's officially called.

61
00:02:57.990 --> 00:03:01.190
Sometimes you'll hear it called CIFS,
C-I-F-S,

62
00:03:01.190 --> 00:03:04.380
which is the Common Internet File System.

63
00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:05.500
And when you hear a name like that,

64
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:08.850
Common Internet File System, that sounds
like an open standard, doesn't it?

65
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:13.660
Well, Microsoft did actually get it
standardized, but funny thing here.

66
00:03:13.660 --> 00:03:16.420
Did you know that you can have
a patent on a standardized technology?

67
00:03:16.420 --> 00:03:17.190
>> That's interesting.

68
00:03:17.190 --> 00:03:19.485
>> Microsoft knows.

69
00:03:19.485 --> 00:03:23.630
[LAUGH] So, CIFS is not exactly
something that just anybody can deploy.

70
00:03:23.630 --> 00:03:26.600
It is SMB, and so
those names are basically interchangeable,

71
00:03:26.600 --> 00:03:27.950
as far as we're concerned.

72
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.690
So, what happened was years ago.

73
00:03:29.690 --> 00:03:32.570
I mean this was 12, 15 years ago maybe.

74
00:03:32.570 --> 00:03:34.360
A group of people had a great idea.

75
00:03:34.360 --> 00:03:37.040
Which is, hey, we're not gonna
license this for Microsoft.

76
00:03:37.040 --> 00:03:38.980
Not for
a free operating system like Linux.

77
00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:41.250
So instead,
we're going to reverse engineer it.

78
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:43.620
And that's what they did,
they started reverse engineering it.

79
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:48.050
And tweaking it and pulling functionality,
that was available in SMB.

80
00:03:48.050 --> 00:03:51.720
And bringing it into an open standard,
or an open source product.

81
00:03:51.720 --> 00:03:55.630
Which they called Samba, and
Samba is just a play on SMB.

82
00:03:55.630 --> 00:03:57.440
And so Samba is the open source version.

83
00:03:57.440 --> 00:04:02.320
Now, the reason I go to this history, the
reason it's important is you need to know

84
00:04:02.320 --> 00:04:06.670
that Samba is not 100%
compatible with SMB.

85
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:10.610
There are features in SMB that
are not supported in Samba.

86
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:12.692
So, as we go through this
configuration on Red Hat.

87
00:04:12.692 --> 00:04:15.760
I'm gonna point out a few different
places that we need to be aware

88
00:04:15.760 --> 00:04:17.260
that certain things don't work.

89
00:04:17.260 --> 00:04:20.770
Technically the official version of SMB
that is implemented in the new version

90
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:22.729
of windows is SMB version 4.

91
00:04:22.729 --> 00:04:25.420
And it's got things like
session encryption,

92
00:04:25.420 --> 00:04:27.648
that samba doesn't support, right?

93
00:04:27.648 --> 00:04:29.511
If I just want to share
files on the network and

94
00:04:29.511 --> 00:04:32.310
use basic network connectivity,
Samba works great.

95
00:04:32.310 --> 00:04:35.250
But, if I wanna start getting into more
advanced things, I'll tell you what'll

96
00:04:35.250 --> 00:04:38.060
happen, you're gonna start moving back
over to NFS is what you're gonna do,

97
00:04:38.060 --> 00:04:40.370
cuz then you get all
the advanced bells and whistles.

98
00:04:40.370 --> 00:04:42.250
But, Samba does have its place.

99
00:04:42.250 --> 00:04:43.990
And so we certainly need to
know how to implement it.

100
00:04:43.990 --> 00:04:46.620
And implementing it on Red Hat,
is actually not that hard,

101
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:50.820
because with most of our installs,
Samba is already there.

102
00:04:50.820 --> 00:04:52.510
In fact, I believe,

103
00:04:52.510 --> 00:04:56.900
if you do anything except the minimal
install, Samba is already installed.

104
00:04:56.900 --> 00:04:57.720
And on the minimal install,

105
00:04:57.720 --> 00:05:00.540
I believe Samba is already
there it's just not turned on.

106
00:05:00.540 --> 00:05:03.300
It's really not a whole lot
of effort to get it in there.

107
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:05.480
It's just getting it configured and
getting it turned on.

108
00:05:05.480 --> 00:05:07.890
So I wanna start with configuring a sever.

109
00:05:07.890 --> 00:05:10.180
A server that will share
folders on the network, so

110
00:05:10.180 --> 00:05:11.730
Windows machines can access us.

111
00:05:11.730 --> 00:05:14.230
And then at the end of the episode
I'll talk about being a client,

112
00:05:14.230 --> 00:05:17.160
that you can actually have your
Red Hat machine, if you're

113
00:05:17.160 --> 00:05:21.620
running on a work station you can browse
the network and connect to Samba share.

114
00:05:21.620 --> 00:05:25.950
SMB shares that are on Microsoft severs so
you get that kind of cross compatibility

115
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:29.210
and we should lump Mac OS into this
because Apple did the same thing.

116
00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:32.330
Apple basically worked SMB in and

117
00:05:32.330 --> 00:05:35.450
Apple went a different route because
they licensed SNB from Microsoft.

118
00:05:35.450 --> 00:05:38.845
They actually pay for it, so
they have a better compatibility but

119
00:05:38.845 --> 00:05:41.203
they're still at only SNB version 3 not 4.

120
00:05:41.203 --> 00:05:43.010
So like they can't do encryption either.

121
00:05:43.010 --> 00:05:45.670
But in Linux we have
the free version with some.

122
00:05:45.670 --> 00:05:48.890
>> That must have been a tough check
to write and send over to Microsoft.

123
00:05:48.890 --> 00:05:51.515
I know they're not
the greatest of friends.

124
00:05:51.515 --> 00:05:52.330
[LAUGH]
>> That's true.

125
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:54.480
Microsoft is a different
company that they used to

126
00:05:54.480 --> 00:05:55.390
be but-
>> True

127
00:05:55.390 --> 00:05:57.330
>> The other thing to remember is,

128
00:05:57.330 --> 00:06:01.300
if you want to get a foothold
in the business desktop world,

129
00:06:01.300 --> 00:06:02.460
you need this kind of connectivity.

130
00:06:02.460 --> 00:06:04.620
It doesn't matter if you like or
hate Microsoft.

131
00:06:04.620 --> 00:06:06.560
You need to be compatible
to make this work.

132
00:06:06.560 --> 00:06:07.412
That's what they're doing.

133
00:06:07.412 --> 00:06:12.104
And eventually the goal is hopefully they
can make people realize they don't need

134
00:06:12.104 --> 00:06:13.370
Windows any more.

135
00:06:13.370 --> 00:06:16.350
That they can use Linux and
this is the foothold to do it.

136
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:19.540
All right, so let's see how we can
get that foothold put in place.

137
00:06:19.540 --> 00:06:22.330
I'm gonna start right here on
my trusty Red Hat box that we've

138
00:06:22.330 --> 00:06:23.755
been using throughout this series.

139
00:06:23.755 --> 00:06:26.040
And I'm gonna drop into a terminal.

140
00:06:26.040 --> 00:06:29.590
I'm gonna so all of this from the
terminal, because that way you see a way

141
00:06:29.590 --> 00:06:34.500
that works in both the GUI and
in headless system, cuz on a server

142
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:37.380
we're not normally gonna have the GUI so
I'll do it all through the terminal.

143
00:06:37.380 --> 00:06:39.850
It doesn't truly matter
because at the end of the day,

144
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:42.290
there are some GUI utilities out there for

145
00:06:42.290 --> 00:06:47.030
configuring Samba, but they're not
a part of the official Samba release.

146
00:06:47.030 --> 00:06:49.400
They're third parties that
wrote GUIs to bring them in.

147
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:54.210
So, I don't like to use those because
sometimes new features come in to Samba

148
00:06:54.210 --> 00:06:57.080
and you've got to wait for
the GUIs to update and then inevitably,

149
00:06:57.080 --> 00:07:00.270
whoever was maintaining the Samba GUI,
stops maintaining it and

150
00:07:00.270 --> 00:07:00.960
now you've got to switch.

151
00:07:00.960 --> 00:07:05.260
So I always recommend just use the command
line for configuring Samba, it's not that

152
00:07:05.260 --> 00:07:08.930
hard to get configured although
you will see it is a lot of steps.

153
00:07:08.930 --> 00:07:10.970
I'm gonna through a lot of
steps here in the episode.

154
00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:15.422
And don't worry about feverishly writing
these down, we'll put the show notes,

155
00:07:15.422 --> 00:07:19.046
these little guys right here along
with the episode on the website so

156
00:07:19.046 --> 00:07:21.669
that you're able to get those and
see the steps.

157
00:07:21.669 --> 00:07:24.326
Cuz it is a lot, it's easy to miss things.

158
00:07:24.326 --> 00:07:26.676
All right, the first thing I
wanna do is I wanna check and

159
00:07:26.676 --> 00:07:28.490
see if Samba's installed on the machine.

160
00:07:28.490 --> 00:07:32.900
And it likely is but
it doesn't hurt to run a quick check.

161
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:35.670
Now I'm going to be doing
a ton of commands here.

162
00:07:35.670 --> 00:07:39.410
And all of these commands need
to be run as an administrator,

163
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:43.320
need to be run as root basically.

164
00:07:43.320 --> 00:07:47.266
And so I would really need to do
a sudu for every single command.

165
00:07:47.266 --> 00:07:51.357
If you're one of those people that
don't like to do sudu over and over and

166
00:07:51.357 --> 00:07:55.045
over again, then what you can do is,
well there is a few options,

167
00:07:55.045 --> 00:07:57.554
you can use "su" and become the root user.

168
00:07:57.554 --> 00:08:02.380
And then that way, every command you
issue is now going to be issued as root.

169
00:08:02.380 --> 00:08:04.630
See how my user name just changed to root?

170
00:08:04.630 --> 00:08:09.040
The negative with this is if you forget,
you now have an open shell as root, and

171
00:08:09.040 --> 00:08:10.220
it's just sitting there.

172
00:08:10.220 --> 00:08:13.280
And if somebody came along and
sat down after you got up,

173
00:08:13.280 --> 00:08:14.860
now they'd have root
access to the machine.

174
00:08:14.860 --> 00:08:17.159
So that's not really
the recommended way to do it.

175
00:08:18.230 --> 00:08:19.870
Running individual sudo commands is.

176
00:08:19.870 --> 00:08:24.710
I mean you could also cheat and do like
a sudo sh to launch a shell as root.

177
00:08:24.710 --> 00:08:25.540
But the same thing.

178
00:08:25.540 --> 00:08:26.867
Same thing as doing su.

179
00:08:26.867 --> 00:08:30.299
So I'm gonna go ahead and type sudo every
time just cuz I'm in the habit of doing

180
00:08:30.299 --> 00:08:33.112
that, which is funny that I say
that cuz I forget to type it a lot.

181
00:08:33.112 --> 00:08:34.085
>> You forget all the time.

182
00:08:34.085 --> 00:08:35.329
[LAUGH]
>> But
