643
00:29:41.660 --> 00:29:44.160
let me get rid of those empty
lines I chucked at the end.

644
00:29:45.300 --> 00:29:46.256
Not-
>> [CROSSTALK] Not that it

645
00:29:46.256 --> 00:29:46.973
bothers anything.

646
00:29:46.973 --> 00:29:48.575
>> Yeah, it's my pet peeve.

647
00:29:48.575 --> 00:29:51.596
It used to be a big deal,
like in really old versions of Red Hat,

648
00:29:51.596 --> 00:29:54.961
it used to get super angry when you
had a bunch of empty lines at the end.

649
00:29:54.961 --> 00:29:56.818
But not anymore.

650
00:29:56.818 --> 00:29:59.860
All right, old habits are hard to-
>> [CROSSTALK] Yes, they are.

651
00:29:59.860 --> 00:30:03.928
>> All right, so now I've got my
Samba configuration in place and

652
00:30:03.928 --> 00:30:05.730
I should be good to go.

653
00:30:05.730 --> 00:30:10.100
What's left is I do need to start Samba,
I have some security concerns too.

654
00:30:10.100 --> 00:30:12.990
I need to open connections
on the firewall and

655
00:30:12.990 --> 00:30:16.540
there's that pesky SE Linux thing
that runs in the background.

656
00:30:16.540 --> 00:30:21.310
SE Linux that restricts services to
certain folders, Samba has no idea, and

657
00:30:21.310 --> 00:30:24.330
SE Linux has no idea about this
/shares folder that I made, so

658
00:30:24.330 --> 00:30:25.680
I've got to open that up too.

659
00:30:25.680 --> 00:30:27.880
But I've kind of run out of time on this.

660
00:30:27.880 --> 00:30:31.536
I hate to break up to a second one on it,
but I have enough configuration left that

661
00:30:31.536 --> 00:30:34.777
we're gonna have to break this one up
into a part two and go from there.

662
00:30:34.777 --> 00:30:37.927
So technically,
just to kind of place ourselves,

663
00:30:37.927 --> 00:30:40.649
technically I'm done configuring Samba.

664
00:30:40.649 --> 00:30:42.995
I haven't started it yet,
that's a problem.

665
00:30:42.995 --> 00:30:44.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean, I haven't marked it to start

666
00:30:44.880 --> 00:30:46.890
when I boot up, so I have to do that.

667
00:30:46.890 --> 00:30:48.220
But the configuration's done.

668
00:30:48.220 --> 00:30:51.130
Our folders are set up,
our users, our groups are set up.

669
00:30:51.130 --> 00:30:54.670
The Samba configuration is done, so
we've seen everything we need for Samba.

670
00:30:54.670 --> 00:30:57.750
Everything else is really Red Hat stuff.

671
00:30:57.750 --> 00:31:00.606
Going in and opening the Red Hat firewall,
configuring SE Linux and

672
00:31:00.606 --> 00:31:01.718
turning on permissions.

673
00:31:01.718 --> 00:31:06.375
Everything I've done up to this point
would really be the same on Ubuntu or

674
00:31:06.375 --> 00:31:08.411
DBN or one of the other distros.

675
00:31:08.411 --> 00:31:11.495
We'll get into the Red Hat specifics in
this next episodes that we can get in and

676
00:31:11.495 --> 00:31:12.115
pair that off.

677
00:31:12.115 --> 00:31:14.871
But just know if you're watching this and
following it step by step,

678
00:31:14.871 --> 00:31:18.055
make sure you watch part two [LAUGH] or
you're gonna lose some important stuff and

679
00:31:18.055 --> 00:31:18.980
it's not gonna work.

680
00:31:18.980 --> 00:31:19.850
>> All right, Don, well,

681
00:31:19.850 --> 00:31:22.740
we look forward to seeing those
administrative tasks that we're gonna need

682
00:31:22.740 --> 00:31:28.450
to complete before we actually have
a full-fledged working Samba installation.

683
00:31:28.450 --> 00:31:31.420
And that being said,
our time has expired for this episode.

684
00:31:31.420 --> 00:31:32.850
We thank you for this one, though.

685
00:31:32.850 --> 00:31:34.050
We'll see you in the next one.

686
00:31:34.050 --> 00:31:36.630
We thank you guys for watching,
but we are signing off.

687
00:31:36.630 --> 00:31:39.120
For IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

688
00:31:39.120 --> 00:31:39.638
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

689
00:31:39.638 --> 00:31:41.116
>> We'll see you next time.

690
00:31:41.116 --> 00:31:48.059
[MUSIC]

691
00:31:48.059 --> 00:31:50.915
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue to explain and demonstrate setting up Samba for sharing files with Microsoft Windows clients. They pick back up by performing some Red Hat focused administrative tasks that will complete the Samba connectivity setup. This includes settings up SE-Linux, configuring the firewall, and starting the Samba service.
episodes.title: Samba and SMB Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:06.085
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.085 --> 00:00:08.814
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.814 --> 00:00:12.530
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:14.014
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

5
00:00:14.014 --> 00:00:16.304
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.304 --> 00:00:18.048
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:18.048 --> 00:00:20.918
In today's episode we're
continuing on with more on our

8
00:00:20.918 --> 00:00:23.200
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7 series.

9
00:00:23.200 --> 00:00:27.840
And joining back in the studio,
our good friend for more Samba, Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.840 --> 00:00:28.415
Don, welcome back, sir.

11
00:00:28.415 --> 00:00:29.055
How's it going today?

12
00:00:29.055 --> 00:00:30.520
>> Hey, I am doing great.

13
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:32.388
It's Don the Rambling Man Pezet.

14
00:00:32.388 --> 00:00:34.831
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

15
00:00:34.831 --> 00:00:36.700
we spent most of Pt 1
getting Samba configured.

16
00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:39.232
And technically, in my defense-
>> It is configured, [CROSSTALK]

17
00:00:39.232 --> 00:00:40.520
>> It is configured.

18
00:00:40.520 --> 00:00:42.485
We got Samba completely
configured in Pt 1.

19
00:00:42.485 --> 00:00:47.145
But before we can turn it on,
cuz the temptation is there.

20
00:00:47.145 --> 00:00:49.880
Like, all right, I'm ready,
I'm gonna start those services, I'm done.

21
00:00:49.880 --> 00:00:51.610
We have a couple of little
Red Hat maintenance

22
00:00:51.610 --> 00:00:54.510
things that we need to go through, right,
before we're ready to actually turn it on.

23
00:00:54.510 --> 00:00:58.260
Otherwise, if we go and test it right now,
we're not gonna have much luck, right?

24
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:00.790
So what are some of the things
that we need to take care of?

25
00:01:00.790 --> 00:01:04.430
Well first off,
Red Hat has a handy, dandy,

26
00:01:04.430 --> 00:01:07.650
little firewall built right
into RHDL by default.

27
00:01:07.650 --> 00:01:10.243
And I guess maybe you've turned it off.

28
00:01:10.243 --> 00:01:13.430
But assuming you got it turned on,
which hopefully you do, we're just

29
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:16.800
need to make sure that we allow Samba
clients to connect through our firewall.

30
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:18.670
Otherwise, we're just
not gonna get very far.

31
00:01:18.670 --> 00:01:20.030
So I need to throw that in.

32
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:22.310
Also we've got SELinux.

33
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:25.070
Now SELinux, we haven't filmed
our security episodes, yet.

34
00:01:25.070 --> 00:01:28.770
But SELinux is a special
security sublayer inside of

35
00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:33.130
Red Hat Enterprise Linux that
helps secure the system.

36
00:01:33.130 --> 00:01:37.730
Most of you are familiar with chroot,
and how we can take an application.

37
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:41.060
And instead of it seeing slash
as the root of your drive,

38
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:43.080
in other words being able to
browse the whole file system.

39
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:45.430
We can change it so
that when it looks at slash,

40
00:01:45.430 --> 00:01:47.160
it just sees a particular subfolder.

41
00:01:47.160 --> 00:01:50.590
It creates a jail for
that application, and holds it to it.

42
00:01:50.590 --> 00:01:53.750
And stops one application from being
able to affect files from other apps.

43
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:56.790
Well, SELinux does the same thing,

44
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:00.340
except it doesn't change what
people see on the file system.

45
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:02.350
It just changes what access they have.

46
00:02:02.350 --> 00:02:03.690
So they'll see the whole file system.

47
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:06.016
But if they try and read from a folder
they're not allowed to, it gets blocked.

48
00:02:06.016 --> 00:02:09.110
If they try and write to a folder
they're not allowed to, it gets blocked.

49
00:02:09.110 --> 00:02:11.980
And it really, really,
really locks it down.

50
00:02:11.980 --> 00:02:15.888
Well, when we configured Samba,
we pointed it to a folder,

51
00:02:15.888 --> 00:02:19.950
/shares/public and /shares/private.

52
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:21.270
And by default,

53
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:24.760
the Samba service does not have permission
to even read from those folders.

54
00:02:24.760 --> 00:02:26.722
So again,
if we had started it up right now,

55
00:02:26.722 --> 00:02:30.420
DELinux would've blocked the Samba
service from even seeing its folders.

56
00:02:30.420 --> 00:02:32.600
Better yet, the firewall
blocking our clients from even

57
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:33.680
connecting to the server.

58
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:35.388
Effectively, everything's broke, right?

59
00:02:35.388 --> 00:02:36.710
Network access is broken.

60
00:02:36.710 --> 00:02:37.590
Local access is broken.

61
00:02:37.590 --> 00:02:40.490
Everything's broken, so
we gotta take care of that.

62
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:43.605
And be careful,
if you read any internet guides out there.

63
00:02:43.605 --> 00:02:45.478
Cuz I swear, if I see it one more time,

64
00:02:45.478 --> 00:02:48.362
I keep seeing these instructions
from reputable people.

65
00:02:48.362 --> 00:02:51.890
And it says, okay,
step number five, disable SELinux.

66
00:02:51.890 --> 00:02:53.328
And I'm like, well,
what the heck are you doing?

67
00:02:53.328 --> 00:02:55.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] The reason it's there,

68
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:56.325
disable the firewall.

69
00:02:56.325 --> 00:02:57.318
You can open ports on the firewall.

70
00:02:57.318 --> 00:02:58.290
It's not that hard.

71
00:02:58.290 --> 00:03:00.345
So let's do things the right way, okay?

72
00:03:00.345 --> 00:03:02.963
We're gonna open this up
through SELinux and let it in.

73
00:03:02.963 --> 00:03:06.896
And so let me just get into my handy,
dandy shell here, and

74
00:03:06.896 --> 00:03:08.839
we're gonna do this, now.

75
00:03:08.839 --> 00:03:12.527
Right now, I've got my /shares folder,
right here.

76
00:03:12.527 --> 00:03:16.110
It's in the root of my hard drive,
so /shares.

77
00:03:16.110 --> 00:03:17.490
It's owned by root.

78
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:20.216
It's got some permissions that are set
on it so that the owner has read,

79
00:03:20.216 --> 00:03:20.950
write, execute.

80
00:03:20.950 --> 00:03:23.220
Everybody else has read and
execute to that folder.

81
00:03:23.220 --> 00:03:27.800
And if I look inside of that,
there's my private and public.

82
00:03:27.800 --> 00:03:32.230
We set up the public one to be owned by
nobody, which would effectively be guests.

83
00:03:32.230 --> 00:03:35.642
And the other one by me and
the employees group.

84
00:03:35.642 --> 00:03:37.400
And we've got appropriate
permissions there.

85
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:41.060
But there is read and
write permissions assigned, and

86
00:03:41.060 --> 00:03:42.970
that's where SELinux comes in.

87
00:03:42.970 --> 00:03:45.080
It's gonna block both of those by default.

88
00:03:45.080 --> 00:03:51.310
So what we need to do is we need to change
the security context of those folders.

89
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:56.640
The default for a folder with no context
is to be significantly restricted.

90
00:03:56.640 --> 00:03:59.410
Really, there's not much of anything
that's allowed to access this

91
00:03:59.410 --> 00:04:00.630
folder, right now.

92
00:04:00.630 --> 00:04:03.440
I need to change the context
to let SELinux know that this

93
00:04:03.440 --> 00:04:04.572
is being used for Samba.

94
00:04:04.572 --> 00:04:10.690
And so to do that, we have the chcon
utility, the change context utility.

95
00:04:10.690 --> 00:04:14.590
And I need to tell it what type
of context it's going to be.

96
00:04:14.590 --> 00:04:19.470
And in this case,
it's going to be samba_share_t, right?

97
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:20.880
Now I'm not making that up.

98
00:04:20.880 --> 00:04:21.960
It's not just a name I thought of.

99
00:04:21.960 --> 00:04:26.930
This is an actual context that's included
with the default SELinux configuration.

100
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:29.690
And basically what that
context does is it says,

101
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:32.550
allow the Samba service to
interact with these folders.

102
00:04:32.550 --> 00:04:36.080
So we're just adding it to the list
of stuff that Samba's allowed to see.

103
00:04:36.080 --> 00:04:39.220
Other services, like Apache,
won't be able to see these folders.

104
00:04:39.220 --> 00:04:41.400
Because Apache's not a part
of the sound by context.

105
00:04:41.400 --> 00:04:44.210
So this is kind of
restricting that access down.

106
00:04:44.210 --> 00:04:48.169
And I need to do that for
these /shares/public folder,

107
00:04:48.169 --> 00:04:50.898
as well as the private folder, right?

108
00:04:50.898 --> 00:04:55.230
And really, any folder that I make
that is going to be a part of Samba,

109
00:04:55.230 --> 00:04:59.866
then I need to change that security
context to make sure that SELinux knows

110
00:04:59.866 --> 00:05:01.760
what it is, all right?

111
00:05:01.760 --> 00:05:03.650
So I've got that in place.

112
00:05:03.650 --> 00:05:07.760
Now SELinux should be allowing it through,
and we should be in business there.

113
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:08.520
>> Well done.

114
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:12.331
Now I totally understand why people
tell you, just shut off SELinux.

115
00:05:12.331 --> 00:05:13.609
Cuz that was really difficult.

116
00:05:13.609 --> 00:05:14.120
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

117
00:05:14.120 --> 00:05:17.491
you know the hard part is
figuring out the context name.

118
00:05:17.491 --> 00:05:19.380
So I know I want Samba
to access this folder.

119
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:20.180
What's it called?

120
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:25.485
I wouldn't have thought of samba_share_t
It just doesn't roll right off the tongue,

121
00:05:25.485 --> 00:05:26.340
right?

122
00:05:26.340 --> 00:05:27.950
So you have to go and look it up.

123
00:05:27.950 --> 00:05:32.800
Well, it's kinda easy to put SELinux in
permissive mode and not worry about it.

124
00:05:32.800 --> 00:05:35.280
And that's it, so
people just taking an easy route out.

125
00:05:35.280 --> 00:05:38.890
And the other thing is people look at it
and say, well, what do I need SELinux for

126
00:05:38.890 --> 00:05:42.380
if I've got a firewall blocking hackers
from even getting to my server?

127
00:05:42.380 --> 00:05:45.150
Then I don't need an underlying sublayer.

128
00:05:45.150 --> 00:05:49.555
But if they get past your firewall,
SELinux is your only protection.

129
00:05:49.555 --> 00:05:51.485
You kinda need it, so don't disable it.

130
00:05:51.485 --> 00:05:52.315
Do yourself a favor.

131
00:05:52.315 --> 00:05:53.775
Keep it in place.

132
00:05:53.775 --> 00:05:54.715
Just learn how to use it.

133
00:05:54.715 --> 00:05:55.698
That's all you gotta do.

134
00:05:55.698 --> 00:05:57.695
[LAUGH] I guess you can
say that about anything.

135
00:05:57.695 --> 00:05:58.496
Just learn how to use it.

136
00:05:58.496 --> 00:05:59.717
>> [CROSSTALK] learn how to
fly the space shuttle, Don.

137
00:05:59.717 --> 00:06:00.649
That's all you gotta do.

138
00:06:00.649 --> 00:06:01.660
You're going into space.

139
00:06:01.660 --> 00:06:03.733
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so I've got that.

140
00:06:03.733 --> 00:06:05.293
I haven't messed with the firewall,
though.

141
00:06:05.293 --> 00:06:07.426
So let me go fix that firewall, too.

142
00:06:07.426 --> 00:06:10.600
Same thing, I could disable the firewall,
but I'm gonna do it right.

143
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:14.550
And I'm gonna take the firewall and
I'm going to allow Samba through it.

144
00:06:14.550 --> 00:06:17.853
Now you can do a really specific
firewall rule that says these

145
00:06:17.853 --> 00:06:20.266
are the only IPs that
are allowed to come in.

146
00:06:20.266 --> 00:06:22.600
I'm gonna keep mine a little more generic,
right?

147
00:06:22.600 --> 00:06:25.057
I'm just gonna say, hey,
Samba clients are allowed to connected in.

148
00:06:25.057 --> 00:06:26.749
Cuz I've got that guest folder.

149
00:06:26.749 --> 00:06:29.660
And so I don't wanna go too crazy with
the restrictions on a guest folder.

150
00:06:29.660 --> 00:06:33.940
So I'm gonna create a permanent rule,
not a temporary one, that's important.

151
00:06:33.940 --> 00:06:38.530
And then it's gonna be on my zone=public,
which is the default zone for

152
00:06:38.530 --> 00:06:40.390
remote access to my system.

153
00:06:40.390 --> 00:06:44.590
And I'm gonna add a service.

154
00:06:44.590 --> 00:06:49.457
And it's got a pre-built, and my head's
kinda sitting on top of all this.

155
00:06:49.457 --> 00:06:53.880
But it's got a pre, kinda built-in,
service name there, for Samba.

156
00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:57.413
So that we can see, add-server, and
then I guess I'm word-wrapping, too.

157
00:06:57.413 --> 00:07:00.124
This is kind of a longer command.

158
00:07:00.124 --> 00:07:01.240
There we go.
>> There it is.

159
00:07:01.240 --> 00:07:05.601
>> So firewall-cmd --permanent, so
it'll stay there after a reboot.

160
00:07:05.601 --> 00:07:08.811
--zone=public, so remote access coming in.

161
00:07:08.811 --> 00:07:12.800
--add-server, and,
not server, it's service.

162
00:07:12.800 --> 00:07:15.090
I need to get the syntax right or
this is not gonna work.

163
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:20.010
So I'm adding a service, and that
service that I'm adding is Samba, right?

164
00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:22.290
So that's gonna add that to the firewall.

165
00:07:22.290 --> 00:07:24.690
Interesting thing, though, is that
that doesn't take effect right away.

166
00:07:25.750 --> 00:07:31.970
So I'm just gonna force it to
do that by doing a --reload.

167
00:07:31.970 --> 00:07:32.610
There we go.

168
00:07:32.610 --> 00:07:33.740
That's gonna make it load those rules.

169
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:36.700
So now my SELinux rules are opened up for
Samba,

170
00:07:36.700 --> 00:07:40.918
my firewall is opened up for Samba,
and now I'm open for business.

171
00:07:40.918 --> 00:07:44.690
Well, except for that kind of important
part about starting the Samba-

172
00:07:44.690 --> 00:07:45.580
>> The services.

173
00:07:45.580 --> 00:07:46.409
>> So I need to start them.

174
00:07:46.409 --> 00:07:50.340
There's a few different ways to
go about starting the services.

175
00:07:50.340 --> 00:07:52.942
I need them to start every
time the system boots.

176
00:07:52.942 --> 00:07:55.500
And I need them to start right now.

177
00:07:55.500 --> 00:07:58.066
And fortunately I do have a single
command that I can use to kinda issue all

178
00:07:58.066 --> 00:07:58.706
that out at once.

00:18:35.180 --> 00:18:38.279
And I'm not just saying this because
you are my boss or whatever.

404
00:18:38.279 --> 00:18:40.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> But that one was one of the best.

405
00:18:40.370 --> 00:18:43.290
And it was very straightforward,
nothing seemed too complex.

406
00:18:43.290 --> 00:18:46.530
It was lengthy, right,
took us two episodes to get it done.

407
00:18:46.530 --> 00:18:49.350
Because there were some administrative
tasks that we had to accomplish.

408
00:18:49.350 --> 00:18:53.236
Setting up the conf file, making
sure we get the file name server, or

409
00:18:53.236 --> 00:18:56.860
the NetBIOS thing right, and
smb.conf, that's always fun.

410
00:18:56.860 --> 00:19:00.113
But as far as like, from start to finish,
this was very simple,

411
00:19:00.113 --> 00:19:01.650
very straightforward.

412
00:19:01.650 --> 00:19:05.760
Nothing too complex that our users out
there wouldn't be able to follow through.

413
00:19:05.760 --> 00:19:07.250
Great stuff, and we appreciate that.

414
00:19:07.250 --> 00:19:07.960
>> Yeah, no problem.

415
00:19:07.960 --> 00:19:10.400
>> That being said,
we are done for the day.

416
00:19:10.400 --> 00:19:13.210
We're done with Samba,
moving on to bigger and better things.

417
00:19:13.210 --> 00:19:15.420
So hopefully we'll see you guys
on those upcoming episodes.

418
00:19:15.420 --> 00:19:17.690
As for this one,
it is time for us to sign off.

419
00:19:17.690 --> 00:19:20.140
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

420
00:19:20.140 --> 00:19:20.960
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

421
00:19:20.960 --> 00:19:21.900

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the File System Hierarchy found in Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Here, they take you through and explain the intended purpose of common directories like `/boot`, `/etc`, `/proc`, `/opt`, and `/sbin`.
episodes.title: File System Hierarchy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.021 --> 00:00:06.290
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.290 --> 00:00:08.183
[MUSIC]

00:00:08.183 --> 00:00:12.075
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.075 --> 00:00:13.785
>> All right, greetings everyone and

welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.010 --> 00:00:17.580

7
00:00:17.580 --> 00:00:21.210
In today's episode its more on
our Red Hat enterprise Linux,

8

well version number seven is out.

00:00:22.840 --> 00:00:24.360

11
00:00:27.900 --> 00:00:29.130
friend Mr. Don Pezet.

12
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:29.930
Don, welcome back sir.

13
00:00:29.930 --> 00:00:30.480
How's it going?

14
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:31.153
>> It is going great, Daniel.

15
00:00:31.153 --> 00:00:33.011
You left a big enough pause in there,
we could always edit and

16
00:00:33.011 --> 00:00:34.807
change it to version eight,
version nine and keep going.

17
00:00:34.807 --> 00:00:35.503
>> Every time.

18
00:00:35.503 --> 00:00:36.165
It's my plan.

19
00:00:36.165 --> 00:00:38.851
[LAUGH]
>> Which does work out kind of well

20
00:00:38.851 --> 00:00:42.951
because what we're about to talk about
is the file system hierarchy found in

21
00:00:42.951 --> 00:00:44.552
Red Hat, which remarkably,

22
00:00:44.552 --> 00:00:48.420
has been pretty unchanged since all
the way back in Red Hat version one.

23
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:51.170
So it's a pretty stable thing.

24
00:00:51.170 --> 00:00:54.285
But it is something that we need to be
familiar with, and there have been a few

25
00:00:54.285 --> 00:00:56.733
little changes in Red Hat 7 that
we need to be aware of also.

26
00:00:56.733 --> 00:01:00.582
So that's what we're gonna take a look
at it and what this is all really

27
00:01:00.582 --> 00:01:05.010
centering around, is when you do
a Red Hat Enterprise Linux install.

28
00:01:05.010 --> 00:01:07.670
And you start browsing the hard drive,
there's a directory structure.

29
00:01:07.670 --> 00:01:10.690
There's a number of different folders and

30
00:01:10.690 --> 00:01:15.600
they all have really interesting names
like /usr, /etc, /boot, and so on.

31
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:18.840
And you might ask yourself,
what are all these folders?

32
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:22.740
All different junk in there and why do
they choose to name some of these things,

33
00:01:22.740 --> 00:01:25.360
these different names.

34
00:01:25.360 --> 00:01:28.388
And the reason is, or
the short answer is that Red Hat didn't.

35
00:01:28.388 --> 00:01:30.025
Red Hat didn't name any of this stuff.

36
00:01:30.025 --> 00:01:33.824
That there is an open standard
out there which is called

37
00:01:33.824 --> 00:01:40.030
the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard and it's
actually put together by an organization.

38
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:41.930
Let me bring up their web page here.

39
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:43.980
I've got it in the background here,
here we go.

40
00:01:43.980 --> 00:01:47.710
The Filesystem Hierarchy Standard,
their web page is not much to look at.

41
00:01:47.710 --> 00:01:50.248
I think it's written in HTML 1.1.

42
00:01:50.248 --> 00:01:52.451
I mean, it's yeah, it's kinda old school.

43
00:01:52.451 --> 00:01:58.349
But if you ever wanna see this on your
own, the website is pathname.com/fhs.

44
00:01:58.349 --> 00:02:00.426
That's where they have
the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

45
00:02:00.426 --> 00:02:01.534
>> If it ain't broke, Don, don't fix it.

46
00:02:01.534 --> 00:02:02.196
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

47
00:02:02.196 --> 00:02:05.111
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they haven't fixed it since 2004,

48
00:02:05.111 --> 00:02:06.840
was the last update on this one.

49
00:02:06.840 --> 00:02:09.155
It looked outdated in 2004 too,
by the way.

50
00:02:09.155 --> 00:02:11.240
>> [LAUGH] Yes it did.

51
00:02:11.240 --> 00:02:14.080
>> When I got started with Linux,
and I think you and

52
00:02:14.080 --> 00:02:16.940
I talked about this but
how it was before a show or

53
00:02:16.940 --> 00:02:20.390
something about, what's your first
version of Linux that you worked with?

54
00:02:20.390 --> 00:02:23.160
And mine was a very early
version of Slackware.

55
00:02:23.160 --> 00:02:25.011
And I think you had said [CROSSTALK]?

56
00:02:25.011 --> 00:02:25.853
>> Red Hat.

57
00:02:25.853 --> 00:02:27.350
>> It was Red Hat.

58
00:02:27.350 --> 00:02:31.330
Well, one of my big complaints
about Linux in the very beginning

59
00:02:31.330 --> 00:02:35.500
was how things were so
inconsistent between the distros.

60
00:02:35.500 --> 00:02:38.950
That you could do something on Slackware,
and turn around and

61
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:40.910
go to Red Hat and it wouldn't work.

62
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:43.680
Or I'd have software that
worked perfectly under Debian,

63
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:46.225
and then I would jump over to Gentoo,
and good luck.

64
00:02:46.225 --> 00:02:48.150
>> [LAUGH]
>> You had so

65
00:02:48.150 --> 00:02:53.210
many different things that were not right
when you went from distro to distro.

66
00:02:53.210 --> 00:02:57.380
And so, if you went to a website to
download software like Wire Shark or

67
00:02:57.380 --> 00:02:58.570
Libre Office or whatever,

68
00:02:58.570 --> 00:03:02.560
they would have to have install packages
for all these different operating systems.

69
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:05.720
And they'd usually just pick
the most popular distros.

70
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:08.920
And if you weren't popular, tough luck,
you didn't get the software.

71
00:03:08.920 --> 00:03:12.540
And so that really kinda hurt
Linux in the early days.

72
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:16.295
Well, the manufacturers, the vendors, the
developers, they all recognize that too.

73
00:03:16.295 --> 00:03:18.570
Which was just becoming
too much of a pain.

74
00:03:18.570 --> 00:03:22.520
And so most of the Linux distros
that were out there adopted what's

75
00:03:22.520 --> 00:03:24.760
called the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

76
00:03:24.760 --> 00:03:25.850
So the folder names and

77
00:03:25.850 --> 00:03:30.860
the folder locations are actually
consistent across the different distros.

78
00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:36.668
And that way, if I write a program and
my installation script says we're gonna

79
00:03:36.668 --> 00:03:42.860
install into slash op slash Don Co,
or whatever, whatever that folder is.

80
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:48.440
I can expect that slash op folder to
exist on several different distros.

81
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:51.420
So now I can write one set
of installation scripts.

82
00:03:51.420 --> 00:03:56.730
Now, I might have to package it
as an RPM for Red Hat, CentOS,

83
00:03:56.730 --> 00:04:01.760
and Fedora, and
package it as a Debian package.

84
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:05.580
It was a DPM or whatever that
we use under Debian and Ubuntu.

85
00:04:05.580 --> 00:04:07.990
I might have to repackage
it different ways.

86
00:04:07.990 --> 00:04:12.590
But the file contents on the inside and
the scripts that I use,

87
00:04:12.590 --> 00:04:13.370
those are identical.

88
00:04:13.370 --> 00:04:17.816
So now it's just really running a package
converter which is not really different

89
00:04:17.816 --> 00:04:22.199
than saying, I'm gonna zip it up here and
I'm gonna be zip it over here, or RAR or

90
00:04:22.199 --> 00:04:25.309
ARJ, or whatever, ARJ,
that's getting a little old.

91
00:04:25.309 --> 00:04:28.176
>> [LAUGH]
>> But whatever archive it is I wanna use.

92
00:04:28.176 --> 00:04:29.610
It's really not any different than that.

93
00:04:29.610 --> 00:04:33.300
So developing software that becomes
portable, easy to move between distros,

94
00:04:33.300 --> 00:04:38.020
becomes a heck of a lot easier when
people follow a consistent standard and

95
00:04:38.020 --> 00:04:39.640
FHS is that standard.

96
00:04:39.640 --> 00:04:41.980
So Red Hat follows it,

97
00:04:41.980 --> 00:04:46.030
although they have tweaked it a little bit
cuz God forbid people follow a standard.

98
00:04:46.030 --> 00:04:49.190
In their defense though the standard,
hasn't changed since 2004,

99
00:04:49.190 --> 00:04:50.360
that's 12 years ago.

100
00:04:50.360 --> 00:04:54.640
The filming of this episode and
that's a long time.

101
00:04:54.640 --> 00:04:56.050
Things have changed since then.

102
00:04:56.050 --> 00:04:59.918
Things have evolved so, if you ever
get bored though go to the website,

103
00:04:59.918 --> 00:05:04.910
pathname.com/fhs, and they've got
the document in ten different formats.

104
00:05:04.910 --> 00:05:06.380
But I'll just pull up the web one here.

105
00:05:06.380 --> 00:05:08.490
This is the file system
hierarchy standard.

106
00:05:08.490 --> 00:05:13.030
And they basically lay out all the
different folders that are expected to be

107
00:05:13.030 --> 00:05:14.620
present on a machine.

108
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:19.084
And kind of what their purpose is, so
if you look we'll see defined here /bin,

109
00:05:19.084 --> 00:05:26.280
/boot, /dev, /etc, /home,
there's /opt that I mentioned and so on.

110
00:05:26.280 --> 00:05:28.580
They're all listed right here.

111
00:05:28.580 --> 00:05:30.830
And as long as vendors,

112
00:05:30.830 --> 00:05:35.360
distros follow this pattern, it makes it
a heck of a lot easier for us to operate.

113
00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:36.980
Now, here's where it gets weird.

114
00:05:36.980 --> 00:05:40.340
Is that they'll tell us things like,
hey your slash s bin and

115
00:05:40.340 --> 00:05:42.420
that should be system binaries.

116
00:05:42.420 --> 00:05:46.020
Well, what counts as a system binary?

117
00:05:47.100 --> 00:05:51.130
Red Hat may have one opinion of
what counts as a system binary, and

118
00:05:51.130 --> 00:05:55.620
boon two canonical might have a different
opinion of what counts as a system binary.

119
00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:59.500
And so, we start ending up with
some things being in S bin, and

120
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:04.700
other things being over in bin,
essential user command binaries, right?

121
00:06:04.700 --> 00:06:07.000
Or even the ones that
are hidden inside of usr,

122
00:06:07.000 --> 00:06:12.080
there's a /usr/bin and a /usr/sbin and
so those get moved off.

123
00:06:12.080 --> 00:06:16.707
Well you'll see down here,
the /usr hierarchy and you start to see,

124
00:06:16.707 --> 00:06:20.719
there, /user/bin,
/user/sbin right there, right?

125
00:06:20.719 --> 00:06:24.579
And these are non-essential
standard system binaries, okay?

126
00:06:24.579 --> 00:06:28.015
So there is a little bit of
interpretation that goes into this.

127
00:06:28.015 --> 00:06:31.520
And if you read up on, you can click on,
you can start to tell about it and

128
00:06:31.520 --> 00:06:35.493
kinda what you think, what you go in there
and what did you do but it doesn't get as

129
00:06:35.493 --> 00:06:39.360
detailed to saying here's what we
consider non-essential binaries.

130
00:06:39.360 --> 00:06:43.013
That's still left up to the distros and
that still creates some confusion.

131
00:06:43.013 --> 00:06:47.630
And so Red Hat has actually taken some
steps on their side to even simplify that

132
00:06:47.630 --> 00:06:50.767
to kind of resolve it and
make it a little bit easier.

133
00:06:50.767 --> 00:06:56.460
So let's stop looking at the standard and
start looking at the Red Hat install.

134
00:06:56.460 --> 00:06:58.350
Now I could use the CLI for this but

135
00:06:58.350 --> 00:07:04.160
I'm gonna use the GUI and
just browse into My Computer.

136
00:07:04.160 --> 00:07:07.221
And we're gonna take a look
at that file system hierarchy

137
00:07:07.221 --> 00:07:09.210
as it's laid out right here, okay.

138
00:07:10.360 --> 00:07:14.454
And we start to look at it,
we'll see some folders like /bin,

139
00:07:14.454 --> 00:07:18.590
/boot, these are all ones that we're
kind of used to see in this series,

140
00:07:18.590 --> 00:07:22.590
if you've watched most of our episodes,
we've definitely spent some time in /etc

141
00:07:22.590 --> 00:07:27.310
doing configurations and things in /lib,
where system D is all tucked away.

142
00:07:27.310 --> 00:07:30.132
So those are folders that we've seen and
worked with.

143
00:07:30.132 --> 00:07:35.148
Some of these other ones, we haven't
really worked with at all like /home,

144
00:07:35.148 --> 00:07:40.175
I haven't really talked about in any
of our episodes, or /media or /proc.

145
00:07:40.175 --> 00:07:41.719
I don't think I mentioned /proc at all.

146
00:07:41.719 --> 00:07:43.995
So what the heck are these things?

147
00:07:43.995 --> 00:07:47.292
Let me run through the critical ones and
we'll get a chance to see what they are.

148
00:07:47.292 --> 00:07:50.473
Let me start with boot, right, /boot.

149
00:07:50.473 --> 00:07:54.316
This is where the boot operating systems,
boot files are.

150
00:07:54.316 --> 00:07:59.991
When we talk about the systemd and
nit process The system

151
00:07:59.991 --> 00:08:03.995
process is launched
after the system boots.

152
00:08:03.995 --> 00:08:07.590
In the boot folder is how we
actually boot our system.

153
00:08:07.590 --> 00:08:10.710
Our Linux kernel actually resides
right there inside of boot.

154
00:08:10.710 --> 00:08:14.390
If I browse into it you'll see a bunch of
stuff in here like my grub boot loader.

155
00:08:14.390 --> 00:08:17.860
I'll see the initial RAM
drive that's created.

156
00:08:17.860 --> 00:08:20.010
When the kernel loads it needs
some temporary storage and

157
00:08:20.010 --> 00:08:23.230
it generates a RAM drive to operate
inside, and so we see that.

158
00:08:23.230 --> 00:08:26.010
And as we scroll down
here towards the bottom,

159
00:08:27.060 --> 00:08:30.530
VM linuz with a Z and
then a version number.

160
00:08:30.530 --> 00:08:32.240
This is my kernel.

161
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:38.360
Now when I install this work station it
was running Red Hat enterprise Linux 7.2.

162
00:08:38.360 --> 00:08:42.390
And then after we filmed about ten
episodes the released 7.3 and so

163
00:08:42.390 --> 00:08:43.790
my work station updated.

164
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:46.150
And so I actually have two
kernels sitting here, right?

165
00:08:46.150 --> 00:08:47.600
The one from 7.2 and the new one from 7.3.

166
00:08:47.600 --> 00:08:50.390
And you can see the different
version number there.

167
00:08:50.390 --> 00:08:53.800
This one's sub release 327,
this one's sub release 514.

168
00:08:53.800 --> 00:08:54.710
And so

169
00:08:54.710 --> 00:08:59.400
when this system boots, I get a menu that
let's me pick which one I want to boot to.

170
00:08:59.400 --> 00:09:02.990
It defaults to the newest one, but if I
have a problem I can always scale back.

171
00:09:02.990 --> 00:09:07.600
That's what's being stored right here in
the boot folder, are all those things

172
00:09:07.600 --> 00:09:11.480
that happen when my system boots up and
starts to do what it needs to do.

173
00:09:11.480 --> 00:09:15.920
>> So Don, like our system here it
updated and got the new kernel.

174
00:09:15.920 --> 00:09:18.570
Once we realize we have a stable
system with that kernel it's okay for

175
00:09:18.570 --> 00:09:20.780
us to delete the old one?

176
00:09:20.780 --> 00:09:21.420
>> You can.

177
00:09:21.420 --> 00:09:24.330
It's usually a good idea to keep two.

178
00:09:24.330 --> 00:09:26.400
Which is kind of what we see here.

179
00:09:26.400 --> 00:09:28.030
And that's what it does by default.

180
00:09:28.030 --> 00:09:32.160
Is that as it continues to update, it's
not gonna just keep piling them in there.

181
00:09:32.160 --> 00:09:34.180
It usually just keeps that one and
the one before.

182
00:09:34.180 --> 00:09:35.650
But you can load as many
as you want in there.

183
00:09:35.650 --> 00:09:38.080
There might even be a specific need for
that.

184
00:09:38.080 --> 00:09:41.870
You might have debug kernels, ones that
have all the debugging flags enabled.

185
00:09:41.870 --> 00:09:45.380
And then you might have production
kernels and different things for testing.

186
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:46.420
If you're a developer,

187
00:09:46.420 --> 00:09:49.760
you may find that you need several canals
to achieve what you're trying to achieve,

188
00:09:50.760 --> 00:09:53.100
most of us don't do that and so
you'll just see two in there.

189
00:09:53.100 --> 00:09:55.370
>> So because of the standard then
that we've been talking about,

190
00:09:55.370 --> 00:09:58.320
if we move the canals out of that
folder which we could probably do,

191
00:09:58.320 --> 00:10:03.340
all right, because we have the access,
we would then make the system dis-stable.

192
00:10:03.340 --> 00:10:04.350
Yes, yeah.
Typically and

193
00:10:04.350 --> 00:10:05.820
there's actually multiple reasons.

194
00:10:05.820 --> 00:10:07.590
Not just because we're
breaking the file hierarchy,

195
00:10:07.590 --> 00:10:11.440
because when we boot,
we expect that boot folder to be there.

196
00:10:11.440 --> 00:10:14.640
And the boot folder is normally
actually a separate partition, and

197
00:10:14.640 --> 00:10:17.680
so it's the first thing that get
mounted when we start to go and run.

198
00:10:17.680 --> 00:10:20.500
That /boot is like it can't be encrypted

199
00:10:20.500 --> 00:10:22.027
because if it's encrypted
we can't get to the kernel.

200
00:10:22.027 --> 00:10:23.396
[LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] out of luck, right?

201
00:10:23.396 --> 00:10:27.053
Versus the rest of our storage
that might all be encrypted and so

202
00:10:27.053 --> 00:10:29.675
it needs to be separate and
special, right?

203
00:10:29.675 --> 00:10:32.345
And that's all part of our

>> [LAUGH] So

661
00:33:13.076 --> 00:33:15.134
a couple different items that
are showing up in there.

662
00:33:15.134 --> 00:33:18.208
And there's even subfolders
in here like the opt folder.

663
00:33:18.208 --> 00:33:21.085
But you'll see where it's not
really being used by anything.

664
00:33:21.085 --> 00:33:22.943
But it's just there.
>> There was a linked mail folder,

665
00:33:22.943 --> 00:33:24.323
maybe it was linking back to.

666
00:33:24.323 --> 00:33:24.939
>> There we go.

00:33:24.939 --> 00:33:26.758
All right yep,
it's linking over to the spool.

00:33:26.758 --> 00:33:28.849
So the spool folder's really important,
right?

669
00:33:28.849 --> 00:33:32.127
Your printing service and
your email queues and a lot of that stuff.

670
00:33:32.127 --> 00:33:34.458
They all end up in the spool folder.

671
00:33:34.458 --> 00:33:38.851
And so if I take a look in there,

672
00:33:38.851 --> 00:33:42.220

673
00:33:42.220 --> 00:33:44.600
So that's what we're gonna see there.

674
00:33:44.600 --> 00:33:46.870
I've got Samba that we
installed in another episode.

675
00:33:46.870 --> 00:33:48.438
These guys are all being stuck in here.

676
00:33:48.438 --> 00:33:50.741
Samba can handle shared
printers on the network.

677
00:33:50.741 --> 00:33:53.620
So it needs a place to store
print jobs while it's waiting.

678
00:33:53.620 --> 00:33:54.840
That's the place.

679
00:33:54.840 --> 00:33:58.355
So that's all being put inside of /var,

680
00:33:58.355 --> 00:33:59.847
Especially if you're running Apache.

681
00:33:59.847 --> 00:34:03.930
Cuz if you take a look at /var/www.

683

684
00:34:11.424 --> 00:34:14.065
Since I just have one host, I've got HTML.

685
00:34:14.065 --> 00:34:15.300
And there it is.

686
00:34:15.300 --> 00:34:16.688
Now notice how it's empty.

687

If I browse to it,

688
00:34:19.266 --> 00:34:20.845
But the default web page is read only.

689
00:34:20.845 --> 00:34:23.175
And so

690
00:34:23.175 --> 00:34:26.096
But if I wanna start customizing

691
00:34:26.096 --> 00:34:28.490
I'm gonna put them right here and
that's why it has to go in /var.

692
00:34:28.490 --> 00:34:31.243
So that's why that one is there.

693
00:34:31.243 --> 00:34:35.638
All right, so while not the most
exciting topic in the world.

694
00:34:35.638 --> 00:34:38.417
It is nice to see that all of these
crazy names in the file system

695
00:34:38.417 --> 00:34:39.438
aren't just made up.

696
00:34:39.438 --> 00:34:42.422
It's not just some arbitrary
thing that Red Hat decided to do.

697
00:34:42.422 --> 00:34:45.679
But instead is Red Hat
adhering to a standard.

698
00:34:45.679 --> 00:34:48.700
To make it where Linux
distributions can interoperate.

699
00:34:48.700 --> 00:34:51.398
And that was a pivotal
thing that helped Linux,

700
00:34:51.398 --> 00:34:54.376
in general,
become an accepted operating system.

701
00:34:54.376 --> 00:34:57.901
Because up until then it was

702

703
00:34:59.669 --> 00:35:04.399
And so Linux was kind of a joke

704
00:35:04.399 --> 00:35:05.748
They just wouldn't want to deploy it.

705
00:35:05.748 --> 00:35:07.402
And that's certainly not the case anymore.

706
00:35:07.402 --> 00:35:08.178
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> Right?

707
00:35:08.178 --> 00:35:11.760
And it's things like these, the FHS,
that help us to achieve that.

708
00:35:11.760 --> 00:35:13.161
>> Well, and
you make great points there, right?

709
00:35:13.161 --> 00:35:14.723
The fact that they have standardized this.

710
00:35:14.723 --> 00:35:17.782
To say, well, if we all play nice and
we all do the same thing.

711
00:35:17.782 --> 00:35:20.698
Then we can all share in
the benefits of that.

712
00:35:20.698 --> 00:35:21.927
And that's exactly what they've done.

713
00:35:21.927 --> 00:35:25.178
And I know if you're new to Linux
you look at all of these different,

714
00:35:25.178 --> 00:35:27.014
Don has called them crazy file names.

715
00:35:27.014 --> 00:35:28.098
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they are.

716
00:35:28.098 --> 00:35:30.160
They're very strange at first look.

717
00:35:30.160 --> 00:35:31.785
But the more you work with them.

718
00:35:31.785 --> 00:35:34.018
And now that you have some

719
00:35:34.018 --> 00:35:35.850
The more sense they start to make.

00:35:35.850 --> 00:35:37.045
And trust us.

721
00:35:37.045 --> 00:35:39.955
If you're going to actually use Linux

722

shape or form.

723

You will get familiar with them very,
very quickly.

724
00:35:42.355 --> 00:35:46.240
Because it's something you're

725
00:35:46.240 --> 00:35:49.213

00:35:51.948 --> 00:35:54.025

00:35:54.025 --> 00:35:57.402

00:36:01.920 --> 00:36:02.870

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate and explain how to manage storage and file systems in RHEL7. They start with foundations like MBR and GPT partitions. Then they walk you through partitioning a disk with command line utilities like fdisk, gdisk, and parted, as well as the graphical tool gparted. Finally, you will see how to put a filesystem on your disks and then mounting and unmounting the new volume.
episodes.title: Managing File Systems

hey Red Hat's not really that much

If I need to format a disk, or whatever,

Red Hat Enterprise Linux, and

So there's certain things that you can

Things like converting file systems,

54
00:02:35.730 --> 00:02:38.460
First off, this whole thing is
about managing file systems.

55
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:39.630
What the heck is a file system?

56
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:42.161
Well, when you get a hard drive and
you want to put files on it,

57
00:02:42.161 --> 00:02:43.690
you can't just chuck them on there.

58
00:02:43.690 --> 00:02:46.020
You've got to have the hard drive
prepared to store those files so

59
00:02:46.020 --> 00:02:47.230
you'll be able to find them.

60
00:02:47.230 --> 00:02:48.966
And there are a numerous
different ways we can store them.

61
00:02:48.966 --> 00:02:52.848
And Red Hat Enterprise Linux supports
all the ways that we see in other Linux

62
00:02:52.848 --> 00:02:53.800
distro.

63
00:02:53.800 --> 00:02:59.100
There's the standard EXT file system
that we use in most Linux distros or

64
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:00.810
XFS is what it's called sometimes.

65
00:03:00.810 --> 00:03:06.490
But EXT 2, 3, 4, each of the different
versions, all supported by Red Hat.

66
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:11.628
We also have the non Red Hat or
non Linux type file systems like UFS from

67
00:03:11.628 --> 00:03:17.580
the Unix world, we have FAT, FAT32,
and NTFS all from the Microsoft world.

68
00:03:17.580 --> 00:03:21.785
We actually don't have support for
HFS, at least not natively,

69
00:03:21.785 --> 00:03:26.296
which is the Apple, what is it,
Apple Journal Extended File System,

70
00:03:26.296 --> 00:03:30.203
it's some crazy weird name that-
>> It's really, really.

71
00:03:30.203 --> 00:03:33.212
Yeah, HFS, Extended Journal File System.

72
00:03:33.212 --> 00:03:35.088
[LAUGH]
>> It's just [LAUGH] The names don't

73
00:03:35.088 --> 00:03:38.580
all make sense, necessarily,
but they all serve a purpose.

74
00:03:38.580 --> 00:03:43.370
Now, in the RedHat world, in the Linux
world, you're gonna hear a lot about two

75
00:03:43.370 --> 00:03:48.660
final systems that are kind of considered
cutting edge at that's ReiserFS and BTRFS.

76
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:53.910
ReiserFS was one of the first ones to
come out that introduced journaling.

77
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:54.422
In other words,

78
00:03:54.422 --> 00:03:56.696
when you wrote to the hard drive,
you didn't write directly to the data.

79
00:03:56.696 --> 00:03:58.530
You wrote to a journal first.

80
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:01.150
And only when the journal was 100%
complete was it then written to

81
00:04:01.150 --> 00:04:02.330
the actual data.

82
00:04:02.330 --> 00:04:05.690
And the reason it did that was, if you
were halfway through writing data, and

83
00:04:05.690 --> 00:04:07.050
you lost power.

84
00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:11.780
If you were writing to the actual data,
well that data's not corrupt.

85
00:04:11.780 --> 00:04:14.280
But if you're writing to a journal
instead, when the system reboots,

86
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:15.540
it just throws away the journal.

87
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:16.610
Incomplete write, that's it.

88
00:04:16.610 --> 00:04:18.710
And we still have the original data,
it's nice and safe.

89
00:04:18.710 --> 00:04:20.830
>> So
that's was what ReiserFS was pushing.

90
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:24.190
It had some interesting
political stuff that happened.

91
00:04:25.540 --> 00:04:27.599
The developer was arrested for
murder, but anyway.

92
00:04:27.599 --> 00:04:29.089
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That stuff happened,

93
00:04:29.089 --> 00:04:33.510
and so ReiserFS is kind of going away,
is replaced by BTRFS, sadly a true story.

94
00:04:33.510 --> 00:04:35.989
So BTRFS is kind of the replacement.

95
00:04:35.989 --> 00:04:39.881
And so a lot of people are talking about,
if you're using Fedora Linux BTRFS should

96
00:04:39.881 --> 00:04:42.850
be on your radar, you have that
option when you do the install.

97
00:04:42.850 --> 00:04:48.456
When we installed RHEL, you probably
noticed we didn't have the option and

98
00:04:48.456 --> 00:04:52.231
that is because BTRFS is
only in preview on RHEL 7.

99
00:04:52.231 --> 00:04:57.210
So, if you use BTRFS, you're not
going to get support from RedHat.

100
00:04:57.210 --> 00:04:59.770
I mean they will give you some pointers or
whatever but they are not going to

101
00:04:59.770 --> 00:05:03.560
guarantee any kind of SLA on it,
because it's still considered preview.

102
00:05:03.560 --> 00:05:05.960
So, when we're dealing with
RedHat enterprise Linux,

103
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:08.390
we wanna stick to the tried and true.

104
00:05:08.390 --> 00:05:13.810

file systems are pretty much all the same.

105
00:05:13.810 --> 00:05:17.195
They're are all based on EXT 2,
but they have added functionality.

106
00:05:17.195 --> 00:05:22.499
And EXT 4 has journaling functionality
in it just like Riser SF does.

107
00:05:22.499 --> 00:05:25.630
And so
EXT4 is kinda the one we're gonna go with.

108
00:05:25.630 --> 00:05:30.150
In a typical day it gives us great
performance, has journaling support,

109
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:31.540
does a lot that we need it to do.

110
00:05:31.540 --> 00:05:35.110
It works great with LVM, and Raid,
and all the other technologies.

111
00:05:35.110 --> 00:05:36.730
So usually that's what
we're gonna deal with.

112
00:05:36.730 --> 00:05:39.327
So in this show,
I'm gonna focus mostly on EXT4.

113
00:05:39.327 --> 00:05:42.709
But I will kind of point out some of the
other file systems as we go just in case

00:05:42.709 --> 00:05:44.410

115
00:05:44.410 --> 00:05:47.590
So I happen to have a RedHat
box right in front of me.

00:05:47.590 --> 00:05:51.300

00:05:51.300 --> 00:05:53.360

00:06:11.820 --> 00:06:12.810

00:06:16.970 --> 00:06:20.290

to think about what file system I'm gonna

127
00:06:20.290 --> 00:06:22.557
use, and make sure I size my

128

If you're using EXT4, it's not really

129
00:06:25.914 --> 00:06:29.545
EXT4 can go huge on the partition,

130
00:06:29.545 --> 00:06:33.680
versus some of the older file

131
00:06:33.680 --> 00:06:36.720
So in my case,
I just need to see my physical disks and

00:06:36.720 --> 00:06:38.900

133
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:43.850
So the first thing to do here is
just take a look at those disks are.

134
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:46.060
And we have a nice little utility.

135
00:06:46.060 --> 00:06:50.575
All the work I'm gonna do here in this
episode is really going to be tied to root

00:06:50.575 --> 00:06:51.830
level permissions.

137
00:06:51.830 --> 00:06:53.590
So you've gotta be root to
be able to do this stuff.

138
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:56.880
So I'm gonna sudu everything,
which is kinda annoying.

139
00:06:56.880 --> 00:07:00.371
You might drop to a root shell if you want
and you just do an su or a sudu sh or

140
00:07:00.371 --> 00:07:01.783
whatever it is you wanna do.

141
00:07:01.783 --> 00:07:04.940
But anyhow, so
I'm gonna make sure I do that.

But for FSCK, when you boot up your

633
00:32:11.913 --> 00:32:17.230
system, there's a file system check
that runs to look for errors.

634
00:32:17.230 --> 00:32:20.620
And most systems have either a timer, so

635
00:32:20.620 --> 00:32:23.740

or a counter.

00:32:23.740 --> 00:32:27.000

of boots we run a check.

00:32:27.000 --> 00:32:29.670

that number of boots,

00:32:29.670 --> 00:32:32.590

it changes this 0 to a 1.

00:32:32.590 --> 00:32:38.350

boot, it'll run FSCK on that file system.

640
00:32:38.350 --> 00:32:43.280
So if I wanna run FSCK on my new
partition, I can chuck a 1 in there, and

641
00:32:43.280 --> 00:32:46.090
that'll make it where it'll run
FSCK the next time that it boots.

642
00:32:46.090 --> 00:32:48.780

00:32:48.780 --> 00:32:52.900
So it'll always run fsck, which may not

00:32:52.900 --> 00:32:54.510
So that's kinda up to me.

00:32:54.510 --> 00:32:57.430
The reason we specify here
is there's some partitions,

00:33:01.470 --> 00:33:02.920

00:33:07.150 --> 00:33:10.200
But if you put the file system check here,

00:33:10.200 --> 00:33:11.430

00:33:11.430 --> 00:33:14.080
So I'm just gonna add a 00

00:33:14.080 --> 00:33:16.310

00:33:16.310 --> 00:33:19.220
So, and like I said, I'll look it up and

00:33:19.220 --> 00:33:22.310
notes whether it's supposed to be

00:33:22.310 --> 00:33:25.970

It's gonna be available for me.

00:36:36.778 --> 00:36:37.468

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the very powerful Logical Volume Manager(LVM) for managing disks in Linux. They begin with the basics of using LVM. This includes creating physical volumes, volume groups, and logical groups. Then they demonstrate mounting the logical volume, adding more storage to the groups, making things permanent in fstab, and even deleting volumes.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:59.190

00:04:05.740 --> 00:04:11.020

00:04:11.020 --> 00:04:12.860

00:04:12.860 --> 00:04:14.920

00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:21.980

00:26:58.155 --> 00:27:00.637
Or however much space it is that
you're adding, you'll punch in.

508
00:27:00.637 --> 00:27:03.954
And then who it is you're adding it to.

509
00:27:03.954 --> 00:27:07.598
So I'm gonna add it to /dev/vg1/website.

510
00:27:07.598 --> 00:27:11.049
And so it's gonna look into vg1 and make
sure that it's got a terabyte available,

511
00:27:11.049 --> 00:27:12.210
which I do.

512
00:27:12.210 --> 00:27:16.100
And then it's going to expand
out that logical volume, right?

513
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:19.879
And so there it goes,
logical volume successfully re-sized.

514
00:27:19.879 --> 00:27:21.125
Happened very quickly.

515
00:27:21.125 --> 00:27:26.237
Now, if I do a df-h,
and take a look at it,

516
00:27:26.237 --> 00:27:29.370
it's still 246 gigs.

517
00:27:29.370 --> 00:27:31.531
What the heck happened?

518
00:27:31.531 --> 00:27:36.670
Well if you do an lvs to look at
your logical volumes, it did grow.

519
00:27:36.670 --> 00:27:38.920
The logical volume did grow.

520
00:27:38.920 --> 00:27:42.470
But ext4 is not seeing that.

521
00:27:42.470 --> 00:27:44.740
It doesn't know that it happened, okay?

522
00:27:44.740 --> 00:27:48.350
So there's a couple of little extra
steps we have to do to get this working.

523
00:27:48.350 --> 00:27:54.150
And one of those is, well,
we shouldn't have to do it.

524
00:27:54.150 --> 00:27:56.750
If for
some reason lvs didn't show the growth,

525
00:27:56.750 --> 00:27:58.080
we might have to do a partition probe.

526
00:27:58.080 --> 00:28:00.100
Meaning you're going to run part probe.

527
00:28:00.100 --> 00:28:05.000
It usually shows up so we shouldn't have
to do it, but the part probe utility just

528
00:28:05.000 --> 00:28:07.960
looks for partition changes and
makes the system aware of them.

529
00:28:07.960 --> 00:28:10.710
In my case, and really in your case,
it should automatically detect them so

530
00:28:10.710 --> 00:28:11.980
we can kind of skip that step.

531
00:28:11.980 --> 00:28:13.680
But the other thing we need to do.

532
00:28:13.680 --> 00:28:18.720
Is, it's time, we need to break
out the resize2fs utility right.

533
00:28:18.720 --> 00:28:21.920
So that's where we go in and
we tell it to jump up.

534
00:28:21.920 --> 00:28:26.728
But we had to do the lvresize first,
otherwise the resize2fs

535
00:28:26.728 --> 00:28:29.596
wouldn't overwrite-
>> Right, it wouldn't see anything, right,

536
00:28:29.596 --> 00:28:30.214
it wouldn't be there yet.

537
00:28:30.214 --> 00:28:32.286
>> It just wouldn't be aware of it.

538
00:28:32.286 --> 00:28:36.607
So now that's done, we can jump in
here and we can say resize2fs, and

539
00:28:36.607 --> 00:28:39.315
I know I'm running ext 4, but ext 2, 3,

540
00:28:39.315 --> 00:28:44.020
and 4 are actually the same thing,
they just have extra features added on.

541
00:28:44.020 --> 00:28:45.791
So the utility is still 2fs.

542
00:28:45.791 --> 00:28:53.627
So I'm gonna resize 2fs/dev/vg1/website,
and there it goes.

543
00:28:53.627 --> 00:28:55.158
It extends out.

544
00:28:55.158 --> 00:29:01.265
And now my pvs, vgs, and
lvs output, they don't change.

545
00:29:01.265 --> 00:29:06.788
But if I do a df-h and take a look,
I can see my website is now 1.3

546
00:29:06.788 --> 00:29:12.930
terabytes in size, I'm using next
to none of it, and there we go.

547
00:29:12.930 --> 00:29:14.050
I didn't have to unmount it.

548
00:29:14.050 --> 00:29:15.130
I didn't have to take it offline.

549
00:29:15.130 --> 00:29:16.390
Didn't have to reboot the server.

550
00:29:16.390 --> 00:29:17.900
Did all that while I was online.

551
00:29:17.900 --> 00:29:19.180
Assuming you have hot plug drives, right?

552
00:29:19.180 --> 00:29:22.260
Otherwise when I added that third drive I
probably would've needed to power off for

553
00:29:22.260 --> 00:29:26.750
that and power back on, but
once it's done that's it, it's now there,

554
00:29:26.750 --> 00:29:28.090
it's mounted it's available.

555
00:29:28.090 --> 00:29:31.320
There's a few other steps I need to do if
I'm actually going to put my website here.

556
00:29:31.320 --> 00:29:34.370
I need to approve the context
through FC Linux,

557
00:29:34.370 --> 00:29:37.930
I'd need to add it to my f stab table,
so it's there when we reboot.

558
00:29:37.930 --> 00:29:40.300
We need to set it up for
our backup plans and so on.

559
00:29:40.300 --> 00:29:42.560
But otherwise it's there and it's done.

560
00:29:43.560 --> 00:29:49.720
Now If we wanna tear it all down again,
well, the commands are the same.

561
00:29:49.720 --> 00:29:53.910
We got lvremoved, vgremoved and
pvremoved that we can go through,

562
00:29:53.910 --> 00:29:56.420
we can delete each of the objects.

563
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:59.870
You can't remove a physical volume
if it still has volume groups on it.

564
00:29:59.870 --> 00:30:02.650
And you can't remove a volume group if
it still has logical volumes on it.

565
00:30:02.650 --> 00:30:05.690
So you gotta delete your logical volumes
first, then you delete your volume groups,

566
00:30:05.690 --> 00:30:07.100
then you delete your physical volumes.

567
00:30:07.100 --> 00:30:09.730
And you basically back it all out,
and now it's gone.

568
00:30:09.730 --> 00:30:12.180
So it's pretty easy to remove
that stuff after the fact.

569
00:30:12.180 --> 00:30:17.239
But once this is created, the flexibility
that we get with it is really impressive.

570
00:30:17.239 --> 00:30:20.790
And I held this demonstration
just to creating a volume and

571
00:30:20.790 --> 00:30:24.920
resizing it cuzthat's what
most people are interested in.

572
00:30:24.920 --> 00:30:29.748
But if you want the advanced things such
as snapshotting, thin provisioning and

573
00:30:29.748 --> 00:30:32.881
raid arrays, I'm holding off for
the SSM for that.

574
00:30:32.881 --> 00:30:34.999
Because you can do it right from here,
it's just hard.

575
00:30:34.999 --> 00:30:38.024
So in real life you're not gonna do
it that way you're gonna use the SSM.

576
00:30:38.024 --> 00:30:40.236
So be sure to jump over
to our SSM episode, and

577
00:30:40.236 --> 00:30:42.460
we'll see how to do
the more complex things.

578
00:30:42.460 --> 00:30:44.680
It's actually really easy,
even this is easy.

579
00:30:44.680 --> 00:30:47.410
So I pretty much use the SSM for
everything these days.

580
00:30:47.410 --> 00:30:50.672
But knowing these LVM tools are really
nice because they work on pretty much

581
00:30:50.672 --> 00:30:51.822
every out there.

582
00:30:51.822 --> 00:30:55.052
And the SSM is still fairly new.

583
00:30:55.052 --> 00:30:59.220
It's still an evolving technology so
a lot of people haven't adapted yet.

584
00:30:59.220 --> 00:31:03.794
So this is the tried and
true way of working with the LVM.

585
00:31:03.794 --> 00:31:07.900
>> LVM is definitely awesome stuff,
and even if you do jump to SSM and

586
00:31:07.900 --> 00:31:13.610
make that leap and say, that's gonna be my
storage management choice, that's fine.

587
00:31:13.610 --> 00:31:16.250
But you're probably still gonna
run the LVM from time to time, so

588
00:31:16.250 --> 00:31:20.060
it's really good for you to have this
foundation knowledge of LVM, because

589
00:31:20.060 --> 00:31:23.890
I can't tell you how many times someone's
asked me, I'm having trouble with LVM.

590
00:31:23.890 --> 00:31:27.137
And you're like, yeah, okay,
you didn't do the PV group correctly and

591
00:31:27.137 --> 00:31:28.119
all that other stuff.

592
00:31:28.119 --> 00:31:29.691
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a lot of fun,

593
00:31:29.691 --> 00:31:31.798
you gotta walk it through
each one of the steps, but

594
00:31:31.798 --> 00:31:35.190
there's a lot of power in there and that's
be the soup de jour for quite some time.

595
00:31:35.190 --> 00:31:38.060
So again, you're still probably going to
have to deal with that from time to time.

596
00:31:38.060 --> 00:31:41.100
That being said, Don,
looking forward to that SSM show.

597
00:31:41.100 --> 00:31:44.270
And we do thank you for
dropping by for this here episode.

598
00:31:44.270 --> 00:31:47.690
And getting us even a little more
acclimated into storage management inside

599
00:31:47.690 --> 00:31:48.830
of Red Hat Linux.

600
00:31:48.830 --> 00:31:52.380
But we have elapsed our time for
today, at least in this episode.

601
00:31:52.380 --> 00:31:54.747
We'll have to make another one on SSM.

602
00:31:54.747 --> 00:31:55.612
That will be a lot of fun.

603
00:31:55.612 --> 00:31:56.360
Well hopefully we will see you guys there.

604
00:31:56.360 --> 00:31:59.048
As for us, we're going to go ahead and
sign off for IT Pro TV.

605
00:31:59.048 --> 00:32:00.411
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

606
00:32:00.411 --> 00:32:01.527
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

607
00:32:01.527 --> 00:32:04.295
>> See you next time.

608
00:32:04.295 --> 00:32:10.020
[MUSIC]

609
00:32:10.020 --> 00:32:13.594
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to utilize file system Snapshots in Red Hat Enterprise Linux. They start by installing Snapper, the snapshot utility and then creating the storage structure needed to facilitate the use of snapshots. You'll also see how to create a Snapper config file and ultimately, take snapshots, work with snapshots, revert changes using snapshots, and deleting snapshots.
episodes.title: File System Snapshots
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.696
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.696 --> 00:00:05.792
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.792 --> 00:00:08.209
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.209 --> 00:00:11.727
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.727 --> 00:00:13.786
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.786 --> 00:00:16.672
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.672 --> 00:00:19.774
I am your host Daniel Lowrie and
in todays episode well,

8
00:00:19.774 --> 00:00:22.616
it's more on our red hat
enterprise Linux series.

9
00:00:22.616 --> 00:00:26.098
And joining us back in the studio
is the man you know and love,

10
00:00:26.098 --> 00:00:29.119
it is John Jerset, no,
Don Pezet, that's right.

11
00:00:29.119 --> 00:00:29.943
>> What's his name again?

12
00:00:29.943 --> 00:00:31.664
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, Daniel,

13
00:00:31.664 --> 00:00:34.365
let's kick this one off,
we're going snapshot crazy today.

14
00:00:34.365 --> 00:00:35.191
>> This is gonna be fun.

15
00:00:35.191 --> 00:00:37.210
>> Yup,
we're gonna jump back into the storage.

16
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:39.803
We've been tackling these last few
episodes working inside of storage

17
00:00:39.803 --> 00:00:40.500
inside of Red Hat.

18
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:45.333
I wanna cover one kind of important
concept which is volume snapshots.

19
00:00:45.333 --> 00:00:48.760
Snapshots are a technology that's
really evolved quite a bit.

20
00:00:48.760 --> 00:00:51.600
And we typically use it in
the sense of virtual machines.

21
00:00:51.600 --> 00:00:54.209
So if you've got KVM or VirtualBox, or

22
00:00:54.209 --> 00:00:58.650
whatever virtualization
platform you're using, VMWare.

23
00:00:58.650 --> 00:01:00.459
They all support doing snapshots
of an entire machine, and

24
00:01:00.459 --> 00:01:01.737
that's great if you're virtualizing.

25
00:01:01.737 --> 00:01:02.596
>> Love it.

26
00:01:02.596 --> 00:01:06.880
>> If you're not virtualizing though,
snapshots aren't very useful, are they?

27
00:01:06.880 --> 00:01:09.200
You can't do them, well, that's not true.

28
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:12.987
We can actually do snapshots thanks to
the LVM, the Logical Volume Manager.

29
00:01:12.987 --> 00:01:17.880
With the LVM, we're creating disk
partitions that aren't real partitions,

30
00:01:17.880 --> 00:01:20.450
they're logical volumes that
are laying on top of volume groups.

31
00:01:20.450 --> 00:01:24.690
That are being spread across disks and all
this other magic, and they lend themselves

32
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:28.960
to having snapshots created just like any
kind of virtual machine that's out there.

33
00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:31.518
So we're gonna take a look at
how to do snapshots on volumes,

34
00:01:31.518 --> 00:01:33.840
even on a non virtual machine,
on physical hardware.

35
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:39.560
So I'm gonna pick back up with this stuff
we had set up in the very last episode.

36
00:01:39.560 --> 00:01:41.840
If you watched our LVM episode,

37
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:46.560
we created some logical volumes and
so on, I've deleted those.

38
00:01:46.560 --> 00:01:47.740
But I still have a volume group handy.

39
00:01:47.740 --> 00:01:50.970
So let me show you what I've got on this
system and we'll kind of go from there.

40
00:01:50.970 --> 00:01:55.320
It is important to remember that what I'm
about to show you works on top of LVM.

41
00:01:55.320 --> 00:01:59.580
So if you've got traditional disks
defined like just /dev /sda1 and

42
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:04.132
you've dropped a file system on it,
you can't really do snapshots there.

43
00:02:04.132 --> 00:02:07.503
So sorry, you can use Rsync to do
snapshots that certainly works but

44
00:02:07.503 --> 00:02:10.870
it's really a file level thing
versus a disk level thing.

45
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:14.050
So what I'm gonna show you is disk
level and it's done as part of the LVM.

46
00:02:14.050 --> 00:02:18.410
So if I take a look I've got
my three physical disks here,

47
00:02:18.410 --> 00:02:23.490
sdb1, sdc1 and sdd1,
they're 500 gig disks.

48
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:27.210
And they're all in a volume group one,
and so

49
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:29.560
I still have volume group
one sitting right here.

50
00:02:29.560 --> 00:02:32.590
Now I deleted the volumes that
we've created in the last episodes.

51
00:02:32.590 --> 00:02:36.210
So I just have volume group one and
it's one and a half terabytes in size.

52
00:02:36.210 --> 00:02:38.980
And what I want us to remember
is that it is one and

53
00:02:38.980 --> 00:02:43.780
a half terabytes in size, and
that it contains three disks.

54
00:02:43.780 --> 00:02:46.200
The three disks are gonna be important for
later.

55
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:50.750
Now, we can obviously add more disks if
we need to, or take disks out, and so on.

56
00:02:50.750 --> 00:02:52.270
But by having multiple disks,

57
00:02:52.270 --> 00:02:56.560
it allows me to really achieve sizes that
I wouldn't normally be able to achieve.

58
00:02:56.560 --> 00:02:58.600
When I do snapshots,

59
00:02:58.600 --> 00:03:03.040
snapshots actually rely on some of that
flexibility being able to add more space.

60
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:06.880
Cuz as we take snapshots,
they need space to sit in, right,

61
00:03:06.880 --> 00:03:08.430
they're gonna occupy room.

62
00:03:08.430 --> 00:03:11.250
And what a snapshot really does is
it says I'm gonna take your disk,

63
00:03:11.250 --> 00:03:15.360
you've been making changes, putting data
in there, and I'm gonna freeze it in time.

64
00:03:15.360 --> 00:03:18.740
And now, anymore changes that you make
to that disk are actually going to get

65
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:20.960
written to a separate volume.

66
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:23.000
And then you can freeze that
one in time if you want, and

67
00:03:23.000 --> 00:03:25.460
then we'll make more to another one and
it keeps adding volumes.

68
00:03:25.460 --> 00:03:31.090
Now where that gets tricky is if
I create a one terabyte volume,

69
00:03:31.090 --> 00:03:35.200
and I take a snapshot of it and freeze it
in time, that's one terabyte of space,

70
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:36.820
that volume might be next to empty.

71
00:03:36.820 --> 00:03:39.200
But now I've frozen that
one terabyte of space and

72
00:03:39.200 --> 00:03:42.180
I start writing more data to another
volume, it's extremely wasteful.

73
00:03:42.180 --> 00:03:47.860
So if I want to setup snapshots,
I have to do thin provisioned volumes and

74
00:03:47.860 --> 00:03:49.810
that's why I had to delete
the volumes from the last episode,

75
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:50.990
because they weren't thin provisioned.

76
00:03:50.990 --> 00:03:52.890
I just laid them out,
taking up their full space,

77
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:55.580
which is what we normally
do on production service.

78
00:03:55.580 --> 00:03:56.190
But in lab and

79
00:03:56.190 --> 00:04:00.580
test environments we're snapshots of the
most useful we typically thin provision.

80
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:03.900
So thin provision says this volumes only
going to take up the amount of space that

81
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:05.870
it's actually using.

82
00:04:05.870 --> 00:04:06.820
And as I throw in more and

83
00:04:06.820 --> 00:04:10.720
more data in there it will grow up
to its maximum size so it can vary.

84
00:04:10.720 --> 00:04:14.000
And that way when I freeze it
in time it's frozen with just

85
00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:17.380
the data that's actually being used,
much for efficient and

86
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:20.060
each snapshot that I add onto
it is gonna be tracking changes.

87
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:21.960
I can still run out of space,
that still happens.

88
00:04:21.960 --> 00:04:24.406
We got to plan for
the amount of space of our snapshots and

89
00:04:24.406 --> 00:04:27.596
as a result you typically don't wanna
keep snapshots around very long.

90
00:04:27.596 --> 00:04:31.059
When your done with the snapshot you need
to remove it and get it out of there and

91
00:04:31.059 --> 00:04:33.500
then you can move on and do other things.

92
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:37.850
And everything I'm gonna show you
here is done straight through LVM and

93
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:40.320
another utility called Snapper.

94
00:04:40.320 --> 00:04:43.940
That's a part of the Red Hat distribution,
so we're gonna see how to use those.

95
00:04:43.940 --> 00:04:47.500
But we're also gonna revisit this in the
SSM episode cuz you'll see I have to do

96
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:49.590
quite a few different commands
to get this all working.

97
00:04:49.590 --> 00:04:53.770
In the SSM, they make it a lot easier and
so we'll typically manage it in the SSM.

98
00:04:53.770 --> 00:04:56.939
But I wanna show you how to do it with
just snapper because a lot of people

99
00:04:56.939 --> 00:05:00.487
prefer that if they don't want to get
involved with the SSM since it's a little

100
00:05:00.487 --> 00:05:01.375
bit cutting edge.

101
00:05:01.375 --> 00:05:02.490
>> And they make a fine lawnmower.

102
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:06.530
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And multipurpose tools.

103
00:05:06.530 --> 00:05:08.260
All right, so let's get to work,

104
00:05:08.260 --> 00:05:10.970
first thing, I need a volume
that is thin provisioned, right?

105
00:05:10.970 --> 00:05:14.270
So in the last episode I created a volume
for my website, I'm gonna do that again.

106
00:05:14.270 --> 00:05:18.028
I'm gonna create another volume for
my website and so I'm gonna use lvcreate.

107
00:05:18.028 --> 00:05:23.730
And this time,
before I create that volume,

108
00:05:23.730 --> 00:05:27.500
I need it to be thin provisioned and I
need it to be able to support my snapshot.

109
00:05:27.500 --> 00:05:32.000
And so, what I actually need to do,
is I need to create a thin provision pool.

110
00:05:32.000 --> 00:05:36.340
That I can then start to throw my
volumes into and other things.

111
00:05:36.340 --> 00:05:42.240
So, I'm gonna create a pool first and I'm
gonna use --thin when I designate this.

112
00:05:42.240 --> 00:05:48.590
And so I'm gonna create vg1/pool1,
so I'm just creating a pool.

113
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:51.270
I'm just calling it pool one,
cuz I'm gonna stick volumes in there,

114
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:52.130
I might have my website.

115

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the System Storage Manager(SSM) which is meant to be an all-in-one solution for storage management. Here you will see how to use the SSM to perform a variety of tasks like listing volumes, creating volume groups, creating logical groups, and mounting. Also shown is adding disks, working with snapshots, and setting up RAID.
episodes.title: System Storage Manager (SSM)
