00:28:30.630 --> 00:28:31.160
There we go.

579
00:28:32.560 --> 00:28:34.250
All right.
And then we'll recreate it and this time,

580
00:28:34.250 --> 00:28:35.710
I'll be smart enough to specify a size.

581
00:28:35.710 --> 00:28:38.384
So back when I was defining all
the different stuff like the name and

582
00:28:38.384 --> 00:28:41.277
the file system type and all that,
I should have done just a quick size.

583
00:28:41.277 --> 00:28:43.610
I'll just make it 10 gigs and there we go.

584
00:28:43.610 --> 00:28:46.939
All right, so that will leave me enough
room so that I can come back and, shoot,

585
00:28:46.939 --> 00:28:48.550
I just hit Images, so I can do website.

586
00:28:48.550 --> 00:28:51.590
And let me just correct that.

587
00:28:53.490 --> 00:28:55.182
And I'm just gonna tell it to raid 0.

588
00:28:55.182 --> 00:28:57.964
And there it goes.

589
00:28:57.964 --> 00:28:59.016
All right.

590
00:28:59.016 --> 00:29:00.300
So now I've got them created.

591
00:29:00.300 --> 00:29:07.460
And if I do a ssm list volumes,
it'll pop right up.

592
00:29:07.460 --> 00:29:09.730
I can see images and website.

593
00:29:09.730 --> 00:29:12.090
Let me stretch this out so
it doesn't wrap.

594
00:29:13.270 --> 00:29:14.870
It's gonna wrap no matter what, isn't it?

595
00:29:14.870 --> 00:29:16.290
So, [LAUGH] I'm just
trying to stretch it so

596
00:29:16.290 --> 00:29:18.400
it wouldn't do the little
word wrap one here.

597
00:29:18.400 --> 00:29:19.780
It looks a little cleaner when it doesn't.

598
00:29:21.790 --> 00:29:23.810
And there we go,
now that's what I wanna see.

599
00:29:23.810 --> 00:29:27.230
So now I can see images and
website, both of them, right here.

600
00:29:27.230 --> 00:29:31.990
And if I scroll over, I can see I've
got raid1, a mirror on this one.

601
00:29:31.990 --> 00:29:34.540
And I've got RAID 0 or
a striped on this one.

602
00:29:34.540 --> 00:29:36.970
So it's actually set up
the RAID configuration for

603
00:29:36.970 --> 00:29:40.410
me on the back end,
in addition to all the LVM stuff.

604
00:29:40.410 --> 00:29:43.560
And if I had thin provisioned them,
then I can start taking snapshots and

605
00:29:43.560 --> 00:29:44.650
that would all be configured too.

606
00:29:44.650 --> 00:29:48.900
So, it really is able to knock out
everything from those last three episodes,

607
00:29:48.900 --> 00:29:51.420
all in one command if we really want to.

608
00:29:51.420 --> 00:29:53.428
It can really do impressive
things like that.

609
00:29:53.428 --> 00:29:55.973
>> Well SSM is definitely
one stop shopping for

610
00:29:55.973 --> 00:29:58.527
our storage management goodness, right?

611
00:29:58.527 --> 00:30:01.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll wrap it into that little ball,

612
00:30:01.490 --> 00:30:04.760
because it is, it's great,
this stuff, being able to do RAID and

613
00:30:04.760 --> 00:30:08.790
setting up partitions and volumes and
doing the whole nine yards from one

614
00:30:08.790 --> 00:30:15.290
console is a much nicer aspect than
having to go through all the rigmarole.

615
00:30:15.290 --> 00:30:17.700
Other ways don't work well,
using LVM obviously works very well,

616
00:30:17.700 --> 00:30:18.650
it's been used for a while.

617
00:30:19.650 --> 00:30:22.580
Every now and then, you gotta check
an old fdisk for good measure, right,

618
00:30:22.580 --> 00:30:25.130
make sure you don't forget
where you came from.

619
00:30:25.130 --> 00:30:29.250
But using SSM to just handle
everything saves me time, and

620
00:30:29.250 --> 00:30:31.710
the convenience factor is definitely
worth the squeeze on that.

621
00:30:31.710 --> 00:30:34.680
Don, is there anything else we need to
know about SSM before we wrap up the show?

622
00:30:34.680 --> 00:30:35.450
>> I think that's about it.

623
00:30:35.450 --> 00:30:40.520
Definitely, if you go to their website,
the SSM, it's on SourceForge, I believe.

624
00:30:40.520 --> 00:30:43.290
You can go there and you can see
all the stuff they're developing.

625
00:30:43.290 --> 00:30:46.730
Be aware that Red Hat doesn't go
with the latest version of SSM.

626
00:30:46.730 --> 00:30:47.430
They test it out and

627
00:30:47.430 --> 00:30:52.070
make sure it's okay before rolling it out
into the RATL distribution, so just get

628
00:30:52.070 --> 00:30:54.830
an idea of what's on the horizon, some of
the different projects they're working on.

629
00:30:54.830 --> 00:30:57.290
They're constantly rolling new
things into SSM on the back end, and

630
00:30:57.290 --> 00:30:59.370
it makes it a really flexible tool to use.

631
00:30:59.370 --> 00:31:02.970
>> All right, well thank you, Don, and
we thank you guys for watching, but

632
00:31:02.970 --> 00:31:05.700
it is that time yet
again for us to sign off.

633
00:31:05.700 --> 00:31:08.968
And well, signing off, for ITProTV,
I've been host, Daniel Lowrie.

634
00:31:08.968 --> 00:31:09.660
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

635
00:31:09.660 --> 00:31:10.483
>> We'll see you next time.

636
00:31:10.483 --> 00:31:18.318
[MUSIC]

637
00:31:18.318 --> 00:31:20.654
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the difference between the files systems available in RHEL7 so that you can choose the correct one for your environment. They compare and contrast the EXT2/3/4, XFS, and BTRFS filesystems.
episodes.title: Choosing a File System
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.942
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.942 --> 00:00:08.280
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.280 --> 00:00:11.999
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.999 --> 00:00:13.954
>> All right, greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.954 --> 00:00:16.502
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.502 --> 00:00:20.620
I'm your host Daniel Lowry and in today's
episode we are continuing on with our

7
00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:23.151
Red Hat enterprise Linux
version seven series.

8
00:00:23.151 --> 00:00:26.549
Joining us back in the studio again to
lend his expertise on that very topic is

9
00:00:26.549 --> 00:00:28.102
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.102 --> 00:00:29.651
Don, welcome back, sir,
and how is it today?

11
00:00:29.651 --> 00:00:30.680
>> It's going great, Daniel.

12
00:00:30.680 --> 00:00:31.440
Thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:34.070
I'm ready to dive right back into
the world of Red Hat Enterprise and

14
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:34.930
Linux version seven.

15
00:00:34.930 --> 00:00:38.537
So in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at file systems and

16
00:00:38.537 --> 00:00:41.404
Daniel was actually making
fun of me before the show.

17
00:00:41.404 --> 00:00:43.477
He said, Don, how many episodes
are we gonna do on file systems?

18
00:00:43.477 --> 00:00:45.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> We've kinda been going on about this

19
00:00:45.770 --> 00:00:51.110
for a while, and the main reason I wanted
to spend more time on file systems is that

20
00:00:51.110 --> 00:00:54.110
it's an area where I see a lot
of people make mistakes.

21
00:00:54.110 --> 00:00:57.240
I see a lot of people who have deployed
Linux out there in a production

22
00:00:57.240 --> 00:01:01.890
environment and
they make decisions that are incorrect.

23
00:01:01.890 --> 00:01:05.880
And it leads to a difficult
situation to correct later on.

24
00:01:05.880 --> 00:01:08.380
Adjusting your file systems is not
necessarily something you wanna

25
00:01:08.380 --> 00:01:10.600
do in a production environment,
if you can avoid it.

26
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:12.723
So making the right
decisions at the beginning,

27
00:01:12.723 --> 00:01:14.960
it's gonna save you a ton
of time down the road.

28
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:18.603
So, in our earlier episodes,
we focused on things like partitioning and

29
00:01:18.603 --> 00:01:21.760
volume creation, the LVM,
the SSM, tools like that.

30
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:24.980
In this episode, I wanna back up just
a little bit from all these tools and

31
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:26.240
fancy gadgets.

32
00:01:26.240 --> 00:01:28.850
And just talk about the file
systems themselves, right?

33
00:01:28.850 --> 00:01:33.940
Because choosing the right file system is
something that's very easy to get wrong

34
00:01:33.940 --> 00:01:36.870
and kind of annoying to fix down the road.

35
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:37.730
I say kind of annoying.

36
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:40.580
There's some parts where it's actually
really easy to change from one

37
00:01:40.580 --> 00:01:41.370
file system to another.

38
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:43.390
There's other ones where
it's very difficult.

39
00:01:43.390 --> 00:01:46.562
And as soon as your get Red Hat involved,
Red Hat the company,

40
00:01:46.562 --> 00:01:49.010
there's only so
much that they support for us.

41
00:01:49.010 --> 00:01:51.799
And so there's some scenarios where
you're not allowed to migrate from

42
00:01:51.799 --> 00:01:52.907
one file system to another.

43
00:01:52.907 --> 00:01:55.178
You gonna end up having to
redo everything from scratch,

44
00:01:55.178 --> 00:01:58.380
which if we're talking about a massive
data store, can really be a headache.

45
00:01:58.380 --> 00:02:00.880
So if we can avoid that, all the better.

46
00:02:00.880 --> 00:02:04.460
And so I wanna talk a little bit about
each of the primary file systems supported

47
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:06.210
by Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

48
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:09.890
And how we choose which one we wanna use,
why we might pick one over another, and

49
00:02:09.890 --> 00:02:10.390
so on.

50
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:12.720
That's gonna be our focus
right here in this episode.

51
00:02:12.720 --> 00:02:14.090
>> Well, Don, you make a great point,

52
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:17.170
is there is a plethora of
different file systems for

53
00:02:17.170 --> 00:02:21.680
us to choose from inside of Red Hat Linux,
or any Linux for that matter.

54
00:02:21.680 --> 00:02:25.814
What would be some of the beginning
considerations that we would need to take

55
00:02:25.814 --> 00:02:27.507
in to even begin to choose one?

56
00:02:27.507 --> 00:02:28.064
>> All right, so

57
00:02:28.064 --> 00:02:30.856
[COUGH] one thing we need to think
about is what are the defaults, right?

58
00:02:30.856 --> 00:02:31.379
>> Mm-hm.

59
00:02:31.379 --> 00:02:34.138
>> Because how do most
of us install Red Hat?

60
00:02:34.138 --> 00:02:36.426
Next, Next, Next, Next,
Next, Next, done, reboot.

61
00:02:36.426 --> 00:02:37.179
>> The right way.

62
00:02:37.179 --> 00:02:40.239
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And so if you do that, right?

63
00:02:40.239 --> 00:02:43.838
If you just cruise right through
the install and go with all the defaults,

64
00:02:43.838 --> 00:02:47.400
you're gonna end up with one file system,
which is the XFS file system.

65
00:02:47.400 --> 00:02:51.380
Now that's different from
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and earlier.

66
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:57.220
If you did 6 and earlier, you'd have EXT
4, or even EXT 3, the old EXT file system.

67
00:02:57.220 --> 00:03:03.860
So XFS has replaced EXT as the default
file system in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

68
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:08.510
At the same time, you'll hear a lot of
people talking about this new file system,

69
00:03:08.510 --> 00:03:10.410
BTRFS, right?

70
00:03:10.410 --> 00:03:13.620
And now, we got three different ones
to pick from, which do we want?

71
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:18.410
Do we want EXT, do we want XFS,
do we want BTRFS, which one?

72
00:03:18.410 --> 00:03:21.600
Well, sadly,
there's not an easy answer for it, right?

73
00:03:22.732 --> 00:03:25.723
I guess if I had to go for
what I'd call the easy answer,

74
00:03:25.723 --> 00:03:27.295
it would be just go with XFS.

75
00:03:27.295 --> 00:03:28.950
It's kinda hard to go wrong with XFS.

76
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:31.910
You can just cruise through,
pick that one, and run with it.

77
00:03:31.910 --> 00:03:37.740
And you kinda get the most balanced
solution of the ones that are available.

78
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:40.530
But there are times where EXT is better.

79
00:03:40.530 --> 00:03:42.490
There are times when BTRFS is better.

80
00:03:42.490 --> 00:03:45.330
It's just something we've gotta make
sure we understand the differences of.

81
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:49.860
So let's talk a little bit about each one,
and kind of where they excel, right?

82
00:03:49.860 --> 00:03:52.655
EXT, EXT is the extended file system,

83
00:03:52.655 --> 00:03:57.157
it's been prominent in the Linux world for
a long, long time.

84
00:03:57.157 --> 00:04:01.820
If you're running Red Hat, Cent OS,
Fedora they all share that common core.

85
00:04:01.820 --> 00:04:03.575
It makes sense they'd use
that same file systems.

86
00:04:03.575 --> 00:04:05.811
But [INAUDIBLE], Ubuntu, Jentu,

87
00:04:05.811 --> 00:04:09.907
all the other guys,
they've been running EXT for years also.

88
00:04:09.907 --> 00:04:14.902
So EXT is nice and standard across all
the Linux distros that are available.

89
00:04:14.902 --> 00:04:17.660
But there's more than one
version that's out there, right?

90
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:21.829
On most modern Linux distros,
including Red Hat, EXT 2 is the lowest

91
00:04:21.829 --> 00:04:26.085
version in that supported,
the original EXT's no longer supported.

92
00:04:26.085 --> 00:04:30.030
So EXT2 is kinda that base file system.

93
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:35.450
But then you've got EXT version 3, and EXT
version 4, so we get to pick and choose.

94
00:04:35.450 --> 00:04:40.880
Well, the neat thing about EXT is that
it's really all just one file system, EXT.

95
00:04:40.880 --> 00:04:43.320
But with extra little features,
extra little bells and

96
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:45.210
whistles turned on for each.

97
00:04:45.210 --> 00:04:48.452
So, if I have an EXT file
system that's EXT2 and

98
00:04:48.452 --> 00:04:53.053
I decide I wanna make it EXT3,
I don't even have to take it offline.

99
00:04:53.053 --> 00:04:56.145
I just enable a few options,
now I'm running EXT3.

100
00:04:56.145 --> 00:04:58.820
And then if I wanna go EXT4,
kinda the same thing.

101
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:03.137
You'd have to mount and unmount, but
otherwise you can get to EXT4 really easy.

102
00:05:03.137 --> 00:05:08.537
So simple, easy transition between
the three different versions.

103
00:05:08.537 --> 00:05:12.699
As far as features are concerned,
the things that were added, under EXT2,

104
00:05:12.699 --> 00:05:15.400
there was this big limitation
that people hated.

105
00:05:15.400 --> 00:05:17.090
There's always file system limitations,
right?

106
00:05:17.090 --> 00:05:23.570
There's a limit on the size of your
volume, right, your file system itself and

107
00:05:23.570 --> 00:05:28.520
then the size of a single file,
an individual file can only be so large.

108
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:30.620
And with older file systems like EXT2,

109
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:34.260
they were written back in the day when
hard drives were incredibly expensive,

110
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:36.550
storage was small,
you didn't have giant files.

111
00:05:36.550 --> 00:05:38.640
And so it didn't support
anything too terribly giant.

112
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:41.550
EXT3 bumped that up.

113
00:05:41.550 --> 00:05:44.768
So we have bigger file systems,
we got bigger individual files, but

114
00:05:44.768 --> 00:05:48.109
the other thing we did with the EXT3,
I don't know why I'm saying we.

115
00:05:48.109 --> 00:05:49.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> The developers,

116
00:05:49.090 --> 00:05:50.710
I wasn't involved in that at all.

117
00:05:50.710 --> 00:05:56.150
The other thing the EXT3 did is it
removed the directory limitation.

118
00:05:56.150 --> 00:05:58.100
Under EXT2 there is
a subdirectory limitation.

119
00:05:58.100 --> 00:06:02.952
You could only have, get ready for
it, 32,000 subdirectories, so.

120
00:06:02.952 --> 00:06:04.245
>> I can't live with that now.

121
00:06:04.245 --> 00:06:06.050
>> I know, it's shocking.

122
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:10.110
But oddly enough, you'd be surprised
how quickly you eat up subdirectories,

123
00:06:10.110 --> 00:06:12.820
especially if you're doing things like
downloading the kernel source code from

124
00:06:12.820 --> 00:06:14.580
more than one version of the kernel and
so on.

125
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:16.564
You'll blow out
the subdirectories pretty quick.

126
00:06:16.564 --> 00:06:20.354
So 32,000 subdirectories was a limit
that a lot of people were hitting.

127
00:06:20.354 --> 00:06:25.197
And in EXT3, they changed the way those
directories were indexed so that you would

128
00:06:25.197 --> 00:06:29.294
now be able to have an unlimited
number of subdirectories in a folder.

129
00:06:29.294 --> 00:06:30.895
So that limitation went away.

130
00:06:30.895 --> 00:06:36.698
So larger file system sizes,
larger file sizes, and more subfolders.

131
00:06:36.698 --> 00:06:38.990
That's kinda the big
advantage of going with EXT3.

132
00:06:38.990 --> 00:06:42.814
And as a result, there really
is no reason to go EXT2 anymore.

133
00:06:42.814 --> 00:06:46.808
You might as well go EXT3 and
that's that, all right?

134
00:06:46.808 --> 00:06:50.951
EXT4, though,
it had a big difference, all right?

135
00:06:50.951 --> 00:06:54.608
Under EXT3, the way the system worked,
and EXT2 for that matter,

136
00:06:54.608 --> 00:06:58.050
was that it worked using
what's called bitmapping.

137
00:06:58.050 --> 00:07:03.910
That you'd have an entry in the EXT
table that would say this file exists.

138
00:07:03.910 --> 00:07:07.720
And then it would have a bitmap,
a map that pointed to all

139
00:07:07.720 --> 00:07:10.580
the bits that made up that file that
were located out across the hard drive.

140
00:07:10.580 --> 00:07:12.970
So this map would tell you where
you could find everything.

141
00:07:12.970 --> 00:07:15.600
Whenever you looked up a file,
you'd go to this map

142
00:07:15.600 --> 00:07:18.120
to find out where all the file's bits
were and go and gather those and

143
00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:21.140
bring them back, and then you'd have
the information that's in that file.

144
00:07:21.140 --> 00:07:22.853
That's the way that they worked.

145
00:07:22.853 --> 00:07:26.683
That lookup system,
it doesn't scale terribly well.

146
00:07:26.683 --> 00:07:30.075
As your system gets bigger and bigger and
bigger and has more and more files,

147
00:07:30.075 --> 00:07:31.083
lookups take longer.

148
00:07:31.083 --> 00:07:33.519
And the bitmap becomes
harder to update and

149
00:07:33.519 --> 00:07:36.504
fragmentation on the drive
becomes a common thing.

150
00:07:36.504 --> 00:07:41.008
So it's not the most scalable for some
of the large file systems we have today.

151
00:07:41.008 --> 00:07:48.161
In EXT4, it switched to a different system
where it uses what are called extents.

152
00:07:48.161 --> 00:07:52.706
And extents are a little more
like relational database lookups,

153
00:07:52.706 --> 00:07:57.497
where instead of a straight up bitmap,
we have these queries we kinda

154
00:07:57.497 --> 00:08:02.142
run against an extent, and
an extent Can spread across i-nodes.

155
00:08:02.142 --> 00:08:06.826
And if you're not familiar with i-nodes,
anytime you write data to a disk,

156
00:08:06.826 --> 00:08:09.570
the data that we write, I might have one.

157
00:08:09.570 --> 00:08:10.580
Let's say I have one bit,

158
00:08:10.580 --> 00:08:14.120
an actual single bit of data to write,
which never happens, right?

159
00:08:14.120 --> 00:08:16.090
But when you go to write
it to the hard drive,

160
00:08:16.090 --> 00:08:18.340
hard drives don't store individual bits.

161
00:08:18.340 --> 00:08:21.600

00:08:30.310 --> 00:08:34.580

system is it was built around i-nodes, and

166
00:08:34.580 --> 00:08:37.330
it meant that our storage
was somewhat inefficient.

167
00:08:37.330 --> 00:08:41.410

00:08:41.410 --> 00:08:43.810

00:08:43.810 --> 00:08:44.786
they're more flexible.

of storing data on the drive,

00:20:17.500 --> 00:20:20.160
It can only address up to 8EB, so
that's why I've got that limit there.

380
00:20:20.160 --> 00:20:24.060
Same thing happens on the maximum
volume size, we've got 500TB tested for

381
00:20:24.060 --> 00:20:25.665
the maximum volume size and

382
00:20:25.665 --> 00:20:31.023
16EB is what the theoretical maximum for
XFS volume sizes would be.

383
00:20:32.150 --> 00:20:36.140
And then BTRFS, notice I don't have
a number, at all, not in parentheses.

384
00:20:36.140 --> 00:20:39.470
And that's because Red Hat doesn't
guarantee BTRFS at all right now.

385
00:20:39.470 --> 00:20:41.160
It's still preview functionality.

386
00:20:41.160 --> 00:20:45.595
But 8EB for the maximum file size,
16EB for maximum volume size.

387
00:20:45.595 --> 00:20:49.425
And again, that's the Linux kernel
putting that limit in place, not BTRFS.

388
00:20:49.425 --> 00:20:52.545
BTRFS can go even further,
but the Linux kernel can't.

389
00:20:52.545 --> 00:20:54.265
Eventually, that will change.

390
00:20:54.265 --> 00:20:57.912
Remember that Red Hat Enterprise Linux,
it doesn't run the latest and

391
00:20:57.912 --> 00:21:00.237
greatest kernel that's released, right?

392
00:21:00.237 --> 00:21:06.590
So I wanna say,
didn't they just approve 4.3?

393
00:21:06.590 --> 00:21:08.210
>> Somewhere in there, yeah.

394
00:21:08.210 --> 00:21:12.960
>> I wanna say 4.3 is the latest and
greatest straight out of Linux's mouth.

395
00:21:12.960 --> 00:21:16.118
But if we take look at my
version of Red Hat here now,

396
00:21:16.118 --> 00:21:19.640
I'm running 7.3 at least I think I am.

397
00:21:21.410 --> 00:21:25.010
Yeah, I'm running 7.3 which is the latest
version of RHEL that's out right now.

398
00:21:25.010 --> 00:21:29.420
I'm full up on my updates and
if I take a look at my kernel version,

399
00:21:29.420 --> 00:21:35.710
I'm running 3.10 but if the latest and
greatest is 4.3, that's a big difference.

400
00:21:35.710 --> 00:21:41.460
But remember that Red Hat is focused
on stability not focused on latest and

401
00:21:41.460 --> 00:21:42.260
greatest, right?

402
00:21:42.260 --> 00:21:44.340
If you want latest and
greatest, go to Fedora.

403
00:21:44.340 --> 00:21:46.530
But if you want stability,
Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

404
00:21:46.530 --> 00:21:50.770
>> And that's really a good philosophy
on their side of things because when you

405
00:21:50.770 --> 00:21:54.770
install Red Hat you're thinking I have
a rock solid server that is going to work

406
00:21:54.770 --> 00:21:55.580
for me, and

407
00:21:55.580 --> 00:21:58.640
then they're going to be able to support
it in case something does go wrong.

408
00:21:58.640 --> 00:22:01.930
That's why they try to stick to
things that they know works and

409
00:22:01.930 --> 00:22:04.900
that they can guarantee to you
should work in a certain way.

410
00:22:04.900 --> 00:22:08.220
So it's a good philosophy on their part,
I do believe.

411
00:22:08.220 --> 00:22:11.650
Now, Don, we've talked about
the different file systems and

412
00:22:11.650 --> 00:22:16.510
seen how large and things they can
do with file sizes and volume sizes.

413
00:22:16.510 --> 00:22:19.750
Let's just say, in for instance,
I'm throwing it out there

414
00:22:19.750 --> 00:22:23.630
I'm not the greatest systems
administrator in the world.

415
00:22:23.630 --> 00:22:26.530
I've been chucked some Red Hat and
said, get this running.

416
00:22:26.530 --> 00:22:30.410
And for whatever reason,
I've chosen EXT2 or something.

417
00:22:30.410 --> 00:22:32.910
I've chosen the wrong file system.

418
00:22:32.910 --> 00:22:33.450
What do I do?

419
00:22:33.450 --> 00:22:37.200
Do I have to blow everything away or
are there options?

420
00:22:37.200 --> 00:22:41.040
>> All right, so there's options,
and it comes down to a few things.

421
00:22:41.040 --> 00:22:44.350
But technically, look.

422
00:22:44.350 --> 00:22:46.925
I'm gonna pretend to be
official Red Hat employee here.

423
00:22:46.925 --> 00:22:48.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> For a minute, which I'm not.

424
00:22:48.260 --> 00:22:49.860
By the way, let me just say that.

425
00:22:49.860 --> 00:22:52.265
You should have chose correctly.

426
00:22:52.265 --> 00:22:55.100
[LAUGH]
>> So what you need to do now is you need

427
00:22:55.100 --> 00:22:59.270
to get a second set of disks,
partition them the way that you want,

428
00:22:59.270 --> 00:23:02.770
apply the right file system, and move
your data over to the new file system.

429
00:23:02.770 --> 00:23:06.430
Okay, it's as simple as that, so
if you add EXT3 and you wanted the EXT4.

430
00:23:06.430 --> 00:23:10.420
Or you have EXT4 and you want XFS,
or you have XFS and you want BTRFS.

431
00:23:10.420 --> 00:23:13.880
Maybe you went with BTRFS,
realized it was preview,

432
00:23:13.880 --> 00:23:16.300
now you want to go back to XFS or
something.

433
00:23:16.300 --> 00:23:19.730
Then what you need to do is create
a second volume that's formatted the right

434
00:23:19.730 --> 00:23:24.380
way, move your data over to it, and
then you can blow away the original data.

435
00:23:24.380 --> 00:23:26.190
That's it.
It's not much of a migration at

436
00:23:26.190 --> 00:23:26.710
all, is it?

437
00:23:26.710 --> 00:23:28.720
Right?
It's really just creating a whole new file

438
00:23:28.720 --> 00:23:30.040
system and moving data.

439
00:23:30.040 --> 00:23:33.420
So that's what's officially supported.

440
00:23:33.420 --> 00:23:37.080
And the reason for that,
the reason that Red Hat doesn't say, here,

441
00:23:37.080 --> 00:23:39.120
just run this utility and
you can convert it.

442
00:23:39.120 --> 00:23:42.750
Is that conversion utilities
are usually just kind of kludges or

443
00:23:42.750 --> 00:23:44.310
hacks that have been written.

444
00:23:44.310 --> 00:23:48.170
And it can lead to some really
weird things down the road, right?

445
00:23:48.170 --> 00:23:53.171
A great example is in EXT3,
you don't have extents, right?

446
00:23:53.171 --> 00:23:55.219
You still have your regular bitmaps, and

447
00:23:55.219 --> 00:23:57.628
your regular way of writing
to your file system.

448
00:23:57.628 --> 00:24:01.799
When you go into EXT4,
Now you have extents.

449
00:24:01.799 --> 00:24:06.610
Well, any new file you
create will use extents.

450
00:24:06.610 --> 00:24:11.150
Any old file will still be
using the bitmap system.

451
00:24:11.150 --> 00:24:14.830
So I've gotta go through and touch every
single file to get it switched over to

452
00:24:14.830 --> 00:24:18.090
the extents system, and if I don't
know to do that, then technically,

453
00:24:18.090 --> 00:24:21.350
I've now got a system that's
running both EXT3 and EXT4.

454
00:24:21.350 --> 00:24:25.890
And you can actually mount
an EXT3 partition as EXT4, but

455
00:24:25.890 --> 00:24:28.350
you can't go the other way around.

456
00:24:28.350 --> 00:24:31.050
So if I decide to go backwards
from EXT4 down to EXT3,

457
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:33.884
all those files that are using
extents really get hosed.

458
00:24:33.884 --> 00:24:36.848
And I can lose data,
and that's bad, right?

459
00:24:36.848 --> 00:24:41.710
Moving from EXT to XFS or EXT to BTRFS,
they're completely different.

460
00:24:41.710 --> 00:24:47.660
And so making that kind of transition,
boy, that can really lead to data loss.

461
00:24:47.660 --> 00:24:49.900
And if you've got a huge amount of data,

462
00:24:49.900 --> 00:24:54.595
you might not notice the data loss right
away, and then you end up with a problem.

463
00:24:54.595 --> 00:24:55.854
Right, I could throw a funny
story out of this one.

464
00:24:55.854 --> 00:24:59.335
>> [LAUGH]
>> I have all of my movies at home,

465
00:24:59.335 --> 00:25:02.550
I used to just have DVDs, right?

466
00:25:02.550 --> 00:25:04.450
Ripped all the DVDs to storage, and

467
00:25:04.450 --> 00:25:07.770
put them on a couple of
terrabyte volumes that I had.

468
00:25:07.770 --> 00:25:09.690
That's where all the movies are stored.

469
00:25:09.690 --> 00:25:13.418
And I did a conversion like this,
flipping from one file system to another.

470
00:25:13.418 --> 00:25:14.890
And everything seemed fine.

471
00:25:14.890 --> 00:25:16.940
And then over the next few months,

472
00:25:16.940 --> 00:25:20.530
there were occasionally movies that
I would hit, I go to watch the movie.

473
00:25:20.530 --> 00:25:25.230
And all of a sudden, a little bit of video
from one movie would get injected into

474
00:25:25.230 --> 00:25:30.220
another, and it would basically break it
up, and really, you kind of ignored it.

475
00:25:30.220 --> 00:25:34.870
It wasn't a big deal until, I think it
was Goodfellas that got inserted into

476
00:25:34.870 --> 00:25:38.105
Beauty and the Beast, if I remember right,
which is a terrible mix.

477
00:25:38.105 --> 00:25:41.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what's my solution for that?

478
00:25:41.560 --> 00:25:43.090
I have no way to see it.

479
00:25:43.090 --> 00:25:47.048
I have to watch every single movie I
own to spot the ones that had gotten

480
00:25:47.048 --> 00:25:48.148
damaged, right?

481
00:25:48.148 --> 00:25:50.631
>> You need to explain to your son why
that man was getting stabbed in the eye.

482
00:25:50.631 --> 00:25:53.433
[LAUGH]
>> You don't normally put a person in

483
00:25:53.433 --> 00:25:54.890
the trunk, but sometimes.

484
00:25:54.890 --> 00:25:57.850
So [LAUGH] that's the kind
of things that happen.

485
00:25:57.850 --> 00:26:03.250
And if you got a huge volume of data, you
can't have that, right, in a production.

486
00:26:03.250 --> 00:26:07.827
My movie's at home, who cares, but in a
production environment, if that's a sales

487
00:26:07.827 --> 00:26:12.420
database or medical records, financial
data, you can't have data loss like that.

488
00:26:12.420 --> 00:26:14.004
It is not acceptable, and so

489
00:26:14.004 --> 00:26:17.640
that's why we don't have that
official conversion supported.

490
00:26:17.640 --> 00:26:20.610
All right, but I do wanna show you
guys some of the mechanisms in there,

491
00:26:20.610 --> 00:26:23.283
cuz it's actually easy to move
from one file system to another,

492
00:26:23.283 --> 00:26:24.790
which is just a couple of commands.

493
00:26:24.790 --> 00:26:26.601
But I know I don't have
enough time in this episode.

494
00:26:26.601 --> 00:26:29.460
So maybe we'll do a part two,
and I'll kinda walk through it.

495
00:26:29.460 --> 00:26:30.885
Just know that that's
kind of a second option.

496
00:26:30.885 --> 00:26:35.515
So, your first option is, create a new
file system, move your data to it.

497
00:26:35.515 --> 00:26:37.595
It's safe, it's guaranteed to work.

498
00:26:37.595 --> 00:26:41.316
It does require that you have twice
the amount of data that you need cuz you

499
00:26:41.316 --> 00:26:44.405
gotta create a complete separate set
of storage, right, that's the negative.

500
00:26:44.405 --> 00:26:46.735
But otherwise, you know it works,
and Red Hat will support you, right?

501
00:26:48.429 --> 00:26:53.070
But the second option is, maybe we
don't go the Red Hat support way, and

502
00:26:53.070 --> 00:26:57.370
instead, we take the existing file system
as is, and we convert it in place.

503
00:26:57.370 --> 00:27:01.144
Which there are ways to do,
especially EXT2, to 3, to 4,

504
00:27:01.144 --> 00:27:03.553
those are really easy to move between.

505
00:27:03.553 --> 00:27:07.500
And so you can find stuff all over
the Internet where people are doing it.

506
00:27:07.500 --> 00:27:08.410
I wanna show you some examples,

507
00:27:08.410 --> 00:27:12.600
so that just know that you're not gonna
have Red Hat support when you do that.

508
00:27:12.600 --> 00:27:16.885
And it's a great idea, which I should've
done with my stupid movies, and I didn't.

509
00:27:16.885 --> 00:27:19.472
>> [LAUGH]
>> To run an MD5 checksum on all of your

510
00:27:19.472 --> 00:27:23.387
files, so that you can then go right
back and do the checksum again and

511
00:27:23.387 --> 00:27:27.430
verify whether any of your files
got damaged in the conversion.

512
00:27:27.430 --> 00:27:30.130
At a minimum, take a back up,
so that you can restore.

513
00:27:30.130 --> 00:27:32.540
Those are all things to think about
when you do a conversion that way.

514
00:27:32.540 --> 00:27:33.190
>> Awesome stuff.

515
00:27:33.190 --> 00:27:37.283
Well, we've learned a lot today about the
file systems, why we'd wanna choose one

516
00:27:37.283 --> 00:27:40.931

the correct path for our environments.

517
00:27:40.931 --> 00:27:44.111
And I know Don is really itching to
show us how to do some conversions, so

518
00:27:44.111 --> 00:27:44.960
that'll be cool.

519
00:27:44.960 --> 00:27:47.850
Hopefully, you'll stick around for
that, but as for this episode,

520
00:27:47.850 --> 00:27:49.120
it looks like we've come to an end.

00:27:49.120 --> 00:27:50.530
Don, thank you for joining us today.

522
00:27:50.530 --> 00:27:52.090
And we thank you guys for watching.

I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate migrating from one file system to another. They begin by showing you the officially supported method for migrating file systems which involves moving data from one disk to another with the desired file system. Then they show you how to perform an in-place file system migration by converting the file system.

00:00:28.731 --> 00:00:32.620

But it is an interesting

37
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:47.240
This is old school,
it's an ext2 file system on this drive.

00:01:47.240 --> 00:01:49.520
And it's where I'm storing my website.

39
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.740
And so I say, boy,

00:01:55.220 --> 00:01:57.840
And at a minimum,
it'd be nice to get journaling.

00:01:57.840 --> 00:02:00.140

dirty rights onto my website pages and
stuff.

So I want to get this moved over

45
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:12.940
If I wanna go XFS.

00:02:12.940 --> 00:02:14.350
I can just whip up an XFS drive.

00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:16.860

48
00:02:16.860 --> 00:02:17.470
Right.
And so

that's the way that it's recommended.

00:02:18.760 --> 00:02:20.640
And if you have a small set of data,

51
00:02:20.640 --> 00:02:21.870
Here it's just a website.

52
00:02:21.870 --> 00:02:22.880
Not a big deal.

00:02:22.880 --> 00:02:26.500

00:02:30.570 --> 00:02:34.980

equal size and
format it with the new file system and

copy all my data over and then I can

00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:44.290
Right?

That copy operation could

but for

521
00:27:37.200 --> 00:27:41.850
the time being, it's still not fully
signed off, Red Hat's really close.

522
00:27:41.850 --> 00:27:46.610
I gotta imagine it'll be RHEL 8,
where btrfs becomes the default.

523
00:27:46.610 --> 00:27:47.800
But it's just not yet.

524
00:27:49.095 --> 00:27:51.305
>> Well, Don, I guess you could always
go and hack the Red Hat website and

525
00:27:51.305 --> 00:27:52.775
change the agreement, and

526
00:27:52.775 --> 00:27:56.983
say [LAUGH] yeah we support BTRFS and
that probably won't work.

527
00:27:56.983 --> 00:27:59.695
But it is really cool that
we can do it if we want to.

528
00:27:59.695 --> 00:28:02.595
You just, like you said, you gotta be
aware that they're not gonna support it.

529
00:28:02.595 --> 00:28:03.315
If things go awry,

530
00:28:03.315 --> 00:28:08.157
you're all on your own or hope you have a
good standing at a great forum somewhere.

531
00:28:08.157 --> 00:28:08.761
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

532
00:28:08.761 --> 00:28:09.438
>> That's gonna help a lot

533
00:28:09.438 --> 00:28:10.240
in that situation.

534
00:28:10.240 --> 00:28:13.840
Don, anything else we need to know about
converting or migrating a disk in Linux?

535
00:28:13.840 --> 00:28:14.820
>> I think that's about it.

536
00:28:14.820 --> 00:28:18.210
I mean just remember, if you do have
the extra storage, do it the right way.

537
00:28:18.210 --> 00:28:20.420
Just you know, create the second set
of storage, copy your data over.

538
00:28:20.420 --> 00:28:21.730
It's not very hard.

539
00:28:21.730 --> 00:28:23.420
It does require taking
your data offline for

540
00:28:23.420 --> 00:28:24.820
a moment while you
switch the mount points.

541
00:28:24.820 --> 00:28:26.480
But other than that,
it's not a big deal, and

542
00:28:26.480 --> 00:28:28.260
you'll maintain that support
that you're paying for.

543
00:28:28.260 --> 00:28:29.990
>> That's right.
And we'll post Don's credit card

544
00:28:29.990 --> 00:28:31.333
information a little later in the show

545
00:28:31.333 --> 00:28:32.199
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

546
00:28:32.199 --> 00:28:33.360
>> So that you can do that.

547
00:28:33.360 --> 00:28:35.410
That being said, it is time for
us to get out of here.

548
00:28:35.410 --> 00:28:36.840
We thank you guys for watching.

549
00:28:36.840 --> 00:28:38.620
Don, thanks for stopping by as well.

550
00:28:38.620 --> 00:28:41.990
But signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

551
00:28:41.990 --> 00:28:42.690
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

552
00:28:42.690 --> 00:28:43.420
>> We'll see you next time.

553
00:28:43.420 --> 00:28:51.068
[MUSIC]

554
00:28:51.068 --> 00:28:53.390
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don give you a working knowledge of the XFS file system. Here they will show you how to work with XFS as your daily driver, performing tasks like creating, mounting, and repairing XFS volumes. They also show changing the XFS options like setting drive labels and/or UUID. Finally, they show you how to take a backup using `xfsdump`.
episodes.title: Working with XFS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.668
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.668 --> 00:00:08.288
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.288 --> 00:00:12.225
You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.225 --> 00:00:16.698
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:16.698 --> 00:00:20.752
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on with

6
00:00:20.752 --> 00:00:24.020
more on our
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Version 7 series.

7
00:00:24.020 --> 00:00:27.560
And coming back for a little more of that
action is our good friend, Mr Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:28.380
Don, welcome back, sir.

9
00:00:28.380 --> 00:00:29.270
How's it going?

10
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:30.370
>> It is going well, Daniel.

11
00:00:30.370 --> 00:00:33.260
And I'm back for what I promised,
at least for now.

12
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:35.208
The last were file system episodes.

13
00:00:35.208 --> 00:00:37.730
I do wanna wrap up a few more
commands on file systems,

14
00:00:37.730 --> 00:00:40.520
where we kind of check this one and
then move on to our next topic.

15
00:00:40.520 --> 00:00:43.210
But I've mentioned more than once,

16
00:00:43.210 --> 00:00:46.800
that XFS is the default file system
in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

17
00:00:46.800 --> 00:00:50.860
So if you're deploying RHEL7 on
a new system, expect to see XFS,

18
00:00:50.860 --> 00:00:53.250
that's kind of what you're gonna get.

19
00:00:53.250 --> 00:00:57.078
Well, if you're new to XFS, there's some
commands you need to be familiar with to

20
00:00:57.078 --> 00:01:00.267
make sure you know how to work with it and
understand what it expects.

21
00:01:00.267 --> 00:01:02.444
And for the most part,
this isn't anything too crazy.

22
00:01:02.444 --> 00:01:07.402
But the thing is, we've been steeped in
the EXT ecosystem for so long, EXT 2,

23
00:01:07.402 --> 00:01:11.260
EXT 3, EXT 4,
that there's commands that we're used to.

24
00:01:11.260 --> 00:01:15.600
And those commands have kinda been, well,
they've been replaced by new XFS commands.

25
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:18.150
So I just wanna run through some
of the typical scenarios of stuff

26
00:01:18.150 --> 00:01:23.490
that we're gonna use as we go about
a normal day of operation with XFS.

27
00:01:23.490 --> 00:01:26.400
So let's kick it off nice and
easy with creating an XFS file system, and

28
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:27.720
then we'll move on from there.

29
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:29.780
So if I have a partition created.

30
00:01:29.780 --> 00:01:33.460
You use fdisk, you create a partition,
you get it put in place.

31
00:01:33.460 --> 00:01:34.940
And you need to throw
a file system on there,

32
00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:38.920
we've got mkfs that'll let us
create an XFS file system.

33
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:40.540
So let me just show you
an example of that real quick.

34
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:45.516
I'm gonna do mkfs.xfs, and
then I just point it to whatever

35
00:01:45.516 --> 00:01:49.330
it is that I'm trying to
drop a file system on.

36
00:01:49.330 --> 00:01:52.426
And when you do that, it's just
gonna give you a quick set of output

37
00:01:52.426 --> 00:01:55.192
here that's gonna let you know
the sector size and B size and

38
00:01:55.192 --> 00:01:58.642
all the other different things that
it tracks that goes and creates that.

39
00:01:58.642 --> 00:02:01.546
And if there is an error,
you'd spot that error here.

40
00:02:01.546 --> 00:02:05.410
But hopefully it just drops on there and
you're in business, right?

41
00:02:05.410 --> 00:02:07.980
New file system ready to go.

42
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:10.390
And as far as mounting it, it's really
no different than anything else.

43
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:13.530
Red Hat does automatic
file system detection.

44
00:02:13.530 --> 00:02:18.210
So I can always come in and
I can say that I wanna mount /dev/sdb1.

45
00:02:18.210 --> 00:02:20.284
I'm gonna mount that to /temp.

46
00:02:21.580 --> 00:02:22.710
And it's mounted.

47
00:02:22.710 --> 00:02:24.520
And if I use the mount command
to verify what happened,

48
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:27.390
I can see right here that it mounted it.

49
00:02:27.390 --> 00:02:30.120
And it mounted it as
a file system type of XFS.

50
00:02:30.120 --> 00:02:33.730
So so far, nothing really new here,
all right?

51
00:02:33.730 --> 00:02:37.120
But one of the cool things that
we get with XFS is journaling.

52
00:02:37.120 --> 00:02:38.880
And I know I've talked about
journaling in other episodes, but

53
00:02:38.880 --> 00:02:40.460
just to recap it really quick.

54
00:02:40.460 --> 00:02:42.160
When you write to a file in XFS,

55
00:02:42.160 --> 00:02:45.520
you don't write to the actual file,
instead you write to a journal.

56
00:02:45.520 --> 00:02:48.780
And only when you have 100% written
all your data to the journal,

57
00:02:48.780 --> 00:02:50.560
does it then apply that
data to the actual file.

58
00:02:50.560 --> 00:02:54.010
And what that does is it gives us
protection in case we have a system

59
00:02:54.010 --> 00:02:59.050
interruption of some sort, power outage,
or drive cable comes loose, or whatever,

60
00:02:59.050 --> 00:03:01.700
and you're half way through a write,
if you're ever writing to the actual file

61
00:03:01.700 --> 00:03:04.400
when the system boots back up,
that file's now corrupt, we lose our data.

62
00:03:04.400 --> 00:03:06.440
It's really bad on databases.

63
00:03:06.440 --> 00:03:10.200
But with XFS it just looks at the journal
and says there's half a write here,

64
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:10.910
let's just throw it away.

65
00:03:10.910 --> 00:03:14.100
And the file stays intact,
that's what XFS does.

66
00:03:14.100 --> 00:03:17.583
Well it does that every time
you mount the partition.

67
00:03:17.583 --> 00:03:19.760
Now I just mounted this for
the first time.

68
00:03:19.760 --> 00:03:22.760
And so it's a brand new journal,
there's nothing special there.

69
00:03:22.760 --> 00:03:25.830
But if I get in and
then start to mess with it, so like if I

70
00:03:25.830 --> 00:03:30.900
copy some kind of file, I'm sure I've got
something laying around here I can copy.

71
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:34.645
So if I copy my website for example to-
>> Which is magnificent.

72
00:03:34.645 --> 00:03:36.460
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's awesome.

73
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:37.760
So if I copy that over,

74
00:03:37.760 --> 00:03:42.530
when that file copies over,
it's actually writing to the journal,

75
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:45.970
when it's done it's then turning it
into the file data and it's in place.

76
00:03:45.970 --> 00:03:48.453
So the journal is now active,
the journal has got entries in it.

77
00:03:48.453 --> 00:03:50.510
The entries should be a 100%
complete at this point.

78
00:03:50.510 --> 00:03:53.875
But maybe they're not,
if it's a massive file is still ongoing.

79
00:03:53.875 --> 00:03:58.115
So that journal is really
one of the big benefits XFS.

80
00:03:58.115 --> 00:04:02.525
And every time you mount the file system,
that's when it looks for

81
00:04:02.525 --> 00:04:05.095
incomplete journal entries and
throws them away.

82
00:04:05.095 --> 00:04:07.235
So it's not looking for
incomplete entries right now.

83
00:04:07.235 --> 00:04:08.535
If there is an incomplete entry right now,

84
00:04:08.535 --> 00:04:10.205
it assumes that you're still writing,
right?

85
00:04:10.205 --> 00:04:11.840
You just need more time to finish.

86
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:16.730
But if I reboot, or
if I unmount the folder, right?

87
00:04:16.730 --> 00:04:18.060
So I mounted it a minute ago.

88
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:26.499
If I unmount, That directory and
then remount it, right?

89
00:04:26.499 --> 00:04:29.199
That just caused the journal to
get scanned and it looked for

90
00:04:29.199 --> 00:04:31.145
any incomplete write and threw then away.

91
00:04:31.145 --> 00:04:34.310
So I had a good clean journal
when the system booted up.

92
00:04:34.310 --> 00:04:35.830
And that all happens in the backgrounds,

93
00:04:35.830 --> 00:04:38.160
we don't really get
involved in that at all.

94
00:04:38.160 --> 00:04:40.311
It's just being done by the system.

95
00:04:40.311 --> 00:04:42.348
In fact,
no matter how much you dig around,

96
00:04:42.348 --> 00:04:44.065
you don't see the journal in there.

97
00:04:44.065 --> 00:04:47.560
But it is actually kind of
parked away in the background.

98
00:04:47.560 --> 00:04:49.340
We'll see it pop up a few
different times later on.

99
00:04:50.850 --> 00:04:53.910
All right, so as far as working with it,
really not anything too crazy there.

100
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:57.720
If I ever go to mount an XFS file
system and I get a failure, right?

101
00:04:57.720 --> 00:05:00.420
Something goes wrong,
it says the file system is corrupt or

102
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:03.910
the journal is dirty or there's dirty
reads going on or something like that.

103
00:05:03.910 --> 00:05:07.570
If I get file system warnings, then I'll
probably wanna run a file system check.

104
00:05:09.320 --> 00:05:11.760
FSCK, that utility that has
been around forever and

105
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:15.270
ever, well,
it doesn't actually support XFS.

106
00:05:15.270 --> 00:05:18.090
Although Red Hat has put a little
alias wrapper onto it, so

107
00:05:18.090 --> 00:05:22.140
you can do fsck.xfx, and
point it to an XFS file system.

108
00:05:22.140 --> 00:05:26.950
What it's actually calling in the
background is a utility called xfs_repair.

109
00:05:29.770 --> 00:05:34.330
It's built in to RHEL, it's right
there and it lets you scan the system,

110
00:05:34.330 --> 00:05:38.180
and looks for corrupted files, checks the
journal, checks all the information and

111
00:05:38.180 --> 00:05:40.050
make sure the system is intact.

112
00:05:40.050 --> 00:05:41.930
We do need to unmount the disk.

113
00:05:41.930 --> 00:05:45.533
If it's a live partition,
something like the root mount point, for

114
00:05:45.533 --> 00:05:48.512
that one I would have to go into
an fstab folder and set it so

115
00:05:48.512 --> 00:05:50.893
that it would scan
the drive on the next boot.

116
00:05:50.893 --> 00:05:52.964
It would probably do it anyway
if it detected failure, so

117
00:05:52.964 --> 00:05:54.399
I probably don't even have to do that.

118
00:05:54.399 --> 00:05:57.192
But if it's something like
this that I can take offline,

119
00:05:57.192 --> 00:05:58.889
then I can always just unmount it.

120
00:06:01.095 --> 00:06:03.965
And then once it's taken offline, oops.

121
00:06:03.965 --> 00:06:07.600
[LAUGH] it's busy cuz I'm in the folder,
so let me get out of the folder.

122
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:10.119
There we go.
And so now I can come in and

123
00:06:10.119 --> 00:06:15.489
I can run exf_repair, and
I can just point it right at that disk.

124
00:06:15.489 --> 00:06:19.129
And so it runs through, there is my seven
checks that it does, comes back looks like

125
00:06:19.129 --> 00:06:22.674
everything is good, I didn't get a message
saying the file system was changed.

126
00:06:22.674 --> 00:06:25.650
And so, that means that it
didn't find any problems.

127
00:06:25.650 --> 00:06:27.933
If it found a problem I'd get a message
saying the file system was changed.

128
00:06:27.933 --> 00:06:31.160
So, easy enough to do that repair.

129
00:06:31.160 --> 00:06:35.620
For a live volume, if it reboots and
it doesn't run the file system check but

130
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:39.460
you know there's errors, then what you
need to do is edit the fstab entry.

131
00:06:39.460 --> 00:06:47.645
So if you go into /etc/fstab and
you find the entry where it's mounted.

132
00:06:47.645 --> 00:06:53.730
See this /dev/mapper/rhel-root,
this is an XFS volume.

133
00:06:53.730 --> 00:06:57.830
And if I want it to be checked the next
time it boots, I can come over here and,

134
00:06:57.830 --> 00:06:58.540
see this 0 0?

135
00:06:58.540 --> 00:07:01.170
I can take that first 0 and
just change it to a 1.

136
00:07:01.170 --> 00:07:03.890
And when you reboot that'll
force it to do a check.

137
00:07:03.890 --> 00:07:08.310
And in the past that would be FSCK,
now it's actually going to be

138
00:07:08.310 --> 00:07:13.470
xfs repair that it runs and checks a
system at boot time while it's not in use.

139
00:07:13.470 --> 00:07:15.347
So that's how we would work
around that if we had to,

140
00:07:15.347 --> 00:07:16.681
you don't normally have to do that.

141
00:07:18.694 --> 00:07:20.811
All right, now, what we've just seen,

142
00:07:20.811 --> 00:07:23.240
I know we've just kinda
covered them briefly.

143
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:24.670
Those are your typical commands.

144
00:07:24.670 --> 00:07:25.770
You create a file system,

145
00:07:25.770 --> 00:07:29.540
you mount it, maybe you have to repair
from time to time, and that's about it.

146
00:07:29.540 --> 00:07:31.920
But XFS has a lot of other features,
a lot of bells and

147
00:07:31.920 --> 00:07:33.030
whistles that make it kinda nice.

148
00:07:33.030 --> 00:07:36.290
Like we can grow the file system
if we need to, to make it bigger.

149
00:07:36.290 --> 00:07:40.800
You can turn on all sorts of crazy
backup type functionality in it.

150
00:07:40.800 --> 00:07:42.510
It's got some really advanced bells and
whistles, and

151
00:07:42.510 --> 00:07:44.640
that's what I want to spend
the rest of this episode on.

152
00:07:44.640 --> 00:07:47.970
These are features that you guys might
not use everyday, you might not use ever.

153
00:07:47.970 --> 00:07:50.590
But it's nice to learn about them and
know they exist so

154
00:07:50.590 --> 00:07:52.880
you can take advantage of them if you can,
all right?

155
00:07:52.880 --> 00:07:54.880
Well, let's talk about
growing that file system.

156
00:07:54.880 --> 00:07:59.782
When you have the file system in place,
it actually can grow,

157
00:07:59.782 --> 00:08:04.782
you've got a utility for it,
which is xfs_growfs All right,

158
00:08:04.782 --> 00:08:10.561
and if you just run that against
the file system like this /dev/sdb1.

159
00:08:10.561 --> 00:08:13.924
If I run that, it's gonna basically say,
take that volume and

160
00:08:13.924 --> 00:08:17.250
grow it to fill all the available
space on the drive.

161
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:19.420
And it'll stretch it out and
it'll grow to fill that.

162
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:23.440
Or I can go a little further and I can say
-D, and I can specify the actual size.

163
00:08:23.440 --> 00:08:27.601
So maybe I want it to grow by 10 gigs or
something.

164
00:08:27.601 --> 00:08:29.590
And so
then we can bump it up by even larger.

165
00:08:30.610 --> 00:08:36.540
But this is not really the command we
need to be using inside of Red Hat.

166
00:08:36.540 --> 00:08:39.970
At Red Hat, they really only support
one way of growing the file system and

167
00:08:39.970 --> 00:08:42.720
that's through the LVM,
the logical volume manager.

168
00:08:42.720 --> 00:08:45.010
BTRFS has LVM built-in and that's nice.

169
00:08:45.010 --> 00:08:47.430
But for everything else,
for XFS and EXT and

170
00:08:47.430 --> 00:08:50.870
those guys,
we need to have the LVM in place.

171
00:08:50.870 --> 00:08:55.390
So if you think you're going to need to
be growing your file system in the future

172
00:08:55.390 --> 00:08:59.350
then you should really consider
deploying LVM first, and

173
00:08:59.350 --> 00:09:01.910
putting your XFS volume on top of it,
right?

174
00:09:01.910 --> 00:09:05.380
And I know we covered how to
do that in other episodes, but

175
00:09:05.380 --> 00:09:07.508
just to kind of recap that real quick.

176
00:09:07.508 --> 00:09:11.030
If I wanna create a new volume for

177
00:09:11.030 --> 00:09:15.770
my XFS data to be stored in, I can come in
and I can choose the SSM to do it, right?

178
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:17.890
With the System Storage Manager.

179
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:22.170
SSM's not installed by default, though,
so I'm gonna install that real quick.

180
00:09:22.170 --> 00:09:27.308
So this is gonna be my
system-storage-manager.

181
00:09:29.487 --> 00:09:32.738
And once that's installed, I'll have
a nice little command line utility that

182
00:09:32.738 --> 00:09:34.670
makes it super easy to deploy things.

183
00:09:34.670 --> 00:09:38.300
You guys saw that when I dropped
that XFS file system on a partition,

184
00:09:38.300 --> 00:09:40.580
that was one command, and

the utility is xsfdump, right?

403
00:21:54.644 --> 00:21:56.077
A little inconsistency how they have

404
00:21:56.077 --> 00:21:57.080
underscores in some-
>> Yeah

405
00:21:57.080 --> 00:21:58.331
>> Of them and not others?

406
00:21:58.331 --> 00:22:00.882
Frustrating, but anyhow, xfsdump and

407
00:22:00.882 --> 00:22:04.640
we're gonna specify what it
is we're gonna be backing up.

408
00:22:04.640 --> 00:22:08.600
And when we back it up, there's a few
things that we have to provide, right?

409
00:22:08.600 --> 00:22:11.970
First of, we have to tell it
where we're backing up to.

410
00:22:11.970 --> 00:22:17.706
So I'm gonna back up to
/mnt/backup/websites.bak.

411
00:22:17.706 --> 00:22:19.980
All right, so
that's the backup that I'm gonna make.

412
00:22:19.980 --> 00:22:27.570
And then, I need to tell it what
my backup level is going to be.

413
00:22:27.570 --> 00:22:30.030
And the level is where things
get a little bit weird.

414
00:22:30.030 --> 00:22:32.750
A level of 0, that's a full backup.

415
00:22:32.750 --> 00:22:35.050
I'm gonna take a full
backup of the system.

416
00:22:35.050 --> 00:22:36.920
And then you've got
levels one through nine.

417
00:22:36.920 --> 00:22:39.250
And one through nine are incrementals,
right?

418
00:22:39.250 --> 00:22:42.420
And so let's say we're doing
a standard Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday,

419
00:22:42.420 --> 00:22:44.350
Thursday, Friday backup system.

420
00:22:44.350 --> 00:22:48.200
On Monday, I would run a level 0,
take a full backup.

421
00:22:48.200 --> 00:22:52.290
But on Tuesday, I'd run level 1,
that's the first incremental.

422
00:22:52.290 --> 00:22:55.440
On Wednesday, I'd run level 2,
that's the second incremental.

423
00:22:55.440 --> 00:23:00.032
On Thursday, level 3,
Friday level 4, I got that, right?

424
00:23:00.032 --> 00:23:00.600
>> Yeah.
>> So

425
00:23:00.600 --> 00:23:02.130
we're running the fourth
incremental on Friday,

426
00:23:02.130 --> 00:23:06.120
and then come the next Monday we would
switch back into a level 0 again, right?

427
00:23:06.120 --> 00:23:08.649
So you can have up to nine incrementals.

428
00:23:08.649 --> 00:23:10.537
What if you need more
than nine incrementals?

429
00:23:10.537 --> 00:23:11.162
Well too bad.

430
00:23:11.162 --> 00:23:12.858
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I'm not aware of a way.

431
00:23:12.858 --> 00:23:13.467
>> There's no way.

432
00:23:13.467 --> 00:23:15.460
>> Yeah,
I don't think there is a way to do that.

433
00:23:15.460 --> 00:23:20.040
Because the levels need to be only used
once until the next full back up, right?

434
00:23:20.040 --> 00:23:21.840
So that's how this is kind of set up here.

435
00:23:21.840 --> 00:23:25.500
So I'm just gonna say l 0,
I'm doing a full back up, all right?

436
00:23:25.500 --> 00:23:28.870
And then I just need to
give it a media name.

437
00:23:28.870 --> 00:23:30.620
Now media names really mattered on tape.

438
00:23:30.620 --> 00:23:32.810
With files, we have file names,
so it's kind of redundant, but

439
00:23:32.810 --> 00:23:33.760
I'll give it a media name.

440
00:23:33.760 --> 00:23:35.230
I'm gonna just call it website.

441
00:23:35.230 --> 00:23:38.980
And then I need to tell it a label for
that media.

442
00:23:38.980 --> 00:23:43.570
Again, labels are really handy with tape,
with files they're somewhat redundant.

443
00:23:43.570 --> 00:23:46.660
But I'll give it a label,
I'm just gonna call it my full_backup or

444
00:23:46.660 --> 00:23:50.220
you might call it like the Monday
full backup or something like that.

445
00:23:50.220 --> 00:23:52.370
And then I need to tell
it what I'm backing up.

446
00:23:52.370 --> 00:23:55.051
I'm backing up /mount/website.

447
00:23:55.051 --> 00:24:00.380
And what I'm pointing to is where that
file system is mounted, all right?

448
00:24:00.380 --> 00:24:04.374
I'm not pointing to /dev/sde1 or whatever.

449
00:24:04.374 --> 00:24:05.523
I'm pointing to where it's mounted.

450
00:24:05.523 --> 00:24:08.252
It'll find the disk based on that, right?

451
00:24:08.252 --> 00:24:10.950
And when I run that,
it's gonna reach out and

452
00:24:10.950 --> 00:24:15.080
it's gonna back up that file system and
dump it right into that file.

453
00:24:15.080 --> 00:24:18.470
All right, now that was Monday,
that was my full backup.

454
00:24:18.470 --> 00:24:21.360
When Tuesday rolls around, well.

455
00:24:21.360 --> 00:24:22.559
I just call it website.bak.

456
00:24:22.559 --> 00:24:25.812
I probably should've done something
like a one under score, two under score

457
00:24:25.812 --> 00:24:29.100
whatever to keep them separate cuz
you need each one to be separate.

458
00:24:29.100 --> 00:24:31.368
On a tape, you can just keep
appending to the same tape.

459
00:24:31.368 --> 00:24:33.590
But on a file,
it won't let you do that, so.

460
00:24:33.590 --> 00:24:36.770
What you would do is come in here and
change this to level 1.

461
00:24:36.770 --> 00:24:39.517
And, you'd specify you're media name.

462
00:24:39.517 --> 00:24:40.906
You'd give it a different label.

463
00:24:40.906 --> 00:24:44.010
So I might call this my incr_backup.

464
00:24:44.010 --> 00:24:46.720
And then, you'd specify what
you were backing up, right?

465
00:24:46.720 --> 00:24:50.210
So basically the same process,
you're just changing the level number and

466
00:24:50.210 --> 00:24:51.732
then the label, so
you can keep it straight.

467
00:24:51.732 --> 00:24:55.280
All right, but once that's backed up,

468
00:24:55.280 --> 00:25:00.910
what we'll be able to see is that
it created a little backup file.

469
00:25:00.910 --> 00:25:02.110
And my website is very,

470
00:25:02.110 --> 00:25:06.960
very small and if you look at that,
it's only 22 kilobytes in size.

471
00:25:06.960 --> 00:25:07.650
Right?

472
00:25:07.650 --> 00:25:08.690
Pretty small.

473
00:25:08.690 --> 00:25:13.480
It didn't do a bit for bit backup like
DD would've, it did a data backup.

474
00:25:13.480 --> 00:25:17.350
It got all the data that was necessary
as well as all the XFS index

475
00:25:17.350 --> 00:25:18.170
and all that stuff.

476
00:25:18.170 --> 00:25:20.780
It got all that stuff that was necessary
and it didn't get all the extra stuff.

477
00:25:20.780 --> 00:25:25.310
So that's why this is a better option
than DD for backing up an XFS volume.

478
00:25:25.310 --> 00:25:29.010
Now when it comes to restoring,
I can restore the whole thing, or

479
00:25:29.010 --> 00:25:31.180
I can restore individual files out of it.

480
00:25:31.180 --> 00:25:35.950
So if I just wanna get my
index.html file back out of it or

481
00:25:35.950 --> 00:25:41.210
something I can, or I can just
restore the whole thing if I want.

482
00:25:41.210 --> 00:25:46.840
To restore, instead of xfsdump,
we have xfsrestore, that we use.

483
00:25:46.840 --> 00:25:49.700
And that's what use to just
get that data back out again.

484
00:25:49.700 --> 00:25:54.170
And when we do it, we need to
know what it is we wanna restore.

485
00:25:54.170 --> 00:25:59.959
So before we run that, or before we get
too far, I normally start with xfsdump-I,

486
00:25:59.959 --> 00:26:04.194
which says, show me what my
backups are cuz I might not know.

487
00:26:04.194 --> 00:26:07.490
And it would give you a list of
all the backups that you've done.

488
00:26:07.490 --> 00:26:09.920
I've only done one, so
it lists it right here.

489
00:26:09.920 --> 00:26:11.840
It's my full backup.

490
00:26:11.840 --> 00:26:13.610
There's the session label and
it's got a session ID.

491
00:26:13.610 --> 00:26:17.000
And then as we look down,
you can start to see the level, so

492
00:26:17.000 --> 00:26:20.570
I know this is a full backup and
not a incremental.

493
00:26:20.570 --> 00:26:23.900
I can see it's only got one stream,
one set of data that's inside it.

494
00:26:23.900 --> 00:26:29.560
On a tape, you could have more than one
session ID inside of the same tape.

495
00:26:29.560 --> 00:26:32.989
So when you go to restore it,
you'd need to specify that session ID.

496
00:26:32.989 --> 00:26:36.650
But when you're backing up the files,
there's usually only one backup per file.

497
00:26:36.650 --> 00:26:38.410
So you don't have to worry about
session IDs and all that mess.

498
00:26:38.410 --> 00:26:39.940
It makes it a lot easier.

499
00:26:39.940 --> 00:26:47.428
So if I wanna bring my data back, I can
come in and I can say, xfsrestore-f and

500
00:26:47.428 --> 00:26:51.170
tell it the source,
where is my data coming from.

501
00:26:52.390 --> 00:26:58.383
And so mine is coming from
the /mount/backup/website.bak.

502
00:26:58.383 --> 00:27:05.135
And then where I want it to restore to,
which would be /mount/website.

503
00:27:05.135 --> 00:27:08.087
And then, it's basically just
gonna crack open that file and

504
00:27:08.087 --> 00:27:11.760
get everything that it can and
drop it off over in the destination.

505
00:27:11.760 --> 00:27:13.070
And so there it goes scanning through and

506
00:27:13.070 --> 00:27:16.020
hopefully you get this nice
little Restore Status: SUCCESS.

507
00:27:16.020 --> 00:27:18.760
Your data's been put back and
now you've recovered.

508
00:27:18.760 --> 00:27:20.770
And again, it's only restoring the data.

509
00:27:20.770 --> 00:27:23.420
It's not zeroing out sectors
that were zero beforehand.

510
00:27:23.420 --> 00:27:25.330
It didn't back that up like DD would.

511
00:27:25.330 --> 00:27:28.460
Instead it just drops it on there and
we're back in business very, very quickly.

512
00:27:28.460 --> 00:27:30.904
So xfsdump and restore works pretty well.

513
00:27:30.904 --> 00:27:37.300
Now it does get a little bit trickier if I
have incrementals, but it's not that bad.

514
00:27:37.300 --> 00:27:39.710
You just need to add a dash
r to the command line.

515
00:27:39.710 --> 00:27:43.985
So I did dash f for that source and if you
add a dash r, that makes it recursive.

516
00:27:43.985 --> 00:27:48.240
And it'll restore the full and then each
incremental after it that it finds and

517
00:27:48.240 --> 00:27:50.050
bring those back online and
get you put back in place.

518
00:27:50.050 --> 00:27:52.910
So if you've got incrementals,
you just need to go a little bit further.

519
00:27:52.910 --> 00:27:57.735
>> Don, would you say that this xfsdump

520
00:27:57.735 --> 00:28:03.420
is a better or even a replacement built
in utility for XFS enabled drives?

521
00:28:03.420 --> 00:28:05.110
Than DD, should I say.

522
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:06.200
>> Definitely better than DD.

523
00:28:06.200 --> 00:28:06.890
>> Yeah.

524
00:28:06.890 --> 00:28:11.530
>> Okay and the reason I pause here is
that, if you just have a single system and

525
00:28:11.530 --> 00:28:13.025
you're trying to script and
automate stuff.

526
00:28:13.025 --> 00:28:16.050
xfsdump, xfsrestore,
they work fine, right?

527
00:28:16.050 --> 00:28:20.870
But there's not a lot of centralized
management or reporting.

528
00:28:20.870 --> 00:28:22.450
I can't come in the morning and say,

529
00:28:22.450 --> 00:28:25.140
hm I wonder if my backups
were successful last night.

530
00:28:25.140 --> 00:28:26.150
I don't know.
I mean, I can go with,

531
00:28:26.150 --> 00:28:28.510
I see a file was created, and
I might go and check it and

532
00:28:28.510 --> 00:28:29.510
see if it got interrupted.

533
00:28:29.510 --> 00:28:33.400
You might have noticed, when I did
the xfsdump-I, it showed whether or

534
00:28:33.400 --> 00:28:34.370
not it got interrupted.

535
00:28:34.370 --> 00:28:36.690
That kind of stuff, I can go in and see.

536
00:28:36.690 --> 00:28:42.600
But there's really no substitute for
a good, centralized backup solution.

537
00:28:42.600 --> 00:28:46.790
And that means third party
software like Arcserve or

538
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:48.710
open source software like Bacula.

539
00:28:48.710 --> 00:28:53.630
Any of that stuff will usually provide
all the functions that you want and

540
00:28:53.630 --> 00:28:55.350
give you centralized management.

541
00:28:55.350 --> 00:28:57.810
Here I have to write it into
the scripts that I did.

542
00:28:57.810 --> 00:29:01.695
If I create a cron job for xfsdump, I'd
have to have it where it shot me emails

543
00:29:01.695 --> 00:29:05.000
and ran various tests to
make sure things worked.

544
00:29:05.000 --> 00:29:08.240
It's not terribly flexible,
I guess is what I'm getting at here.

545
00:29:08.240 --> 00:29:10.518
But if I'm about to replace a hard drive,

546
00:29:10.518 --> 00:29:13.680
I'll use xfsdump like crazy
cuz it's way faster than DDs.

547
00:29:13.680 --> 00:29:19.210
So I can use xfsdump to dump that file
system, change out the hard drive and

548
00:29:19.210 --> 00:29:22.200
use xfsrestore to put the file
system back on there.

549
00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:25.890
And it's way faster than DD,
knocked it out, and I'm done.

550
00:29:25.890 --> 00:29:27.580
That's usually how I end up using it.

551
00:29:27.580 --> 00:29:30.200
But, how you use it is kind of
up to you and your situation.

552
00:29:30.200 --> 00:29:33.160
>> Well it's still a really cool utility,
has a lot of flexibility, and

553
00:29:33.160 --> 00:29:35.700
the ability to do things
like incremental backups.

554
00:29:35.700 --> 00:29:38.930
I mean that's nice, it, like we said,
totally kicks the mess out of old DD,

555
00:29:38.930 --> 00:29:41.120
even though DD is a great utility.

556
00:29:41.120 --> 00:29:44.840
Everything needs to evolve and
come to a better fruition.

557
00:29:44.840 --> 00:29:47.490
This xfsdump is definitely that.

558
00:29:47.490 --> 00:29:52.120
Don, anything else we need to know
about XFS before we sign off today?

559
00:29:52.120 --> 00:29:54.160
>> That's about it, I mean there's
obviously a lot more out there.

560
00:29:54.160 --> 00:29:57.652
I went kinda quick and just covered
the major utilities that we've got to work

561
00:29:57.652 --> 00:29:59.060
with XFS and change things.

562
00:29:59.060 --> 00:30:01.095
So, that's basically it.

563
00:30:01.095 --> 00:30:03.414
But again, do your research,
jump out there.

564
00:30:03.414 --> 00:30:05.344
You'll find there is a lot other commands,
and

565
00:30:05.344 --> 00:30:07.720
we might add some additional
footage later on to cover it.

566
00:30:07.720 --> 00:30:10.580
But, I don't wanna go too
crazy on it because I

00:30:10.580 --> 00:30:13.930
know that Btrfs is coming around the
corner a lot of the stuff changes for it,

568
00:30:13.930 --> 00:30:16.170
so that's what we'll see in the future.

569
00:30:16.170 --> 00:30:19.430
>> All right, well thank you so
much for explaining XFS to us and

570
00:30:19.430 --> 00:30:21.520
how we can use it as our daily driver.

571
00:30:21.520 --> 00:30:24.970
And we do thank you guys for watching,
but it is time for us to sign off.

00:30:24.970 --> 00:30:27.500

your host Daniel Lowrie.

>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:16.870 --> 00:00:19.945
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

7

that's right it's more on our
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7 Series.

8
00:00:23.891 --> 00:00:27.548

>> It is going great Daniel,
ready to dive in and

00:00:30.722 --> 00:00:34.450
start taking a look at disk encryption
inside of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, and

12
00:00:34.450 --> 00:00:38.940
as most of you guys know, disk encryption
is somewhat important these days.

13
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:42.180
I guess we don't necessarily have
to have it, it's not on by default.

14
00:00:42.180 --> 00:00:45.470
If you install RHEL 7,
your disks are not encrypted.

15
00:00:45.470 --> 00:00:48.460
But, there's a lot of us that have
systems that are out there that we don't

16
00:00:48.460 --> 00:00:53.340

7 days a week control over.

17
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:56.070
And so there's a risk of

00:00:56.070 --> 00:00:58.050
in turn losing the data that's on them.

19
00:00:58.050 --> 00:01:02.750
Now the reason encryption is not on by
default in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is

20
00:01:02.750 --> 00:01:05.230
that a lot of us are deploying
it as a server operating system.

21
00:01:05.230 --> 00:01:08.860
And on a server,
we usually have the physical security in

22
00:01:08.860 --> 00:01:13.860
place that disc-based encryption really
doesn't provide any benefit whatsoever.

23
00:01:13.860 --> 00:01:17.800
Physically encrypting the disc really just
protects us from somebody coming in and

24
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:20.500
stealing the device, which is not normally
going to happen in the server room.

25
00:01:20.500 --> 00:01:23.380
But if you have Red Hat desktops or

26
00:01:23.380 --> 00:01:26.620
laptops that are deployed out there well,
especially laptops.

27
00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:30.550
Very easy for somebody to leave it on
a cab, get it stolen at the airport,

28
00:01:30.550 --> 00:01:33.110
or whatever, and
now you've got a laptop that has

29
00:01:33.110 --> 00:01:35.410
potentially sensitive data on
it that's been compromised.

30
00:01:35.410 --> 00:01:39.530
So what we may need to do
is to encrypt that data.

31
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:42.280
And it may not even be that we
want to necessarily do it, but

32
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:45.878
that we're required by some kind of
government regulations or guideline or

33
00:01:45.878 --> 00:01:48.372
whatever that we need to go in and
encrypt that data.

34
00:01:48.372 --> 00:01:53.006
So we have a nice little system for doing
that right inside of Red Hat called LUKS,

35
00:01:53.006 --> 00:01:54.315
which is L-U-K-S.

36
00:01:54.315 --> 00:01:58.842
And I'm not gonna lie to you, it's one of
those acronyms that's super annoying and

37
00:01:58.842 --> 00:02:00.010
nobody ever says it.

38
00:02:00.010 --> 00:02:05.380
It's the Linux Unified Key Setup
on Disk Format.

39
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:08.830
Which I know is way more words
than L-U-K-S, but It's a-

40
00:02:08.830 --> 00:02:11.110
>> They said hey, that's enough of that.

41
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:11.920
Yeah.
[LAUGH] Right.

42
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:15.770
>> When it comes to Unix acronyms
all rules are off I guess.

43
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:18.190
But, anyhow so we have this LUKS system.

44
00:02:18.190 --> 00:02:20.580
It's built right into
Red Hat enterprise Linux and

45
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:24.050
you might have even noticed it I probably
skipped over in the install episode.

46
00:02:24.050 --> 00:02:25.370

And if somebody steals this server and
