00:25:55.300 --> 00:25:58.320
runs out of the building,
they no longer have access to that SAN.

491
00:25:58.320 --> 00:26:01.120
And so they'd no longer have access to
that password to be able to decrypt and

492
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:01.990
gain access.

493
00:26:01.990 --> 00:26:03.100
And so you'd have that protection.

494
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:06.040
So you can embed the password right here.

495
00:26:06.040 --> 00:26:08.520
If you do,
you can either type the password.

496
00:26:08.520 --> 00:26:12.210
So I could type mine,
that's the password I used.

497
00:26:12.210 --> 00:26:15.650
So you can type that in, or
you can do a path to a file somewhere.

498
00:26:15.650 --> 00:26:22.190
So you might have a SAN file, server1.key
or whatever, and it's just a text file.

499
00:26:22.190 --> 00:26:25.250
And in that file all you have is what
the password for that volume is.

500
00:26:25.250 --> 00:26:26.420
So that'll work too.

501
00:26:26.420 --> 00:26:29.220
But if you just leave it as empty,
then it's gonna prompt us.

502
00:26:29.220 --> 00:26:31.050
And that's typically what we want.

503
00:26:31.050 --> 00:26:35.337
Now you might be encrypting
the master disk, your root.

504
00:26:35.337 --> 00:26:38.610
And then you have ten other
volumes that are all encrypted.

505
00:26:38.610 --> 00:26:40.850
Well, I don't want a prompt for
all ten passwords.

506
00:26:40.850 --> 00:26:45.330
So I might put all ten passwords in here,
or links to files on all ten.

507
00:26:45.330 --> 00:26:49.710
And the very first one be the root drive
or where all those other keys are stored.

508
00:26:49.710 --> 00:26:51.980
And I have to provide that one password.

509
00:26:51.980 --> 00:26:54.830
But once that's done, it can now access
all the other ones inside of it.

510
00:26:54.830 --> 00:26:57.410
So then I can use one pass phrase
to protect the whole thing,

511
00:26:57.410 --> 00:26:58.710
even though I've got ten volumes.

512
00:26:58.710 --> 00:27:01.250
So couple of different options
on how you wanna handle that.

513
00:27:01.250 --> 00:27:02.770
I'm gonna leave mine blank,
though, so it will prompt.

514
00:27:02.770 --> 00:27:06.140
If anybody reboots the server,
it's gonna prompt, all right.

515
00:27:06.140 --> 00:27:07.980
So I'll go ahead and save that.

516
00:27:07.980 --> 00:27:10.700
So now when the system boots up,
it hits crypttab.

517
00:27:10.700 --> 00:27:15.460
It goes to open sdb1, prompts me for
the passphrase, and then it's open.

518
00:27:15.460 --> 00:27:19.370
And then it hits fstab, and
it's able to mount it and bring it online.

519
00:27:19.370 --> 00:27:22.357
And so now, everything's gonna
access in the way that we want.

520
00:27:22.357 --> 00:27:26.188
And we're in business, okay?

521
00:27:26.188 --> 00:27:29.680
Once that's done,
that's pretty much all we need there.

522
00:27:31.140 --> 00:27:34.570
As far as cryptsetup is concerned,
that's really, well,

523
00:27:34.570 --> 00:27:36.560
I guess we can go a little bit further.

524
00:27:36.560 --> 00:27:39.760
I might have things like SELinux and stuff
that I have to manage for this volume.

525
00:27:39.760 --> 00:27:41.350
And I do all that stuff like normal.

526
00:27:41.350 --> 00:27:42.860
None of that's really any different.

527
00:27:42.860 --> 00:27:45.520
But I mentioned you could do
more than one pass phrase.

528
00:27:45.520 --> 00:27:47.390
I've got one pass phrase for me.

529
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:49.970
What if I wanna add a pass phrase for
Daniel, right?

530
00:27:49.970 --> 00:27:51.550
So that's not that hard to do.

531
00:27:51.550 --> 00:27:53.517
All we do is [CROSSTALK]
>> It's dangerous.

532
00:27:53.517 --> 00:27:54.999
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It is.

533
00:27:56.803 --> 00:28:00.210
Remember, we don't want to just share
one key because it is dangerous, right?

534
00:28:00.210 --> 00:28:02.770
You have an employee who get disgruntled,
or you let somebody go,

535
00:28:02.770 --> 00:28:04.820
you don't wanna have to go and
reset all these keys.

536
00:28:04.820 --> 00:28:08.790
So we can use cryptsetup, and
we can add more keys, right?

537
00:28:08.790 --> 00:28:13.089
So I can say,
sudo cryptsetup LuksAddKey, and

538
00:28:13.089 --> 00:28:15.570
then the device that I'm adding a key to.

539
00:28:15.570 --> 00:28:17.798
So I might want to add it to /dev/sdb1.

540
00:28:17.798 --> 00:28:20.084
Now it's gonna be mad.

541
00:28:20.084 --> 00:28:22.348
I think it's gonna be mad
because I'm mounted right now.

542
00:28:24.004 --> 00:28:29.838
Let's see, I'm pretty sure we have to
unmount this thing, Before we do this.

543
00:28:31.964 --> 00:28:33.045
I have no idea what I just typed.

544
00:28:33.045 --> 00:28:37.741
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyhow, let's see.

545
00:28:37.741 --> 00:28:39.294
You know what?
Actually, I'm doing this wrong, anyway.

546
00:28:39.294 --> 00:28:40.389
Let me back up.

547
00:28:40.389 --> 00:28:44.030
So I'm sudo-ing this.

548
00:28:44.030 --> 00:28:47.560
Technically, you don't have to be
a full-blown administrator to do this.

549
00:28:47.560 --> 00:28:51.960
Anybody who currently has a pass phrase
can add somebody else's pass phrase.

550
00:28:51.960 --> 00:28:55.240
If you have access to the data, you can
give somebody else access to the data.

551
00:28:55.240 --> 00:28:58.580
So when I the LuxAddKey,
the first thing it's asking me is not for

552
00:28:58.580 --> 00:29:00.345
what the new phrase is,
which is what I was typing.

553
00:29:00.345 --> 00:29:03.452
It's asking me to enter
any existing pass phrase.

554
00:29:03.452 --> 00:29:06.450
So anybody who's got a current key,
they need to punch that in.

555
00:29:06.450 --> 00:29:11.140
So I'm going to punch in
what my key is there.

556
00:29:11.140 --> 00:29:15.650
And now it verifies my key, and
it'll let me add an additional key.

557
00:29:15.650 --> 00:29:18.430
Now Red Hat recommends that
you do no more than eight.

558
00:29:18.430 --> 00:29:19.396
After you get past eight keys,

559
00:29:19.396 --> 00:29:21.076
it just starts becoming
really difficult to manage.

560
00:29:21.076 --> 00:29:22.630
And LUKS doesn't do so well with it.

561
00:29:22.630 --> 00:29:24.354
So I'm gonna add another one.

562
00:29:27.813 --> 00:29:29.925
And I'll type it twice.

563
00:29:32.868 --> 00:29:36.350
And there we go, and what it's
doing is it's adding another key.

564
00:29:36.350 --> 00:29:38.810
Not adding another key
to decrypt the disk,

565
00:29:38.810 --> 00:29:41.820
adding another key to allow
decrypting the master key.

566
00:29:41.820 --> 00:29:42.858
So the master key is the same.

567
00:29:42.858 --> 00:29:44.892
It's this pass phrase that's different.

568
00:29:44.892 --> 00:29:46.590
And actually it didn't make me dismount,
so there we go.

569
00:29:46.590 --> 00:29:50.560
So that worked, and
now I've got a second key assigned.

570
00:29:50.560 --> 00:29:51.980
And so now I can give that one to Daniel.

571
00:29:51.980 --> 00:29:53.280
Hey, Daniel, here's your key.

572
00:29:53.280 --> 00:29:53.890
He's got his.

573
00:29:53.890 --> 00:29:55.050
I've got mine.

574
00:29:55.050 --> 00:30:00.600
And then if we let him go, or whatever,
things don't work out, as they tend to do.

575
00:30:00.600 --> 00:30:05.110
>> How about I'm temporarily helping out
with administrative duties on the disk?

576
00:30:05.110 --> 00:30:05.880
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

577
00:30:05.880 --> 00:30:07.171
>> Yeah, so that's gonna happen.

578
00:30:07.171 --> 00:30:07.775
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

579
00:30:07.775 --> 00:30:09.460
>> So you're a contractor.

580
00:30:09.460 --> 00:30:10.690
You come in, you do your work.

581
00:30:10.690 --> 00:30:13.460
The contract's over, so
I just need to remove that access.

582
00:30:13.460 --> 00:30:18.276
I can come in, and
we just do LuksRemoveKey, right?

583
00:30:18.276 --> 00:30:21.630
And then we enter the pass
phrase that we wanna remove.

584
00:30:21.630 --> 00:30:27.170
And so I punch in his key, and
then it's gonna remove that key.

585
00:30:27.170 --> 00:30:29.209
The master key stays the same, but

586
00:30:29.209 --> 00:30:32.620
his key is no longer valid for
decrypting the master key.

587
00:30:32.620 --> 00:30:34.887
Mine is still valid, his is gone, right?

588
00:30:34.887 --> 00:30:40.490
So easy to add keys, and remove keys after
the fact, to give people temporary access.

589
00:30:40.490 --> 00:30:42.879
So, all right,
once that's done, we're online.

590
00:30:42.879 --> 00:30:43.958
We're in business.

591
00:30:43.958 --> 00:30:45.530
We just treat it like a normal disk.

592
00:30:45.530 --> 00:30:47.789
At this point, we kinda ignore
the decryption going on in the background.

593
00:30:47.789 --> 00:30:52.018
It is seamless to us, seamless to
the services, and you're in business.

594
00:30:52.018 --> 00:30:53.272
That's effectively LUKS.

595
00:30:53.272 --> 00:30:57.292
>> Yeah, and what's cool about it was that
if you have a pretty good idea of how to,

596
00:30:57.292 --> 00:31:00.292
at this point, you should,
of how to do the disk mounting,

597
00:31:00.292 --> 00:31:03.138
creating volumes,
all that other good stuff.

598
00:31:03.138 --> 00:31:07.930
All you're doing now is basically adding
how to encrypt them on top of that.

599
00:31:07.930 --> 00:31:09.050
So it's just one little thing.

600
00:31:09.050 --> 00:31:11.341
It seems like a lot because it took us 30
minutes to do this and Don explaining it.

601
00:31:11.341 --> 00:31:13.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> But really he just added one thing,

602
00:31:13.450 --> 00:31:17.070
which is here's how to encrypt it and
make sure that encryption works.

603
00:31:17.070 --> 00:31:19.370
Plus all the other stuff you
already know about using disk and

604
00:31:19.370 --> 00:31:20.230
managing file systems.

605
00:31:20.230 --> 00:31:22.425
So pretty simple, not too bad.

606
00:31:22.425 --> 00:31:24.700
I thought it was actually gonna be
a whole lot more difficult than it was.

607
00:31:24.700 --> 00:31:27.230
Don you made it look very seamless,
very easy.

608
00:31:27.230 --> 00:31:30.580
So that being said, I'm looking at our
clock, you know what else is easy?

609
00:31:30.580 --> 00:31:32.225
Is the time has expired.

610
00:31:32.225 --> 00:31:33.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's easy for us to close it down.

611
00:31:33.940 --> 00:31:38.010
So Don, thank you, very much, for
explaining encryption on disks for

612
00:31:38.010 --> 00:31:39.000
us using LUKS.

613
00:31:39.000 --> 00:31:42.100
We thank you guys for joining us today,
but we are ready to sign off.

614
00:31:42.100 --> 00:31:44.480
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

615
00:31:44.480 --> 00:31:45.395
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

616
00:31:45.395 --> 00:31:50.870
>> We'll see you next time.

617
00:31:50.870 --> 00:31:53.578
[MUSIC]

618
00:31:53.578 --> 00:31:57.260
>> Thank you for watching ITproTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look into managing Security-Enhanced Linux or SE-Linux. The goal of this episode is to equip you for working in an SE-Linux environment which includes learning the SE-Linux Modes, checking and changing status, and finally configuring SE-Linux to working with both standard and non-standard services.
episodes.title: Managing SELinux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.084 --> 00:00:03.115
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.115 --> 00:00:04.774
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:04.774 --> 00:00:05.380
California.

4
00:00:05.380 --> 00:00:06.900
>> [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.900 --> 00:00:08.224
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.224 --> 00:00:11.874
>> You're watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:11.874 --> 00:00:13.942
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

8
00:00:13.942 --> 00:00:16.470
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

9
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:19.613
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

10
00:00:19.613 --> 00:00:24.780
we are continuing on moving forward on our
Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 7 series.

11
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:27.650
And joining us back for a little more
of that action, is our good friend and

12
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:29.270
mentor, Mr. Don Pezet.

13
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:31.160
Don, welcome back sir, how's it going?

14
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:33.780
>> It is going great Daniel, I'm actually
really excited about this episode,

15
00:00:33.780 --> 00:00:36.630
because we're gonna be tackling SELinux,

16
00:00:36.630 --> 00:00:41.060
which is the security enhanced Linux,
that's found in Redhat Enterprise Linux.

17
00:00:41.060 --> 00:00:42.254
>> I thought it was a myth.

18
00:00:42.254 --> 00:00:45.290
[LAUGH]
>> I know, we've mentioned it in almost

19
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:48.030
every single stinking episode
we filmed on this content.

20
00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:51.390
And it's because it's such an integral
part of Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

21
00:00:51.390 --> 00:00:56.300
For those of you who haven't heard of
SELinux, it's a special security sublayer

22
00:00:56.300 --> 00:01:00.420
that's been added onto the Linux
operating system, and technically,

23
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:01.700
any distro can use it.

24
00:01:01.700 --> 00:01:04.285
But Red Hat is really the company
that pushed it forward and

25
00:01:04.285 --> 00:01:05.840
even got it put in place.

26
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:11.299
And what it's designed to do is
to give us fine grained granular

27
00:01:11.299 --> 00:01:16.254
control of file access for
people and software and so on.

28
00:01:16.254 --> 00:01:20.794
It really improves the way the security
is managed inside of Linux.

29
00:01:20.794 --> 00:01:25.089
Think about traditional Unix
file permissions, right?

30
00:01:25.089 --> 00:01:29.103
When we talk about POSIX file permissions
and stuff that you have the UGO,

31
00:01:29.103 --> 00:01:31.637
the User, the Group, and the Other, right?

32
00:01:31.637 --> 00:01:32.462
Let me get in here,

33
00:01:32.462 --> 00:01:36.010
and instead of just rattling on,
let me show you guys as an example.

34
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:38.890
Let me get into my website here.

35
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:42.610
All right, so,
when I look at normal files,

36
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:44.620
they've got permissions over here, right?

37
00:01:44.620 --> 00:01:47.180
And you've got the first little bit
here that identifies whether we're

38
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:48.590
a directory or not.

39
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:51.570
And then the next three
values are the user values.

40
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:55.660
Whoever owns this file is the user, and
they've got read and write, or read,

41
00:01:55.660 --> 00:01:57.130
write, and execute, or whatever.

42
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:00.880
The next block, that's the group, and
what permissions they would have.

43
00:02:00.880 --> 00:02:04.500
And then everybody else,
that's the other, U-G-O.

44
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:05.680
Here's the user.

45
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:08.270
Here's the group, and
then the other is everybody else.

46
00:02:08.270 --> 00:02:11.030
Well, that only gives me so much control.

47
00:02:11.030 --> 00:02:11.650
It's just one group.

48
00:02:11.650 --> 00:02:14.890
It's just one user, and then there's
everybody else, and that's it.

49
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:17.960
What if I want five groups to have access?

50
00:02:17.960 --> 00:02:19.340
Well, I've gotta create five groups.

51
00:02:19.340 --> 00:02:20.450
I've gotta create a sixth group.

52
00:02:20.450 --> 00:02:23.500
Put the five all in that sixth group,
and then you get into nesting, and

53
00:02:23.500 --> 00:02:25.210
it gets really complex really fast.

54
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:28.310
It's just not very flexible,
and if you wanna go per file,

55
00:02:28.310 --> 00:02:30.000
it gets even more complex.

56
00:02:30.000 --> 00:02:33.360
It's also limited to just files,
so it doesn't go beyond that.

57
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:38.790
If I have ports, or even like virtual
services I want people to access,

58
00:02:38.790 --> 00:02:40.050
they don't have file
permissions like this.

59
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:42.560
So, it's really limited, but that's okay,

60
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:46.800
cuz this is just how it was designed back
in the 1970s, a long, long time ago.

61
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:48.668
Security needs were different then.

62
00:02:48.668 --> 00:02:52.580
>> So, what SELinux does, is it bolts
on on top of all this, and it creates

63
00:02:52.580 --> 00:02:58.290
security policies, which are mandatory
access controls, or access control lists

64
00:02:58.290 --> 00:03:03.730
that dictate this software is allowed
to access these things, and that's it.

65
00:03:03.730 --> 00:03:05.380
It's not allowed to access anything else.

66
00:03:05.380 --> 00:03:08.610
And this user is allowed to access
these other things, and that's it,

67
00:03:08.610 --> 00:03:10.190
not allowed to access anything else.

68
00:03:10.190 --> 00:03:13.390
And you can get extremely
specific with it.

69
00:03:13.390 --> 00:03:14.730
Now, what is that important?

70
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:18.620
It's important because if somebody
hacks into your Red Hat Server, and

71
00:03:18.620 --> 00:03:22.010
they compromise Apache, well,
if they compromise it, and

72
00:03:22.010 --> 00:03:26.510
that service is run as root, for example,
which it shouldn't be, but if it is,

73
00:03:27.520 --> 00:03:30.370
they now have root access to the whole
box, they can access whatever they want.

74
00:03:30.370 --> 00:03:32.180
But in SELinux, I can say, you know what?

75
00:03:32.180 --> 00:03:33.930
I don't care if Apache has run its root.

76
00:03:33.930 --> 00:03:37.452
The Apache services only allowed to access
to these files and folders and that's it.

77
00:03:37.452 --> 00:03:39.600
They're not allowed to
access anything else.

78
00:03:39.600 --> 00:03:40.370
And so now, yes,

79
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:45.460
Apache might be fully compromised, but
they can't access the rest of the system.

80
00:03:45.460 --> 00:03:48.870
We've kind of jailed,
we've restricted each service, or

81
00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:52.220
each user to just the little
areas they're allowed to access.

82
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:56.520
Now, when you install Red Hat Enterprise
Linux, SELinux is already installed and

83
00:03:56.520 --> 00:03:57.680
turned on.

84
00:03:57.680 --> 00:04:00.830
Already there, in all the different
installation modes that we've picked,

85
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:05.610
from minimal all the way up to full server
with GUI, they're all there, right?

86
00:04:05.610 --> 00:04:09.120
And if you're just deploying standard
services, you can kind of ignore it.

87
00:04:09.120 --> 00:04:10.950
You don't really have to worry about it.

88
00:04:10.950 --> 00:04:15.180
But it won't be long until
you customize a service or

89
00:04:15.180 --> 00:04:19.752
install a non-standard service, and you
bump into SELinux and stuff doesn't work.

90
00:04:19.752 --> 00:04:21.830
Right, let me show you
what that looks like.

91
00:04:21.830 --> 00:04:25.240
So, I've got this folder, /mnt/website.

92
00:04:25.240 --> 00:04:26.360
In some of the other episodes,

93
00:04:26.360 --> 00:04:29.030
I have mentioned how I wanna move
my website to a different volume.

94
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:32.180
And so I've got this one mounted, it's
actually mounted on an encrypted volume,

95
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:34.700
so I've got this from kinda
pushed off to the side.

96
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:39.088
I wanna put my website here, and

556
00:27:47.030 --> 00:27:51.810
So what we do, is we need to
feed that log into audit2allow.

00:27:51.810 --> 00:27:52.790
There's a few ways to do that.

558
00:27:52.790 --> 00:27:56.880
You can take the deny lines of the log and
put it in a text file and feed that to it.

00:27:56.880 --> 00:28:01.790
But what I normally do, if you have a nice
clean log, if it's a new system that

560
00:28:01.790 --> 00:28:04.840
you're testing the software on, which is
what you're supposed to do by the way.

561
00:28:04.840 --> 00:28:08.210
Then you can just take that log file and
feed it right into that.

562
00:28:08.210 --> 00:28:12.630
So what I'll do is something like grep.

563
00:28:13.780 --> 00:28:14.970
And I'll look for my service.

564
00:28:14.970 --> 00:28:16.880
Remember this is custom,
it's whatever you called it.

565
00:28:16.880 --> 00:28:18.550
It might be Don's Demon or whatever.

566
00:28:18.550 --> 00:28:20.140
I'm just gonna do httpd.

567
00:28:20.140 --> 00:28:26.956
So I'm gonna look for
the httpd string in /var/log/audit.log.

568
00:28:26.956 --> 00:28:29.800
And the reason I'm using grep on this one,

569
00:28:29.800 --> 00:28:35.530
is I don't want to get denies from other
software that I may not want to permit.

570
00:28:35.530 --> 00:28:38.995
I just wanna focus on my custom software
here, so I'm doing just that service.

571
00:28:38.995 --> 00:28:44.860
And I'm gonna take that, and
I'm gonna feed that into audit2allow.

572
00:28:44.860 --> 00:28:47.290
Now when I ran audit2allow a moment ago,
it just sat there.

573
00:28:47.290 --> 00:28:49.250
And the reason is, it was expecting input.

574
00:28:49.250 --> 00:28:53.180
Well I'm gonna be taking
the output of my grep command and

575
00:28:53.180 --> 00:28:54.610
piping it into audit2allow.

576
00:28:54.610 --> 00:28:56.760
So now it has something to do, all right?

577
00:28:56.760 --> 00:28:59.040
And I don't want to go too crazy on this,
so

578
00:28:59.040 --> 00:29:04.720
I'm gonna do a -m which
tells it just to monitor.

579
00:29:04.720 --> 00:29:06.290
Show me what you find.

580
00:29:06.290 --> 00:29:08.810
Okay, so take a look in there and
show me what you find.

581
00:29:08.810 --> 00:29:09.800
And I need it to tell it.

582
00:29:09.800 --> 00:29:14.080
Or, I'm sorry,
I'm getting this a little wrong.

583
00:29:14.080 --> 00:29:16.710
-m, I'm telling it the module
I want to look for.

584
00:29:16.710 --> 00:29:19.210
And the module I want is httpd.

585
00:29:19.210 --> 00:29:21.100
I need to do -w.

586
00:29:21.100 --> 00:29:22.811
Which is gonna wrap on me here.

587
00:29:22.811 --> 00:29:23.736
There we go.

588
00:29:23.736 --> 00:29:26.900
-w, and the w is what's telling
it I want it to monitor.

589
00:29:26.900 --> 00:29:27.790
Tell me why.

590
00:29:27.790 --> 00:29:29.080
Tell me why things got blocked.

591
00:29:29.080 --> 00:29:32.110
And so it's gonna look at the denies and
tell me what happened, right?

592
00:29:32.110 --> 00:29:34.020
So this isn't gonna change anything.

593
00:29:34.020 --> 00:29:36.620
It's just gonna interpret the logs for me.

594
00:29:36.620 --> 00:29:41.145
And when I run that It's gonna take a look
and assuming that I get my path right,

595
00:29:41.145 --> 00:29:46.480
/var/log/audit.log.

596
00:29:46.480 --> 00:29:47.490
There we go.

597
00:29:47.490 --> 00:29:51.220
It tries to convert those
denies into plain english.

598
00:29:51.220 --> 00:29:57.080
This one, Missing a type enforcement allow
rule, it's not allowed to access MNT_T.

599
00:29:57.080 --> 00:30:00.610
So it's telling me what's wrong and
it's highlighting all those denies.

600
00:30:00.610 --> 00:30:03.560
So now I'm just looking at the denies,
right?

601
00:30:03.560 --> 00:30:08.120
And I can go a step further and
I can get rid of that -w and

602
00:30:08.120 --> 00:30:13.890
I can change the -m from
a lowercase m to a capital M.

603
00:30:13.890 --> 00:30:18.370
And what's that's gonna do is it's gonna
say, I want to do this for this module,

604
00:30:18.370 --> 00:30:22.680
but I need you to create for
me a policy file that matches for

605
00:30:22.680 --> 00:30:25.680
that module that will allow
it to do what it needs to do.

606
00:30:25.680 --> 00:30:28.678
So, when I run that,
it generates a file for me,

607
00:30:28.678 --> 00:30:34.210
httpd.pp, right, pp is for policy package.

608
00:30:34.210 --> 00:30:38.750
It's a binary file that's made that
has all the settings necessary

609
00:30:38.750 --> 00:30:40.239
to allow httpd to work.

610
00:30:41.720 --> 00:30:44.754
And all I have to do
import that policy in and

611
00:30:44.754 --> 00:30:48.580
now SELinux knows how to
handle my custom software.

612
00:30:48.580 --> 00:30:53.350
So this might be Don's Demon.pp and
I can import that in and

613
00:30:53.350 --> 00:30:55.910
it doesn't matter that no one else in
the world has ever heard of this thing,

614
00:30:55.910 --> 00:30:59.180
now SELinux will know what exactly
what to allow for that software.

615
00:30:59.180 --> 00:31:05.960
So all I have to do is say semodule -i,
cuz I'm importing.

616
00:31:05.960 --> 00:31:10.570
And I'm gonna import that module.

617
00:31:10.570 --> 00:31:13.130
And that's gonna bring it
into my system policy.

618
00:31:13.130 --> 00:31:16.160
So it's gonna become a part of
the SELinux security policy.

619
00:31:16.160 --> 00:31:20.180
And if somebody ever resets the file
system to default policies.

620
00:31:20.180 --> 00:31:22.620
My policy will still be there,
and so it will read that.

621
00:31:22.620 --> 00:31:24.040
My software will continue to work.

622
00:31:24.040 --> 00:31:26.180
This is what we really want, right?

623
00:31:26.180 --> 00:31:31.850
And now that it's there, I can make sure
that it worked by doing an semodule -l and

624
00:31:31.850 --> 00:31:34.080
that will list all the modules,
so you can go through and

625
00:31:34.080 --> 00:31:37.420
see if your custom software is now on
that list, right, which it should be.

626
00:31:37.420 --> 00:31:40.690
Mine was technically already
there because httpd is standard.

627
00:31:40.690 --> 00:31:43.724
But if you added your own,
then it would be something new.

628
00:31:43.724 --> 00:31:45.018
All right.

629
00:31:45.018 --> 00:31:47.940
Now that it's there, what do I do?

630
00:31:47.940 --> 00:31:49.510
Well, it's there.

631
00:31:49.510 --> 00:31:51.238
The policy's in place.

632
00:31:51.238 --> 00:31:54.898
What I should be able to do
is turn off permissive mode.

633
00:31:54.898 --> 00:31:56.584
So I'm gonna do a.

634
00:31:56.584 --> 00:32:00.680
setenforce enforcing.

635
00:32:00.680 --> 00:32:01.400
Right?

636
00:32:01.400 --> 00:32:07.249
And I can do an sestatus and
make sure that I am enforcing.

637
00:32:07.249 --> 00:32:12.510
And if I restart,
I'm not sure If I have to restart HTTPd or

638
00:32:12.510 --> 00:32:14.050
not but I'm gonna restart anyway.

639
00:32:15.480 --> 00:32:19.725
So I'm gonna restart it, and
now it should work, right?.

640
00:32:19.725 --> 00:32:24.038
If I go back here, let me get a clean
Firefox instance up and going.

641
00:32:27.050 --> 00:32:30.507
And as soon as that comes
up I'm gonna try and

642
00:32:30.507 --> 00:32:34.163
browse to my system and
we'll see what we get.

643
00:32:34.163 --> 00:32:36.300
And there it is,
I get Don's Super Awesome Website.

644
00:32:36.300 --> 00:32:39.360
If I add test.html to
the end I get the test site.

645
00:32:39.360 --> 00:32:40.790
Everything's working, all right.

646
00:32:40.790 --> 00:32:43.383
I didn't have to go through and figure
out the individual folders and stuff.

647
00:32:43.383 --> 00:32:45.810
The policy takes care of it.

648
00:32:45.810 --> 00:32:50.483
And if I look at that from the file
system's point of view, And

649
00:32:50.483 --> 00:32:55.391
I look inside of /mnt,
see how the website still has mnt_t?

650
00:32:55.391 --> 00:33:01.590
And if I look inside of that, even these
guys, they've got the wrong policy, right?

651
00:33:01.590 --> 00:33:02.590
But that's okay.

652
00:33:02.590 --> 00:33:05.320
Because the policy that we
loaded into the system policy

653
00:33:05.320 --> 00:33:07.310
overrides the context that's here.

654
00:33:07.310 --> 00:33:09.390
Yes, the context is mnt_t.

655
00:33:09.390 --> 00:33:11.302
But HTTPd, in this one case,

656
00:33:11.302 --> 00:33:15.446
is allowed to access it because
that's what our policy states.

657
00:33:15.446 --> 00:33:17.310
So I don't even have to go and
adjust these files.

658
00:33:17.310 --> 00:33:20.533
That's why I don't care if somebody
resets these to defaults anymore.

659
00:33:20.533 --> 00:33:22.266
Because my policy is still there and

660
00:33:22.266 --> 00:33:25.440
HTTPd can function the way
that it needs to function.

661
00:33:25.440 --> 00:33:27.930
It's not hard to do,
it just takes a few minutes.

662
00:33:27.930 --> 00:33:30.960
And I can support standard software and
custom software, and

663
00:33:30.960 --> 00:33:33.030
I didn't have to disable SELinux.

664
00:33:33.030 --> 00:33:34.460
>> Wow, that's really interesting.

665
00:33:34.460 --> 00:33:37.530
So instead of having to work with
each individual folder, directory,

666
00:33:37.530 --> 00:33:39.740
whatever, you just do it in SELinux.

667
00:33:39.740 --> 00:33:44.090
And say, here's a new policy, I don't care
what's going on inside the file structure.

668
00:33:44.090 --> 00:33:45.879
This is what I want you to be able to do,
and

669
00:33:45.879 --> 00:33:49.830
SELinux looks at itself instead of looking
at the files to see what the context is.

670
00:33:49.830 --> 00:33:53.480
>> Yep, the only negative is
if this is custom software,

00:33:53.480 --> 00:33:55.620
every time your dev team says hey,

00:33:55.620 --> 00:33:59.660
you need to say wait a minute,
give me a copy of that.

00:33:59.660 --> 00:34:01.560
And you need to run that test.

674
00:34:01.560 --> 00:34:04.960
Bring up a brand new Red Hat Enterprise
Linux box, run the software,

675
00:34:04.960 --> 00:34:06.433
generate an SELinux policy.

676
00:34:06.433 --> 00:34:09.125
It's just a file, that HTTPd.pp file.

677
00:34:09.125 --> 00:34:13.003
I could take that and copy it to

678
00:34:13.003 --> 00:34:15.550
And now we're ready to push
that new deployment, right?

679
00:34:15.550 --> 00:34:18.480
So we need to make sure we test that
custom software before we roll it out.

680
00:34:18.480 --> 00:34:19.900
Standard software,
we wouldn't have to worry about so

681
00:34:19.900 --> 00:34:21.390
much, but custom software, we would.

682
00:34:21.390 --> 00:34:22.700
>> All right, very cool.

SELinux, obviously,

we have to learn them just

00:34:38.407 --> 00:34:41.900
And I know old dogs and

00:34:41.900 --> 00:34:46.200
it's not that difficult and

00:34:47.920 --> 00:34:49.867
>> One thing I didn't mention, Daniel,

SELinux can manage ports,

00:35:04.490 --> 00:35:05.800
SELinux controls that.

00:35:05.800 --> 00:35:08.710
So I'll put some notes in the show notes

00:35:08.710 --> 00:35:09.380

00:35:09.380 --> 00:35:12.300
But just be aware,

00:35:12.300 --> 00:35:13.590

704
00:35:13.590 --> 00:35:14.460
>> Really cool.

00:35:14.460 --> 00:35:15.351

SELinux is not the big demon

>> [LAUGH]

>> That being said,

00:26:37.596 --> 00:26:40.515
I haven't added any protocol or
sources to mess with, but

515
00:26:40.515 --> 00:26:42.910
all those things are right
there in the GUI too.

516
00:26:42.910 --> 00:26:46.774
So it's just a all around more
robust solution than iptables was,

517
00:26:46.774 --> 00:26:48.638
from a usability perspective.

518
00:26:48.638 --> 00:26:49.790
>> Yeah, and that makes sense.

519
00:26:49.790 --> 00:26:54.400
I'm a long term iptables user,
Don has used iptables as well.

520
00:26:54.400 --> 00:26:57.332
Really if you've been working in
a Linux environment, whatsoever.

521
00:26:57.332 --> 00:27:01.820
IP tables has been your firewall for
quite some time, and he's totally right.

522
00:27:01.820 --> 00:27:05.857
It gets a little convoluted with
the switches and the read domain page.

523
00:27:05.857 --> 00:27:09.709
It can be a little daunting, even though
we had to do a lot of dash-dash-this and

524
00:27:09.709 --> 00:27:10.750
dash-dash-that.

525
00:27:10.750 --> 00:27:14.360
Human readable words make this
a whole lot easier to work with.

526
00:27:14.360 --> 00:27:16.960
And Don,
you've done a fantastic job as normal

527
00:27:16.960 --> 00:27:19.410
of showing us how to at least
get our feet wet in it.

528
00:27:19.410 --> 00:27:22.030
>> Yeah, the hardest part
with firewall cmd is simply

529
00:27:22.030 --> 00:27:23.630
remembering the command line.

530
00:27:23.630 --> 00:27:25.950
There's a lot of dash dash this and
dash dash that.

531
00:27:25.950 --> 00:27:28.793
But you can pull up the manual file for
firewall dash cmd.

532
00:27:28.793 --> 00:27:31.153
It is the default firewall in
Red Hat Enterprise Linux, so

533
00:27:31.153 --> 00:27:34.310
whether you're setting up a server or
workstation it's there.

534
00:27:34.310 --> 00:27:38.180
Easy to work with, no more mucking about
on the config files if you don't want to.

535
00:27:38.180 --> 00:27:40.865
You can do everything right from
the command line, it's pretty easy to use.

536
00:27:40.865 --> 00:27:41.417
>> All right.

537
00:27:41.417 --> 00:27:45.651
Well now,
we've got our feed web with firewall D.

538
00:27:45.651 --> 00:27:49.706
And that's kind of a funny play
on words there or lit, so fire.

539
00:27:49.706 --> 00:27:50.835
Always a good time.

540
00:27:50.835 --> 00:27:53.655
That being said, it obviously
is the end of our episode here,

541
00:27:53.655 --> 00:27:54.600
cuz I'm getting punchy.

542
00:27:54.600 --> 00:27:56.815
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're gonna call it a day.

543
00:27:56.815 --> 00:27:57.725
Thanks for watching.

544
00:27:57.725 --> 00:28:00.745
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lawry.

545
00:28:00.745 --> 00:28:01.458
>> And I'm Dom.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate how to take the already secure SSH and secure it even further. They will show you techniques for hardening both the SSH server and clients including changing the default port, restricting who can login, and configuring key-based authentication.
episodes.title: Securing SSH
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:03.262
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.262 --> 00:00:08.233
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK] [SOUND]

3
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:12.203
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.203 --> 00:00:14.047
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:14.047 --> 00:00:16.950
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:19.834
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:19.834 --> 00:00:23.850
we are jumping back into our
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Version 7 series.

8
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:27.000
Joining us back for that action
is our good friend, Mr Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.000 --> 00:00:27.990
Don, how's it going today?

10
00:00:27.990 --> 00:00:29.080
>> It is going swell, Daniel,

11
00:00:29.080 --> 00:00:31.880
ready to dive right back into
Red Hat Enterprise Linux security.

12
00:00:31.880 --> 00:00:35.230
And in this episode we're gonna
talk about something that is not so

13
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:36.570
much Red Hat exclusive.

14
00:00:36.570 --> 00:00:39.350
I know I've tried to focus on
things that are available in

15
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:40.620
RHEL that make it special.

16
00:00:40.620 --> 00:00:45.650
But this is one that is just really
super important for any distro, really.

17
00:00:45.650 --> 00:00:48.070
And that's securing SSH.

18
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:53.590
SSH, the secure shell protocol,
it is installed and enabled in, as

19
00:00:53.590 --> 00:00:57.350
far as I'm aware, every variation of the
installation of Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

20
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:01.710
So when you install it,
you've got secure shell up running and

21
00:01:01.710 --> 00:01:04.400
listening for people to open remote
shell connections to your system.

22
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:06.540
Now it is secure, right?

23
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:07.965
It's in the name, secure shell, right?

24
00:01:07.965 --> 00:01:08.664
>> So they say.

25
00:01:08.664 --> 00:01:10.480
>> So it's gotta be secure.

26
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:12.340
It's definitely better than Telnet,
that's for

27
00:01:12.340 --> 00:01:17.550
certain, but the default config
is not as secure as it could be.

28
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:21.775
So whenever I bring up a new Red Hat box,
one of the first things that I do is I sit

29
00:01:21.775 --> 00:01:25.155
down and I try and tighten up
the security of SSH a little bit and

30
00:01:25.155 --> 00:01:27.368
make it run as securely as I can, right?

31
00:01:27.368 --> 00:01:30.152
So that's what we're gonna take a look
at right here, is how we do that,

32
00:01:30.152 --> 00:01:32.314
how we secure SSH and
get it running the way that we want.

33
00:01:32.314 --> 00:01:35.261
So I'm gonna take my work
station here that I've got,

34
00:01:35.261 --> 00:01:37.580
I'm running Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

35
00:01:37.580 --> 00:01:40.140
And I haven't messed with SSH at all, but

36
00:01:40.140 --> 00:01:42.900
I know it's running on
here because it always is.

37
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:48.625
If I drop into a terminal and
just do a quick little test here,

38
00:01:48.625 --> 00:01:55.603
right, if I do an SSH with my
username into my local IP 127.00.1.

39
00:01:55.603 --> 00:01:59.006
If I go in and try to remote into that,
when I go to connect,

40
00:01:59.006 --> 00:02:03.180
I'm gonna get a message that says
verify the key fingerprint, right?

41
00:02:03.180 --> 00:02:06.110
So is this the server you think it is?

42
00:02:06.110 --> 00:02:10.360
Well, I'm sitting on the server, so I know
it is the server I'm trying to connect to.

43
00:02:10.360 --> 00:02:14.410
But in real life land, we'd wanna make
sure that this was the actual server.

44
00:02:14.410 --> 00:02:16.881
Because otherwise,
the next thing it asks for is my password.

45
00:02:16.881 --> 00:02:20.955
And if I say yes and I'm on some false
server, I could start sending my password

46
00:02:20.955 --> 00:02:23.793
to a server that I don't trust,
that I don't know, so

47
00:02:23.793 --> 00:02:28.070
we need to make sure that we are connected
to who we think we're connecting to.

48
00:02:28.070 --> 00:02:30.640
>> Don, how would we know if
that key was correct or not?

49
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:35.570
>> All right, so when you enable SSH,
it actually shows you the fingerprint.

50
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:36.640
But we didn't enable it, did we?

51
00:02:36.640 --> 00:02:37.407
>> No, we did not.

52
00:02:37.407 --> 00:02:39.330
>> Part of the default install,
so we never saw that.

53
00:02:39.330 --> 00:02:43.510
So, [COUGH] the fingerprint is actually
being calculated off of a key that's right

54
00:02:43.510 --> 00:02:44.670
on your system.

55
00:02:44.670 --> 00:02:50.370
So /etc/ssh is a folder that contains
a lot of the information about ssh,

56
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:54.290
and that key, that ECDSA key that
was being displayed right there,

57
00:02:54.290 --> 00:02:56.510
is located right in that folder.

58
00:02:56.510 --> 00:02:58.565
Now here, let me see if I can
kinda browse and find it.

59
00:02:58.565 --> 00:03:02.180
Actually, let me elevate my
permissions real quick because

60
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:05.090
it doesn't let non-admins
get into that stuff.

61
00:03:05.090 --> 00:03:09.454
So, I'm gonna bump into /etc/ssh.

62
00:03:09.454 --> 00:03:12.483
And if you poke around in there,
you'll see a bunch of files.

63
00:03:12.483 --> 00:03:17.005
And we've got ssh_host_ecdsa key and

64
00:03:17.005 --> 00:03:20.480
ecdsa_key.pub, right?

65
00:03:20.480 --> 00:03:23.890
So that's the public key and the private
key that's being used for this server.

66
00:03:23.890 --> 00:03:27.240
Now public key is the one that's being
presented to us when we connect, and

67
00:03:27.240 --> 00:03:29.380
it's the fingerprint of that
key that's asking us to verify.

68
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:30.970
So we can always compare that and

69
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:34.790
make sure it is the right key for
us, all right?

70
00:03:34.790 --> 00:03:38.570
Now when we fire up a server, a lot of
the stuff is already configured for us.

71
00:03:38.570 --> 00:03:39.900
So we didn't even have to
know about these keys.

72
00:03:39.900 --> 00:03:41.810
It's just there and
it's running, and technically,

73
00:03:41.810 --> 00:03:45.560
I'm still SSHed in, so
let me get out of that, there.

74
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:49.890
So what we need to do is we need to
tweak the way the security works.

75
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:52.000
Let me show you some of the problems
that we have by default.

76
00:03:52.000 --> 00:03:55.660
By default, our server is listening
on port 22 for connections coming in.

77
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:58.200
It's opened up on the firewall,
firewall D.

78
00:03:58.200 --> 00:04:03.150
And anybody in the entire planet could
connect to this server on port 22 and

79
00:04:03.150 --> 00:04:04.520
present credentials.

80
00:04:04.520 --> 00:04:06.730
Now is that a problem?

81
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:07.270
It depends.

82
00:04:07.270 --> 00:04:08.662
>> I'm already running
Hydra against it right now.

83
00:04:08.662 --> 00:04:10.427
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

84
00:04:10.427 --> 00:04:11.463
>> Somebody could attempt to brute

85
00:04:11.463 --> 00:04:12.080
force it, right?

86
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:13.950
Anybody could connect and
build a secure tunnel.

87
00:04:13.950 --> 00:04:15.860
And then they start throwing usernames and
passwords.

88
00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:17.880
So we need things like fail2ban and

89
00:04:17.880 --> 00:04:20.530
other protocols that will stop people
from brute forcing a password.

90
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:22.580
And that stuff's turned on by default too.

91
00:04:22.580 --> 00:04:24.380
But we can certainly restrict that.

92
00:04:24.380 --> 00:04:28.275
The other thing is, if you're an attacker,
I'll put you on the spot, Daniel,

93
00:04:28.275 --> 00:04:32.340
if you're gonna attack my system,
what user account would you target first?

94
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:35.660
>> Well, my ultimate goal is gonna
be root, that's what I want.

95
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:38.190
It's the ultimate system, and
I've been there, so that's what I want.

96
00:04:38.190 --> 00:04:40.120
>> It's the one account you know exists,

97
00:04:40.120 --> 00:04:42.360
you don't know if there's
a dpezet account.

98
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:45.027
Maybe I called it Don Pezet, maybe I
just called it Don, who knows, right?

99
00:04:45.027 --> 00:04:46.960
But root, you know root exists.

100
00:04:46.960 --> 00:04:47.990
So people are gonna target it.

101
00:04:47.990 --> 00:04:54.220
And in RHEL 7 at least,
the root account is allowed to SSH in.

102
00:04:54.220 --> 00:04:57.860
So if I were to repeat my little
example there and try and

103
00:04:57.860 --> 00:04:59.077
log in as root-
>> And

104
00:04:59.077 --> 00:05:01.950
Don's username is always ladiesman2367,
right?

105
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:03.930
>> Everybody knows that, right?

106
00:05:03.930 --> 00:05:07.050
So when I come in here and
punch this in, I connect and

107
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:09.370
I'm logged in as root, right?

108
00:05:09.370 --> 00:05:11.450
So the root user is allowed to SSH in,

109
00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:13.410
a lot of other distros have
disabled that by default.

110
00:05:13.410 --> 00:05:15.310
So I probably wanna turn that off.

111
00:05:15.310 --> 00:05:18.660
And I wanna go beyond that and
not only turn that off, but

112
00:05:18.660 --> 00:05:21.680
change who's allowed to
SSH in in the first place.

113
00:05:21.680 --> 00:05:25.790
And we can do all of that right
through a simple little spot.

114
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:31.377
So I'm gonna elevate my privileges again,
and I'm going to edit a little file.

115
00:05:31.377 --> 00:05:39.800
So let me edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

116
00:05:39.800 --> 00:05:44.108
If you dive into that file, this is
the ssh demon and its configuration and

117
00:05:44.108 --> 00:05:47.480
all the stuff that tells
it how to do what it does.

118
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:49.080
And as you look through it,

119
00:05:49.080 --> 00:05:53.990
there's a number of things in here we can
tweak to make our system more stable,

120
00:05:53.990 --> 00:05:57.750
secure, and just more hardened
than it is out of the box.

121
00:05:57.750 --> 00:06:00.440
And the first one that I'm gonna look for
is that root account.

122
00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:05.510
If you just do a quick search for root,
you'll find it real quick right here.

123
00:06:05.510 --> 00:06:08.610
And the way this file is structured is

124
00:06:08.610 --> 00:06:12.280
most of the things in here are commented
out, which means they don't take effect.

125
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:16.030
So this line, PermitRootLogin yes,
is commented out.

126
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:17.590
It doesn't take effect, does it?

127
00:06:17.590 --> 00:06:21.420
But we just saw a minute ago
that it does work, right?

128
00:06:21.420 --> 00:06:25.330
What they did at Red Hat, and
this was a great idea, is they said,

129
00:06:25.330 --> 00:06:29.240
we're gonna put all the defaults
in the file, and comment them out.

130
00:06:29.240 --> 00:06:32.460
So you can look at this and see, and say
all right, yeah, it's commented out, but

131
00:06:32.460 --> 00:06:36.330
the default is, yes,
root would be allowed to log in.

132
00:06:36.330 --> 00:06:38.610
So if I wanna change that,
I've got two choices.

133
00:06:38.610 --> 00:06:42.430
I could just edit this line, that's what I
normally do, but there's a lot of people

134
00:06:42.430 --> 00:06:45.720
that say, leave that there, so
you know what the default is.

135
00:06:45.720 --> 00:06:47.620
And then just add another line.

136
00:06:47.620 --> 00:06:50.561
And come in and say PermitRootLogin no.

137
00:06:50.561 --> 00:06:52.148
>> That seems like a lot more typing,
Don [LAUGH].

138
00:06:52.148 --> 00:06:55.277
>> It is more typing,
which is why I don't like it, but

139
00:06:55.277 --> 00:06:59.060
it is nice though that you know okay,
that's not the default.

140
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:02.870
I've overridden the default, and this guy
right up here, that one's got the default.

141
00:07:02.870 --> 00:07:06.330
So right here,
I'm saying PermitRootLogin no,

142
00:07:06.330 --> 00:07:08.970
that's gonna disable that root
login account, all right?

143
00:07:08.970 --> 00:07:14.080
Now that's enough to secure the root
account, but I like to go a step further

144
00:07:14.080 --> 00:07:18.575
because technically, anybody with a user
account on this system can connect in and

145
00:07:18.575 --> 00:07:20.920
there's a lot of stuff with user accounts.

146
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:23.780
All the user account has to have is
a password, any account with a password.

147
00:07:23.780 --> 00:07:25.240
Now why do I mention that?

148
00:07:25.240 --> 00:07:28.048
Well, let me get out of this file for
a second.

149
00:07:28.048 --> 00:07:34.180
If you take a look at etc/passwd, that's
where your user accounts are stored.

150
00:07:34.180 --> 00:07:37.650
And you start looking down the list and
you see all these accounts, right?

151
00:07:37.650 --> 00:07:41.960
And if you get down to, like me,
I've got dpezet and there's an x here.

152
00:07:41.960 --> 00:07:44.180
That's where the password
would normally be stored.

153
00:07:44.180 --> 00:07:46.190
Followed by my ID and my account, right?

154
00:07:46.190 --> 00:07:48.651
So I'm allowed to connect
in because of that.

155
00:07:48.651 --> 00:07:52.994
Some of these systems, like tcpdump,
it has a user account,

156
00:07:52.994 --> 00:07:56.012
and look at its shell, /sbin/nologin.

157
00:07:56.012 --> 00:07:58.171
So if it tries to connect,
what's gonna happen?

158
00:07:58.171 --> 00:08:01.953
It's not gonna work, but if you've
installed third-party software it might

159
00:08:01.953 --> 00:08:04.140
not have it shell map to no login.

160
00:08:04.140 --> 00:08:07.140
And if that happens,
it could still try an SSH in and

161
00:08:07.140 --> 00:08:11.530
potentially get a shell, or when you SSH,
you don't have to use a shell.

162
00:08:11.530 --> 00:08:14.580
You can just build a tunnel,
to tunnel other access to the system and

163
00:08:14.580 --> 00:08:17.577
then even these no login one's pose
a risk in that scenario, right.

164
00:08:18.680 --> 00:08:23.230
And if you take a look
inside of /etc/shadow,

165
00:08:23.230 --> 00:08:26.410
here's where you can see whether
somebody actually has a password set.

166
00:08:26.410 --> 00:08:29.438
And so if you look,
see how my account dpezet and

167
00:08:29.438 --> 00:08:34.140
I've got this huge chunk of
ciphertext coming after it,right.

168
00:08:34.140 --> 00:08:35.706
That's how I know I have a password.

169
00:08:35.706 --> 00:08:38.653
If I look at tcpdump,
see how it has, exclamation point.

170
00:08:38.653 --> 00:08:40.758
It doesn't actually have a password,
right.

171
00:08:40.758 --> 00:08:45.650
It's not blank, it's that it's not
designed for interactive login so

172
00:08:45.650 --> 00:08:51.050
it's not going to work, but as you
skim through this list any service or

173
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:56.090
any application that does have
a password could potentially get in and

174
00:08:56.090 --> 00:08:58.110
that root user is right there.

175
00:08:58.110 --> 00:09:01.520
I've already secured root by saying it's
not allowed to use SSH,but if you have

176
00:09:01.520 --> 00:09:04.290
anybody else in this list,
you might wanna secure them too.

177
00:09:04.290 --> 00:09:08.690
And the way to do everybody else is
a little bit different than root user.

178
00:09:08.690 --> 00:09:14.985
So, if I go back into
/etc/ssh/sshd_config and

179
00:09:14.985 --> 00:09:18.820
I'm gonna right back to
our set that root user.

180
00:09:18.820 --> 00:09:23.540
There's another option we can specify
in here that's not really documented,

181
00:09:23.540 --> 00:09:25.550
it's not in here as a default.

182
00:09:25.550 --> 00:09:29.730
And that's the AllowUsers entry.

183
00:09:29.730 --> 00:09:31.900
And we can specify exactly who is allowed.

184
00:09:31.900 --> 00:09:36.060
And so if I say, AllowUsers dpezet,
that's it, it's just me.

185
00:09:36.060 --> 00:09:39.890
Only me, I'm the only one allowed,
nobody else is allowed to SSH in.

186
00:09:39.890 --> 00:09:43.100
So if they try and connect and

00:31:45.385 --> 00:31:48.455
[COUGH] Could we actually use unique
keys for every server, right?

646
00:31:48.455 --> 00:31:51.230
Cuz I said you can just take this
one public key upload it everywhere.

647
00:31:51.230 --> 00:31:52.903
>> Right.
>> If my private key gets compromised,

648
00:31:52.903 --> 00:31:53.709
I'm screwed, right?

649
00:31:53.709 --> 00:31:54.257
>> That would be bad.

650
00:31:54.257 --> 00:31:55.225
>> Because now somebody can
get into all my servers.

651
00:31:55.225 --> 00:31:57.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yes you can, right?

652
00:31:57.520 --> 00:32:00.570
So when you generated that key,
it got a default name but

653
00:32:00.570 --> 00:32:02.500
you can override the name
when you create it.

654
00:32:02.500 --> 00:32:05.480
And then you can upload a different
key to different servers so

655
00:32:05.480 --> 00:32:07.400
you could have a separate one.

656
00:32:07.400 --> 00:32:10.260
It becomes a bit of an administrative
challenge to keep it all straight.

657
00:32:10.260 --> 00:32:12.460
So there is software out there
that'll help you with that.

658
00:32:12.460 --> 00:32:14.970
But you certainly can,
you can have a different key for

659
00:32:14.970 --> 00:32:16.810
every single server you connect to.

660
00:32:16.810 --> 00:32:17.914
It does certainly work.

661
00:32:17.914 --> 00:32:18.695
>> Well that sounds fun.

662
00:32:18.695 --> 00:32:20.074
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

663
00:32:20.074 --> 00:32:20.825
>> That being said,

664
00:32:20.825 --> 00:32:23.910
it does look like we've come to
the end of our time for this episode.

665
00:32:23.910 --> 00:32:25.278
We do thank you guys for watching.

666
00:32:25.278 --> 00:32:29.240
We thank Don for explaining this to us,
but it looks like it's time to sign off.

667
00:32:29.240 --> 00:32:31.800
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowery.

668
00:32:31.800 --> 00:32:32.640
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

669
00:32:32.640 --> 00:32:34.167
>> We'll see you next time.

670
00:32:34.167 --> 00:32:40.830
[MUSIC]

671
00:32:40.830 --> 00:32:43.716
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain how to keep your Red Hat Enterprise Linux systems secure by installing security updates. They begin by showing you how to check for and apply security updates available for your system from the terminal and then jump over to the Red Hat Customer Portal to perform security updates.
episodes.title: Security Updates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.362 --> 00:00:07.204
Welcome to ITProTV
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.204 --> 00:00:08.660
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.660 --> 00:00:14.262
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> All right greetings everyone and

4
00:00:14.262 --> 00:00:16.360
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.360 --> 00:00:18.160
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

6
00:00:18.160 --> 00:00:22.220
today's episode will you know we're
back with more on our red hat Linux.

7
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:23.550
Our Enterprise Linux series.

8
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:25.950
Joining us back from the studio yet again.

9
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:28.610
Is our good friend and
mentor, Mr. Don Bizet.

10
00:00:28.610 --> 00:00:29.460
Don, welcome, sir.

11
00:00:29.460 --> 00:00:30.290
How's it going today?

12
00:00:30.290 --> 00:00:31.570
>> It is going just well, Dane.

13
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:33.070
Ready to dive right back in to Red Hat.

14
00:00:33.070 --> 00:00:36.350
In this episode,
we're taking a look at security updates.

15
00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:39.280
One of the cool things about Red Hat
Enterprise Linux is that it's commercially

16
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:40.170
supported.

17
00:00:40.170 --> 00:00:42.730
And that means when there is some kind
of vulnerability or whatever, we're not

18
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:46.700
waiting on a community patch, we get the
guys at Red Hat corporate to sit down, and

19
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:49.400
they write the patch and they get these
things pushed out very, very quickly.

20
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:51.900
So you're gonna stay
as secure as possible,

21
00:00:51.900 --> 00:00:54.260
as far as most of the Linux
platforms are concerned.

22
00:00:54.260 --> 00:00:58.050
Now where this gets a little tricky
is we need to adjust the way that we

23
00:00:58.050 --> 00:01:00.850
handle updates, for
our system to take that into account.

24
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:05.080
Because inevitably what happens
is we run into a problem where.

25
00:01:05.080 --> 00:01:08.044
We're running maria DB 4.1.

26
00:01:08.044 --> 00:01:10.180
And maria DB 4.2 comes out.

27
00:01:10.180 --> 00:01:12.840
And 4.2 has some new features It changes

28
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:14.560
how something works and
we don't want that.

29
00:01:14.560 --> 00:01:16.290
It's gonna break our software.

30
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:23.050
But it also fixes some security stuff and
newly do on that, but now what do we do?

31
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:26.430
It happens with web browsers all the time,
where hey,

32
00:01:26.430 --> 00:01:29.440
I can't go to the latest version of this
web browser cuz it breaks some site that

33
00:01:29.440 --> 00:01:31.160
my employees need to be able to use.

34
00:01:31.160 --> 00:01:35.620
So how do we balance security and
feature updates like that.

35
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:40.330
And what Red Hat does, is they do push
out the regular updates just like

36
00:01:40.330 --> 00:01:45.600
every distro out there, but
they also push out just security updates.

37
00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:48.060
We can go in and say hey, I don't want
all the new features or crazy bells and

38
00:01:48.060 --> 00:01:51.490
whistles, I just want the security
updates, keep my system protected.

39
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:53.100
And there's a way to do that,

40
00:01:53.100 --> 00:01:55.640
we just have to handle updates
a little bit different, right.

41
00:01:55.640 --> 00:02:00.210
Normally what I would do if I had
a system that I needed to update, right.

42
00:02:00.210 --> 00:02:06.380
I would jump right in and
I would just say, update, right?

43
00:02:06.380 --> 00:02:08.500
And it's gonna reach
out to the server and,

44
00:02:08.500 --> 00:02:11.450
well, assuming that I have
the permissions to run the command.

45
00:02:11.450 --> 00:02:15.550
It'll jump right out to the server, and
it'll find out what updates are available.

46
00:02:15.550 --> 00:02:18.207
And it'll give me a big fat
list of updates, over three.

47
00:02:18.207 --> 00:02:21.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> Apparently I'm pretty up to date.

48
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:23.580
So it'll find those updates,
and then it'll say, hey,

49
00:02:23.580 --> 00:02:25.240
do you want to install them or not, right.

50
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:28.720
But when I look at this,
are these security updates?

51
00:02:28.720 --> 00:02:30.070
Are these feature updates?

52
00:02:30.070 --> 00:02:31.870
If they are security updates,
what are they fixing?

53
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:33.550
I don't know.

54
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:36.350
I don't see any of that here and

55
00:02:36.350 --> 00:02:39.420
so I'm not getting any of that
extra information that I need.

56
00:02:39.420 --> 00:02:41.490
So there's a series of commands
that we need to use and

57
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:43.130
I'm going to say no to all this stuff.

58
00:02:44.180 --> 00:02:47.240
One of them's related to Java so
you know that's gotta be security.

59
00:02:47.240 --> 00:02:48.760
But I wanna know for a fact, right.

60
00:02:48.760 --> 00:02:50.440
I wanna know about these things.

61
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:54.070
And I also wanna know about security
things that I've already been patched for.

62
00:02:54.070 --> 00:02:56.050
How do I keep up with that stuff?

63
00:02:56.050 --> 00:02:57.770
So in this episode,
I wanna show you two things.

64
00:02:57.770 --> 00:03:00.780
I wanna show you a set of command
line utilities we can run that will

65
00:03:00.780 --> 00:03:04.000
tell us all sorts of information
about the security updates.

66
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:06.890
And then I want to show you
the red hat customer portal.

67
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:10.530
And how it has a whole section
in there where we can keep track

68
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:13.360
of the vulnerabilities and other things
that are out there that we need to be

69
00:03:13.360 --> 00:03:15.650
aware of in patching on our systems,
all right?

70
00:03:15.650 --> 00:03:17.100
But let's start right here
from our command line.

71
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:20.660
The first thing I wanna show you
guys is when I ran yum update

72
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.460
I'm actually telling the system,
hey I wanna do an update.

73
00:03:23.460 --> 00:03:26.690
But I didn't want to do an update,
I just wanted to see the updates.

74
00:03:26.690 --> 00:03:30.250
And so you can do a yum check-update.

75
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:33.620
Which says, I dont actually wanna
do the update just check and

76
00:03:33.620 --> 00:03:36.000
see what available and tell me about it.

77
00:03:36.000 --> 00:03:39.070
And so when you run that command,
it's gonna reach out and look for

78
00:03:39.070 --> 00:03:42.810
those updates in return
the exact same data.

79
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:46.130
The only advantage here is that
it didn't offer to install it.

80
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:48.950
I couldn't accidentally hit enter which
automatically makes them install.

81
00:03:48.950 --> 00:03:51.410
So check-update is a great way to do that.

82
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:55.310
But check-update has another little
command line modifier that you can use.

83
00:03:55.310 --> 00:03:57.200
Which is --security.

84
00:03:57.200 --> 00:04:00.330
In other words, check for updates and

85
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:03.690
just show me the ones that
are security updates.

86
00:04:03.690 --> 00:04:06.670
Now I can get a better idea
of what these updates are.

87
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:10.610
I've got three updates available and wow,

88
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:12.780
that's quite a bit that just
came across the screen, right?

89
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:13.810
Quite a bit of stuff.

90
00:04:13.810 --> 00:04:18.567
Well, I can see expat.x86_64.

91
00:04:18.567 --> 00:04:21.581
This package right here,
that's one package needed for

92
00:04:21.581 --> 00:04:23.760
security out of three available.

93
00:04:23.760 --> 00:04:27.660
There were three updates but only one
of them is actually a security update.

94
00:04:27.660 --> 00:04:31.900
So those other two, they might be
adding features or functionality,

95
00:04:31.900 --> 00:04:34.690
might be a bug fix, but
not a security-related bug.

96
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:37.390
Maybe there was a typo in the program,
something like that.

97
00:04:37.390 --> 00:04:41.050
I don't need to rush to do those,
I don't need to worry about breaking

98
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:45.810
my custom software or website with
updates that don't add anything.

99
00:04:45.810 --> 00:04:47.060
I need the security update.

100
00:04:47.060 --> 00:04:47.640
Right?
And

101
00:04:47.640 --> 00:04:50.820
I can see there is really just
one of them that truly did that.

102
00:04:50.820 --> 00:04:53.900
Now all the stuff that
scroll across the screen

103
00:04:53.900 --> 00:04:56.130
what it's showing here is
all the dependencies, right.

104
00:04:56.130 --> 00:04:58.370
And the dependencies
are pretty significant.

105
00:04:58.370 --> 00:05:00.630
But none of these
dependencies had updates.

106
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:01.620
If they did,

107
00:05:01.620 --> 00:05:05.380
it has to check the dependency to say, is
this a security update for the dependency.

108
00:05:05.380 --> 00:05:08.070
Right, so that's why all this stuff
is scrolling across the screen.

109
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:12.560
And you know, I don't remember off hand,
but I think it's like no-dependencies or

110
00:05:12.560 --> 00:05:15.360
something like that that you can add and
it hides all that stuff.

111
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:17.870
But what I want is right
here to end anyway, so

112
00:05:17.870 --> 00:05:19.780
you can just let it run and there you go.

113
00:05:19.780 --> 00:05:24.240
But just remember,
that was check -update --security.

114
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:26.650
Just show me the ones that actually
have security updates in them.

115
00:05:28.050 --> 00:05:30.038
And we can go a little
bit further with that.

116
00:05:30.038 --> 00:05:36.390
There's a yum update info command.

117
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:39.220
And normally this would show you
information about any particular update.

118
00:05:39.220 --> 00:05:41.350
You could specify the update and
that was it.

119
00:05:41.350 --> 00:05:45.710
But if it's a security update that
we're concerned about we can say

120
00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:49.290
sudo yum updateinfo security.

121
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:51.760
And that's gonna say give me
information about that security update.

122
00:05:51.760 --> 00:05:55.370
I know that expat apparently
is a security update.

123
00:05:55.370 --> 00:05:56.440
What about it, right?

124
00:05:56.440 --> 00:05:58.940
Or if there were five different
ones I can just run this and

125
00:05:58.940 --> 00:06:00.630
it'll tell me about all five of them.

126
00:06:00.630 --> 00:06:03.510
And so it's gonna do a lookup to
find out what needed to be done and

127
00:06:03.510 --> 00:06:05.690
then it's gonna give me
a little bit of output.

128
00:06:05.690 --> 00:06:07.490
And when I say a little bit,
boy do I mean it.

129
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:08.470
It really didn't no.

130
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:11.280
It didn't give me much at all.

131
00:06:11.280 --> 00:06:13.360
That's an interesting one.

132
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:14.310
>> It's moderate.

133
00:06:14.310 --> 00:06:16.110
>> Let's change here.

134
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:20.480
It may actually be that it's
not a true security issue,

135
00:06:20.480 --> 00:06:22.410
that it's flagged as a security update.

136
00:06:23.500 --> 00:06:28.630
Sometimes you see where there's a
vulnerability that is yet to be exploited.

137
00:06:28.630 --> 00:06:31.430
So it is a security problem but

138
00:06:31.430 --> 00:06:35.040
it's not being exploited yet so
it's not like an urgent thing.

139
00:06:35.040 --> 00:06:38.260
So you're here sometimes people will tell
you about the new update, how to blade was

140
00:06:38.260 --> 00:06:41.800
great example, you need to push out
this fix today, don't test just

141
00:06:41.800 --> 00:06:46.010
push it out because you are vulnerable
right now, people are exploiting this.

142
00:06:46.010 --> 00:06:48.550
But other times there
is these radicle ones,

143
00:06:48.550 --> 00:06:52.323
It's theoretically possible to break 256.

144
00:06:52.323 --> 00:06:57.250
It doesn't mean that we should move to 512
right now, but in the near future we will.

145
00:06:57.250 --> 00:07:01.240
Those kinds of things can cause it to
show up in one area and not another.

146
00:07:01.240 --> 00:07:03.300
I ran yum updateinfo security.

147
00:07:03.300 --> 00:07:10.690
I'm going to change that and
run yum updateinfo CVEs, right?

148
00:07:10.690 --> 00:07:14.630
CVEs, you'll hear about CVEs in any
other security manual that you read.

149
00:07:14.630 --> 00:07:18.080
And it's common vulnerabilities and
exploits.

150
00:07:18.080 --> 00:07:22.270
So when somebody learns about a new
vulnerability it gets documented and

151
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:23.950
assigned a CVE number.

152
00:07:23.950 --> 00:07:28.805
And so there is more than likely
a CVE number attached to this

153
00:07:28.805 --> 00:07:33.260
Expat.x86_64 file.

154
00:07:33.260 --> 00:07:37.060
So if I pull this up,
hopefully I'll get some more output here.

155
00:07:37.060 --> 00:07:39.650
If I don't, then we really get confused.

156
00:07:39.650 --> 00:07:41.370
And I don't, all right.

157
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:44.740
No, wait,
I'm Overlooking the output on my screen.

158
00:07:44.740 --> 00:07:47.391
So there is a CVE attached to it.

159
00:07:47.391 --> 00:07:52.971
So CVE- 2016- 0718 Moderate/Sec,

160
00:07:52.971 --> 00:07:56.046
so it is a moderate issue.

161
00:07:56.046 --> 00:07:59.258
It's a security issue and
that's what's being tied to it.

162
00:07:59.258 --> 00:08:00.545
And so it's giving me that information.

163
00:08:00.545 --> 00:08:03.480
>> And the cool thing is you can
actually look up those CDE numbers, and

164
00:08:03.480 --> 00:08:06.881
sometimes they have a lovely little thing
called proof of concept codes that go

165
00:08:06.881 --> 00:08:07.670
along with them.

166
00:08:07.670 --> 00:08:10.400
And that's real fun for
you budding hackers out there [LAUGH].

167
00:08:10.400 --> 00:08:12.700
>> Yeah, and the proof of concept
code is what you can take in and

168
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:15.690
turn into an exploit, so those are usually
the ones that have already been exploited,

169
00:08:15.690 --> 00:08:17.210
and those are ones that you
really have to worry about.

170
00:08:17.210 --> 00:08:20.280
So now I've got the CVE number,
I can go and look that up.

171
00:08:20.280 --> 00:08:21.962
I can look it up on Red Hat's website.

172
00:08:21.962 --> 00:08:26.240
I don't normally do it, but you can look
it up right here from the command line.

173
00:08:26.240 --> 00:08:29.130
I don't, I actually don't
remember the command for that.

174
00:08:29.130 --> 00:08:33.925
There's a -v or verbose,
or something like that.

175
00:08:33.925 --> 00:08:37.690
It'll actually display the CV information
right here in the command line.

176
00:08:37.690 --> 00:08:38.540
Apparently, that's not it.

177
00:08:38.540 --> 00:08:40.025
But I don't normally pull it here.

178
00:08:40.025 --> 00:08:43.846
Because what's really gonna happen is,
if you're supporting hundreds of servers,

179
00:08:43.846 --> 00:08:46.832
you're not remoting into the servers and
pulling these updates and

180
00:08:46.832 --> 00:08:48.660
looking at it right from here.

181
00:08:48.660 --> 00:08:51.460
We're normally doing it from
the Red Hat customer portal.

182
00:08:51.460 --> 00:08:54.480
And that's where we'll see the CVs and
we can easily read the documentation and

183
00:08:54.480 --> 00:08:55.270
do it at our leisure.

184
00:08:55.270 --> 00:08:58.200
So I'm gonna show you guys
that way here in a little bit,

185
00:08:58.200 --> 00:08:59.810
we'll pull up the detailed information.

186
00:08:59.810 --> 00:09:03.960
But now I know that,
that one package does need to be updated.

187
00:09:03.960 --> 00:09:07.950
It does have a vulnerability,
it's moderate so that's enough for

188
00:09:07.950 --> 00:09:10.400
me to worry about it, and
I need to push that update out.

189
00:09:10.400 --> 00:09:11.398
The other two updates?

190
00:09:11.398 --> 00:09:12.982
I can let those sit there,
I don't care about those.

191
00:09:12.982 --> 00:09:16.960
But this one, I need to get
that updated sooner or later.

192
00:09:16.960 --> 00:09:21.740
And so, when I do a yum update,
instead of just running yum update and

193
00:09:21.740 --> 00:09:26.540
updating the whole thing, if it's just
one, like this, I can go in and just say,

194
00:09:26.540 --> 00:09:27.160
Update expat.

195
00:09:27.160 --> 00:09:28.824
And that's it, right?

196
00:09:28.824 --> 00:09:33.248
Or, I could say update --security.

197
00:09:33.248 --> 00:09:39.860
And when I do that, now it's only gonna
update packages that are security updates.

198
00:09:39.860 --> 00:09:41.552
And see how expat is the only
thing that shows up.

199
00:09:41.552 --> 00:09:45.600
That's useful cuz you might have a hundred
packages that need to be updated.

200
00:09:45.600 --> 00:09:49.113
Maybe you just did a new install,
fresh and clean new install, and

201
00:09:49.113 --> 00:09:51.826
there's 100 packages
that need to be updated.
