it is a very important one right.

506
00:26:38.780 --> 00:26:41.348
Because things are gonna break,
things are gonna crash and

507
00:26:41.348 --> 00:26:44.028
it's good to let Red Hat know
that these things are breaking.

508
00:26:44.028 --> 00:26:47.766
Even if you don't open a support ticket,
hey, something went wrong,

509
00:26:47.766 --> 00:26:51.380
maybe there's an incompatibility
with some software that we have,

510
00:26:51.380 --> 00:26:53.640
maybe you could go in there and fix that.

511
00:26:53.640 --> 00:26:57.690
Make what have better, so we do want
to be employing this, we do wanna

512
00:26:57.690 --> 00:27:01.230
make sure that we know how to work
with it maybe for developing in-house.

513
00:27:01.230 --> 00:27:04.970
A fault occurs, we can generate those
reports, send them over to our developers.

514
00:27:04.970 --> 00:27:08.770
Then they can sift through all
that hieroglyphics that they

515
00:27:08.770 --> 00:27:10.010
called [LAUGH] code.

516
00:27:10.010 --> 00:27:12.754
Figure out what went wrong,
and get things fixed, and

517
00:27:12.754 --> 00:27:15.438
just keep people at the ready
on when things go wrong,

518
00:27:15.438 --> 00:27:19.576
Don doesn't like waking up in the morning,
finding 12 errors [LAUGH] in his log.

519
00:27:19.576 --> 00:27:22.010
He will know that as soon as it happens.

520
00:27:22.010 --> 00:27:26.080
That being said, Don, is there anything
else we need to know about the ABRT tool?

521
00:27:26.080 --> 00:27:29.240
>> I think that's about it, just remember
you can customize it to report to

522
00:27:29.240 --> 00:27:31.480
third party systems or whatever you want,
so take advantage of that,

523
00:27:31.480 --> 00:27:35.470
get it integrated into your development
cycle, and It'll save you a lot of time.

524
00:27:35.470 --> 00:27:38.070
>> All right, well, thanks so
much Don for explaining it for us.

525
00:27:38.070 --> 00:27:40.898
And thank you guys for watching, but
we are gonna go ahead and sign off.

526
00:27:40.898 --> 00:27:43.200
For ITPRO.TV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

527
00:27:43.200 --> 00:27:43.807
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

528
00:27:43.807 --> 00:27:46.048
>> And we'll see you next time.

529
00:27:46.048 --> 00:27:51.976
[MUSIC]

530
00:27:51.976 --> 00:27:55.448
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through using SOS Reports for those unfortunate times when you need to contact Red Hat Support and supply them with server information. They will show you how to create both standard and custom SOS reports and then upload them to Red Had Support.
episodes.title: SOS Reports
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:01.289
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.289 --> 00:00:07.248
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.248 --> 00:00:08.330
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.330 --> 00:00:12.304
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.304 --> 00:00:14.136
>> All right everyone, greetings and

6
00:00:14.136 --> 00:00:16.524
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.524 --> 00:00:18.170
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.170 --> 00:00:22.090
in today's episode it's more of our
Red Hat Enterprise Linux series.

9
00:00:22.090 --> 00:00:25.230
Joining us back for a little more of that
action is our good friend, our mentor,

10
00:00:25.230 --> 00:00:27.870
our guiding star, Mr Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:28.690
Don, welcome to the show.

12
00:00:28.690 --> 00:00:29.315
How's it going today?

13
00:00:29.315 --> 00:00:30.051
>> Thank you for having me back, Daniel.

14
00:00:30.051 --> 00:00:33.128
[LAUGH] Very, very emotional
opening there, I feel special.

15
00:00:33.128 --> 00:00:34.074
All right so-
>> The feeling.

16
00:00:34.074 --> 00:00:37.198
>> Speaking of special things
let's talk about SOS reports.

17
00:00:37.198 --> 00:00:40.066
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I don't have a good transition

18
00:00:40.066 --> 00:00:44.110
on this one, so we filmed an episode
on the Automatic Bug Reporting Tool.

19
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:45.570
And the ABRT's pretty cool, right.

20
00:00:45.570 --> 00:00:48.190
You have an application that's crashing,
and

21
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:51.720
ABRT can send information right up to
Red Hat or your ticketing system, or

22
00:00:51.720 --> 00:00:55.080
wherever, and provide them information
about the crash that happened.

23
00:00:55.080 --> 00:00:58.143
Well, here's the challenge with the ABRT.

24
00:00:58.143 --> 00:00:59.423
First off, you might not be using it.

25
00:00:59.423 --> 00:01:01.209
Well, there's a challenge.

26
00:01:01.209 --> 00:01:04.595
Challenge number two,
more than one service might be involved.

27
00:01:04.595 --> 00:01:06.980
Right, ABRT doesn't do
a good job with that.

28
00:01:06.980 --> 00:01:10.250
Or three, you might not know
what the heck is going on.

29
00:01:10.250 --> 00:01:14.347
That hey, my server spontaneously
rebooted in the middle of the night, and

30
00:01:14.347 --> 00:01:17.942
it's not like the ABRT can generate
a crash report on one service.

31
00:01:17.942 --> 00:01:19.484
The whole freaking thing rebooted.

32
00:01:19.484 --> 00:01:20.857
I don't even know what to look at.

33
00:01:20.857 --> 00:01:24.713
So in those situations,
the ABRT is not perfect.

34
00:01:24.713 --> 00:01:26.350
No tool is perfect.

35
00:01:26.350 --> 00:01:29.540
But those are the areas where the ABRT
doesn't really solve our problems.

36
00:01:29.540 --> 00:01:35.880
So when that happens you pick up
the phone, you call Red Hat tech support,

37
00:01:35.880 --> 00:01:37.972
and the techs on the phone
are gonna help you with the issue.

38
00:01:37.972 --> 00:01:39.580
They're gonna help try and
isolate it and find it.

39
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:43.180
Now, it used to be that one of the first
things that would happen is they say,

40
00:01:43.180 --> 00:01:45.520
okay, well, can I remote into the server?

41
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:48.690
Can you open up a port or
whatever on the Internet so

42
00:01:48.690 --> 00:01:50.650
I can SSH in and take a look at it?

43
00:01:50.650 --> 00:01:55.540
And then as time evolved they said,
hey, can you fire up WebEx or

44
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:59.490
GoToMyPC or whatever and let me see your
computer, and you can remote into it.

45
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:00.820
And there's problems there.

46
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:03.910
And so now we've reached the point where,
look, if you've gotta

47
00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:07.010
secure a server that's offline there's no
way to let somebody remotely look at it,

48
00:02:07.010 --> 00:02:10.738
but we still need support, and
that's where sosreports come in.

49
00:02:10.738 --> 00:02:12.750
What an sosreport is,

50
00:02:12.750 --> 00:02:17.200
is an archive, it's a tar gzip
just like most things these days.

51
00:02:17.200 --> 00:02:21.070
And inside of that archive
is a collection of

52
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:24.450
every piece of information a support
person could possibly want.

53
00:02:24.450 --> 00:02:30.280
The output for all sorts of commands for
showing statistics and data.

54
00:02:30.280 --> 00:02:32.346
There's collected config files.

55
00:02:32.346 --> 00:02:36.750
There is just a ton of information
tucked away in an sosreport.

56
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:37.650
>> Your mother's maiden name.

57
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:39.168
Your PIN numbers, right?

58
00:02:39.168 --> 00:02:40.389
[LAUGH]
>> Maybe.

59
00:02:40.389 --> 00:02:41.220
>> Could be.

60
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:41.850
>> We joke about it,

61
00:02:41.850 --> 00:02:45.500
but it is amazing the amount of data
that is jammed inside of these files.

62
00:02:45.500 --> 00:02:48.710
It's supposed to be everything
the support person could want.

63
00:02:48.710 --> 00:02:50.330
So instead of having to
remote into your system,

64
00:02:50.330 --> 00:02:52.220
they can just pull up the sosreport and

65
00:02:52.220 --> 00:02:54.230
everything they need is right there,
all right.

66
00:02:54.230 --> 00:02:57.440
So we need to be aware of this
because when you call Red Hat tech

67
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:00.121
support a lot of times this is one of the
first things they'll ask you for is hey,

68
00:03:00.121 --> 00:03:02.830
can you generate an sosreport for
me and send it to me?

69
00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:03.980
So we can do that.

70
00:03:03.980 --> 00:03:07.540
Now when you generate a sosreport,
we've got a command line utility for it.

71
00:03:07.540 --> 00:03:08.610
It's super easy to do.

72
00:03:08.610 --> 00:03:11.960
You generate it and
then you've got to get it up to Red Hat.

73
00:03:11.960 --> 00:03:15.230
And when you do that,
there's a few different ways.

74
00:03:15.230 --> 00:03:16.870
But normally you use
the web ticketing system.

75
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:19.480
So if you've gone to the website and
you've opened up a ticket, or

76
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:21.330
if you call on the phone
they'll open it for you.

77
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:25.730
Then you log in to that ticket, and
you can attach the sosreport right to it.

78
00:03:25.730 --> 00:03:27.460
Now, normally that works just fine.

79
00:03:27.460 --> 00:03:28.910
You get it attached and
you're in business.

80
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:31.827
But there are times when
the sosreport is so

81
00:03:31.827 --> 00:03:35.320
big that you can't upload
it via the web uploader.

82
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:39.250
And so if that happens they have a little
FTP site that you can FTP it to.

83
00:03:39.250 --> 00:03:40.990
And I'll show it a little
bit later in the episode.

84
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:43.240
I'll kind of bring it up to where
you can throw in and upload it.

85
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:45.450
>> Don,
is this like the old SIS report system?

86
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:46.830
Is that similar to that?

87
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:49.167
>> So it actually, [LAUGH] it actually is.

88
00:03:49.167 --> 00:03:54.123
The old SIS report system, which is gone
now, I can't remember when it went away.

89
00:03:54.123 --> 00:03:57.850
I think it was Red Hat 5 where it finally
went away and got replaced by sosreports.

90
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:02.060
But it goes a little bit further than
what the traditional sosreports did and

91
00:04:02.060 --> 00:04:04.507
gives us, or the traditional SIS reports.

92
00:04:04.507 --> 00:04:05.268
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

93
00:04:05.268 --> 00:04:05.953
>> And gives us a little bit

94
00:04:05.953 --> 00:04:06.610
more information.

95
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:09.270
So let me bring this up, and
again, enough talking about it,

96
00:04:09.270 --> 00:04:10.290
let's actually take a look at it.

97
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:13.680
So let's say that I'm having some
problems here on my machine.

98
00:04:13.680 --> 00:04:16.129
For whatever reason it's just not
behaving right, I let Daniel use it for

99
00:04:16.129 --> 00:04:16.969
a few minutes, and now.

100
00:04:16.969 --> 00:04:18.580
>> I was gonna say, it is Don's machine.

101
00:04:18.580 --> 00:04:19.510
>> Yeah, I know, I got issues.

102
00:04:19.510 --> 00:04:22.023
>> I like to put viruses on it,
that's where I store all mine.

103
00:04:22.023 --> 00:04:22.915
[LAUGH]
>> You gotta put them somewhere.

104
00:04:22.915 --> 00:04:24.020
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

105
00:04:24.020 --> 00:04:27.610
>> All right, so if I'm having
problems I just need to get in here.

106
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:30.390
Problems that I can't cope
with with a psychiatrist.

107
00:04:30.390 --> 00:04:33.250
Then I need to get in here and
run an sosreport.

108
00:04:33.250 --> 00:04:38.210
And so you do need to be an administrator
user to do it because it's got

109
00:04:38.210 --> 00:04:39.670
sensitive system data in it, right?

110
00:04:39.670 --> 00:04:40.900
Information about your configuration.

111
00:04:40.900 --> 00:04:44.826
So I do need to sudo this and
then just run sosreport like that.

112
00:04:44.826 --> 00:04:48.520
All right, when you run it,
there it goes, it's gonna do some stuff.

113
00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:50.760
Here it's giving me information
about what it's gonna do.

114
00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:54.030
So it's telling me, hey we're about
to run and collect diagnostic and

115
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:56.650
configure information about this system.

116
00:04:56.650 --> 00:05:00.550
And it's telling me that an archive
containing the collected information will

117
00:05:00.550 --> 00:05:04.220
be generated in, and I need to pay
attention to this, in this folder.

118
00:05:04.220 --> 00:05:08.370
Because it's gonna generate a different
folder for each sosreport and

119
00:05:08.370 --> 00:05:10.870
I might have generated
other ones in the past.

120
00:05:10.870 --> 00:05:11.970
They might still be sitting there.

121
00:05:11.970 --> 00:05:14.090
It's not a good idea to keep
them laying around by the way,

122
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:16.790
but anyhow, that's where it's gonna be.

123
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:18.160
So that's where it's gonna generate it.

124
00:05:18.160 --> 00:05:19.630
It's gonna store it right there.

125
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:21.260
I can go in and find it.

126
00:05:21.260 --> 00:05:23.770
And send it up to the support person,
right?

127
00:05:23.770 --> 00:05:26.900
And they're telling me here that it'll be
treated in accordance with the privacy

128
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:28.490
policies published at blah, blah, blah.

129
00:05:28.490 --> 00:05:31.050
Because there's data in there
you don't wanna get out.

130
00:05:31.050 --> 00:05:33.509
All right, so I'm gonna copy that just so
I've got it and I don't forget,

131
00:05:33.509 --> 00:05:34.890
and then I'll press Enter.

132
00:05:34.890 --> 00:05:36.680
And now it's gonna ask me a few questions.

133
00:05:36.680 --> 00:05:39.200
Now when we generate an sosreport, and

134
00:05:39.200 --> 00:05:42.260
we upload it to Red Hat,
they get a lot of sosreports.

135
00:05:42.260 --> 00:05:44.370
Or you,
yourself might be generating a lot.

136
00:05:44.370 --> 00:05:49.170
So it's a good idea to attach a host
name as well as the username for

137
00:05:49.170 --> 00:05:50.380
your account with Red Hat.

138
00:05:50.380 --> 00:05:52.230
So it kind of maps it to yours.

139
00:05:52.230 --> 00:05:54.610
The reality is, if you're attaching
it to the ticket yourself,

140
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:56.880
you can put whatever you want in here and
it doesn't really matter.

141
00:05:56.880 --> 00:05:58.430
But we try and keep it accurate.

142
00:05:58.430 --> 00:06:00.970
It's asking for
my first initial and last name.

143
00:06:00.970 --> 00:06:02.723
And if you look, if I just press Enter,

144
00:06:02.723 --> 00:06:04.648
the default is the host
name of the system.

145
00:06:04.648 --> 00:06:07.971
It wants first initial and last name cuz
that's normally your Red Hat identity when

146
00:06:07.971 --> 00:06:09.359
you log in into the Red Hat portal.

147
00:06:09.359 --> 00:06:12.139
So I'm gonna update that and
put the correct information in there,

148
00:06:12.139 --> 00:06:13.376
the default is not accurate.

149
00:06:13.376 --> 00:06:16.582
And then enter the case ID we're
generating for this report.

150
00:06:16.582 --> 00:06:19.270
If I'm on the phone with Red Hat I've
already got a case ID and

151
00:06:19.270 --> 00:06:20.580
I can punch it in here.

152
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.664
But if I'm just getting ready for
contacting Red Hat,

153
00:06:23.664 --> 00:06:25.215
I don't have a case ID yet.

154
00:06:25.215 --> 00:06:29.050
And so you can leave it blank, or
put in a fake number, or whatever.

155
00:06:29.050 --> 00:06:32.720
Or you can always open the ticket with
them, get the case ID and then come back

156
00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:36.420
and generate it, after the fact or
whatever, so it has the right case ID.

157
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:39.329
I don't have one, so
I'm just gonna put, I'll do 1234.

158
00:06:40.870 --> 00:06:42.820
All right, and off it goes.

159
00:06:42.820 --> 00:06:45.897
Notice it's running 98 different things.

160
00:06:45.897 --> 00:06:47.279
98 different commands.

161
00:06:47.279 --> 00:06:50.382
Some of them are as simple as
catting a file onto the screen so

162
00:06:50.382 --> 00:06:52.940
that it can then store it in the document.

163
00:06:52.940 --> 00:06:56.260
Other ones it's copying actual config
files and it's just reaching out and

164
00:06:56.260 --> 00:06:59.020
doing all that stuff,
gathering all that information.

165
00:06:59.020 --> 00:07:01.090
And some of it's data from files.

166
00:07:01.090 --> 00:07:06.029
Some of it's output from other commands,
like it'll run ps aux.

167
00:07:06.029 --> 00:07:08.774
So it'll pull up a list of all the current
processes that are running and

168
00:07:08.774 --> 00:07:10.070
the users that are calling them.

169
00:07:10.070 --> 00:07:14.491
It'll run top and pull up the process
utilization, the memory utilization.

170
00:07:14.491 --> 00:07:20.054
It'll do free to pull up memory,
df to pull up disk usage.

171
00:07:20.054 --> 00:07:24.185
It'll even do dh a little bit
to pull up some folder sizes.

172
00:07:24.185 --> 00:07:25.421
What else do we have?

173
00:07:25.421 --> 00:07:27.235
>> I think the last one it ran was yum.

174
00:07:27.235 --> 00:07:29.464
>> Did it actually say it on the screen?

175
00:07:29.464 --> 00:07:32.080
>> Yeah, it was scrolling through it.

176
00:07:32.080 --> 00:07:33.190
>> Are we missing updates?

177
00:07:33.190 --> 00:07:34.025
That would be a good thing.

178
00:07:34.025 --> 00:07:35.680
Cuz the support person
might look at it and

179
00:07:35.680 --> 00:07:38.300
say you've got this problem
with Apache crashing.

180
00:07:38.300 --> 00:07:41.840
And we have five more updates for the
stinking thing that you haven't done and,

181
00:07:41.840 --> 00:07:43.180
look at this one,
it's in the release notes,

182
00:07:43.180 --> 00:07:44.988
fixes crashes, so-
>> [LAUGH]

183
00:07:44.988 --> 00:07:46.221
>> That kind of stuff.

184
00:07:46.221 --> 00:07:50.234
It sounds dumb but
if you've ever worked the support desk.

185
00:07:50.234 --> 00:07:51.845
Daniel, you've got horror stories.

186
00:07:51.845 --> 00:07:52.533
>> Golly.

187
00:07:52.533 --> 00:07:53.346
Been in the trenches.

188
00:07:53.346 --> 00:07:55.506
Anybody that's been there
before you're like, yeah,

189
00:07:55.506 --> 00:07:57.443
well why are all these
updates over here blinking?

190
00:07:57.443 --> 00:07:59.104
Well, you know updates break things.

191
00:07:59.104 --> 00:07:59.905
They also fix them.

192
00:07:59.905 --> 00:08:02.700
[LAUGH]
>> It always slows me down when I try and

193
00:08:02.700 --> 00:08:03.882
shut the computer down.

194
00:08:03.882 --> 00:08:05.862
>> [LAUGH]
>> Great, all right, well fine.

195
00:08:05.862 --> 00:08:06.522
>> That's fun.

196
00:08:06.522 --> 00:08:10.010
>> Okay, so it generates the file and
now that it's generated,

197
00:08:10.010 --> 00:08:12.870
it actually moves it from that
temporary folder that was made,

198
00:08:12.870 --> 00:08:14.660
remember the temporary
folder that it gave me?

199
00:08:14.660 --> 00:08:20.370
And so now its telling me, the SOS report
as has been saved in /var/tmp/ and

200
00:08:20.370 --> 00:08:23.020
then here's the archive
that was generated.

201
00:08:23.020 --> 00:08:24.970
That has that data stored inside of it.

202
00:08:24.970 --> 00:08:26.010
Okay, so it's got it.

203

I'm not normally troubleshooting it.

429
00:20:19.510 --> 00:20:22.210
So that's an example of why
that might be turned off.

430
00:20:22.210 --> 00:20:25.330
Or dovecot,
maybe I'm not running dovecot, right?

431
00:20:25.330 --> 00:20:29.530
IMAP and POP3,
you run that on some servers but

432
00:20:29.530 --> 00:20:31.570
not most of them, so it's turned off.

433
00:20:31.570 --> 00:20:35.750
But if this is my mail server,
then I need dovecot turned on so

434
00:20:35.750 --> 00:20:37.970
that I can be able to get that
information and output it.

435
00:20:39.030 --> 00:20:41.668
Grub is kind of a fun one, because
if you're having problems with grub,

436
00:20:41.668 --> 00:20:43.067
you probably can't run SOS reports.

437
00:20:43.067 --> 00:20:47.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I guess I should throw that in.

438
00:20:47.070 --> 00:20:50.670
SOS report can be run from
single user mode, it's just not

439
00:20:50.670 --> 00:20:54.690
the most useful at that point, cuz you're
not actually booted from your full OS.

440
00:20:54.690 --> 00:20:58.180
So a lot of stuff is gonna be missing,
but it can still gather a bunch of data.

441
00:20:58.180 --> 00:21:00.750
The main problem with running
it from single user mode

442
00:21:00.750 --> 00:21:04.380
is that /var/temp is either not mounted,
or mounted read-only.

443
00:21:04.380 --> 00:21:06.130
So when it goes to generate the report,

444
00:21:06.130 --> 00:21:08.190
it's gonna have a problem
writing the report.

445
00:21:08.190 --> 00:21:12.240
So you'll have to remount /var/temp
somewhere that's read-write

446
00:21:12.240 --> 00:21:13.400
before running SOS reports.

447
00:21:13.400 --> 00:21:16.534
So just hopefully you never run into that,
but if you ever do,

448
00:21:16.534 --> 00:21:18.299
that's how you work around that.

449
00:21:18.299 --> 00:21:23.741
All right, so if I wanna turn things on,
turn things off, this is how I do it.

450
00:21:23.741 --> 00:21:28.220
Or if I just want particular modules,
I can go through and find those and

451
00:21:28.220 --> 00:21:29.201
pick them out.

452
00:21:29.201 --> 00:21:33.280
You'll see like here's
the firewalld module.

453
00:21:33.280 --> 00:21:36.340
If I just wanna do that one, and
I can come through and I can specify it.

454
00:21:36.340 --> 00:21:41.808
So if I wanna run an SOS report,
and I'm gonna do -o for only, and

455
00:21:41.808 --> 00:21:47.076
I'll do firewalld and I can run that and
it's gonna go ahead and

456
00:21:47.076 --> 00:21:53.250
generate that report and let me just
put in the proper information here.

457
00:21:53.250 --> 00:21:54.923
I don't have a case.

458
00:21:54.923 --> 00:21:59.172
So I'll run that and
see it just did Running 1/1 firewalld and

459
00:21:59.172 --> 00:22:02.420
it generated that report super fast.

460
00:22:02.420 --> 00:22:07.550
And the reasoning there is that the file
only had to get data from one place.

461
00:22:07.550 --> 00:22:12.419
And so if I look at that new
one that I just generated,

462
00:22:12.419 --> 00:22:17.417
let me do a ls /-la so
we can actually see file sizes.

463
00:22:17.417 --> 00:22:20.940
And look how much smaller that is.

464
00:22:20.940 --> 00:22:22.310
Let me make that human readable.

465
00:22:23.935 --> 00:22:28.940
There, so I went from 9.2 megs when
I included everything down to 2.8k.

466
00:22:28.940 --> 00:22:32.940
Right, really small cuz it's just
the firewall settings, and that's it.

467
00:22:32.940 --> 00:22:35.300
I don't have to do anything
else too terribly crazy.

468
00:22:35.300 --> 00:22:39.000
It's just the information I need and
it's tucked away and [INAUDIBLE].

469
00:22:39.000 --> 00:22:43.720
>> So you can either grab everything under
the sun or just the exact specific thing

470
00:22:43.720 --> 00:22:48.020
that you need for your situations, you're
contacting Red Hat and you need support.

471
00:22:48.020 --> 00:22:50.050
Hey, I know there's
a problem with firewalld.

472
00:22:50.050 --> 00:22:51.330
It's not working correctly.

473
00:22:51.330 --> 00:22:55.020
Let me just get you that cuz why have
everything else if you don't need it?

474
00:22:55.020 --> 00:22:57.590
>> Absolutely, and this is an easy
way to get that information.

475
00:22:57.590 --> 00:22:59.480
So keep that in mind as you generate this.

476
00:22:59.480 --> 00:23:01.700
And again, if they're normal sized files,

477
00:23:01.700 --> 00:23:04.350
then you'll just upload them right
through the web interface for

478
00:23:04.350 --> 00:23:07.480
the ticketing system on Red Hat site and
you'll provide it right there.

479
00:23:07.480 --> 00:23:08.400
If it's too big, though,

480
00:23:08.400 --> 00:23:12.860
they'll say hey, we need you to
upload this to our FTP site.

481
00:23:12.860 --> 00:23:17.920
And their FTP site if you ever have to
do it, it is, let me just show you.

482
00:23:17.920 --> 00:23:19.721
Whoops, let me just regenerate that.

483
00:23:19.721 --> 00:23:21.410
>> Just do it again.

484
00:23:21.410 --> 00:23:23.205
>> If you ever have to do it,

485
00:23:23.205 --> 00:23:28.682
what you do is you copy the SOS report
somewhere that you can actually use it.

486
00:23:28.682 --> 00:23:35.382
And then you're going to ftp
to dropbox.redhat.com and

487
00:23:35.382 --> 00:23:40.410
the Dropbox website is a little bit weird.

488
00:23:40.410 --> 00:23:43.490
Because they way it works
is when you get connected,

489
00:23:43.490 --> 00:23:47.940
it's gonna give you this big message
telling you the ls command is disabled.

490
00:23:47.940 --> 00:23:50.333
You're not allowed to see
anything on this server.

491
00:23:50.333 --> 00:23:53.991
You can upload and then it disappears,
and that's it, right?

492
00:23:53.991 --> 00:23:57.504
Because there might be other customers
uploading their sensitive data and

493
00:23:57.504 --> 00:23:59.018
you don't have access to that.

494
00:23:59.018 --> 00:24:03.258
So when you upload it, it's gone,
you can't touch it again, that's it.

495
00:24:03.258 --> 00:24:07.787
So when you upload it, you need to make
sure that you've got the case number in

496
00:24:07.787 --> 00:24:11.968
that file name so it knows that
the Red Hat guys, people actually care,

497
00:24:11.968 --> 00:24:14.070
can [LAUGH] go in there and find it.

498
00:24:14.070 --> 00:24:17.410
>> Microsoft guys are like, yeah,
I told you not to do that [LAUGH].

499
00:24:17.410 --> 00:24:21.060
>> Microsoft actually has a really
tight licensing deal with Red Hat now

500
00:24:21.060 --> 00:24:22.930
because they do it in Microsoft Azure.

501
00:24:22.930 --> 00:24:25.380
So they do get involved sometimes.

502
00:24:25.380 --> 00:24:28.340
But you'll see here where basically
it's just telling me the commands.

503
00:24:28.340 --> 00:24:32.550
And they want me to put it
as [casenumber]- [file].

504
00:24:32.550 --> 00:24:36.540
So the case number is right there in
the file name so that they have it.

505
00:24:36.540 --> 00:24:41.673
And as soon as I upload it, it's now gone
and I can't take it back, it's just there.

506
00:24:41.673 --> 00:24:42.697
And that's the end of it.

507
00:24:42.697 --> 00:24:45.621
But do be careful because-
>> No take backs.

508
00:24:45.621 --> 00:24:50.103
>> No take backs, and if you look at
how the file is named by default,

509
00:24:50.103 --> 00:24:53.950
it's not named the way they want it to be,
right?

510
00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:57.890
If you put a case number,
the case number and date are here, and

511
00:24:57.890 --> 00:24:59.970
the file name is kinda before it.

512
00:24:59.970 --> 00:25:03.670
So you probably need to rename the SOS
report before you upload it that way.

513
00:25:03.670 --> 00:25:04.730
But, that's how you do it.

514
00:25:04.730 --> 00:25:06.320
You throw it right into their Dropbox.

515
00:25:06.320 --> 00:25:09.090
And that case number is
how they'll identify it.

516
00:25:09.090 --> 00:25:11.280
If it's too big to upload on the website,

517
00:25:11.280 --> 00:25:14.200
you've got to have a case number
before you can FTP it up there.

518
00:25:14.200 --> 00:25:17.490
If you try to FTP it up there with
no case number, they just delete it.

519
00:25:17.490 --> 00:25:18.960
It doesn't get read.

520
00:25:18.960 --> 00:25:21.900
>> Gotcha, and then obviously you're
already on the phone with these people

521
00:25:21.900 --> 00:25:22.460
at this point.

522
00:25:22.460 --> 00:25:24.470
So they're gonna see there it is.

523
00:25:24.470 --> 00:25:26.190
I can now open it up and see it.

524
00:25:26.190 --> 00:25:29.600
Is there ever a time where we would
upload it before we contact them and

525
00:25:29.600 --> 00:25:33.170
have them contact us or
does that ever work out or?

526
00:25:33.170 --> 00:25:35.210
>> If you create a web ticket, right?

527
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:37.520
And so you do the ticket right
through the customer portal and

528
00:25:37.520 --> 00:25:39.850
you create the ticket there and
you haven't talked to anybody yet.

529
00:25:39.850 --> 00:25:41.730
You'd get a case number and
if you tried to upload and

530
00:25:41.730 --> 00:25:45.720
it failed, then you might FTP it up ahead
of time without having talked to anybody.

531
00:25:45.720 --> 00:25:47.392
But you'd have a case
number at that point.

532
00:25:47.392 --> 00:25:49.783
There's never a scenario where you'd
upload it without a case number.

533
00:25:49.783 --> 00:25:50.851
>> Okay.
>> Yeah.

534
00:25:50.851 --> 00:25:55.114
>> Well, Don, now that we know how to use
SOS reports so that we can take advantage

535
00:25:55.114 --> 00:25:58.086
of the fact that we get
technical support with Red Hat,

536
00:25:58.086 --> 00:26:00.640
that's a very advantageous thing for us.

537
00:26:00.640 --> 00:26:02.350
That's a good thing,
so play around with it,

538
00:26:02.350 --> 00:26:04.960
make sure that you understand
how to generate that.

539
00:26:04.960 --> 00:26:07.310
If you need to, this is probably
not something, hopefully anyway,

540
00:26:07.310 --> 00:26:11.150
that's you're doing on a daily basis
unless you're using it like Don does.

541
00:26:11.150 --> 00:26:13.820
Where I just wanna stay on
top of things that might.

542
00:26:13.820 --> 00:26:17.200
Otherwise, for people like me, I'm
gonna put a cheat sheet down somewhere.

543
00:26:17.200 --> 00:26:20.870
I'm gonna keep a file that says,
how to do SOS reports in the correct way.

544
00:26:20.870 --> 00:26:21.880
Maybe that will help you out as well.

545
00:26:21.880 --> 00:26:24.010
Don, is there anything else we
need to add to this episode?

546
00:26:24.010 --> 00:26:25.130
>> That's about all I've got on this one.

547
00:26:25.130 --> 00:26:28.470
>> All right, that being said looks
like it's time for us to call it a day.

548
00:26:28.470 --> 00:26:30.610
Well, thank you for watching,
and we're signing off.

549
00:26:30.610 --> 00:26:33.120
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

550
00:26:33.120 --> 00:26:33.990
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

551
00:26:33.990 --> 00:26:35.960
>> We'll see you next time.

552
00:26:35.960 --> 00:26:41.914
[MUSIC]

553
00:26:41.914 --> 00:26:44.395
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore a variety of ways to monitor system performance on your Red Had Enterprise Linux servers and workstations. They start by monitoring the "Big 4" (CPU, Memory, Network, and Disk) with the venerable command-line tools like `top`, `df`, and `free`. Then they move into GUI tools like OProfile.
episodes.title: Monitoring System Performance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:06.613
Welcome back to ITPROTV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.613 --> 00:00:08.777
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.777 --> 00:00:10.668
You are watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:10.668 --> 00:00:13.367
>> All Right, greetings everyone And
welcome another episode of ITPROTV.

5
00:00:13.367 --> 00:00:17.480
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

6
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:23.330
well if you're here for more Red Hat
Linux, you've come to the right place.

7
00:00:23.330 --> 00:00:26.010
Cuz that's what we're doing, and
joining us back in the studio, again,

8
00:00:26.010 --> 00:00:27.980
is our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.980 --> 00:00:30.160
Don, welcome back again sir,
and how's it going?

10
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:32.630
>> It is going great Daniel, and
just ready to dive right back in.

11
00:00:32.630 --> 00:00:35.740
In this one we're gonna be taking a look
at monitoring performance inside of

12
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:37.300
Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

13
00:00:37.300 --> 00:00:38.810
If you got a server that's up and
running or

14
00:00:38.810 --> 00:00:40.770
even a workstation that's up and running.

15
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:42.920
The real challenge is keeping it up and
running.

16
00:00:42.920 --> 00:00:45.760
And making sure that it's running
at the proper performance

17
00:00:45.760 --> 00:00:46.840
levels that we expect, right.

18
00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:48.110
I know I'm guilty of this.

19
00:00:48.110 --> 00:00:51.500
That I get a brand new computer, I'm like,
man this is the faster computer ever.

20
00:00:51.500 --> 00:00:55.180
And then a year later,
this thing's slow as a dog.

21
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:56.550
I gotta get a new computer.

22
00:00:56.550 --> 00:00:58.760
And it turns out it's either one or
two things.

23
00:00:58.760 --> 00:01:00.210
Either one, something's wrong.

24
00:01:00.210 --> 00:01:00.980
Or two.

25
00:01:00.980 --> 00:01:02.982
>> The imperfections is yours.

26
00:01:02.982 --> 00:01:03.551
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:03.551 --> 00:01:04.439
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or two.

28
00:01:04.439 --> 00:01:06.970
I've just adjusted and
now I'm used to that speed and

29
00:01:06.970 --> 00:01:08.690
it's not fancy to me anymore.

30
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:12.340
So monitoring performance,
let's just set up baselines.

31
00:01:12.340 --> 00:01:15.790
And we can see like is the machine
actually slower than it used to be, or

32
00:01:15.790 --> 00:01:17.310
is it just me?

33
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:18.425
A lot of times it is.

34
00:01:18.425 --> 00:01:20.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> So We don't know that.

35
00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:23.890
We can't figure that out unless we've
been monitoring performance in the past.

36
00:01:23.890 --> 00:01:26.950
We need to know how things were in the
good times, to recognize how bad the bad

37
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:29.490
times are, or if the bad times
actually even bad in the first place.

38
00:01:29.490 --> 00:01:32.974
So that's what we're gonna take a look at,
right here.

39
00:01:32.974 --> 00:01:35.110
Now, I wanna start with the command line,

40
00:01:35.110 --> 00:01:38.130
there's a great GUI from monitoring
performance inside of redhat.

41
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:41.660
If you're on a desktop or a server
with a GUI, it really is impressive,

42
00:01:41.660 --> 00:01:45.350
We'll use it later but
on a lot of systems we don't have a GUI.

43
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:46.580
So let's start with the command line and

44
00:01:46.580 --> 00:01:49.900
see how things work there and then
we'll branch out to the GUI afterwards.

45
00:01:49.900 --> 00:01:53.090
So I'm gonna crack open
a quick terminal and

46
00:01:53.090 --> 00:01:55.160
we'll take a look at some of
our typical performance stuff.

47
00:01:55.160 --> 00:01:58.080
Now when it comes to monitoring
performance on a server

48
00:01:58.080 --> 00:02:00.990
we kind of have the big
four that we monitor.

49
00:02:00.990 --> 00:02:06.650
The Processor, Memory,
disc and network, right?

50
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:08.750
Those are kind of the four
things that we monitor.

51
00:02:08.750 --> 00:02:13.320
Network bandwidth, disc I/O, processor
utilization, and memory utilization.

52
00:02:13.320 --> 00:02:16.060
And we've got commands that show us a lot
of that information to be able to see

53
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:17.220
what's going on.

54
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:18.370
If we start with processor,

55
00:02:18.370 --> 00:02:21.090
that's kind of the easiest one cuz
there's several cool utilities for it.

56
00:02:22.570 --> 00:02:26.760
The main thing I usually wanna know in a
system is not necessarily how much CPU one

57
00:02:26.760 --> 00:02:30.540
process is eating up over another one,
but how many processes are running?

58
00:02:30.540 --> 00:02:33.690
Everybody who runs a processor,
a program, a service, whatever,

59
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:34.810
they all run in the background and

60
00:02:34.810 --> 00:02:38.300
they all add up and they might only
be using a small amount of CPU each.

61
00:02:38.300 --> 00:02:41.260
But when you've got a thousand
of them,They add up and

62
00:02:41.260 --> 00:02:43.260
all of a sudden your CPU is pegged out.

63
00:02:43.260 --> 00:02:45.300
So for that, we've got the ps command.

64
00:02:45.300 --> 00:02:49.600
ps is the process command and
it's gonna show me, by default,

65
00:02:49.600 --> 00:02:52.500
my processes,
what I'm doing on the system.

66
00:02:52.500 --> 00:02:56.480
But if I wanna get a good view of
the whole system, I can sudo it and

67
00:02:56.480 --> 00:02:58.700
I can do ps aux, all right?

68
00:03:00.510 --> 00:03:05.010
AX is what will really just show me all
the processes that are running for me.

69
00:03:05.010 --> 00:03:07.330
AUX will show me all the users, and

70
00:03:07.330 --> 00:03:09.090
will let me know the use
name of those processes.

71
00:03:09.090 --> 00:03:14.200
I am gonna to run ps aux, and
I am gonna to get quite a bit of output.

72
00:03:14.200 --> 00:03:20.230
Now, ps aux Displays the processes
as they were at that very moment.

73
00:03:20.230 --> 00:03:23.730
The screen does not update, so
these processes might be closed by now.

74
00:03:23.730 --> 00:03:25.280
>> It's like a snapshot in time.

75
00:03:25.280 --> 00:03:27.560
>> Yeah!
>> This is how it was at that very moment.

76
00:03:27.560 --> 00:03:32.980
And what you should see is that a lot of
these are things like kernel threads and

77
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:33.860
CPU actions,

78
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:37.750
watchdogs, These are things that are
always running, it's a part of the system.

79
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:40.800
That's not us that did it,
it's just there.

80
00:03:40.800 --> 00:03:44.080
And so,
I see a ton of things tied to root,

81
00:03:44.080 --> 00:03:46.080
even though I'm not logged in as root,
right.

82
00:03:46.080 --> 00:03:48.910
I did Sudo, so
I guess that sort of ran as root but

83
00:03:48.910 --> 00:03:51.630
all this stuff I didn't run,
it's part of the system.

84
00:03:51.630 --> 00:03:56.960
So the system things normally have
the square brackets around them, see how

85
00:03:56.960 --> 00:04:00.870
all these have square brackets, And that's
kind of letting us know those are system.

86
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:03.730
AFter that we start getting to things
that we have a little more control over.

87
00:04:03.730 --> 00:04:07.730
So I am seeing things
like stuff with a path.

88
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:09.890
So right here we have got our LVM.

89
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:13.870
The logical volume manager that's
kicking in and doing some stuff.

90
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:16.530
And shoot, it got trimmed.

91
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:19.600
Let me rerun the command so
we can get that not trimmed as much.

92
00:04:21.070 --> 00:04:22.750
The output can be a little
on the wide side.

93
00:04:22.750 --> 00:04:26.690
But you'll start to see DNS mask
that's running in the background.

94
00:04:26.690 --> 00:04:29.190
Colord for doing colored output.

95
00:04:29.190 --> 00:04:32.420
We've got udev's disk naming service.

96

in is not good enough.

546
00:26:41.530 --> 00:26:43.000
I just can't do it.

547
00:26:43.000 --> 00:26:44.850
>> I just wanna show this thing.

548
00:26:44.850 --> 00:26:45.350
>> So.

549
00:26:46.350 --> 00:26:46.880
>> Well see, Don,

550
00:26:46.880 --> 00:26:50.083
you don't know that the glyph of
the jackal with the two headed snake.

551
00:26:50.083 --> 00:26:52.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> Means CPU register EIP.

552
00:26:52.300 --> 00:26:54.388
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, so anyhow.

553
00:26:54.388 --> 00:26:55.790
We're supposed to find this stuff in here.

554
00:26:55.790 --> 00:26:57.630
When you run it from the command line
you can actually limit it to your

555
00:26:57.630 --> 00:26:58.330
individual application.

556
00:26:58.330 --> 00:27:00.570
But the idea is that you start
it running and then you go and

557
00:27:00.570 --> 00:27:02.960
you run your application, you run
the program and you perform the action.

558
00:27:02.960 --> 00:27:04.780
And when it's done you stop it.

559
00:27:04.780 --> 00:27:08.540
And when you hit the flush button it
actually writes it all to a log file on

560
00:27:08.540 --> 00:27:09.970
the hard drive that you can then compare.

561
00:27:09.970 --> 00:27:12.880
That's how it operates,
that's the basic operation of the program.

562
00:27:12.880 --> 00:27:14.218
It's an impressive one.

563
00:27:14.218 --> 00:27:18.032
If you're ever interested in learning
something that is borderline

564
00:27:18.032 --> 00:27:22.460
a foreign language, pull up the
documentation for OProfile, it's massive.

565
00:27:22.460 --> 00:27:26.200
But if you really need detailed
performance data of an application,

566
00:27:26.200 --> 00:27:28.520
that's the way to do it,
it's impressive stuff.

567
00:27:28.520 --> 00:27:32.250
>> That's right you download, you install
and you chuck it off to the developer and

568
00:27:32.250 --> 00:27:34.640
let them interpret that stuff for us.

569
00:27:34.640 --> 00:27:37.969
But that being said, we had a lot of
great tools that we've seen today for

570
00:27:37.969 --> 00:27:40.818
monitoring our performance and
our Red Hat systems, right?

571
00:27:40.818 --> 00:27:43.062
We've used TOP and the PS utility.

572
00:27:43.062 --> 00:27:45.530
You use those all the time.

573
00:27:45.530 --> 00:27:47.970
I probably use those on a daily
basis on my daily driver.

574
00:27:47.970 --> 00:27:51.260
Just because you're always trying to
find rogue processes that are running or

575
00:27:51.260 --> 00:27:52.530
what's eating up all my memory.

576
00:27:52.530 --> 00:27:54.610
We got free, we can see things like that.

577
00:27:54.610 --> 00:27:55.710
Very cool stuff.

578
00:27:55.710 --> 00:27:59.630
And not to mention that if you are running
a desktop, you do have the graphical

579
00:27:59.630 --> 00:28:03.480
interface, usually at your beck and
call, so you can jump on that as well.

580
00:28:03.480 --> 00:28:07.690
Don, thank you so much for
showing us how we can monitor our systems.

581
00:28:07.690 --> 00:28:10.160
Anything else you wanna throw
in the fire before we let it go?

582
00:28:10.160 --> 00:28:12.340
>> Never underestimate the power
of third-party systems, right?

583
00:28:12.340 --> 00:28:15.190
There's plenty of third-party software
out there that can monitor Linux and

584
00:28:15.190 --> 00:28:16.880
Red Hat systems really, really well.

585
00:28:16.880 --> 00:28:19.590
So take advantage of those, but
the buil- in tools are great for

586
00:28:19.590 --> 00:28:22.490
monitoring single systems and
they're free, they're right there.

587
00:28:22.490 --> 00:28:23.310
>> That's right.

588
00:28:23.310 --> 00:28:26.030
All right that being said looks like we've
come to the end of our time for today.

589
00:28:26.030 --> 00:28:27.690
We thank you guys for watching.

590
00:28:27.690 --> 00:28:31.270
It's time to sign off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

591
00:28:31.270 --> 00:28:32.150
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

592
00:28:32.150 --> 00:28:33.792
>> We'll see you next time.

593
00:28:33.792 --> 00:28:40.410
[MUSIC]

594
00:28:40.410 --> 00:28:42.655
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the world of troubleshooting through the monitoring of system logs. They cover topics like DMESG, syslog, system log rotation, remote system log monitoring, the systemd journal and log filtering.
episodes.title: Monitoring System Logs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:03.571
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:03.571 --> 00:00:06.802
>> Live from San Francisco,
California [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.802 --> 00:00:08.336
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.336 --> 00:00:09.960
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:09.960 --> 00:00:15.385
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.Tv.

6
00:00:15.385 --> 00:00:16.555
I'm you host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.555 --> 00:00:21.295
And it today's episode, we are moving
through our Red Hat Enterprise Linux, and

8
00:00:21.295 --> 00:00:24.415
joining us back in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:24.415 --> 00:00:25.475
Don, how are you doing, sir?

10
00:00:25.475 --> 00:00:26.315
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

11
00:00:26.315 --> 00:00:28.125
Ready to dive right back
in the world of Red Hat.

12
00:00:28.125 --> 00:00:30.905
And today, we're gonna be looking
at monitoring our system logs.

13
00:00:30.905 --> 00:00:33.910
And we're not talking about,
you know Lincoln Logs or

14
00:00:33.910 --> 00:00:38.090
Yule logs but we're just going into our
regular system logs which are incredibly

15
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:40.840
useful resource for trouble shooting.

16
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:43.580
That when you start having
issues on a system,

17
00:00:43.580 --> 00:00:46.130
the logs are where we go to
find out that information.

18
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:48.900
And if you watched like
our SE Linux episode,

19
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:52.645
those logs are really important for
tracking if software is getting blocked,

20
00:00:52.645 --> 00:00:54.450
and fixing it and getting that working.

21
00:00:54.450 --> 00:00:57.750
Or even in the episodes where we created
things like USB installation media, we

22
00:00:57.750 --> 00:01:01.330
used the logs to be able to figure out the
name of a device that we just plugged in.

23
00:01:01.330 --> 00:01:03.830
Logs are incredibly useful.

24
00:01:03.830 --> 00:01:05.460
They're also slightly misunderstood.

25
00:01:05.460 --> 00:01:08.740
A lot of people just assume the system is
logging exactly the way they want it to

26
00:01:08.740 --> 00:01:10.270
and never configure it.

27
00:01:10.270 --> 00:01:13.070
And only once something bad
happens do they go and look and

28
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:16.150
find out that the logs weren't
working exactly the way they wanted.

29
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:18.809
So there is a little bit of
TLC that we need to show.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss virtualization technologies in RHEL. They will talk about concepts like QEMU, KVM as well as QEMU plus KVM and libvirt. They will explain the requirements to support these technologies, performing the process through the GUI and the CLI.
episodes.title: Using QEMU and KVM
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.414
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.414 --> 00:00:06.796
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.796 --> 00:00:08.295
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.295 --> 00:00:11.364
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.364 --> 00:00:14.890
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:16.810
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

7
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:22.160
in today's episode we are continuing
through our Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

8
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:26.207
And joining me back in the studios today
for this endeavor is none other than Mr.

9
00:00:26.207 --> 00:00:26.905
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.905 --> 00:00:28.005
Don how ya doin' sir?

11
00:00:28.005 --> 00:00:28.645
>> I'm doing swell.

12
00:00:28.645 --> 00:00:32.045
Let's get ready to dive back in, in this
episode, we're going to be taking a look

13
00:00:32.045 --> 00:00:35.385
at virtualization on top of
Red Hat Enterprise Linux seven and

14
00:00:35.385 --> 00:00:39.195
that's a big topic because Red Hat has
a number of big pushes going on right now

15
00:00:39.195 --> 00:00:44.315
with the whole open stack movement and
open shift and different things.

16
00:00:44.315 --> 00:00:47.875
So, virtualization is becoming
a standard component in pretty much

17
00:00:47.875 --> 00:00:50.020
any data center that's out there.

18
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:53.280
What I want to look at is Red Hat's
recommended virtualization solution and

19
00:00:53.280 --> 00:00:54.550
how we can get it installed an up and

20
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:58.430
running and the way that we can use it
to then participate in Open Stack or

21
00:00:58.430 --> 00:01:01.820
Open Shift or whatever else it is that
we choose to deploy on the network.

22
00:01:01.820 --> 00:01:05.290
The first thing I need to understand
is what is that recommended solution.

23
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:08.710
And Red Hat actually has three different

24
00:01:08.710 --> 00:01:10.700
components that go together
in the recommended solution.

25
00:01:10.700 --> 00:01:14.190
Because what they found was there was
really no one piece that did everything.

26
00:01:14.190 --> 00:01:15.550
They kinda needed to couple it together.

27
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:21.220
So the names you're gonna hear
batted about the most are QEMU,

28
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:24.110
KVM, and LibVert, all right?

29
00:01:24.110 --> 00:01:25.570
So what are all of those?

30
00:01:25.570 --> 00:01:27.160
I'll start with QEMU.

31
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:29.990
QEMU, like its name implies,
is an emulator.

32
00:01:29.990 --> 00:01:33.220
It emulates processor, memory, network,

33
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:36.930
hard drive, and
it creates virtual machines.

34
00:01:36.930 --> 00:01:40.750
So if I wanna whip up a virtual
Linux server that's a web server, or

35
00:01:40.750 --> 00:01:45.710
virtualize a Windows machine, or whatever
I can fire up QEMU and I can do it.

36
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:48.220
Now QEMU does a great job but

37
00:01:48.220 --> 00:01:52.300
it is an emulator, and emulation is
not the fastest thing on the planet.

38
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:58.040
It creates a fake processor, fake memory,
fake hard drive, fake network adapters.

39
00:01:58.040 --> 00:02:01.670
So when your virtualized operating
system goes to talk to the processor or

40
00:02:01.670 --> 00:02:05.160
it goes to talk to the memory,
it's talking to something fake, and

41
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:08.590
QEMU has to translate that from
something fake to something real.

42
00:02:08.590 --> 00:02:11.600
And that translation, that takes time.

43
00:02:11.600 --> 00:02:13.740
And the time is very small,
right, nanoseconds.

44
00:02:13.740 --> 00:02:14.990
This is really short.

45
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:18.530
But it's an eternity for computers.

46
00:02:18.530 --> 00:02:22.400
So what that means is that if I
virtualize something under QEMU

47
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:25.900
it's not going to run at what we
call wire speed or bare metal speed.

48
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:28.030
It's gonna run a little bit slower.

49
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.210
You don't get the same performance.

50
00:02:30.210 --> 00:02:32.010
So QMEU, great at what it does, but

51
00:02:32.010 --> 00:02:35.460
not perfect as far as
performance is concerned.

52
00:02:35.460 --> 00:02:41.150
And that's where KVM comes in, KVM, the
Kernal Virtual Machine environment, what

53
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:46.690
it let's you do, is it lets you create
virtual machines that use a hypervisor.

54
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:48.550
And a hypervisor is not an emulator.

55
00:02:48.550 --> 00:02:53.080
An emulator creates a fake processor,
fake memory, and so on.

56
00:02:53.080 --> 00:02:55.710
A hypervisor is more like a traffic cop.

57
00:02:55.710 --> 00:02:59.750
It says no one system has
exclusive access to this CPU,

58
00:02:59.750 --> 00:03:02.590
you all share it and
I'm just gonna be the traffic cop.

59
00:03:02.590 --> 00:03:05.385
I'm gonna say, okay,
Wes it's your time to use the CPU.

60
00:03:05.385 --> 00:03:06.149
[SOUND] Your time is up.

61
00:03:06.149 --> 00:03:07.205
Now it's this guy's time.

62
00:03:07.205 --> 00:03:09.113
[SOUND] His time is up,
now it's this person's time.

63
00:03:09.113 --> 00:03:13.892
And everybody gets access to the resources
and KVM as a hyper visor does

64
00:03:13.892 --> 00:03:18.266
great at being the traffic cop for
processor and memory, the two

65
00:03:18.266 --> 00:03:23.660
components that were really sensitive
to speed on, that's what it does.

66
00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:28.998
All right but
it doesn't do network adapters or disk.

67
00:03:28.998 --> 00:03:32.710
And so what Red Hat does is they say
all right let's combine the two.

68
00:03:32.710 --> 00:03:38.550
Let's get QEMU working with KVM and
then KVM can handle the CPU and

69
00:03:38.550 --> 00:03:42.920
the memory, and
QEMU can handle the disk and the network.

70
00:03:42.920 --> 00:03:45.350
The network, if we virtualize that,
that's trivial.

71
00:03:45.350 --> 00:03:48.320
The disk, the disk needs to be virtualized
no matter what because we're putting

72
00:03:48.320 --> 00:03:51.510
all of our writes into a separate
file anyway, not a raw file system.

73
00:03:51.510 --> 00:03:54.430
If it was a raw file system, it would
be a different story, but even then,

74
00:03:54.430 --> 00:03:58.290
on a raw file system, you wouldn't have
two virtual machines accessing the same

75
00:03:58.290 --> 00:04:01.840
raw file system so that's always
gonna be virtualized no matter what.

76
00:04:01.840 --> 00:04:04.725
No matter what software you run,
even if you're running VM ware or

77
00:04:04.725 --> 00:04:07.468
something like that,
you're gonna have the same situation.

78
00:04:07.468 --> 00:04:11.353
So QEMU virtualizes what has to be done,
anything that KVM can handle,

79
00:04:11.353 --> 00:04:13.619
it handles, and the two work together and

80
00:04:13.619 --> 00:04:17.150
you end up with the best
virtualization environment possible.

81
00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:19.810
It's very stable, it's very fast,
and very reliable.

82
00:04:19.810 --> 00:04:22.370
And used by a ton of people.

83
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:25.000
Like little companies
like Amazon web services.

84
00:04:25.000 --> 00:04:29.140
Well, they only spin a few million virtual
machines every single stinking day

85
00:04:29.140 --> 00:04:31.530
they use QEMU plus KVM.

86
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:33.440
That's the model that Red Hat follows.

87
00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:37.820
So very stable, very tested,
very widely used environment.

88
00:04:37.820 --> 00:04:41.440
The only problem is it's
two different programs, and

89
00:04:41.440 --> 00:04:45.350
it's kind of a pain to manage if you have
to talk to two different programs, so

90
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:49.430
what Red Hat did is they said let's
solve this, let's create a standard API.

91
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:55.590
A single place we talk to that can
then turn around and talk to QEMU and

92
00:04:55.590 --> 00:05:00.460
KVM for us, so we just have one thing to
talk to and that's where Libvirt comes in.

93
00:05:00.460 --> 00:05:03.560
Libvirt is short for
library virtualization.

94
00:05:03.560 --> 00:05:05.120
It's a virtualization library or

95
00:05:05.120 --> 00:05:10.558
an API that we can talk to that front
ends these different systems on the back.

96
00:05:10.558 --> 00:05:13.730
And Red Hat didn't stop with QEMU and KVM,
they actually went a little further and

97
00:05:13.730 --> 00:05:15.370
added support for Xen.

98
00:05:15.370 --> 00:05:18.480
Xen which is a very common Open Source
virtualization platform and

99
00:05:18.480 --> 00:05:21.062
a few others are kind
of stuck in there too.

100
00:05:21.062 --> 00:05:26.140
So Libvirt can front end all sorts of
different systems on the back end.

101
00:05:26.140 --> 00:05:29.920
But the official solution that we want to
go with, the Red Hat recommended solution,

102
00:05:29.920 --> 00:05:34.590
is QEMU plus KVM on the back end,
and Libvirt on the front end.

103
00:05:34.590 --> 00:05:37.970
And they got a suite of utilities
that all interact with Libvirt.

104
00:05:37.970 --> 00:05:41.536
>> Now Don, I've been a part of some
of the virtualization shows before that

105
00:05:41.536 --> 00:05:42.237
we have here.

106
00:05:42.237 --> 00:05:45.582
And one of the things that's always
a necessity is a certain set

107
00:05:45.582 --> 00:05:48.045
of requirements to run
any piece of software or

108
00:05:48.045 --> 00:05:51.160
hardware if you will,
if you need adequate performance.

109
00:05:51.160 --> 00:05:54.210
What are we looking at when it
comes to requirements for this?

110
00:05:54.210 --> 00:05:55.040
>> We have a couple of things,

111
00:05:55.040 --> 00:05:57.830
the traditional requirements, things like
how much disk space and memory they need,

112
00:05:57.830 --> 00:05:59.240
are kinda laughable right there.

113
00:05:59.240 --> 00:06:03.240
The minimum requirements are 2GBs of
RAM and 6GBs of hard drive space but

114
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:06.360
that's a drop of the bucket,
that's nothing.

115
00:06:06.360 --> 00:06:07.780
You're gonna need more.

116
00:06:07.780 --> 00:06:10.220
Your virtual machines,
they need memory, they need disk space.

117
00:06:10.220 --> 00:06:12.810
And so you need way more than minimum
requirements are, so let's just

118
00:06:12.810 --> 00:06:15.630
pretend those don't exist and you need
to think about your virtual machines.

119
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:18.770
So how much RAM are you going to assign,
how much disk space do you need to assign.

120
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:20.780
That's how much space
you're going to need.

121
00:06:20.780 --> 00:06:22.970
Where we need to be more
concerned though is the CPU.

122
00:06:22.970 --> 00:06:24.820
Not just any old CPU will work.

123
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:27.730
It's got to be a 64 bit CPU,
it can be Intel for AMD.

124
00:06:27.730 --> 00:06:32.659
Which means AMD64 is what we normally
see even on Intel processors so

125
00:06:32.659 --> 00:06:38.601
if you got a nice Intel i5 or i7 and
it's 64 bit it's actually AMD64 not Intel.

126
00:06:38.601 --> 00:06:41.781
Intel 64-bit was a titanium processors and

127
00:06:41.781 --> 00:06:45.760
I don't know Wes,
can you even buy Itanium anymore?

128
00:06:45.760 --> 00:06:46.270
>> I don't know.

129
00:06:46.270 --> 00:06:49.490
I'm thinking ever since Xeon came out,
I believe they're a thing of the past.

130
00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:51.980
>> Yeah, it's one of things where
Intels just didn't catch on, but

131
00:06:51.980 --> 00:06:53.860
AMDs did, that's the one we all run now.

132
00:06:53.860 --> 00:06:56.680
So, but it does need to be 64-bit.

133
00:06:56.680 --> 00:06:58.270
Beyond that,
there's not really a requirement.

134
00:06:58.270 --> 00:07:01.640
And normally, if this were a VMware show,
this is where I would say, you gotta make

135
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:05.450
sure you have the virtualization
extensions as part of that CPU, right?

136
00:07:05.450 --> 00:07:10.508
In Intel, you have what is called Intel
VT-x, the virtual technology extensions.

137
00:07:10.508 --> 00:07:15.182
And in AMD, you have what's called AMDV or
AMD Virtualization, not very exciting.

138
00:07:15.182 --> 00:07:20.168
But those are extensions in the process
that make them allow a hyper-visor to work

139
00:07:20.168 --> 00:07:23.730
and if they're missing,
the hyper-visor won't work.

140
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:28.324
Well there's products like VMWare and
Microsoft Hyper-V where if the hyper-visor

141
00:07:28.324 --> 00:07:31.716
won't work the software just doesn't work,
and that's it.

142
00:07:31.716 --> 00:07:35.350
With QEMU and KVM,
if you're hyper visor is missing,

143
00:07:35.350 --> 00:07:38.310
